reviewText: I bought a new impact wrench and wanted a decent set of sockets to use with it. I picked this set up because of the price and the fact that it's a complete set from 10mm up to 24mm. I've been hammering away on these things non stop and they're holding up great. Thanks Tekton for a good set of impact sockets at a good price point!
summary: Great set of impacts for the price!

reviewText: I love this more than a dead bolt lock, and it works!  Sometimes my door will blow open when we get strong wind gusts, and this guard stops the door from opening up, which is great.  A dead bolt won't do that.. it will simply rip through the door frame and ruin it in the process.  I'm guessing this would withstand a burglar trying to get in, too.  I like that you can open up the door and see who's there before opening it up, if you don't have a peep hole, which I don't.  It's much, MUCH stronger than a chain!Thanks to the help from another reviewer, I was able to install these on two doors with elevated moulding, and they work very nicely.
summary: Can absolutely be used on doors with moulding!!

reviewText: I bought 2 glass table top tables and noticed when I bumped into them or my cats played a bit rough, the glass would shift. They had felt pieces between the glass and the metal base.  I bought these, cleaned the metal base, put these on about every 8 inches.  The glass stays put and they look good underneath it because they are clear.  The adhesive is good.

Bigger than I had imagined but that's perfectly fine. very sharp jab saw; works as expected. If you're in the need of a jab saaw this should be your pick. The other hacksaw from DeWalt has it built in but the ergonomics are not as good.
My husband has really enjoyed these gloves for working on cars, moving stuff, and at work.  They seem to be holding up pretty well.
This is what I expect from Gorilla!  I used this to patch my screens with holes in it.  It has stuck through some very bad storms.  Impressive.  Tears easy too.

I bought this knife on a whim, but I would not have bought it had I known what a "hook" knife is.  It is the kind of knife that you would use to cut through a seat belt by pulling the blade through the webbing, except this knife looks like it would be too small to get any leverage to do that. The knife, really just a gadget, is fine in construction, but I think it's useless.  I wish I had saved my ten dollars.  PS It was described as being capable of opening packages, but the outer edge of the knife is thick and unsharpened, such that you would not be able to get it started or inserted so as to cut with.  Might be a nice key chain and conversation piece.

Finally couldn't wait any longer for a cordless Dremel tool and this one is very powerful for cordless.Easy to manuver and light enough for extended projects.Like the storage case that it came with,and assorted attachments.

I got 2 of these to replace similar thermostats that could only handle one program for the entire week. I needed one that would match my routine of different timings for the weekend. This model does that and is way easier to setup and monitor what is going on than the old ones.Installation was very easy with clear instructions and almost impossible to get wrong. I have a fairly straight forward heating/cooling system but there are detailed steps and diagrams for more complicated systems like heat pumps etc if needed. Setup was also very easy with well documented steps for the initial system match [so it understands what it's controlling] and scheduling the time/temperatures was also easy thanks to the well laid out display.I have had these in for a Month now and am very pleased with the results, I would recommend them to anyone.

I bought the Dremel 10.8v rotary cordless drill for the purpose of removing tile grout. At first it worked well. But, the battery only lasted 45 minutes. Then the problems started. The 1/16 inch grout bits only lasted a few minutes then broke. I had better luck when I was removing 1/8 inch grout because the 1/8 inch bit lasted for hours before it started getting dull. Since the grout bits are not well made, I found another brand that cuts much better, much cheaper in price, and last longer.I HAD to get the grout removed and this was the only tool I found that would do that. But, after a few days the Dremel broke. I still had grout to take care of, so I bought a corded Dremel to continue the work while the cordless was sent in for repairs. To the credit of Dremel, the cordless was promptly repaired and returned along with a free accessory for my trouble. I started using the cordless again and it stopped working again. This time it just stayed on fast speed. So, off it went to the post office again to send in this thing for repair. It is repaired again, but this time I am using the corded Dremel.I also tried the tool on other jobs such as removing paint from a window frame, sanding a small section of wood, drilling a pilot hole for a screw, and cutting off a screw that I could not remove. What I found was that the Dremel did a fair job if you have a steady hand. However, some of the accessories either break easily or grind down quickly. And these accessories are not cheap. You can easily spend 3 times the price in bits and accessories than what you pay for the tool itself.The bottom line is, this thing is mostly good for small work such as crafts. But, can also come in handy when a large drill or sander just will not fit. Just stay away from the cordless.

I am listing one of these DeWALT compressors on Amazon. I have the DeWALT D5514 Compresssor that is stated on Amazon to be 2-Gallon and 135 p.s.i.This is not true. I checked with DeWALT and everyone agrees (except Amazon) that this compressor is rated at 150 p.s.i. and NOT 135 p.s.i.The air pressure gauge and motor on my compressor stops at 150 p.s.i
I use this to power my electric log splitter and it is perfect. Great price or a great product. Don't hesitate to purchase.

some of the best ways for making a decision on buying a tool is watching or using one on a job.Buying sight unseen from Amazon is always a gamble. But this cord seems to be a good value for the purchase price. And it seems to be fairly good in the cold weather we've been having here in Maine this winter.
summary: its ok, id buy it again

reviewText: This timer functions as promised, but the programming is a bit confusing.  Also, when needing to reset a particular itme of programming, it seems you have to go through all the previous programming just to change the one item you want changed.That being said, I just bought three more of them for family members.  I am using mine to control outdoor low-voltage lighting.  Not having to continually re-adjust the clock for the changing sunset (dusk) times is great.  In being particular about not wasting electricity when the lights come on earlier than needed, and having to repeatedly change the start time on a traditional timer, this unit solves that problem completely.  I set it to turn on at dusk (or a few minutes later), and off at a specific time.  The timer knows when dusk is, based on the initial programming, and continually adjusts throughout the seasons.  It works great, and I don't have to fuss with it anymore.The price here on Amazon is great, and is $5-10 less than I saw elsewhere.  I just bought 3 and avoided any shipping charges, too.

The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was because it was hard for me to get sparks. I don't know if there are different grades of flint, so I don't know if that was the reason. There were no instructions included. They give you a big chunk of flint and tinder, so they get an A for that. I kept skinning my knuckles trying to get sparks, but like I said, it might be my ineptitude. This is my first attempt at using this kind of fire starter.
Cord is as advertised.  I used it many times last winter down to almost 0 degrees F and the cord remained flexible and easy to coil.  I just wish it wasn't so expensive...
summary: As advertised, especially in low temps

reviewText: After over 10 years of cordless, I decided to go electric again.  I rarely use the drill outside of the house.  When I use it outside the house it will be near the outlets.  Otherwise, I have plenty of cords and extensions to go with it.My last B&D; failed at the keyless chuck.  But I decided to go with it again because it lasted many years at least so it's not bad at all for the price.Without the battery actually the drill is more manoeuvrable because it is lighter and smaller at the handle.  You don't worry about losing power and charging the battery.  Your workbench won't be clogged up by the charger or one socket is occupied.Without the battery the drill bit being held on the drill is exposed a bit.  It can scratch you as shown in the picture.The bag is actually a good idea as I don't need to spend time putting the drill back in it's case and wind the cord.  I just dump everything in the bag together with the drill bits.  However, the bag is a little small so you have to force the zippers a little bit no matter how you place the drill. Deduct one star for the silliness. [update: actually the bag fits if you put in in one way rather than the other. Still, I know what a very good drill is; my drill before last is pretty good.]The drill itself is like most drills, powerful enough because of the absence of battery, reversible at the push of a slide switch.  Variable speed and hence power is controlled by the switch.  It's good in the sense that my last cordless has a dial of 10 positions for drilling and driving.  I suspect that they don't have variable gears inside anymore.  It could be good as my drill before last failed at the gears.  But cars need gears even though it can be automatic.  For now the VSR switch seems to be sufficient for me, convenient and fairly intuitive too.
summary: Adequate tool for use around the house

reviewerName: J. Nowicki "The Boss and  Mrs. B."
reviewText: This is a great backsaver! It has three outlets so you can light more than one thing.I have our tree and two lighted presents plugged into mine and it works great.I don't have to practically turn myself into a pretzel to get behind or around the Christmas treeto turn the lights on or off. No more doing a balancing act trying to avoid crushing the presents either.I simply tap it with my foot. Save yourself a backache and put it on your Christmas list. I keep the cordstored along with our strings of Christmas lights in one of our 4 Holiday Storage Reels in a Bag sets.Or you can use extension cord all year anywhere you have hard to reach lighting.Either way, Yule see some light with it . . . Or  . . . Yule won't! ~ The Boss
summary: Yule  Decide!  . . .  Will It Be . . . Let There Be Light ! . . . Or  . . . Lights Out !

reviewText: it's a little hard getting the bits into and out of the case; and the soft rubber material its made of feels like it's going to fall apart sometime in the future, but I've got no other complaints.
If you are looking for a sink mounted hot water dispenser to make tea or coffee or oatmeal this would work fine but anything more you will need something larger.

I have a cree 300 in black that has just done its job. I am so happy with it, that I ordered some silver ones. Well on inspection, the first thing I noticed is that the button part has no "O" ring. Second, is that the spring is much smaller compared to my original cree. Third, the threads are not as robust as the original. The body is the same and the LED is the same. The area where you adjust the beam is a little more tight. On my original its very smooth. It will not pose a problem. Only saying its not as smooth. Overall a great flashlight. The color is very nice. I just use regular double A batteries and never have had a problem. Well worth the price.
This is a high quality product that is very affordable.  I replaced my $120 Oakley sunglasses for these.  They look and feel great.

Why more Americans never caught on to using a bidet is beyond me, but I'm Irish, so I can't tell you.  A clean butt is a happy butt in my opinion, and there's nothing like a clean swipe every time.  You not only save on the cost of tissue paper, but you feel clean and refreshed each and every time.  In European hotels, typically we have a toilet, and a bidet.  You wipe first, then you use the bidet.  This has never sat well with me, and I've always been disgusted by it.  With this, you spray, clean yourself off, and then you make a clean swipe.  It is not only hygienic, it's refreshing.  On a hot summer day, sit down for a second, and give yourself a spray.  It cools you down, and puts you in a better mood!  Overall, NECESSARY BUY AND GREAT BUY!
summary: A clean butt is a happy butt!

reviewText: When the box arrived I quickly realized 2 things:1) The box was HEAVY! This is a SOLID faucet - no skimping on quality here!2) The box was large. This was going to be more work than I may have bargained for. 'But, after following the directions (and locating a spot in our house with an outlet under the sink area), we got it all hooked up and ready to try. It's gorgeous - absolutely amazing.

Popped it on my battery.  Showed me it was full.  Charged my phone.  Easy as can be.  I have 2 of these batteries, so for $20 I just gained 2 portable power packs.  Great re-use of something.Would be nice if it locked on.  Could easily slide off in your bag.  Also would be nice if it had a button to check power versus removing it and putting it back on again.  Its fine though.

As a builder of 30+ years I have to say I LOVE lighted levels. I can't believe there aren't a lot more lighted levels out there. There are some but not many. When you're holding a level up against a wall it only makes sense that the chances of it being dark is great especially in low lit rooms. the biggest problem with the Stanley torpedo level is the beveled ends and for that matter ANY level (which include far too many) with beveled ends. Most builders like myself find themselves many many times with the need to continue a level line from an inside corner around the room or from any solid end/start-point ...which is near impossible with a beveled end. I noticed in the past few years companies like Stabila make the plastic end caps easily removable and I suspect it's for the reason I suggested...so for the DIY or beginner crowds this is a heads up for you to think about before buying any level.

The first difference I noticed between this filter and the cheapo ones I normally use was its quietness. The flimsy ones make a surprisingly loud clanking noise when the heat pump kicks on and off; not so with this thicker, heavier one. More significantly, I believe the claims made about odor reduction may be valid. I just got oak installed on my kitchen floor, requiring three finish-coats of polyurethane applied over three days, during which time I moved out of my house. The smell was still pretty strong when I moved back in, but it was soon gone, and I really believe this filter helped.
This Dewalt DW7080 Extension system fit my Dewalt miter saw exactly. It is well made and very strong and works great.

got these for some kitchen gunsmithing on my springfield xd's.worked well for my purposes, actually work for all my guns and i keep finding other uses for them.the plastic little frame they came in feels kinda cheap but it works to keep them in order.

Pricewise LED lights are about where compact fluorescent lamps (cfl) were about 5 years ago. They cost about 5 times what a comparable CFL costs. They are instant on and need no warm up to reach full brightness. Otoh, if just one LED goes bad inside the bulb, then they all burn out (these lamps have multiple LEDs inside the bulb).So, they work nicely but cost way to much especially the larger output bulbs.
summary: About as bright as a compact flourescent but still way too pricey

reviewText: There is a nice button on the front which is supposed to release the sanding base (to switch the pointer for the round).  However, though the button is easy to press, sometimes the stupid base doesn't want to come off and must be wiggled and shaken a lot.  Other times it falls off easily.  This feature clearly needs work.The instructions are a bit weak, especially for a sander with a picture-based mode wheel which is clearly aimed at newbies.One of the few pieces of advice was to start with a coarse paper (duh), but this thing only included 2 sheets of each shape, and both were the same grit.However, the paper and sander are both of good quality.  We used it for about 2 hours strait.  The sandpaper is pretty tough stuff, and didn't wear out.  The sander itself feels solid when operating, with no weird sounds or loose parts as I have experienced with generic machinery.
summary: Mostly a good piece of hardware for the price

reviewText: I do like this item and the price is good, however be aware that it probably will ship from China so it will likely take at least a week to get it in the US. Mine showed up in 13 days. You don't have much in the way of tracking. Nobody else was offering this particular item when I purchased it although some similar items are out there and some have remote sensors. With this one, you need to mount it where you get the light exposure directly.This unit is small which is nice and so far it seems to work OK. Note that the item is not weather proof and you should mount it with the opaque part pointing down so as to not get water in it outdoors. I suppose you could use some silicone sealant if you must mount it the other way. If it is inside a protected fixture you'll probably be fine but then may need to consider reflected light.I wish that Amazon had a standard part of each item posting that says, "ships from..." That would be helpful in making purchasing choices because you'd have a good idea of what to expect in the way of shipping time without having to do a lot of digging in the details.  Usually I want things quickly and I suppose I'm spoiled by Amazon Prime, but I don't see between a week or two, or more as being quick. Once you order, the ship estimate from these guys is ridiculously long. Pretty hard not to beat their estimate.Anyway, the item is OK but I think the waiting time has to be factored into a good review if it is "outside the ordinary".  Amazon says not to do this and I understand that the same item might come from different sellers. You may at some future point, find this item from some other seller and not have this issue. I just think it is useful to know what to expect.

I needed a really bright reflector bulb for a tall ceiling so I chose this G7 since at 1000 lumens it was rated higher than other LEDs I looked at. I am pleased with the quantity of light it gives off and with the instant on feature (perhaps 1/4 second delay...less than the Feit reflectors I also own). The light color is ok, but there is a noticeable difference between this 3000K bulb and the Feit or Philips 2700K LEDs. The light appears pure white, no warmth.

I initially bought  the 15 inch version of this saw only because lowes doesn't stock the 20 inch.I'm cutting a log , (  of 1 foot diameter size ), the 15 inch was ok BUT the 20 inch was a monster.It had no problem cutting through the tree section, I gave out...it never did.I'll work on the rest of this log tomorrow,but I got my slice tonight....planning to cut cross sections, let it dry / shrink...them use it for authentic cutting boards.... The wife wants his and hers.After it dries,I'll season it with walnut oil....food safe. Rather than mineral oil....it takes too long to "cure".I had considered a bow saw BUT didn't want a one use tool or a tool with limited uses.I can cut 2x4's  etc with the 15 and 20 inch fat max....not limited to just logs or tree trunks.The black coating seems durable too,and my blades teeth are as sharp as everAmazon has quick shipping too,ordered it on Saturday , received it on Monday ....although initially they said Tuesday ..
It is wireless, strong, convenientIt does the jobs wellI've used it for wood, metal, plastic and galvanized pipeIt does it all.

It's not a bad tool and I'm glad I own it, but the reality is that it's so bulky that in most situations this tool is just too big and fat to be the right one for the job.  If your nut or bolt is out in the open and you've got plenty of room to work, this is fine.  For example, if you had to take the nut off of a bicycle tire axle, you have lots of room to work.  But if you've got to loosen a nut or bolt on your auto engine or underneath, you usually have limited space to swing the tool, and around the bolt itself.  The tool is probably not going to do the job.
summary: Not a bad tool, but limited usefulness

reviewText: This is like a cross between a vice-grip and a crescent wrench.  This is great for bath/kitchen plumbing when you need to remove stubborn fixtures and do not want to embed the channel lock/pipe wrench teeth into the chrome fixture and leave rough teeth marks on the smooth surface.  The wrench locks down without marring the polished finish and it will not fall off if your hands are slippery wet.  I also would like to see this tool in a 12" version.

reviewText: I bought three new Toto toilets just 2 years ago and one of them started leaking (in the tank so not a leak that makes a mess) several weeks back. Turns out that the float that shuts off the water after a flush no longer turned off the water so it would just drip a bit, or run a bit, or make a really loud pressure noise at times (like the middle of the night when you need a really odd, loud, unfamiliar noise the most).A little research showed that this is a pretty common problem with some Toto's (Toto Carlyle II model in our case) and this is the universal fill valve that replaces many Toto fill valves. This one on Amazon was about half the price of the Toto website and it came in a genuine Toto box so all looks legit.The Toto directions are mostly clear and you could do most of the job without any directions, it's pretty much common sense. But, you need to lookup your toilet model number on the directions to know what height to set it at (it's adjustable) and how much to set the water pressure knob at (it comes with a key you use to set that). It's that key that isn't clearly explained but you basically find your number on the chart, find that number on the key, place the key into the knob and turn it until a it hits the key...essentially you are using the key to set a gap. Once you understand that it's all quite easy and you'll have it replaced in 10 minutes.No tools are needed to put in the new valve but you may need a wrench to get the old nut off the old valve when pulling out the old unit. Other than that it's easy and has worked great ever since I installed it.
summary: Finally, a fix for that nearly new yet leaky Toto toilet

reviewText: I gave this electric screwdriver to my father for Christmas.  He is "very pleased" with the product.  It has adequate power for an electric screwdriver, and has impressive battery staying power.  He was able to screw doorknobs onto all the doors of his church building on a single charge.This screwdriver fits easily into one's hand.  The ergonomics are improved over some earlier models, which don't quite reach a 90 degree angle between the screwdriver and handle portions.  But for really tight spots, you can still straighten it from the 90 degree to the 180 degree position.Like other Black and Decker screwdrivers, there is a light to help you see what you are doing. And like most other Black and Decker products, this little tool seems to be made well.  Overall, I recommend it as a purchase for yourself or for a gift for the handy person in your life.

The last lights I put into the pool deck were almost $140/ea in 2007... and I have 84 of these fixtures!  So, I had my maintenance staff take these fixtures and install them and they're working wonderfully.Two things:1) I didn't need the power supplies, so I feel that's a bit of a waste - I wish the lights were sold separately from the power supplies.2) I don't think we need power supplies any more - all of these lights should be solar, just with much higher wattage diodes. reviewText: These batteries are a very good choice for an inexpensive alkaline. Heavy duty batteries, are not cost effective because although cheaper, they have a very short run time. To get the best bang for your buck, go for alkalines like these.The "Procell" designation is basically Duracell's way of marking these batteries as ones intended for industrial applications. They make them as a separate line so they won't directly compete with their consumer lines.My experience is that these batteries do not last quite as long as the top consumer lines from Duracell and Energizer. However, they are within 10-20% (depending on the application), and are considerably cheaper. So, they are much more cost effective.Unless you are using them in an application where it is difficult to change the batteries, I recommend going with these instead of spending more.If you like this review, please click the "was helpful" button below it.

The quality of these tools was better than I expected (with me being just slightly pessimistic considering they come in a blow-molded case, which often makes me think of a "homeowner's" set of tools, vice a set for a professional).  The ratchets, sockets, and socket accessories are heavy, polished, and strong.  The wrenches are a bit thinner and lighter, but still acceptable.  The screwdrivers have nice, ergonomic grips and well defined heads.  The allen wrench and driver bits are standard.  But my impression of the adjustable wrench, adjustable pliers, and long-nosed pliers is slightly less good:  the adjustable wrench is forged, the adjustable pliers is a little stiff to adjust, and the handles on the two pliers are not my favorite type.Here are some other points worth mentioning:1)  This definitely strikes me as a set you'd keep in your car in the event of a breakdown.  It leans heavily toward mechanic's tools rather than homeowner's tools.  In fact, my general feeling is that there are too many similar sockets taking up space where some more diverse tools might be in order.  If this is your main set of mechanic's tools, than it might make sense, but I suspect most people really into working on automobiles might go with an easily-augmentable set (i.e., that doesn't come in a blow-molded case of this sort).Specifically, for emergency tools or for a more amateur set of tools, it is not imperative to have three different drive sizes, especially because many of the socket output sizes overlap.2)  The 3/8" drive sockets are 12-point, while the 1/4" and 1/2" drive sockets are 6-point.  This appears to be normal, although I'm not entirely sure why.  I assume it's because it requires little effort to use 3/8" drive for everything, where if you are an aficionado or concerned about rounding bolt-heads, you'll switch between drive sizes and always use 6-point sockets.  This sort of reinforces my point number 1, above.3)  Spark plug sockets decrease the amount of metric deep sockets you get with the set.4)  It's nice to get some standard screwdrivers instead of having only the changeable bits.  On the other hand, this is also not strictly necessary overlap.5)  Hex wrenches and screwdriver bits are always going to be sort of a pain to get at in sets like this.6)  The only 1/2" drive socket included that is not a duplicate of those available in 3/8" drive is 21mm.7)  Since the handle does not fold, the plastic clips holding the case together at the top are not super-easy to access.8)  The clips can actually fold in and the case sides can fold in and rest on them.  This can be annoying when you're trying to close the case, but it might be on purpose to make temporary closing of the case easy.I like these tools.  I will feel good knowing they are in my car should a breakdown occur.  And that is the use I think this particular set is best suited for.  I recommend studying the contents carefully before deciding which set to buy for your intended use.

reviewText: This works amazingly! I used it to take off left over adhesive residue from a plastic window insulator film that had been on my window for a couple of years. It was able to take off the residue with no problems! I left the solution on the adhesive residue for more than 30 seconds (which is the instructed time it says to leave it on there) and then used a much sharper scraping device to scrape off the gunk on my window. The scraper cap can only scrape so far, but I'm not reviewing this product for its ability to scrape the gunk off my window, I'm reviewing it for its ability to take off what it's supposed to take off. In that regard, this receives a 5-star rating for what it's advertised to do! Amazing! By the way, if anyone wanted to know, I used a stainless steel wood putty spatula and it worked much better at scraping the gunk off my windows.

I received this bag through the Vine program two days ago and I could not be happier!  Here are the positives:First, the bag has a very solid and not very flexible bottom to it.  This is a good thing since it actually provides some structure to the bag, especially when you place heavy tools (3 pound hammer, 1/2 inch commercial drill, two 18V battery packs and two commercial 18 volt drills).  The bottom is made of heavy rubber which makes it nice for using on a construction site as it will stand up to a lot of abuse and does not get your tools wet if the surface you are placing it onto is wet.Second, the handles are made of webbing that is securily sewn into the sides of the bag!  There is no shift of material when you lift a heavy load.  You can grab the bag quickly and swing it up onto a bench or other item without worrying if it will fall apart!Third, the canvas material that the bag is made of is very heavy and appears to be water repellent.  Taken out in a light rain water only beaded up on the surface.  I have not tried leaving it out in the rain and would not recommend that.  But, when you have to make a dash to your vehicle and the weather is not cooperative, this should help to keep things dry.Fourth, the bag has several pockets, both inside and on the outside, that you can fit tools and such into.  The only down side is that there is no way to secure any of the pockets.  However, things such as electronic levels, tape measures, drill bit sets, etc., seem to stay in place without any problem.Finally, the red of the strap material helps to keep you from accidentally leaving this bag behind!  Black has a way of just melting into the background, especially when you are in a hurry.  The straps on this bag really stand out and help to keep you from leaving it behind on a job site.Now, for the bad aspects;First, there does not appear to be any way to lock this bag.  So, it is not as nice on a job site as a locking tool box.  Still, it is more flexible in what you can place into it.Second, as I mentioned above, there is no way to secure any of the outside pockets.  This means there are NO closures for any of the pockets and anything that fits loosely can fall out!  You might want to stick to only using the inside pockets unless what you are placing in the outside pockets fits REALLY securely.All in all, this is a nice and flexible addition.  I can easily stick a 100 foot power cord into the bag for job locations where it is needed.One final comment, there are NO wheels on this bag and I am very glad of that!  Apparently, there is another bag from this company that has wheels, but this is NOT it!!
summary: Soft sided replacement for tool box

reviewText: The cast aluminum base had a hump in the casting 90 degrees to the plunge travel.  Don't expect to get good results with a tool that references the base to a flat surface when the tool rocks back and forth on its base.  Yes the issue can be resolved with enough elbow grease.  Just apply spray contact adhesive to the back side of coarse grit sandpaper,and stick it to the flat surface of a cast iron jointer table.  Then rub it flat, and reattach the somewhat less than sturdy aluminum base plate.  I just don't like having to do makeshift finishing work on a poorly manufactured tool.  And no, I didn't send it back for an exchange (not purchased from Amazon).  It only took the better part of one day to flatten the base.  It would have taken two weeks for an exchange, which may or may not have been from the same production run with the same exact issue.  Who knows?In summary I have been duped by advertizing to expect that tools with DeWalts name on them should perform reasonably well out of the box.  This one did not.  Being gullible is my own fault so I am only deducting three stars.  Not because the tool did not eventually work well, but because although I paid DeWalt; they didn't pay me to do their work for them.

I have always had two motion sensor lights in my front yard, one pointing at my driveway, the other at my front door, pointing toward the street. After having our cars broken into a couple months ago, i am so relieved to have replaced this unit with my old one. This one is amazingly bright compared to my old ones. We always used to turn off our lights at night, to save electricity, but since these are LED, i feel better about leaving them on all night. my driveway is very long, it can hold four cars lined up front to back, but the lights are positioned about 10 feet into the driveway and it lights up the whole area, all the way down to the street, roughly 20-25 feet.  i absolutely LOVE that you can have the lights pointing in three different directions, and they hold their positions very well. The sensitivity is adaquate and can sense even my dog running around the driveway, which is good enough for me.

reviewText: While looking around in the tool department at the local Sears Store here  in Fairbanks, Alaska, I noticed this sander on the shelf.  I had heard how  great Random Orbital Sanders were from various people, and since it was my  birthday, I snatched it up and took it home.  To date, I have used this  sander for about everything!  Initially, I used it to sand kitchen cabinets  that I built from scratch and faced with Hard Maple. Then, after finding it  did a better overall job than a belt sander, I sanded two cedar patio decks  (ten by twelve ft, and 8-x 12 ft).  I then used it to refinish the capping  board (2"X 6" on my eaves) that had been badly weathered.  I have  used this sander without mercy for hours on end; I have dropped it from  height approaching twenty feet, and have soundly thrashed it on too many  projects to name.  In short, it still operates like the day I took it out  of it's box...four years ago. The grit of sandpaper you install determines  this sander's versatility!  A great buy for the money!Handy Dan

reviewText: This is a very good dryer vent. Heck, this is a very good vent! It has been functioning without a hitch for over a year now. This is a very nice design, and I like the fact that it is closed shut when the dryer is off. It is also easy to clean if you need to (just take the lid off and knock yourself out). Also, I don't know why, but I think it looks nice, nicer that those flappy ones, more "high-tech", but maybe it's just me...BUT, this is not without faults.First of all, it needs to be painted - why the heck don't they just make it white and then I will paint it other color if I need to? Weird... Other reviewers downgrade this issue, but unless you have some skills with that spray paint you'll end up with an ugly looking vent with drippings and such. And why do I have to spend 4 more dollars on a good can of paint when I shouldn't?But the main issue is that this vent comes without any tail piece or sleeve or anything to install it with. How much more would have cost a 1-foot aluminum pipe with a 4-inch plastic collar ?!? I will tell you how much is going to cost you: a few bucks - go to your local Home Depot, Lowes or other hardware store and buy the cheapest through-the-wall dryer vent and use the parts that come with that one (similar to this one:Lambro Industries 4' Wht Dryer Vent Hood 224Ws Dryer Hood Vents). I have cedar wood shingles, and any installation without that pipe would have been pretty nasty unless I was willing to use 50 tubes of silicone to caulk all those cracks and wholes and crevices in my aging siding...But in the end it installed very nice and secure (it's build off of very solid plastic, which is nice, so it doesn't crack when tightening the screws during installation, or when prying off or replacing the lid during cleaning).Anyway, this is a very good vent but I feel forced to give it 4 stars. I just wish I didn't have to deal with the above issues. I also with that they made 6 or 8 inch ones as well cause I need them desperately...
