Their were a few reviews saying that the Fire Extinguishers (FIRE GONE) arrived broken. Both of mine arrived in good condition, packaged tight. No problems. I have one in my Washer/Dryer room just off the Kitchen area. And one in my living room where there is a lot of wires. Most fires start in either the Kitchen from stove top cooking, or in the bedroom from unattended candles, cigarettes and space heaters. Bedroom linens, curtains and beds are extremely flammable. The house I was renting about 2 years ago went up in flames. My roommate was smoking a cigarette in her room (while she had oxygen tubes in her nose from a tank near by. She dropped her cigarette on one of the tubes while she was sat up in bed and within seconds, the whole bed was in flames.The firemen got their pretty fast, but the fire had consumed the bedroom, kitchen and her bathroom which were all located on her side of the house. It's actually the black smoke that travels within seconds throughout the whole house that can kill, not the fire. She's fine and within a year, the house was rebuilt, thank goodness for the firemen AND great House Insurance.Something to consider. Be careful.I'm also buying a fire blanket soon, people always think it wont happen to them but it's best being a little paranoid, just in case. God Bless.
this ruler is nice and tough, but the joints make it a little tough to manipulate, the slide inside is a nice touch for small spaces.

I bought this knowing it was not designed for my Delta TS300, but I also knew that it was modifiable. I have posted pictures of how I set mine up.I basically threw away the instructions after reading through it once to get the basic idea of how the parts fit together. I then assembled the stationary subassembly part of the table and test fitted it to my saw. I then marked the 4 holes to be drilled and where I would need to add a horizontal brace along the lower part of the table saw stand. This brace I made out of a 2x4.I then disassembled the parts and started assembling it directly to the table. The pieces have a lot of adjustment built in by using slotted holes, so as long as you get the 4 holes drilled in the right place on the table saw, you can get it aligned. Precise alignment (as suggested in the original instructions) was not needed. You do have to be careful though to align at least one slot for your miter/cross-cut slide. I don't need both channels, but if I did I could cut out a section of the stationary table top with my router.Once I got the metal pieces bolted in place, I again test-fitted the stationary table top piece to make the final mark for cutting off the edge so that I had clearance for the fence slide. After making this cut (allowing for about an 1/8th inch fence clearance), I assembled the stationary top in place, aligned it and checked for flatness and tightened the bolts.Adding the big folding table to the hinge was then trivial and required no adjustments or cutting. You also don't need 2 people, because one end can rest on the floor while you insert the screws. My TS300 is on a wheeled stand, so the vertical brace is not long enough. The simplest solution was to just put a wood block under the vertical brace made of glued 2x4 pieces. Problem solved.This is a really great table extension and I'm very happy with it. It converts my TS300 into a professional level saw. The extension also doesn't get in the way of using my Bench Dog router extension. This project took 3 hours, with 1 hour spent on thinking about assembly and test fitting the pieces with 2 hours spent on actual assembly. I took my time and didn't rush, and measured twice before drilling or cutting anything.

There's detailed instructions on where to place this fan in a room to get maximum air circulation, but who has time for that? I just need to have it near a plug. It does a good job of spinning fast, but I will have to amend this review at the end of the summer after I see how well it does with a room with Western exposure in the summer.
summary: Powerful Fan That Takes Up Little Space

reviewText: I use this bit on a Router Table with the P-C 7518 motor.  I've used it on scrap pine and Q-sawn White Oak and the finish is incredibly smooth.  Even my wife approved :).I spin it at 21k RPM and it works beautifully.  I highly recommend this bit!
This box is very handy and strong. My hand tools used to be all over the place. This box has two small boxes for loose screws, nuts, bolt and bits. Tray is deep enough to accommodate packaging tape.

I bought this tool at the local lumber yard.  Used it twice very briefly.  Next time I tried to use it the thing just plain would  not turn on.  So I decided to read the review and see this has happened to a couple others... I'm thinking there are many many more out there just like mine.... sitting in the bag on the shelf of wishful thinkers hoping some day the very nice looking tool they bought will suddenly and for no reason come back to life.  I just hate to throw it away but it doesn't work.2 months later; So more on this story... I took it back and they gave me a new one... no questions.1st of February 2014,still working good and have found it to be more usefull than I thought it would be when I first bought it.I've decided to change from 1 to 5 stars.
summary: short life but they replaced it no questions no problems

reviewText: The faucet looks fantastic.  The stainless body is solidly constructed.  The wand, however, is made of plastic. I hope it wears well and doesn't lose its stainless look quickly.  That said, the plastic wand looks great and is lightweight, which is good when used for an extended period of time.Installation was a snap. It took about a half hour, it probably could have been quicker, but I check and re-check the connections, then re-check...residue from an install where I didn't...lol. But, I digress.  It is a bit odd that the water lines are connected to the faucet base, but I would think that shouldn't be an issue for the life of the faucet, I hope I am not wrong!The faucet functions flawlessly thus far (I installed it last night). The handle movement is smooth and precise. The wand slides in and out without a hitch and has a great spray.Overall, I think this is a great faucet for the price. It is solid where it needs to be and I think it will last like all the Moen products I have used in the past.  If any issues pop up, I will edit this review.
Not very good transitioning imho, This is just the nature of the led, a lot of red bleed most of the time but they still look good. just obviously not a controller system with smooth fades. ymmv

Pros:This thing is much brighter than my old 60w incandescent. Tested with my recent purchased Kill-A-Watt, True 9w as advertised, while many other brands are dishonest on this number, I think it's related to the real brightness of the bulb. The light color is very comfortable.Cons:It's not for you if you are looking fo something to work with a dimmer.Overall:What I really love is the brightness of this bulb! The build quality seems good, but I will see how long will it last.Just find out they got a 4 bulbs value pack that can save $1 more per bulb, will definitely buy more!
Good!!! This allows me to solder and work on quite small items, it is a must for any electronics projects!

Look... toilet seats are a fact of life for most of us, and frankly I don't think its asking a lot for them to be reasonably comfortable, durable and easy to clean.  But apparently toilet seat manufacturers do because I have had seat after seat that simply didn't stand up to those basic demands.One of the problems I've found over and over, is that the bolts that hold the seat to the toilet tend to loosen up over time, so that the seat shucks around on the toilet.  This was particularly bad when I was caregiving and my elderly charges moved around quite a bit.  But honestly, in the course of doing whatever business you have to do when you're sitting on the toilet you're going to move around, and the more play the seat gets from the bolts the more likely it is to start to slide.  (I'm not kidding you when I tell you that when I bought this seat at the hardware store, there were three other people there, all looking for a toilet seat that either didn't loosen up easily or was easy to tighten.)  If you don't tighten the bolts constantly, the supports on the underside of the seat will eventually slip off the toilet rim and then there's a very real possibility that the seat will crack.  Anyone who has ever had to sit on a cracked toilet seat will tell you that they bite.Another problem is cleaning the hinge area.  Unless you're one of those rare people who passes strawberry ice cream instead of the usual digestive products, cleaning the seat area can be a nasty business.  Sometimes, for whatever reason -- maybe one too many chili dogs, or the kids gorging on their Halloween candy. I'm trying hard to be delicate here, but still convey useful information -- things don't make it into the bowl, but find their way to the underside of the seat and the space behind it where the bolts are, which means that the nuts that you have to tighten regularly may well be soiled, too, making the whole process really unpleasant.However, the Bemis seat with its easy-clean hinges addresses some of the more annoying problems with a simple design change.  The bolts and nuts are affixed to the toilet independent of the seat.  The top of the bolt creates a good seal that prevents leakage down onto the body of the bolt and the nut that holds it in place.  The seat then is placed on top of the bolt, pressed down, and locked with an easy twist of the hinge lid.  This makes the process of tightening the seat simple.  No more reaching around under the rim of the bowl, sticking your fingers in god-knows-what to tighten the nut.  It also makes removing the seat a breeze, so you can put it in the bathtub and scrub it down with your favorite cleaner (I favor bleach or Lysol) and let it dry while you scrub down the porcelain, removing every bit of organic matter that's found its way to area behind the seat.Personally, I prefer wooden seats because I find them more durable than plastic, and the Bemis is a good, solid wooden seat.  As far as anti-microbial action goes, I don't put much stock in things like that.  I prefer to trust to a good scrub brush and a bottle of my trusty cleaner.  I also appreciate the price of this model.  For all its advantages, it's a very modestly priced option.  You don't have to spend a lot of money for a good toilet seat.  Spend smart and you won't go wrong.
Not that I will need to, but I would buy these again if needed.  I do very little cutting with a reciprocating saw, but when I do, these blades always do the job quickly.

The feather board itself is great, no complaints, no suggestions, works as advertised.  The issue is with the magnesium-aluminum cast runner which measured 0.78 inches across the bridge.  I had to grind it down to fit into the miter slot (which is 0.75 max width).  Also, it would be great if they would include a couple of extra screws; those always get lost.
Had an attic fan installed but it did not come with a thermostat.  Was able to identify what was needed and found it at Amazon at an excellent price.  Works as desired.
summary: Right price for the right item.

reviewText: In the descriptive text, this thing says it has a "daylight-off function"... there's an asterisk after it, but no footnotes for the asterisk to refer to. I'll provide the footnote here:* (not really)That is, the only "daylight off" function it has is if you physically take it off the wall and turn it off until night. Considering that many competing products do incorporate a cheap photocell so you aren't burning up your battery when motion is sensed in broad daylight, that amounts to a pretty dishonest description.It's also a lot more cheaply made than, say, the Mr. Beams lights which sell here at $10 each in a 3-pack and which DO have a photocell to keep them off in the daytime.So saying, for $7.50 it's not worth my time to do a return.I'll just note (1) Don't buy this, and (2) Don't buy anything else by these sellers until the borderline-fraudulent description of this item is changed.Amazon - you need to police the honesty of your sellers' descriptions a little better. And I need to read the reviews better and trust them.
summary: False Description, no "daylight off function". Get a different one.

reviewText: I was looking for a replacement for my old Stanley countersinks and this is it and at a savings too. I needed something for with mild steel and this will do it.
As one reviewer wrote, there's not much to say about nail setters. However, it stood up to my hammer and set the nails in my baseboards. I like the variety of sizes to choose from, too.

I wanted a bright light as a reminder light for use even during the daytime (for when I open a door in a well-lit area.) And this light does exactly that. I just hope that the batteries have a decent lifespan.

I turn this on at bedtime and it gives the vaulted ceilings the full display.  I feel like I am lying peacefully under the sea.  There are a couple of settings, one starts out with red and switches to other solid colors.  The other display is multi-colored.  Both are groovy.  I fall asleep in minutes watching these soothing lights.  So the automatic one hour shutoff works perfectly for me.There are three buttons and after weeks of using this, I still haven't figured out which is which.  I just push them all until I get what I want.  Closer inspection of them with my glasses on doesn't reveal any clues.  But somehow I always get it to work so I have no complaints!Sample provided.

This digital laser thermometer is perfect for what I need.  I travel in an RV and it's good to check the temperature of tires and bearings occasionally.  This is perfect for that and eliminates any gueswork.  Now I can get an accurate reference without getting my hands dirty on tires and wheels.  With the 12:1 ratio and the distance that my hand is from the wheel, I get the temperature exactly where I need it and the laser indicator shows me where I'm pointing.  It appears to be very accurate and it's VERY easy to use.  I hadn't even thought about one of these to help check the temperatures until a friend who also travels in an RV said that he had bought one (different model) and asked me to figure out how to set it up.  It was small, cheap and complicated.  I know he only paid about $15, but quality and convenience are certainly worth something.  I doubt it that device he bought will survivie one trip.  I'm very satisfied after looking at over a dozen similar products.  This is sturdy, easy to use, easy to read and comes in a nice padded cloth case.  You can stop looking.

This is a great setup to carry with me on the road if I need to change a wheel on my truck or trailer.  I have a small tool bag just big enough for a Dewalt impact, 2 batteries, and thsi socket set.  I just grab it and throw it in whatever I am driving that day.

I like this tool. Bought it for my mosquitto zapper and it turns on and off with light sensor and timer.Decided to use it for Christmas lighting.  Working well there too.  Two years pretty steady now with wide range of temps.I'd purchase it again.
summary: Been using it summer and winter!

reviewText: Great all different sizes and easy to use.....price was right and the service great!!!!!!! all in one box great buy!!!!!!!

I didnt realize it is as small as it is, but for such a little tool it comes in handy. the blade is nice and sharp right out of the package and is a great multi-use design. The scissors are ok, sometimes its hard to cut paper because they are not very sharp. The package opener is ideal for blister packs or even just as a box opener, very very sharp. also I didnt realize that it has a pair of tweezers. The spring loaded pliers are great for one hand use, although they dont open very big so you cant really use them for that much. all in all its a wonderful little tool, and youll be surprised how often it comes in handy.
This seemed to work nice for a little while, but then it would chew through batteries like nobodys business. Good idea but this did not work
I bought two of these, one for my dad, and one for the father-in-law.  They are used all the time, and are extremely handy for grilling.

I purchased 8 of these to light up a gun safe.  Compared to safe-specific light strips, this was like stealing from a cost standpoint.  I had initial quality problem with 2 of the eight (DOA), however Amazon's excellent customer service sent me a brand new 2-pack and just told me to trash the DOA ones.  Easy as can be for a consumer.  These products I've had now for 6 months and they are working perfectly.

They sure aren't cheap, but they're great equipment and you'll use them for the rest of your life.  I've used mine to check my table saw and miter saw tables, and even as a straight edge.  Good stuff.

I purchased this multitool as a part of my everyday carry on my key chain as I don't carry any of these tools on me at any given time.  I don't plan to use this everyday but just to have it there when I need it.  This is what I found so far.Pliers/wire cutter - I much prefer the pliers over the scissors as the main tool.  The pliers have teeth for grip but has a flat tip for fine plying.  Can be used in the place of the tweezers if you need stronger tweezing.  I also like the spring to keep the pliers open when not squeezing them.Bottle opener - Something that I always need but never have on me.  The opener also acts as an extension to the handle while using the pliers and gives a little more leverage.Flat blade - Rounded edge with a tanto like tip.  The tip is good as it is closer to the face of the blade lowering the chance that the blade will want to close on your fingers while cutting.  This is very important as it is not a locking blade.  It also comes decently sharp and under its own weight can just cut paper.Flat head driver - Pretty simple and does its job.  Can only handle little torque before starting to bend and damage the tool.Phillips driver/file - The phillips driver is decent and can only handle a small amount of torque, but as for the file, it is next to useless.  Its small and if anything it files in one direction; toward the tool.  Not a main function but don't even consider this as a part of the tool.Scissors - Cuts paper just fine.  I typically don't have much use for this but its a nice to have.Tweezers - This is a nice plus that I didn't realize at first.  They are a bit weak and not as grippy on things like splinters etc.  But since the pliers was designed well, you could use that for tougher jobs instead.Some other things I noticed - After just a day of this on my keychain, the black paint started to come off making it look worn.  I dont mind but just something to mention.  As some others have stated, when opening the pliers, the paint does come off and somewhat gouge the other half of the metal.  Also it comes with excess oil on all of the parts.  To me it is a good thing as it wont corrode before you get it.  You just need to wipe off the excess and you are good to go.  Lastly, the only time you have to open the tool is to use the pliers/wirecutters.  Everything else can be accessed with the tool in the closed position.I've had leatherman's in the past, and wanted to try something different.  I had not been let down (yet).  I would recommend this to keep with you at (mostly) all times.  I will also update should I find that functions break et

I used this when I painted some closets. I have wood floors and wood paneling so I used the tape to protect both. It worked well.The tape is easy to tear by hand. It stuck well to my paneling as well as my floors.  I was able to remove a piece of tape after I placed it on my paneling and reposition it without a problem. It is easy to remove.Some white paint did get on the tape and the tape protected both my floor and paneling. I also used the tape to hold down a small painter's tarp and it worked fine.I will use this again on my next painting project.
summary: It Did A Good Job Protecting My Floors and Walls

reviewText: This is-I must say- is the best snap together shelving unit I've ever bought! Goes together easy and the instructions are plain and simple. You just have to read "All" of the directions 'before' assembly. Then it goes very smooth sailing. I keep it in my one bedroom apartment's living room. And works good on carpet. Very Happy! Five Stars. :)
summary: Just what I ordered and needed!... .

reviewText: I got this tool because I LOVE the laser level and it works so well - NOT so with the laser tape!  I guess we need a little bit more technology before something like this can be very useful as a household tool.  When its low on battery especially, it gives wacky numbers that are nothing close to the actual distance!  It also doesn't work well if you have patterned wallpaper - it needs a solid surface!  When it does work, it only measures to the closest inch - anyone who has done home repairs knows that isn't nearly close enough!  An inch might as well be a mile!  I don't recommend this product.

I have been buying wire brushes at Harbor Freight for next to nothing.  These were more expensive, so I assumed were "more better"!  NOT.  They appear to be about the same quality as the HBF units and it does not appear they will last any longer.  So, I will keep getting mine at Harbor Freight and just keep replacing as I need them.  Much cheaper way to go and, I think, just as good from a usability standpoint.Way over priced.

I ordered 10 of these bulbs to replace 8 incandescent bulbs in my malibu lighting. The first thing I notice was the color was great, nice warm yellow, almost the same as the incandescent bulbs, maybe not quite as yellow. The bulbs were nice and bright, more so than I expected. My original concern that light output not being 360 degrees, would be very noticeable. It is not. I was very surprised by the look of the malibu light with this installed, you cannot tell it is an LED instead of incandescent bulb.While I was surprised by the good qualities of the working lights, I was also surprised to find that 2 of the bulbs were defective. One bulb would not turn on at all (yes i tired it in 2 different fixtures). The second bulb would turn on, but very dim (also tried it in multiple fixtures). It was a good thing I had 2 extras because that is what I needed. I doubt that these bulbs have a 20% fail rate, I was just unlucky.Amazon online chat service was more than helpful. I was given a partial refund to make up for the 2 defective bulbs, and amazon did not require me to return the defective bulbs. As usual amazon was great. I will post updates if any more bulbs should fail ahead of schedule. For now though, my yard looks great!
summary: Great color, good brightness 20% DOA rate

reviewText: I have owned several Skill saws (worm drives) and this is my first time buying the MAG.  I have used them a lot on the job site, unfortunately they were not mine.  Even when my heavy saw was in front of me, I would still gravitate to the light MAG.  I will never go back.  Especially since my table on my last saw got all bent up, which seems to be the common complaint about this MAG.
summary: The trimmed weight is HUGE at the end of the day.

reviewText: I have been gradually phasing out lesser quality tools such as Black & Decker and its offspring Dewalt, for example. I have found Bosch tools to be superior in every respect. Why Consumer Reports (CU) does not even list Bosch in its ratings of cordless drills is a major mystery to me. I guess it is due to the bias which I have detected with CU, IMHO. As far as the Bosch PS31-2AL. Here are some comments regarding the usefullness of this very fine product:Pros:Very handy especially for simple wood or metal jobs.Smaller size adapts well for use in tight areasEasy to use - change bits, etc.Fits well in handCharges quicklyBattery indicator lightLED lightCons:None
The heads on the bolts are quite small.  The bolts are fine it they would have used decent sized bolt heads.  I wish the assortment was bigger.
THIS IS A VERY GOOD PRODUCT. IT PRODUCES A STEADY BRIGHT LIGHT THAT YOU CAN SEE IN THE DARK SPOTS.
I loved it while I used it. Sadly is won't fit in my sheath so I no longer use it. Though when I did it worked great and was very strong and had a good grip on my belt.
I have not had any issues with this battery.  I did call Makita and they informed me that they had a bad batch earlier and have corrected the problem with the newer ones.
It works.  COULD WORK BETTER.  But it works.  That about sums it up.  Make the magnet strong for gawds sake..
summary: It works.  COULD WORK BETTER.  But it works.

reviewText: It is not a $200 set. It is not supposed to be.  For the home wood worker, it is great.  True, the inside of the cut is not purfect, but great for gluing (side are smooth as silk).  And I did not have to spend an arm and a leg for the set.  Very easy to get just the right width with all the shims. Would buy again.

We've had this for two months, and it seems to be working well. One drawback, however, seems to be the following:We have the Nest upstairs, and another thermostat downstairs (two thermostats on one zone). If the downstairs thermostat turns the heat on (which is rare, since the downstairs thermostat is next to the heater), the Nest temporarily gives a wiring error code. Whenever the downstairs thermostat turns off, however, the error code goes away.I like the Android app. On our 4 hour drive home from a weekend away, I set the house from AWAY (50) to normal (68), and came home to an ALMOST warm home. After the house heated up to normal (68), it detected that nobody was home so it dropped the temp back to Auto Away (65). I probably should have guessed that, and next time I'll wait until we're closer to home before logging in to pre-heat the home. Anyhow, it was much better than the old-school thermostat, where we'd come home to a 50 degree home, and have to wait for it to heat up all the way!

I read all the reviews before buying. Wound up getting this one to replace my older 13A Makita 7-1/4" saw. The Makita had unstoppable power, but that is not what I need. I'm a woodworker, and I use this to break down sheet goods and cut hardwood to rough size. It is working pretty hard to rip 5/4 Ash, but it gets 'er done. For 3/4" plywood, it is no effort at all.If you don't cut through materials thicker than 1-1/2", this is a great saw. It weighs probably half of what my Makita did, and that was with the aluminum shoe. The steel shoe of this saw follows aluminum edge guides without binding. (aluminum to aluminum always binds up) The left blade design is great for righties.As for the blade selection, I admit that it isn't extensive. It is only really extensive for the 7-1/4" saws. However, I have what I need. The included blade is not carbide tipped and is pretty much a throw-away. I bought the Skil brand carbide ripping blade. I also found a higher tooth count carbide tipped blade at a local tool store. The key to getting clean cuts in sheet goods with this (or any) circular saw is to make a zero clearance shoe that goes over the stock shoe.If you need to cut 4x4s, this isn't the saw for you. But if you need it to break down sheet goods and cut stuff up to 1-1/2" thick, this one is really handy. So far, I haven't missed my 7-1/4" Makita at all.
summary: Handy size, adequate power for 1-1/2" deep cuts

reviewText: This is the perfect size little saw; I absolutely love it! I have mine mounted to a Rockler acrylic base that I use with a saw guide.  I still use my normal 7 1/4 for 2 x4's and such, but this saw will handle 2x lumber pretty well too. The left side mounted blade is great to see what you're doing, and the light weight is wonderful.  The stock blade is pretty awful, and as others have commented it can be tough to find blades for this saw.  I found that using a Skill 4 3/8" 40T flooring blade with 2 bushings works. The flooring blade has a 20 mm diameter cutout, and you can get bushings to go to 5/8", and then 5/8 of an inch to half-inch is pretty common. You can get this blade at Home Depot and Lowe's. Oshlum (sold on Amazon) has a 24 tooth blade with the correct bushing for under $8, so it makes for a nice general-purpose blade. The smaller blade is nice for veneer plywood, but at 4 3/8 of an inch it won't cut full depth.  Doesn't matter to me as I only use it for plywood, and a lot cheaper than many 60 tooth blades for the 7 1/4 saw.  Just don't lose your bushings! They are gold when it comes to the saw.Just wanted to add, Amazon sells this 42 tooth blade as well: Tenryu SL-14042C that will fit with a 5/8" to 1/2" bushing. This one is 5 1/2" About $29.00.Just do a search for both names. The saw is worth the small inconvenience in locating blades.

There is usually not much you can say about masking tape but all the claims for this one are true.I left it in recently painted walls, a desk and over trim and it removed easily when needed to remove. It is sturdier than the normal tape you get a your local home tool store. It is a darker blue and the glue is strong but not sticky if that is possible. It didn't let any paint run into it...it might be because of the glue or because we applied it fairly tight. Either way, a good product and a nice width for different tasks.

It's strange how a tool I never knew existed will drift into my awareness and within a few weeks I will have developed a need for it. I am not so much into fixing things because I like the work, it seems to be because I am fascinated by equipment and will learn a trade or skill just to use whatever new device holds my attention at the moment. And it comes in handy, especially in a case like the Bosch Fine Cut saw.. When I first saw one a few weeks ago my first thought was, "How cool. But silly. A power handsaw. Is that not a great oxymoron? And what would you use that for?"I liked the way the unit was reversible, the backbone of the saw action is integral to the blade and all the main unit does is provide power. The blade attaches and snaps over to either side in seconds. There are presently only 3 blades available, a coarse, a fine, and a true flush cut fine blade that will only run in one direction due to the offset. I would expect a carbide blade or an abrasive of some sort will be coming soon, as I have often needed a way to trim metal in a similar manner. But still I was unconvinced.About a week after that I got a project to remodel some cabinets in place and instantly discovered "what for". But I resisted at first, thinking I could pull it off with a Japanese backsaw and a recip, even though there would be some problems with scratching the cabinet interior. Before I could get started, I was called to replace a broken board in a redwood pool deck, a five foot section had snapped off of a 12-footer. It would have involved clearing away a railing and everything atop the good wood to remove the long piece and then trim it and replace. An hour, just for that.I picked up the saw immediately. ($99.00 at Lowes) along with 2 extra blades, as I have read they are somewhat delicate.It took longer to run extension cord to the job than to fix it. I marked the broken board to the length of the repair piece and put the Bosch to work. Two minutes, max, I had a perfect cut without a nick on the adjoining boards. One more job like this and the saw has paid for itself. It is hard to find that in a tool.(Added later) - Well, there was that job- replacing a water-damaged bottom panel under a kitchen sink. I probably wouldn't have even considered the job if not for this saw. A little hard to handle in close quarters, but I had the old panel out in about 20 minutes, with no damage to the cabinet. Like surgery.There may be other units out there that perform as well, I have seen cheap jamb saw for twice the price, and I have heard a plate joiner can be pressed into service for things like the deck. But the Bosch was in the right place at the right time for me, and I am very satisfied with the purchase.
summary: If you think you need this saw, you probably do.

reviewText: ....the extension bar arrived with the little chrome ball missing, so my enthusiasm is a little limited so far. The description is also a little off, the handle is uncovered metal. But I want to praise AMAZON's uncomplicated way of handling returns, really no problem at all!

I moved into a new house last year and wanted to add a countdown timer to the bathroom fan in the master bedroom.  I didn't pay enough attention the first time and purchased a Leviton LTB60-1LZ the first time.  When I went to put it in I realized that the Leviton device required a neutral.  This was my own fault for not doing my homework.  On round 2 I did additional research and found that the Lutron MA-T51-LA would fit my needs.  A simple single pole install that fit fine in my existing electrical box.  My only knock on the device is that the usage isn't as clear cut as the Leviton device.  However, once you figure it out it works fine.  The rocker button on the right side of the switch will control the length of time the fan runs.  Just use the button on the right to adjust the timer (indicated in lights on the left side) and then hit the big middle button to start the timer.

My response for the often asked question are these Stainless steel material was:Just because it is shiny and silver does not stainless make. Chrome vanadium or molyedium (chrome-moly) or any of the various alloys of steel are still steel... NOT STAINLESS which in and of itself also has various alloys depending on the properties for the steel that are being achieved.. ( 400, 430, 17-4 , 700 are various grades of stainless steel.. 17-4 is some pretty tough stuff but a B_____ to machine or cast..SHORT ANSWER- SOCKETS ARE NOT, REPEAT NOT STAINLESS STEEL. However, with a high grade of 'regular' steel. these sockets are HARD CHROME PLATED which most corrosion tests and wear or abrasion tests will outperform stainless steel. Even the US Navy designates 'Stainless' as 'Corrosion Resistant' steel.. it can rust under hard conditions. Hard Chrome if done properly.. not flash applied just to say it's hard chrome... will hold up under ANY NORMAL use.. We should live so long.. davzway..  Show LessAm ordering more to replace what was stolen.  Unless you want to pay the extra bucks to buy Craftsman tools.. Stanley  is as good as it gets,, and a GREAT VALUE FOR THE MONEY.UPDATE #1-  Speaking of my former large set (201-pc) which developed a pair of running shoes and ran down the road... the set I am purchasing is the 123-pc.... as best Tool Deal (Amazon had best price I've found for the Stanley brand (only other considered is Craftsman) for the Bucks.... the 123-piece set has everything I will ever need and I don't need the other wrenches in the larger set.
summary: EXELLENT VALUE FOR YOUR BUCK ... AND ... great long lasting tools

reviewText: Impact sockets do wear out and finding them at a good price but still well built is a must. These work, they are tough and they last.

I purchased the La Crosse Technology BC-700 Alpha Power Battery Charger several years ago.  I mostly use Energizer rechargable batteries and I am still using it with batteries in it now, showing full and ready to use.  I know some are not into using rechargable batteries, but I will attest that this charger will change your mind.  Computer keyboards, mice, old transistor radios, LED flashlights, remotes and other items using AA and AAA batteries are using rechargeable batteries in my house.  Do these batteries last as long as a new alkaline battery, no, but they do with the first charge complete and in use.  Oh, and with the right amount of due diligence in monitoring the charging system, you can even recharge alkaline batteries, several times.  Just charge them for about 2 to four hours, take them out to sit for an hour or two, then more charge, more wait . . . until you have a good charge.  Don't forget or they can, but not always, heat up and leak, then they are ruined, as your charger may be also.  I suggest the new rechargable alkaline batteries and a specialized charger, igo comes to mind, if you want to recharge alkaline.  But for a good charger this is it.  When I purchased mine it was about 2/3rds the cost of the one on sale now.  Still a good bargain.  I love mine.
summary: La Crosse Technology BC-700 Alpha Power Battery Charger

reviewText: I got this to sand old walls and patch jobs flat. Does a good job for about 20 minutes, but the suction doesn't really seem to do much for the draw wall dust.
Brass would be better, these rust if not careful. a case would be nice, these are real easy to lose. I bought replacement because the old ones are lost, not worn out.

Very bright, hefty quality weight, aluminum housings. low power draw, very bright for the size and good beam, spot and flood at the same time make them good for offroad, but PLEASE do not use these as fog lights on your bumper on the road at night, you'll blind everyone. The bolts are stainless steel, the mounting bracket mayyyy not be, so i plan to scuff and paint them with a black rust inhibitor and that should prevent rust. I got 4 and plan to mount them on the front of my safari rack on my grand cherokee. i already ordered 2 more for the rear of it, so i can run 4 front, 2 rear.. after looking for a long while, these things are the most impressive and best quality for the cash. may be brighter and better ones out there, but they come with a price that could get you 12 of these for 2. after my install in a few weeks, (waiting on more lights, some relays, wire, etc..) then i'm pulling the rack and will install them all.  i will post pics after such a time. if you want off road lights for your roll bar or rear, don't look or ponder, get them when you can afford to do so. they really are very very impressive. and i don't impress easily with car stuff. thank you tuff led lights. they ARE made in china, but the quality and heft is spot on so far, i'll update if any situations arise.
summary: these are the bing bang dealie shizzle bizzits.. WOW

reviewText: Like my review for the SAE set, this is a good bargain for a well constructed set to good tolerances. Has performed well, but I don't use it commercially so I don't know how it will stand up to hard use.
summary: Stanley 87/126 1/2-Inch Drive Metric Deep Impact Socket Set

reviewText: The 12-volt Rockwell RK2515K2 3RILL (pronounced "thrill") is a 3-in-1 (1) screwdriver, (2) drill, and (3) impact driver. The 3RILL uses a 1/4-inch quick-change hex chuck (as opposed to a traditional 3/8-inch 3-jaw chuck).Pros----- Quick and Easy Drill/Drive Bit ChangeThe quick-change hex chuck makes changing drill/drive bits quick and easy. Simply pull and hold the spring-loaded collet, drop in the bit, and let go of the collet to securely lock in the bit.- Compact and LightweightThe 3RILL is more compact and lightweight than most cordless drills/drivers. It measures only 7-3/4" in length and 7-1/2" in height.- Convenient and Intuitive ControlsThe controls are conveniently located to allow you to change the 3RILL to one of four modes (driver, drill (low speed), drill (high speed), or impact driver), set the direction of the rotation, or control the amount of torque.- Lifetime Battery ReplacementThe package comes with 2 rechargeable batteries. Rockwell's free battery replacement program will replace a faulty or worn out battery FOR AS LONG AS YOU OWN YOUR 3RILL. The CAVEAT is that you have to REGISTER YOUR 3RILL within 90 DAYS OF PURCHASE.- Long Lithium-Ion Battery LifeThe 3RILL uses lithium-ion rechargeable batteries. Lithium-ion rechargeable batteries have the advantage of being able to retain their charge for MUCH longer periods than either NiCad (Nickel-Cadmium) or Ni-MH (Nickel-Metal Hydride) rechargeable batteries.Cons----- WobbleThe convenience of the 1/4-inch quick-change hex chuck comes at a price. The quick-change chuck is built to allow a certain amount of wiggle room to facilitate the ease with which bits can be inserted or removed. As a result, there will be a very slight wobble during drilling or driving. For high precision drilling, the wobble may present a problem.- Inadvertent Switch In The Rotational DirectionI frequently inadvertently change the direction of the rotation due to the placement/design of the directional switch.That's all the cons I have discovered so far after using the 3RILL for 3 weeks. For the most part, I love the 3RILL because it gets my simple home projects (such as hanging up wall shelves, installing curtain rails, removing fixtures, assembling furniture, etc.) done quickly and easily. Moving along...- ControlsThe controls on the Rockwell are intuitive and easy to use. The controls consist of(A) 4-Position Switch (on the top of the unit)This switch sets the unit into 1 of 4 modes: (i) screwdriver, (ii) slow drilling, (iii) fast drilling, and (iv) impact driver.(B) Dial (around the quick-change hex chuck)The dial has numbers 1, 3, 5, 7, 9... through 21 for adjusting the torque of the screw/bolt driver to one of twenty-two clutch settings. Beware you don't set the torque too high for the type of screw/bolt and material (be it hardwood, softwood, plywood, drywall, fiberglass, etc.) or you might strip the top of the screw head and/or damage the material.(C) 3-Position Switch (next to the trigger)This switch controls the direction of the screwing/drilling/impact driving: (i) counter-clockwise, (ii) locked, and (iii) clockwise.- Included AccessoriesIncluded in the package are 1 Flathead screw bit, 1 Philips screw bit, 2 drill bits, 2 battery packs, a battery charger, and a carrying bag.- Additional AccessoriesYou may want to consider getting 3 additional attachments to extend the usefulness of your Rockwell:(1) 1/4-inch Hex Quick Connect to a 3-jaw chuck adapterConsider getting an adapter for turning the 1/4-inch Hex Quick Connect to a traditional 3/8-inch 3-jaw chuck made byRockwell (RW9275)and other manufactures such asHitachi (725405)andMilwaukee (49-22-1560).(2) Magnetic Bit HolderFor an even faster change of your driver bits, get a Magnetic Bit Holder, such as theTEKTON 2901. Bits are secured in a magnetic hex sleeve.(3) Socket ExtensionFor attaching your sockets to the 3RILL, you will need a socket extension such as thisNeiko 3-Piece Chrome-Vanadium Extension Power Bar Set.---Despite a couple of problems, I really like the 3RILL. The most significant problem of the 3RILL is the wobble but I don't deem it fair to penalize a product because of a drawback intrinsic to quick connect hex chucks. Bottom line, for most home projects, the 3RILL will help you get the job done with incredible ease; for drilling that requires extreme precision, you might want to consider getting a driver with a traditional 3-jaw chuck.
summary: Tackles Your Home Projects With Incredible Ease

reviewText: Sometimes it's the simplest of ideas that make life so much, well, simpler.  I can't imagine not having my bench cookies now.  They are great, especially when I am sanding and finishing.  They keep pieces from walking all over your bench.  The extra clearance they give you makes finish work so much easier.  The price is right and the utility is excellent.
Just like the bottle states, it's great for trim work, it fills smalls irregularities and ever so slightly open joints.  Great initial tack, strength and usability.

I bought these to supplement and use at right angles to the 4 larger CC12PVAD clamps I also recently bought. The shorter length makes them handier for attaching to the larger clamps - using the combined clamps as a holding fixture.
Absolute junk. LEDs 4 and 5 quite after first use!! If someone finds a reasonably price reliable make, please let me know.

I highly suggest buying 'Milwaukee' tolls instead! They have a much better warranty and their tools are a higher quality. I am an electrician and will never, ever, buy anything from Makita again.Both my sawzall, AND my drill broke within the first couple years. Not only that, but my co-worker's drill also broke within the same time period. I took both tools in and paid to have them repaired. I had a terrible experience there which I will not even go into.A few months later my sawzall broke again in the same exact place! After many phone calls to Makita, they tell me they will not fix their faulty repair for free! Not only that, but I also find out that my original repairs were supposed to be covered under warranty! After weeks of emails, and leg work, they refuse to refund my money for my original repairs! I simply cannot believe how horrible the Makita company has been.Makita needs to learn a lesson from Costco about customer service. The bottom line is that Makita's tools are cheap junk, and they rely on you, the consumer, to police their own warranty policies. Do Not Buy Makita!

Very cool thermostat.  I'm not sure how much money I'll save (I'm sure it will probably tell me in month or so:)  It looks great on the wall and is very cool that I can turn the temperature down or up from my phone.

Yes, very nice thermostat, like the blue color, and I keep it on all the time. My only grief is that this thermostat keeps rebooting all the time at random.  The screen goes blank,  some seconds later it comes back, as a result I not getting any usage graph, I think that is why, it could be something else.  Is anybody out there having the same issue, rebooting at random and not getting the usage graph?

I bought this toilet Auger because one of our toilets was frequently clogging up and traditional home remedies were not working. The clogs were so bad the toilet bowl would fill up completely with no room for any chemical products and even a plunger would cause a big mess. This Auger took care of the problem from its first use. I simply opened the package, pushed it in the bowl, made a few turns and the clog cleared instantly. I haven't had any clogs since then. There were no visible scratches or damage to the bowl after using this product. I am very happy with this Auger.

I was a little dubious at first but they seemed like a good idea. I found they worked well for light bench work when placed on a bare wood surface and with various success on other surfaces. Obviously they will work better with light work such as sanding than they do with heavy plane or chisel work. Over all I found them to work well if you don't expect them to be as good as bench dogs.

Better Ergonomics:  This drill feels right in the hand, better balance.  By getting rid of the battery stem they gained freedom to design a more ergonomically shaped handle, which I really like.  They also lost compatibility with the older XRP pod type batteries, but I much prefer the newer form factor battery.  The slide in battery is much more compact and easier to install and remove.  This drill is lighter than the 18v XRP drill, mainly due to reduced battery weight.  You'll notice that on the job for sure, and it's a welcome change.  Overall the ergonomics are much improved.Longer Run Time:  The 3 Ah battery has 25% more capacity for longer run time between charges than the 2.4A batteries of the 18V XRP series.  And because they are lithium, they don't have the rapid self discharge of NiCd or NiMh batteries.  So you can not use the drill for a month, and it still has charge, but my older batteries would need a refresh.  Big improvements, to me.Some Cons:  These are really 18v batteries, not 20V -- says so on the box.  Dewalt says they call it 20V to avoid confusion with the older 18v XRP line.  I find it misleading.  I hate to quibble -- these are fine products, big improvements, but I have always trusted Dewalt to be trustworthy.  Makes me wonder....  Another claim is up to 1000 recharges.  I'll believe that when I see it.  I typically get 300-500 charges on a lithium battery before it dies, so 1000 is hard to believe, but let's hope.How you use them can affect battery life.  For best battery life, keep the battery cool, not in a hot truck cab if you can avoid it.  Lithium batteries degrade faster with heat.  Don't leave them sitting in the charger.  And never run it all the way down until the tool stalls.  For some reason, Lithium batteries don't like that.  I'm told there is a shut off in the battery when the battery is close to drained, a safety factor, but why push it?I'm not trying to start a debate here, but it's true that Makita (and Milwaukee, Bosch, Ryobi, Rigid) have had this same slide battery style for several years.  They are all popular for the reasons mentioned, and I'm glad Dewalt updated the battery to the slide format, finally.  I think competition is a good thing, it keeps them all making improvements and the customer wins.When I checked these out at the Big Box Store, I also looked at the baby brother of this drill, the DCD780, and I may get it too.  It's much lighter and smaller, and better for those quick jobs like screw driving, assembly/disassembly of things, whenever you just need a light drill without the heavy duty power of this one.  Its smaller battery is compatible with the charger and batteries of this one, a convenience.Seems to me there is a lot to like in these new Dewalt "20 volt" tools. The better ergonomics and longer run time are a big win.  If you like Dewalt, I think you'll especially like this new line.
summary: Better ergonomics and longer battery life

reviewText: This tarp, while stronger than your typical blue tarp, is not really "heavy duty". I'm using it to cover a large boat and I expect it to last about a year before the sun makes it brittle. It's a fair price, especially with free shipping, but I don't think I'd buy another one.

After gulping down the absurd price of $70 for a replacement 12v battery for my old version Makita drill(s) at the local Orange Box everything but what you need store, this kit came on Amazon as a 'deal of the day' for close to $190.Since the whole kit (2 drills, 2 batteries and a charger) cost almost the same as buying two more replacement batteries for my old drills, I jumped on it. I had been hesitant to move from my old standard blue 12v drills. Seriously, is spending money on a new charger and batteries really worth moving to 18 volts? My 12v drills work just fine. No issues. Well, I'm sad I didn't do this a year ago.The new drills are way lighter, and shorter bit to back.the LED light is way more useable than I thought it would be. I will NOT buy a drill without this again. My old impact driver has it, but not my standard driver.The chuck on the regular drill is awesome, and much better than the old 'twist while holding' style. You twist to lock, then tighten. Hard to explain, but I didn't read the instructions and figured it out in about 15 seconds. It works like you expect it to. Just put in the bit and twist. It knows what you're trying to acomplish.Battery charges really fast as well. Way faster than the old system.Just spent all day screwing sheetmetal trim into roof facia with no arm fatiuge or hand soreness. Balance is awesome, and the extra power is great.I have not used the impact drill from the kit yet. I have nothing bad to say about the old style, so I'm hoping for a nice suprise.The case is a nice toss-in. Nothing fancy here, but a nice place to put both drills and the charger. Probably won't get much use, but it's nice to have.
summary: More power, more speed, better chuck, better balance

I had a rule I failed to follow and that was to buy the tool I want and not try to have all the same batteries . there is a comparitive review in tools of the trade magizine and this saw is very much true to that review .
