These go in straight, load well, don't deflect even with lower velocity, and are more cost effective than my local hardware stores.

I bought this set to replace a couple of heavily used and aging Ni-Cad drills, one of which was a lightweight Makita that I liked very much. I was looking for a compact and lightweight replacement and accepted the battery life and power tradeoff.After shopping around I found that the Makita and the Hitachi equivalent  to be the best balanced and most comfortable in my large and rather arthritic hands. The Makita was a better deal at the time and I've had good luck with most of my Makita tools in the past. Also, I wasn't too impressed with the crappy flashlight that came with the Hitachi kit. Had they included a decent LED light for the extra money, I might have gone with the Hitachi.I haven't used the drill a lot, but it seems as good as my old one. I've been using the driver pretty heavily driving 3 1/2" deck screws and lots of 1 1/2" metal roofing screws. The driver has been very comfortable and for such a small tool has had plenty of power for the job. It is easy to overdrive small screws, but not inevitable. The compact size and belt clip have been very handy up on the roof. I like the way the switches work on both tools - they feel better and are more easily accessible than many of the others I tried in the stores. I found the LED light more useful than I thought I would.The only moderate disappointment has been the battery life. Even though these are the compact batteries, I'd hoped to get a little more life out of them. Using the driver heavily I found I was swapping batteries pretty frequently. It's definitely a tradeoff, and I may eventually buy one of the larger batteries as a backup. That said, they really do charge in about 15 minutes and using a small and light tool is a benefit, especially in tight spaces and for driving lots of screws in a row.The soft case doesn't seem like it will hold up to much abuse, and if I were frequently moving the tools between job sites I would miss the form fitted blow molded case that came with my old Makita and held all the parts tightly.Overall, if the tools and batteries hold up over time, I'll be very happy with this set.

I bought his kit at Home Depot and the drill did not impress me. The bit wobbled way to much to be useful. The impact driver was good. Thinking I got a dud I returned it and ordered another one online. This time the drill was much better, the run-out still was clearly visible by naked eye but not even close what I observed in the first drill ( Mind I tried many different bits with all the same results).  But the impact driver in the second kit is much louder than in the first one and vibrates too much . It feels like something is off center (unlike the driver from the first set).This this supposed to be one of the best drills ever ( based on the price ) but it seems that the technological process of making this tools cut some corners.

This is a dimmable LED light bulb that produces light equivalent to about a 60W incandescent bulb or 15W CFL. Like other LED bulbs, this bulb is rather heavy, so the note on the package suggests only using it in fixtures that can handle a heavy bulb. The bulb is shaped like a regular incandescent bulb, so it fits well in lamps with shades. Indeed, with the light on, it looks just like an incandescent bulb. However, it produces a lot less heat--you can easily hold on to this bulb while lit without burning your hands. That and the fact that it is plastic so it's not going to shatter if dropped or banged make this bulb a great choice for children's or infants' rooms. I've found CFL bulbs exceptionally prone to breaking, and they create a toxic mercury mess when they break. Even if they don't break, you can't just throw a CFL in the trash because of the mercury content, so you have to go to the trouble of returning it to the store or a hazardous waste collection site. This LED, on the other hand, is much less likely to break, and it contains no mercury. It will also last a lot longer than a CFL (and much, much longer) than an incandescent bulb.I find the soft light quality of this bulb very pleasing, and I also like the way it looks in my antique lamp. It's a bit pricey compared to other 11W dimmable LEDs, but it may turn out to last longer.Price comparisonTotal costs (purchase price, electric usage, replacement costs) for 25 years, assuming $.12/kwh:--This dimmable LED bulb (60W equivalent): $88.52--A dimmable CFL bulb(60W equivalent):  $73.25--A dimmable incandescent (60W): $198.25In the long run, this bulb may cost a little more than a dimmable CFL, but it also brings peace of mind since it is less likely to break or produce a mercury spill.
Bought this product for installing new kitchen cabinets. Worked well and very easy to operate. For the money, it is a great buy. Self leveling worked great.

I just love the shower and i could never figure out why someone couldn't create a way for me to hold a portable end of the showerhead while still enjoying the flow of the stationary head and VOILÀ!  I don't think Ana Bath is the first company to invent this idea but they are the first, in my experience, to do it right.  What impresses me the most is the attention to detail that you get when you buy this.1. Very clear instructions2. Sturdy parts3. Plumbers Tape (Can't tell you how many times I've lost mine or had to make a special trip to buy this.)Mine worked on the first try. The flex hose is super long (something I was worried about) and the pressure is awesome and don't even have that much to begin with. Based on the kind letters of gratitude I received from the company, I can recommend this product without hesitation, because if you weren't happy with it, I know you would either get support or get a refund. I really love mine (though it does make it even more tough to leave the shower).
summary: Everything about it is just Conscious!

reviewText: Irwin handles are very comfortable and give excellent grip. The crimps work on all the different stay cons that I use for my business. I am a HVAC professional.

My husband wanted to replace my 25-year-old mercury thermostat with the nest. Fine, sure, whatever. Amazingly, it actually works with my 25-year-old furnace. Who knew?But. One of the undocumented problems with the nest is that it becomes trivial for unresolved disagreements around what actually is a comfortable temperature to escalate into all-out war. First, only one account can control the nest. So, if you want to share access to the web/app interface you ideally need to share access to the email account affiliated with it*, and at the very least share a password on the nest site. Second, adjustments that used to require physical access can now be made even when one partner is 3000 miles away.It's bad enough when someone walks down the hall two minutes after you and fiddles with the thermostat. It's utterly rage-inducing when someone digitally walks down the hall and adjusts the temperature when they aren't even THERE.I turned the heat up. He turned the heat down. I named the thermostat, he named it something else. I turned the heat up again. He turned the heat down and changed the password on the nest account to an insult. I turned the heat up and banned the nest from the wireless network and changed the wifi router password.You can see the trajectory of the problem.So, before jumping to buy the latest tactile, shiny, overpriced, cloud-computing-based listening device for the NSA* that also happens to control your furnace-- you should ask yourself some questions:1. Do I and the people I live with have compatible temperature/environment preferences?2. Do we have good communication and conflict-resolution skills?3. Are we willing to share passwords?*4. When our temperature preferences diverge, is there a window of compromise?5. Can we agree to not make temperature changes remotely, overriding the preferences of the person actually in the home?The nest is $250. Couples counseling can be $250 an hour. You need to consider the strength of your relationship quite seriously before embarking on this journey to a more quantified life; there may in fact be no cost saving at all.That said, we eventually resolved most of our issues regarding the nest. And it's quite nice to return from a long trip and be able to turn the heat on before we disembark from the airplane, rather than walk into a freezing-cold house and wait, shivering, for the furnace to spring to life. But it was a little rocky getting there.There are other issues; the thermostat is in the hallway, which no one ever stands in unless they are coming or going. So I usually end up having to poke the thermostat to tell it *not* to auto-away. Also that hallway is quite protected from the bulk of the air volume of the home, so while it might be a quite comfortable 72, the bedroom might be a sweltering 77. etc. But hey, at least it's pretty.* Now with 100% more Google. Don't be evil! Seriously, though, password/app access may become even more of a problem if authentication on the nest site with a gmail or google apps account ends up being tied to your google account password. It is a Really Bad idea to share passwords for your email account. The interim step may be changing the email tied to the nest account to be a non-gmail email address (easy for me, not so easy for many people), but it will be very interesting to see how this plays out. The acquisition by Google means we will *not* be buying a Nest Protect, as we don't need to invest more money in a product line that may be developed in a way we are not comfortable with.
I use this item often. Good quality, quiet and it is light.  Very easy to handle.  Might not be the unit for someone in a big shop but it sure is handy for a handyman.
Given as a gift to my daughter and her family along with batteries to stock the battery operated toys my granddaughters love.  Works well.

I got this to sand a design into a sheet of lexan.  It worked perfectly and with the pointed end attachment I was able to get into the tiny parts of the design.  Now it looks like I have frosted glass on my PC window in the shape of the NYC skyline.

You can use these dogs as pictured, or just use the black insert as a hold up to steady boards while routing etc. Very handy! Uses common 3/4" dog holes. Got a lot of use out of them already. I like that they are bigger around than most metal dogs, and longer as well, easier to pop out of the hole when I am done.

There is no comparison to these. You can buy cheaper stuff off the rack at car parts stores, hardware stores, or home improvement places. Don't do it. When you compare Milton you will will find that Milton is best. The fittings are cast and formed better. There are no odd machine tool grooves, bad plating, or off-size threads. The brass coupler is a work of art. It locks firmly onto the fitting and releases easily on demand. Once assembled there are no leaks whatsoever. The Milton brass coupler, which requires a pull back on the sleeve to attach and detach, is superior in quickly connecting and disconnecting without losing a lot of air. I can't praise these highly enough, they are fully worth the money.
summary: Quality above the rest of the pack

reviewText: I have used this for a lot of projects, and with a lot of different tools, it has held up very well and I really like how it nicely it lays out and rolls up.  It is very resistant to kinks, and the connectors have held up very well without any leaks.  The biggest project so far has been 900 square foot of tongue in grove pine ceiling, so we are talking about a lot of snags on ladders, and getting run over by scaffolding and it has held up very well. Next project is the same square footage of hardwood flooring in a month or so, and I am confident it will last me many years after that's done.
Good quality Solder which bonds larger copper terminals to copper wire really well.  I have nothing but good stuff to say about this solder.  Good buy.

I have this light in a washroom where the door to the garage is located.  When leaving or coming home at night with items in your hand, it's not always convenient to get the light switch.  This light provides just enough light so you can maneuver and get into/out of the house without setting things down to reach the light switch.
summary: Just the perfect amount of light in a dark washroom.

reviewText: I have one of these (different company) in storage back in the U.S. and I needed a replacement.  I did not skimp and bought the Yellow Jacket (well known for their very high quality extension cords).  I was/am not disappointed.  If I ever need another, I will buy this exact one.

It works fine, the female end holds cords tight, and it's a fairly decent length for the price. The cord doesn't crack or bind in the cold weather, and it is 12/3 wire... try getting one that's priced this cheap at your local "brick & mortar" stores... it ain't happening 'cause they don't sell them this cheap. But, the one really nice thing is that it's made in America and it isn't that cheap China junk.  Contractors, and Subs... go for it, it's a great deal, but order it with your extension cord so you get the free shipping.

I didn't care that much for this "flantern" and I'll tell you why. First, it came with zero instructions, so it took me a few minutes to figure out how it works. "How dumb are you?" you're probably thinking. Well, the thing is, this lantern has no less than five "bumps" that look like they could be click-on switches. I tried each of them in turn, but only one actually turned the light on. Of the others, one was the hidden charging port, two were nothing but decoration, and one is supposed to allow you to adjust the handle into flashlight-mode.That's my second complaint. You're supposed to be able to push this button and angle the handle down, turning the lantern into a flashlight. Mine doesn't work very well. If I push VERY hard and pull on the handle with all my strength, I can get it to move down, but it's extremely difficult. Also, I think the handle was put on backwards, because the finger grips go the wrong way. If I hold it so it's comfortable, the flashlight shines right in my face!My third complaint is that my lantern arrived with a large crack in the clear plastic. It was packaged with lots of air-packs, so I don't know how the damage occurred, unless at the factory. It doesn't render the lantern unusable, but it is kind of annoying that a brand-new product would be broken upon arrival.So, what do I like about this lantern? It's nice that you can keep it plugged in and ready to go in an emergency. The only problem is, suppose your power stays out for a long time and the battery dies? You have no way of recharging it. It isn't like you can just pop a few new batteries in. I really like the plastic loop on top that lets you hang the lantern, so you can use it while camping. That's a plus in my book. In theory, the switch between lantern and flashlight is good, but like I said, the flashlight handle doesn't convert easily on mine, and the grip is backwards, so it fails in that regard. Another good point is that it's really bright.Two stars because it's an okay lantern, if hard to use. But if you really want the convertibility between lantern and flashlight, I'd suggest looking elsewhere.Edited to add (6/10/14): I took this lantern on a camping trip and used it to help me find the bathroom in the middle of the night. On my way back, I got hopelessly lost. Not an experience I would care to repeat, let me tell you! I was grateful to have the flashlight/lantern, but it wasn't enough to keep me on the correct path. I ended up having to completely retrace my steps back to the bathroom, and still managed to get lost AGAIN. The light just wasn't bright enough or wide enough of a beam for me to see the path I was supposed to take. So again, this lantern/flashlight fails. I wanted to like it, I truly did. But it did NOT live up to my expectations.

We all have a bit of trouble when shopping in general, but even more so when shopping on line.  Is it as good as it looks?  Is it really made well or are they talking more propaganda that fact?  Is the price reasonable or over blown?  Well,.....This saw is excellent in all areas. So, five stars?? Sure you buy bigger, better, fancier, and (probably) gold plated someplace..... This one "could" have fancy brass screws, could have a gorgeous teakwood handle, golden edges?? (All humor, but you get my point?)  This is a great quality saw for the money.  It will serve me well for years to come..... who knows, maybe I will make that beautiful teak wood handle for it?  ha ha!Yes, I would buy it again if needed, lost, broken, or damaged.  Do enjoy!
summary: This is an excellent saw for the price.

reviewText: Had a requirement for a multiple head (3) heavy duty short  24 inch (12/3) extension cord. The cord works perfectly, the lite female end shows that power is on to whatever is plugged into it. During power outages this triple header is lent out to family to connect appliances to the generator. Works great and a very handy item to have for multiple electrical connections.
summary: COLEMAN YELLOW JACKET 12/3 15 AMP TRIPLE HEAD extension cord 24"

reviewText: This "Flantern" may have been packaged in frustration-free packaging, but it was also packed in instruction-free packaging.  There was nothing in the box to say how to use this item.  Fortunately, it isn't terribly hard, but some instructions would have been nice.  The first job was to figure out where the on/off switch was located.  It is not the knob on the top!  It is on the side.  Press once and either the lantern or the spotlight turn on.  Press again and it turns off.  Press a 3rd time and the other turns off, with a 4th press turning it off.  The next task was figuring out where to plug in the  charger.  Took me awhile, but I finally noticed that there was something just below the on/off switch that was covered.  I pulled the cover back and found the plug.I noticed there was a large button at the base of the handle, so I assumed it would allow the handle to be moved.  It did, eventually, but I found it very difficult to press the button all the way in while pulling the handle out.  It does allow the handle to be in the position for a spotlight if you want to use it that way.  I also noticed the top of the Flantern seemed odd.  After playing with it, I found you could pull it up to get a handle with a couple of hooks.  Guess this is if you want to hang it up.We have been having odd power outages lately, not to mention being in a hurricane area, so I will enjoy having a light to grab when the power goes out.  I have not tested how long the light will last or how long it will take to charge, but it is bright and it is nice to have the option of a lantern or a spotlight.  Just wish they had included some simple directions.

Good concept, but this ADX "Flantern" feels cheap & operates similarly. As of this review, it's twenty dollars, which is more than I'd say it's worth. The light is sub par, the run time is much less than similar-sized lanterns and/or flashlights that run on batteries, and the build quality doesn't exactly inspire much confidence. I'd never consider this light my primary source of lighting for an emergency, but even as a back-up (or even the back-up to a back-up), it's not worth the cost.It would be much, much better to spend an extra 12 dollars to buy 2 separate lights: theRayovac Sportsman LED Lantern (SE3DLN)(for about 25 dollars), and theDorcy 41-2510 Floating Waterproof LED Flashlight with Carabineer Clip, 32-Lumens, Yellow Finish(for about 7 dollars). You'll have 2 much more powerful, reliable, and longer-lasting lights - a lantern & a waterproof flashlight.
summary: Not bad, but overpriced. Much better options available

reviewText: Excellent product.  It wasn't obvious how it worked from the picture, but the two sides spring outward and hold the bag tight.  A couple tent stakes would help hold it in place if you're using it somewhere windy.  I got it for dumping the mower bags and inside when doing projects.

I've been using this router for a couple of years.  I purchased it to replace my 25-year old Porter-Cable 690...it had become deafeningly loud.  To make a long story short, I love this thing.  It's quiet.  The electronic speed control keeps the bit speed wherever I set it and the soft start keeps it from twisting in my hands when I turn it on.I've never had a problem with the collets releasing bits, either in operation or during bit changes.  The design of the collets is a bit funky.  After you loosen them, they easily unscrew, then get tight and then loosen again.  The bit is held tightly until it loosens the second time.  This is obviously by design and appears to be a safety feature to prevent improperly tightened collets from dropping bits when the router is turned on.Another safety feature (that I inadvertently tested) comes into play if you're using this router in a table and haven't locked it into the base.  When you turn on the router, the torque will unscrew it, except the design of the groves in the motor won't let it unscrew all the way and fall out...you actually have to lift it up slightly to get it to completely unscrew.  You won't notice this if you're using it in a standard base, with the motor facing up, but it prevented a nasty accident when I had it mounted in my router table.I'm your basic weekend woodworker, so I can't comment on reliability in commercial shop with heavy daily use, but it's perfect for my application.Strongly Recommended
This is a great cord for a good price. I purchased it along with the 100 foot 12/3 cord. I doubt you would be disappointed.

Some buddies & I were trying to get a rusty wheel lug off a dead jeep & their Husky wrench snapped. Snapped right @ the nipple.They were using a pipe over the top of the wrench because of how stubborn it was being. All but jumping on top of it.I kind of joked about my new "Denali" set "Whatever that is" - "Ordered off Amazon" - Got some strange looks from an old man, handed off a wrench and said "break it"I'd never used Denali before so i wasn't 'that' confident but figured it's cheap to replace so go for it.Well to everyone's surprise not only did it take the abuse but we got the wheel off. Got some confused looks to go with it too.So yeah the set seems really good the only small complaint i have is i wish the sockets fastened into the case - as an open drop will result in a 10min+ mess.

I was suspicious about this set, but took a chance and bought it. It's an awesome socket set. The quality is very high, the machining of all the sockets is impeccable, and the wrenches are beefy and well-made. Sometimes manufacturers get it right. Is it as good as a Craftsman set? Probably not, but for the price, you get a quality socket set that will out live its owner.

I purchased two of these pegboard based tool, power tool holders. They fit and work well on my galvanized steel pegboards. They are properly sized to support power drills. The foam covered hooks are a nice feature. Although it works fine on 1/4 pegboard material, the hook inserts are 1/8 inch. It would be more sturdy with 1/4 inch inserts.
summary: Sturdy and Properly Sized for Drill/Drivers

reviewText: i am a flashlight junkie.. and this is the favorite in my arsenal. its brighter then the headlights in my car!! can not be beat for the $$.. the strobe makes you disoriented and on high its ridiculous to the point were its hard to look at what your pointing it at. it may not be 3800 LM like it says but i dont care, im going to buy 3 more and replace all the mag lights in my house.

to start-----the Free SuperSaver shipping really helps out.the quality is very nice.I will now shop for a decent automatic or manual operation hose reel to wind this up for storage when not in use.I'd highly recommend this to anyone who is tired of fighting the PVC plastic type hoses that are usually included with new compressors, etc.This hose stays flexible all year round. It's easy to see due to the bright yellow. Reinforced ends to help reduce wear at the connectors.

I got both the SAE and the metric set.  These are very high quality wrenches, and at this price you cannot go wrong.  I've bought inexpensive tools before and regretted it, but this is a rare exception.  They're very good.

I have two of these screwdrivers that we use for assembly - probably an average of 500 screws a week. The screwdrivers are great, but the batteries quit working after a few months. We have also replaced several chargers. When the chargers go, they overcharge, and ruin a battery. I also have a 14V Milwaukee drill, and the batteries don't last long on it either. Seems like a company that makes such a high quality tool would get it together on the batteries.
summary: Screwdriver great, batteries and charger are poor.

reviewText: This is a good solid no frills set that will do the job. A good price for the quality of wrenches, and the delivery is fast.A great deal.
This tool is very good for installing and fastening electrical wires on walls. I used mine for years without any problems.

this is one bright flashlight,well worth the price,their brighter than the streamlight stinger or strion,and less than half the price!incidently,i had one go bad after the exchange and they still warrantied it,thanks!!im a mechanic and its nice to have the light that puts all the others to shame,haha,also their very easy on batteries,long as your using the higher end batterries,those cheap batteries arent worth fooling with,so invest in the better batteries,such as panasonic 18650 or 26550 rechargeable,you,ll find its worth it,all in all best light,best price,best value,superb product,i highly recommend this baby,you just cant beat it for the money....thanks W.Heath

THIS FLASHLIGHT IS WAY OVER RATED. I just purchased another flashlight from Home Depot that is rated at 650 lumens, and it is much brighter than this flashlight, that is rated at 3800 lumens. I'm sure Home depot didn't under rate their flashlight by a factor of six or more. What I am sure of is that this Trustfire is way, way, over rated. Plus, by the time you buy this flashlight, the batteries, and the charger, you are out about $50. And, you better have an extra set of batteries in case you don't have your charger with you, or don't have time to charge them... Also, this flashlight has Off, Bright, Med., Dim, Flashing, and SOS. So, if you are clicking along and miss the setting you want, you have to click five more times. I was lured in by the 3800 lumens rating, and shame on the seller.I just purchased the other flashlight last week from Home Depot. It is their Defiant LED Flashlight that is rated at 650 lumens. It was a closeout, for about seven dollars, so you probably won't find it in the stores. This cheap Home Depot flashlight is much, much brighter than the Trustfire. Wow, it appears to be at least twice as bright as the Trustfire is. This would make the Trustfire,  as a very rough estimate, around 400 lumens. that would make the Trustfire 400/3800 => about 10% of what the seller is claiming. That my friends is just not good business.The Defiant Flashlight from Home Depot is marked on the packaging and on the flashlight with the number, 1000015067. It has  two settings, on and off, which I love. It comes with the set of three alkaline D cells that are needed. The batteries are not rechargeable. The packaging states that it will run for 15 hours with one set of batteries. This flashlight is huge, so it will not fit in your glove box, however, the Trustfire probably won't either.

Well made impact sockets, I threw the cases in the recycle bin. I have these on socket rails to keeps them from rolling around or having a huge case to keep somewhere. They are easy to read and I like the black color. I use these on my 1/2" IR ratchet and impact gun so IR gets my vote!I just used these to replace the exhaust on my 94 Mustang Cobra.
summary: Well Made and Easy to Read

reviewText: I use this everyday, because I don't have an alternative.  I have all the dewalt 20v tools.  This light is durable,well built and reliable, BUT the light beam sucks, its too narrow and intense for a work light.  A Flood light is what we need to work with.  I wish Dewalt listened in on these reviews and would redesign the reflector to be more like a 90 degree flood instead of a 2 degree spot light.The 18v light was better except it wasn't an LED, plus the 18v system had a fluorescent work light.

I've have had this saw for many years and it works very well.  It is lightweight, rugged and dependable.  About the only drawback I see is that it is not the easiest miter saw to align w.r.t. fence perpendicularity to blade. It can be done, but it may take awhile to align perfectly and it doesn't seem to hold alignment as well as it could, so I have to get our the squares to check alignment before attempting any finish work - work which I usually reserve for the table saw or Festool anyway, so this is not much of a problem for me - after all, this saw was intended for jobsite construction, not fine woodworking.  I should also mention that my model does not have soft start electronics.  The amperage spike when you start it is noticeable as is the considerable torque.)I have several Makita tools and they have all proven to be both reliable and durable.  I wouldn't recommend this for finish work (e.g.as a primary angle station in a framing shop) but for the price, it's a good value and sturdy and great for construction.I should also mention that the dust collector works quite well for an open miter saw.  I use a 1 1/4 hose and a shop vac, and this seems to get 85-90% of the dust, and the station itself stays remarkably clean from cut to cut.  only a light dust drifts  to the table top.I should mention that the replacement parts seem to be only available through online dealers that charge enormous shipping fees (though the parts are reasonably priced).  I've replaced some switches, brushes, cords, etc. over the years and invariably the shipping exceeded the cost of the part.  On the positive side, in my case the parts haven't failed that often.Simple Miter saw design, reliable, and competitive price.  Recommended.afterthought: I've come to rely on accurate laser guides on the modern tools.  My Makita L1040 has years of life left in it, but lacked a laser guide.  Oshlun makes a laser for this saw (Oshlun LG-M01 Miter and Portable Saw Laser guide - $22.49 @ Amazon) that works great on this saw.  See my review for details.  There are several other brands of laser guides that may work as well, but I haven't tried them.

The Schlage FE595 Camelot door lock is an excellent product.  It is very well made Itypical of Schlage products), easy to install and simple to program.  The installation took less than 30 minutes and required a single screw driver.  Highly recommended; Amazon delivered the lock very quickly and at a competitive price.  If you are in the market for a keyless door lock, do yourself a favor and give this item a try... you won't be disappointed.
Not sure if it really does anything, however, it is very nice at a great price and does look cool

I bought this product because it had a 1/4" and 3/8" ratchet for the price of one. I was very happy with purchase when I noticed they were the same quality as the expensive alternative of the same patent design. I own a more expensive 1/4" of the same already. These are a great deal for the money.

reviewerName: J. Nowicki "The Boss and  Mrs. B."
reviewText: Wow! This Milwaukee Dual Temperature Heat Gun is powerful! I sometimes have to deal with frozen water pipes at our cabin and thawing them with this gun will be a heck of a lot quicker than using my wife's hair dryer! Especially, since I just had to buy her a'Hot Tools  Professional Hair Dryer'as a replacement for the one I (uh -oops!) burned out. My advice - don't mess around with something not meant for the task at hand, if you need a heat gun this one will serve you well.  It's not only a 'hot bargain', using it can also keep you from 'taking any unnecessary heat'! ~ The Boss

I ordered three different brand clips from Amazon for my boat cover.  Teckton, Cargoloc and Scotty.  The first two brands are identical and Scotty  uses a sliding lock rather than the screw down.  All three clips on the tarp that covers my boat with stood high winds last week with no problem.  They have been installed all winter.  You cant go wrong with any of the three IMO.

This device uses four AA batteries.  The casing is pretty good quality plastic with some heavy duty rubber trimming on one end (why not both?).  It is not heavy and the impression of ruggedbess and durability is ok but not great.  The entire item is about eight inches tall.  The lamp has three settings, bright, bright and flashing.  The lens also flips to it can be used as a flashlight with the light bulb facing out or turned around with the bulb facing downward into the clear glass chamber with a pointy reflector to bounce off the light source for more luminosity.  The light also has a hook on the bottom so the entire device may be hung upside-down.  Unfortaunately, the deflector wich should be attached is loose insight the clear casing.  It rattles around in there so when the lantern is hung on its look, the deflector now falls onto the buld cutting the light out and not serving the purpose of reflection.  The deflector should be attached but it isn't.  There is no way for me to fix it because the casing is sealed.  There is also a strap as shown in the picture.  The amount of light is pretty good for being run by four AA batteries.  It is easy to use and it appears to be rugged enough for normal use except for the damage part.  The unit I got also has a couple of spots of cloudiness on the plastic lens which no doubt cuts into the luminosity of the unit.  It is too bad that quality control (is there any?) didn't spot these two serious flaws.
summary: Good little lantern/flashlight but came damaged with two problems

reviewText: These are great locks ... they look nice, and are easy to install and program. My only complaint is that I wish this unit had the LOCK button like some of their other units so that you just close the door and hit the lock. On this one, you actually have to reach you hand around and click the mechanism ... kind of silly ... or you can program it to disengage the handle unless the code is put in. I don't really like either feature ... I just wish it had a LOCK button on the keypad so that it would just operate like a normal door knob until you want to lock it, at which time you would just pull it shut and push the lock button. But ANYWAY, it is still a good unit and I would recommend it.
I'm a Dewalt guy, but this is overpriced, the tip is HUGE!!!!! Go on ebay and get a china verson for cheaper please.
summary: Buy from China on eBay please!

reviewText: Screwdriver will not work with 120 volt prongs folded out. That's why it does not work as it is packaged in the store. It appears to have enough torque for only using 2.4 volts. My unit worked before I even had to charge it.To take it apart you need 2 sizes of star security bits with center pin holes. Remove the middle screw and slide out the gear reduction clamp. When re-assembling, place the slide switch cover over the pin on the bottom of motor with most of the plate above it. Check operation with 120 volt prongs folded down before screwing halves back together. Slide on nose piece and tweak motor to get gears to mesh. Then slide the clamp in and screw in square black plastic clamp retainer.It uses 2 tabbed AA rechargeable batteries, which can be replaced. There appears to be enough room to remove the old batteries and replace the battery mount with a compact 2 AA battery holder from Radio Shack. Solder the holder wires to the board with red on right side looking at board from the bottom. The large brown capacitor supplies a trickle voltage from the 120 volt line so don't use regular batteries instead of rechargeable!B & D recommends an initial 17 hour charge, but it should not take that long to recharge it after that. I wouldn't recommend keeping the unit plugged in all of the time as this will kill the battery memory. Will follow up if this becomes a problem.

I haven't owned this long enough to see if it lives-up to its claims, but is does emit a beautiful warm glow (much too strong to serve as a night light (IMO))and an attractive addition to my family room. I purchased a second smaller one for my office. I would give it 5 stars if it actually produces the advertised health benefits. We will see.

I ordered this item May 11 and got it finally May 30th. It arrived in a plastic bag, case broken, no proper packaging. The glasses are not bad, however it it is cheap I doubt it will last long, the you have a clip that snaps the magnifiers in and out, we will see how long it lasts, because it is not easy to snap it in and out.

This devise certainly measured the heightened EMF field associated with a nearby power line.  It actually prevented me from purchasing a house which was too close to power lines.  Make sure you take measurements at different times of the day, because the current may vary during the day.
summary: It seems to work as advertised.

reviewText: Good product overall, sturdy and simple to use. Nothing more to say about this product. Recommend, cheap and quality is good.
As others have said, if you want specific color, don't order this. I received red wire, which was fine for my purpose. I don't know if this is a manufacturer problem or an Amazon problem.

Good value in being able to measure magnetic fields, electrical fields, and radio fields.  I used it to measure electrical fields in our new place.  Took it to a lamp store to find lamps with lower electrical fields.  Most modern lamps are fine...if you're in the next room.  Awful lot of electrical energy from lights.  This meter showed me how quickly the fields drop off, so I can estimate how far we have to be from the lamp to be within safe limits.  Meter is not particularly biased as to field direction, so it's easy to detect any field.
The used Dewalt battery charger arrived quickly and worked perfectly. It was used but appeared and acted as if new. I couldn't be happier. Saved a lot of cash too.

This vise worked perfect for assembling an AR on my Desk. It's a solid vise grip with steel (No Dimple) Jaws. It does have a bit of grease however (as it should) so beware of that in the area you're going to put it. I do think that hobby jaw covers would have been a good idea, but this was fine.
summary: Worked perfect but beware of grease

reviewText: These test probes seem to have some high resistance. When using them with my multimeter they register a fairly high resistance when touched together, whereas a simple 14 AWG jumper between common and volt-ohms registers 0.2 ohms. (Meter is not perfect).So I'm not sure if these leads are supposed to have high inductance for a certain style of multi-meter or not but at least be forewarned that they absolutely will not work on every multimeter.edit:Well it turns out that I had to vigorously clean the leads with steel wool. Once I did that their impedance was registered low as it should be. Still, coming straight out of the box this is not a good sign.
summary: These are either crap or fine depending on whether I'm dumb

reviewText: Not a bad set.  when i bought them, i kept in mind that you get what you pay for.  Punch down is a solid state punch down and does not spring back.  I use the crimpers almost every day and don't have any issues with it.  The strippers are nice to have especially with the adjustment screw.

I needed a Torpedo level and I knew that Amazon would have great deal which they did.Not only was this level the one I wanted, it came at a reasonable price.I'm very satisfied with my purchase, Thanks Amazon.

I have a multi-gem tester, but it's unwieldy.This buzzes when it hits metal just like my big tester, so it's not good for teeny tiny diamonds with close prongs.However, it does work only IF you can figure out what is the ctw of your diamond/stone.Calibration can be approximated: try it on whatever jewelry you have that you know the carat weight of. I've found that anything less than 1 carat (who has diamonds more than 1 carat anyway? LOL), you can crank it up to the 4th light and it works well. Go to the 5th light for the fairly tiny guys.Works off regular 9V battery which is a plus, compared to so many tools which use multiple small expensive batteries. I'm guessing that it will also last longer than those small batteries.I also found that rubies and sapphires will up the lights a bit, but not diagnostically...and not as high as a diamond. BTW, on diamonds, it is an almost immediate positive, zipping right up to the red lights!Emeralds did not move the lights, for me, at least.I'd say for quick screening, but not the best reliability...a toy.
summary: OK if you can calibrate it

reviewText: bought 2 but after a couple months one battery wouldn't accept a charge...so it is useless, last battery I buy online

I primarily use it to rip down 4x8 sheets before I go to the table saw. With a proper guide, it runs great.I will say that if you run it left handed, you get plenty of dust in your face. But that can be said about every wood cutting tool I've used. I just have to learn to run right handed....

Not perfect, but it does what I want for the moat part. The switch location, is less than ideal. So that one drawback is all, other than that its a great little, cheap built light. Almost everything is plastic, for the price its exactly what I expected.

My granddaughter has been using this lamp for a couple months now to read by at night before going to sleep. The lamp is plenty bright enough to read comfortably by with no other lights on in the room. The clamp grips firmly, and its arm is flexible and stays in the position you twist it to. I haven't used it for working, but I think it would work find in that capacity too.No negatives.Recommended.
summary: Works fine and a nice bright light.

reviewText: This is a good basic router to own. I use it in a table 99% of the time. It is rated at 2.25 HP, but it feels much more powerful. I've already run this router for hours on end without shutting it off. It's been so hot that I couldn't even touch it. Over 2 years of hard (but not neglectful) use, it has never given me a problem. You cannot go wrong with a Bosch router. I think they make the next best router after Festool.

Fantastic light!  I needed some lighting on the side of my house to illuminate the area without having to run a bunch of wiring.  This light is really bright for a solar light - certainly bright enough to allow you to see.  And since it's motion activated - a feature that works perfectly on this model - it also acts as a security light.  I'm really happy with this light.

I have an ancient faucet in my bathroom. It's a single lever deal with a round plastic handle and had no identifying brand name except for a flowery type logo on the tap I searched high and low for the logo and couldn't find it anywhere. Popping into a few local hardware stores didn't help either.I decided to inquire with a few plumbers about possibly locating a replacement cartridge but-- surprise-- all of them suggested that finding a part for such an old sink was not going to happen so I'd be better off replacing the entire faucet. Since it's so old, it's very hard to get to and rusted badly so the plumbers gave me prices in the range of $400-600. Insanity.I was unable to remove the old cartridge since I didn't have the special tool to do so, so I came on Amazon to see if these cartridges were available and maybe I'd get lucky. I saw this product and the top looks similar to the piece in my sink so I figured I'd give it a try and if it didn't fit, I'd just send it back.The part arrived the next day with the removal tool and within 5 minutes, the sink is good as new. The most astonishing part of this is how easy it is to pull the sink lever now. Having been so used to the old one, I didn't realize it was tough to pull but this new one is like butter.I'm so glad this part fit my sink as I highly doubt it is an actual Moen faucet.

not very bright but it does cast a wide beam and that's what I need in a closet. This is the second one ordered. First one was one year ago and works fine. I like that is rougher, the quality and that is made by a brand name. That's the reason I paid the premium price.

I have to say, A. Kim's review is right on the money. We also despised the auto on night lights which seemed to have a hard time detecting what was night and what was just a cloudy day. We got 2 of these lights with the LED replacement bulb and we couldnt be happier. Great, affordable item!
takes up very little space and works good. a nice 2nd hand for long boards on my chop saw or table saw.

I have a laser printer under my desk and the power switch is in the very back ... with this device I just used some double sided mounting tape and placed  the "clicker" next to my phone ... the current draw of a laser is substantial so that is why I got the heavy duty version ... wish that they  had labeled the on / off with contrasting text, i fixed this problem buy putting about 1 inch of yellow tape on the front and used a RED fine point sharpie to label off / on.  works EXTREMELY well for this purpose for the several weeks that I have had the unit, happy with the purchase AND the function
summary: got very tired of getting up and down

reviewText: I recently purchased both this Gerber Infinity and theStreamlight 66318 MicroStream LED Pen Flashlight. I have to say, this isn't a bad light unless you have a competitor's for comparison. It simply has nothing on the Streamlight. The Streamlight is brighter (a lot), smaller, lighter, more white-blueish, and uses a AAA rather than a AA battery. Both lights seem like they would take a 20 foot fall and are highly durable. The Streamlight has a pushbutton, this light is twist for on. I'm not sure which one is better, I don't really care. The Streamlight just simply seems superior in lightage, and design. This one is so heavy I don't understand who would want to clip it on a shirt.. Maybe a belt.Even the Streamlight is kind of heavy for a shirt (it still has a AAA battery), but at-least it is doable.Again, not a bad micro-flashlight, just inferior in every way to an alternative that only cost a buck more.UPDATE: The new Streamlight 66318 C4 is out making the Gerber light is even more useless than it was before. The C4 is substantially more bright than the regular Streamlight 66318. It's brighter even with a SANYO Eneloop battery, and whenever it runs dead I'll just recharge it.
Not a perfect tool but I love it, looks durable, well built,nice product, Recommended

The concept and convenience of this is great, BUT! I've had this for 6 months and the rocker switch broke already.  The receiver works well but there are 2 thin tabs that hold the rocker and one broke under normal use.  Luckily I had thin white electrical tape so I taped over it to hold it.  The rocker switch is kind of a "false" switch as all you do to make the receiver turn off and on is push on it either way.  So I know what is under it is a button. So with it held into place to put pressure on the button under it when pressed- I may be able to use this a while longer. Should have held up better.

This is a seriously good tool.  The overall length is about 12 inches and has a comfortable handle if you can reach the power source with your hand. If not, it easily attaches to the Amprobe hot stick (they recommend the Hot Stick Tic 410A for voltage higher than 1500VAC).  It's also not very heavy so you won't be straining to use it. The audible signal is loud enough to hear and the visual indicator is easy to see.  Note - this won't tell you how much voltage is present, just that there is voltage present.  It's not a multimeter.Very nice piece of equipment.
Bought two of these to replace 20 year old dial switches. What a difference and they were easy to install
I just punched 60 1/2" by 3/4" deep mortises in rock maple, and the Jet performed like a champ even with the chisels supplied.  No complaints so far.
summary: Jet vs. Rock Maple:  Jet 1, Maple 0

reviewText: I bought 2 of this black steel flint fire starter one for me and one for my grandson. I received the item as it was promise specially it comes from outside the U.S.A, we use it during our camping trip before the fall comes. It really works as it was advertise.Pros: create a lots of sparksgood length about 2.5" magnesium rod and 1" handle2.5" strikergood customer serviceCon: magnesium rod is only 0.184" (4.67mm)This company i deal with got a very good customer service, they respond in a quick and professional way, i will deal or do business anytime with them in the future. but I should have read the rest of reviews !! the light looks like a toy for a child !! also I should have seen the specifications about the light ! I mean do not get me wrong light looks strong and very well made  ,,is ,just that for my job I need something much better more powerful ,,,  but from  a light of  only one AA battery we could not expect much !
