reviewText: After charging a few days, the installation took only 10 minutes.  I mounted the collector at the SW corner of my soffit to maximum exposure, stretched about 15 feet of small wire to the lamp and plugged it in.  Setting the sensitivity and timers would have been easier IF I had taken the instructions up the ladder with me, not relying upon memory.As is, it picks up movement about 25 feet out and I don't have it to maxium sensitivity.  As I leave the garage it "sees" me and switches on before I can get far enough to see the LEDs inside.  That's pretty darn good.Light ouptut is very near that of a 60 watt bulb, the major selling point when I bought this as a "Deal of the Day".

The light is compact and bright but the pocket clip is weak.  Where it clips to the barrel of the light it will pull away from the light and hang up on what ever you are trying to clip it to (pant pocket whether it be your back or leg pocket).  This becomes frustrating when trying to secrure the light quickly.  The brightness & beam focus, buttcapp switch, feel in your hand is great the light just has a weak pocket clip.

You know, I've always bought cheap caulking guns from Lowes/Home Depot and they always seem to work fine.  After all, it's a simple contraption, how much nicer could a 'good' one be??Well this answered my question, I was surprised to see that I actually like this one a lot more than my old cheapies.  It was pretty light weight, the handle pulled easy, and didn't seem to drip caulk all over the place when I was done.Good stuff.

These things are absolutely amazing. I cant believe how inexpensive they are. I take long exposure photographer and used them to light paint. They work perfectly for the job. I brought them to numerous occasions: Red/White/Blue at the Fourth of July to draw "USA" and Green/Red at Santacon as decorations on the santa suit.They operate perfectly (I had 1-2 "duds" that didnt work) and last quite a long time. I've never had one die on me during use. Get creative! I can imagine that if you handed a few to your kids you can have a lot of fun with long exposure photography.

Good multitool. I like the idea that certain tools can be exchanged. A bit heavy and bulky due to the spring assisted blades. Both blades have to have a little play because the assist spring is not strong enough. The worst part of this tool is the file. It is not very good. I would recommend replacing it the saw. The replacement tools are not very expensive. SOG has videos on replacing the tools which are very helpful The sheath is made from leather. It is strong. I would prefer a nylon sheath with extra pockets for a flashlight and other tools. I took off a star for the sheath and a star for the file. I would still recommend the product with its shortcomings.

I bought this for EDC and so far really like it. It fits in my hand well and throws plenty of light for most uses. The one annoying thing and my only gripe is there is a small dark hold in the middle of the hotspot that is somewhat distracting. I'm not sure if it's on all of them or if I got a special one, but it's there on mine. I didn't want to incur the extra cost to try and get it resolved by Streamlight so I'm just dealing with it.Overall I would highly recommend this as an EDC light and it's the perfect combo of size and light output. I took away a star for the dark spot in the beam.
summary: Small, light, works well save for the dark spot in the center of the hotspot

reviewText: Ok, I really love my Gerber LMFII knives (yes, I have 2 of them) and I have used those as my primary survival knife whenever I go outdoors.  Well, I've been bugging to get this BK2 for months and finally pulled the trigger.  Let me just say that it's my new primary knife.Here's my comparison of the Gerber LMFII to the BK2 and why I prefer the Ka-Bar:- I like the pointed tip of the back of the handle on the Gerber LMFII, but the flat back of the handle on the BK2 is more practical as a tool.  The Gerber handle would be a sharper weapon and a better glass breaker, but the BK2 flat handle is better for hammering, which is what I would expect to use it more for- Blade thickness on both knives are right about the same, but I think I give a little bit of an advantage to the BK2.  The BK2's blade is larger from edge to spine than the LMFII though- The handles on the BK2 can be replaced.  This gives you options that the LMFII doesn't give you.  While I prefer the more hard rubber texture of the LMFII, I like the size and versatility of the BK2 more.  The diameter of the BK2 handle is a little larger than the LMFII as well, which I preferred more for my larger hands- The sheath on the BK2 is simple but sufficient.  The sheaths on both knives do the job - they hold the knife either upside down or on a belt.  Both have a pinch area on the sheath that holds the knife handle in so you can hang the sheath upside down from your gear, but I like the shape of the BK2's pinch area better.  My thumb naturally goes to the spot where you press against to get the knife to release.  The LMFII is a little more cumbersome to pull out because there's not really a thumb rest area to leverage against.  Also I actually broke one of the pinch tabs off of the sheath of one of my LMFII's which surprised me.  I was forcing it though, trying to "reshape" it so it would be tighter again after getting deformed from an aftermarket paracord wrap that I had put on the LMFII handle.  My own fault.  However, the LMFII sheath wins for functionality though because it does include a built-in knife sharpener that the BK2 doesn't have.I am convinced that a big thick survival knife is very necessary.  It could be your one and only tool to hammer, cut, pry, chop and slice with.  The BK2 and the LMF both have a great blade that has held up very well so I find both still very useful.  This BK2 just feels good in the hand, is very balanced, and the sheath is simple and does the job.  I have it hanging from the shoulder strap on my bail-out bag so it goes everywhere I need it to go.  I love this knife.

Very nice addition to recreate the standard Jet bandsaw into something much more versatile, and price was great.  Amazon shipped really quickly even with Supersaver.  The instructions are generic for all the bandsaws in this stable (wood, metal, meat, Jet, Powermatic, etc.) and some of the instructions do not apply to the Jet.  Luckily Jet tech support is pretty easy to get on the phone.  Don't bother with the blade that comes in the kit--have your own on hand.  I followed Lonnie Bird's recommendations in The Bandsaw Book and have been delighted.I installed the riser at the time I got the saw, so it was no problem as a one-man operation.  After reading the other comments I was surprised at this.  Given that this is my first bandsaw, it was really pretty simple except for the !?#&!!@*?! power switch relocation.  Would it be so hard to put a one sheet addendum into the box?  The guy at tech support was nice about it.The thing that frustrates me about the finished product is that I have to readjust the cooling blocks if I change the height of the guide assembly significantly.  That is, the post doesn't move perpendicular to the table.  I've tried everything to look for something out of alignment but can't find it.All in all, this really cuts you loose with resaw capacity.  Too bad it's not standard equipment.
summary: A few quirks keep this from being a 5 star rating

reviewText: So much light from a small package. This little guy can be hidden in your hand, yet it can outperform the large flashlights with which we grew up. It is a single mode light; on, off, but no adjustable brightness. The flashlight is able to zoom its brightness. With the lens retracted against its body, it gives a large bright circle of light with no hotspot. With the lens extended, it concentrates its beam to the shape of the led. The light is much brighter when concentrated. This flashlight can run off a single AA battery or a single 14500 lithium ion battery. It is much brighter with 14500 battery. It has an effective belt clip screwed to its side; it can be removed. The construction of the light is very robust. On one of the sides, CREE is printed. On the opposite side, HausBell is written. It was received in a box with the name HausBell printed on it. No instructions were included or nessecary. Below is a list of other flashlights I own and how this flashlight compares.Mini Cree Q5 LED - sold by PoweraddDirect: This light is also $5.99. The Mini Cree Q5 lights up a larger circle of light (not by much) and is slightly less bright due to the beam not being as concentrated. The Mini Cree is a 3 mode light (high, low, and strobe). The lens zooms in and out as does the HausBell. You have the option of using 3 AAA batteries or a single 18650 lithium ion battery ( when used with the included extension).  If size is important, go with the HausBell. If you don't mind a larger flashlight, I would give a very slight edge to the mini Cree Q5. It has more features and a wider beam with little sacrifice to brightness.Lighting Ever adjustable focus - sold by Neon Mart: This light is very similar to the Mini Cree Q5. It is a single mode light with adjustable focus and it runs off 3 AAA batteries only. The beam is the same diameter as the Mini Cree Q5 and a hair less bright than the Mini Cree Q5 using the 18650 battery. Its beam's cutoff is sharper than the Hausbell and Mini Cree. It feels very well made; better than the HausBell and Mini Cree. If had to use a flashlight for work, this would be my choice. I would feel confident it would work every time and since it only uses AAA batteries, I could stock up on them for cheap and never have to worry. This is the light I'm buying my wife. Almost $10, but worth it. Although it gives up a tiny bit of brightness to the others, the build quality and the sharpness of its beam make it my choice for a compact flashlight.Intsun Ultrafire WF502B - sold by Intsun: Longer and skinnier than the above 3 flashlights. It is a 5 mode light (high, medium, low, strobe, and SOS) and has a fixed zoom. You have the choice of using 3 AAA batteries or a single 18650 lithium ion battery. This flashlight performs differently from the others. It is more of a spot beam with residual light that spills off the extremely bright small diameter beam. This light would work well for illuminating a specific area at a great distance. It is much brighter than the above flashlights. This would not be my choice for a light to use to walk the dog at night. It is a more specific use light. Excellent flashlight, but in a different category from the 3 above.Ultrafire Zoomable Cree XM-L T6 - sold by Intsun: Wow, what a flashlight! If you don't mind a bigger flashlight, this is the one to buy. It has the same 5 modes as the WF502B and zooms in and out like the HausBell, Mini Cree, and the Light Ever. You have multiple battery options: a single 26650 li-on, a single 18650 li-on, or 3 AAA batteries. It gives the largest diameter beam and is brighter than the others (except the WF502B, due to the smaller concentrated beam). It is very well made. It is priced around $10; a steal in my opinion.In summary, the HausBell 7W 300L Q5 led flashlight is a stellar performer. It combines size, performance, build quality, and price in one incredible package.I would like to comment about the advertised lumens of all these inexpensive, made in China, flashlights. They're exaggerated. In some cases, grossly exaggerated. Don't let that keep you from buying these great little lights. Their performance is comparable to flashlights priced many times their price. My, have flashlights come a long way!

I just bought this tool back in december 04.  originally to cut baseboard against the wall to trim for wider casing.  worked great.  now I use it to sand crown corners and all types of trim work .  it works great to remove a little excess to flush up cuts.  I now use this tool every week.get this set with the metal caring case.  it is well worth it.kreg
summary: great tool to have in you tool box

reviewText: This turned out to be a good little flashlight. It is tough and easy to use. It has a great output of light and is great for an thing you need it for. Now the batteries get used up like others have mentioned but that is what tends to happen so it is cool. I would recommend this light as it has already come in handy for me.

The wonderful thing about this fixture is that it puts out the light when it gets dark.  I used two of the GE Lighting 21739 26-watt(90-watt equivalent) bulbs and my grandson installed it by screwing it into the house after he found the fixture didn't screw in where the old fixture was attached.  It works great and I love the light that is putting out.
I wouldn't take this knife to war but i would take it camping. I won't buy a second but I am happy I bought this one.

No frills, but it has worked good so far. Handles are more comfortable than most others I've had experience with but you also can't expect an awful lot from an imported hole punch that cost less than $20 bucks. I wouldn't try to start a leather working business with them but for projects here and there I expect that they will hold up. If you are a serious hobbyist these might hold up as a good "get her by" hole punch but I don't see them lasting long under those conditions...guess time will tell.
summary: does what it's supposed to do

reviewText: I'm not sure why others have problems with these or say the do not work with CFL or LED lamps.  I have 4 Heath/Zenith products like this, one is over 10 years old ,..  all work fine and all work fine with every type of  CFL or LED type lamps I tried in it.  I even tried this one with a very low wattage night light type LED corn light that worked as well.I wish this model did not have a coil cord on the remote sensor but I wanted a white one and that is how this model comes.  Otherwise no complaints..  I just used velcro to tack the sensor in several places to test the range and find the most ideal spot for it,. Pretty easy with its test mode. I ended going on top of the enclosure to better hide that stupid coil cord.. I'm using it with a 60 watt LED lamp now for the winter, will probably go to a CFL when the weather warms up.  Ya I would recommend these... A little big for some enclosures but so far I never had a problem with one.
summary: worked fine with CFL or LED

reviewText: I order these blades to go with the new saw. The blades are good but you have to be very careful because they will bend easily.

I bought several incra rules for precision which these definitely offer.  Beware, they are nearly paper thin and have to be held/used gingerly to avoid bending them.  One more thing to worry about in the shop.

I'm a hobby woodworker and don't use a dado set too often.  So when I went looking for a dado set, I wanted one that was low cost.  I first tried a set from Avenger, which is a set made in China.  It was a real piece of junk.  It didn't make accurate width dados and the chippers were different diameters, which left grooves in the bottom of the dado.I finally took the Avenger set back and bought this Freud 6 inch set.  The difference is night and day.  If I set up the Freud set for a 3/8 inch dado, it is dead on at 3/8 inch.  The bottom of the dado is absolutely smooth - not even a hint of unevenness.The only negative about the Freud set is that the spacers are not marked and it's extremely hard to tell the difference between two spacers that are close in size.  I realize that Freud may not have wanted to stamp them because a stamp might have changed the thickness in the area of the stamp, but the sizes could have been etched on.Other than this one problem, I am completely happy and satisfied with this dado set.
summary: Great Dado set for the money

reviewText: I've had Moen shower heads before.  They ALL look great, and work great.  They're well made, and will stand up to cleaning.  I replaced a rain type shower head with this one.  Wife loves rain shower, I prefer pressure.  Bingo.  This shower head is the best of both.  We each have exactly what we want from the shower head, and you can switch back and forth during your shower to your heart's content.

This is a new product on the market that with a knowledge of how it works and its limitations can be quite useful for the single repair person. It collapses into a movable tool with a big roller on one end and a handle on the other. It doesn't need to take a break or not show up and does not come with its own cell phone. With the right jobs it can be a second or third hand on the job and when you don't have paying jobs can be quite useful around the home for your to do list.The cost is a bit high but if you think about it, if your crew mate doesn't show up how handy is that ?

Filing your pets nails is WAY better than clipping them.  You don't have to worry about cutting the quik and making them bleed and cry in pain.  I filed down my 90 pound retriever's nails with this and so far so good.  It was fast and painless.I would recommend you file your pet's nails outside or someplace where there is proper ventilation.  The sanding of the nails flies all over the place and will make it hard to breathe.File down in quick 1-2 seconds burst as to not create too much heat.  Your pet will thank you.

Cleaned up a pair of 8" wheels in a few seconds, bringing them right back into round with no fuss or bother.  The diamonds aren't perfectly uniform, but as long as you sweep it right and left it provides a perfect wheel.  If you leave it in one spot and pull away rather than slide off the side, you get some grooves.Size is perhaps a bit smaller than it appears in the photo--maybe 6" long and a bar about 1-1/4" long and 3/8" square.

When I remodeled a lease house including gutting the kitchen, I decided to purchase several DeWalt cordless power tools.  My most commonly used tool, theDeWalt DC720KA Heavy-Duty Cordless 18-Volt Compact Drill/Driver, continues to be to this day.  At least until I received the Bosch DDH181-01 18V Brute Tough Drill Driver.The Bosch DDH181 drill driver, made in Malaysia or Mexico, comes with a battery fast charger, made in China, 2 18v high capacity lithium-ion batteries, a double-sided Philips drive bit, a removable handle, and a durable plastic carrying case.  The drill driver, weighing 4 lb 11 oz, features 25 + 1 clutch settings, a max 700 lb torque, and a durable ergonomic body.Compared to the DeWalt DC720KA, the Bosch DDH181 is about an inch taller and has a larger profile.  Even though the Bosch DDH181 is larger, it weighs 2 oz less and feels more balanced.  The Bosch DDH181 also has eight more adjustable clutch settings, greater torque, and longer lasting batteries.  Otherwise, both drill drivers offer similar features and kit pieces.One difference I noticed while using the two drills is how well the drilling area is lit.  The DeWalt DC720KA's LED light is placed above the power trigger where it casts a shadow from the barrel and chuck onto the drilling area.  The LED light is placed on the base of the Bosch DDH181, eliminating the shadow problem and fully illuminating the drilling area.  I could hold the Bosch DDH181 double handed without obstructing the light from the drilling area.  I could see where someone may need to fully grasp the handle with their pinky to prevent light blockage, as the angle is fine but the light is positioned about a half inch from the base of the handle.  I don't find this to be a problem though.As an active DYIer, the Bosch DDH181 is more powerful a drill than I need, as I've yet to hit the limits of the DeWalt DC720KA.  If I were buying a drill today, I would still purchase the more economical DeWalt DC720KA.  However, I prefer to use Bosch DDH181 due to its better weight balance and LED light placement.  If you're looking for a durable and more powerful Drill Driver, the Bosch DDH181 is a great option.PROS:Weight balanced ergonomic design700 lb torqueDurable housingLong lasting batteries with a 30 minute quick charge3 year warrantyCONS:None
summary: Durable, Powerful, and Balanced: A Bosch DDH181-01 18V Brute Tough Drill Driver with 2 3.0ah Batteries Review

reviewText: When I purchased these hooks, I had already owned a set of four plastic hooks for years which I, with great reluctance, passed on to a family member with inadequate closet space who guilt tripped me into forking them over. Within a week of this unfortunate decision, I realized I wasn't going to be able to get along without my hooks, and I went looking here on Amazon for a reasonable replacement. I got very lucky with this hook. It is even better than what I had, which was a single hook. This product is two hooks in one, so I can load twice as much on it.My main purpose for these hooks it to hang up drip-dry laundry in my bathroom. The shower-curtain pole can't hold enough. I also wanted a hook which provides an ideal fit over an inside door, that is, not tight enough to damage the paint and not loose enough to wobble or fall off. Happily, these hooks pass the Goldilocks test and are just right.The hooks themselves are attractive and quite sturdy, but I am not personally willing to put them to the ultimate test of strength by sticking a heavily loaded gym bag on them. I need them too much to risk breaking them.
summary: Extremely useful hook for expanding closet space

reviewText: I knew the quality of the cobalt drill bits were great but the storage box is like a mini L-BOXX that my electric drill came in.....not your typical plastic storage case......EXCELLENT DEAL with quality all around...

Although I had to go to Home Depot and buy another set of compression fittings, it was probably my own fault, not a defective product.Instructions weren't really clear, but common sense and a second try, I prevailed. With compression fittings, if you screw up, you don't get a second try. But they're cheap enough. You get plenty of tubing, and an adequate saddle valve. So if you have a convenient source pipe, hookup can be done in less than half an hour. If you're good, less time than it takes to fill a few ice cube trays.And this kit is a lot less than you'd pay in a hardware store.Very pleased with this purchase. Clearer instructions would have merited a fifth star.

I've had a Black & Decker 12V screwdriver for a few years, and it used a NiCD battery. I struggled with that thing because of its relatively low power and short battery life. I was a little wary of the '12-Volt Max' of these drills, but my dad (who has been using Li-Ion coredless tools for a while now) insisted that this new technology was far superior to the older NiCD models.He was right.The drill/driver are AMAZING. They are so much lighter and more compact than my old driver, yet far superior in terms of power, longevity, ease-of-use, and functionality. DEWALT makes great tools, and these little drivers are no exception.- Aesthetic / Ergonomics: standard Dewalt yellow-and-black. The drills are small, fit well in my larger hands as well as my girlfriend's smaller hands, and are light enough to use for extended periods without arm fatigue. I agree with other reviewers that the balance on these units is flawless.- Functionality / Power: these are tough little drivers! You wouldn't believe these are 12V drills, and wouldn't believe they were cordless, if you didn't know it to be so. They are workhorses and I can confirm they perform flawlessly drilling lumber, driving decking screws, putting in drywall anchors, even drilling concrete for putting up brackets/hooks in the garage. I really can't get over how powerful these units are, given their light weight and small size. As an added bonus, each driver has 3 LED lights built in which provide generous lighting of your work surface. They're bright enough for the drivers to double as flashlights in a pinch.- Lithium Ion Batteries / Charger: these batteries are great. One charge lasted me all day with light use; I ended up holding the trigger down and running the impact driver for several straight minutes the night after my first day of use, just to see how long the battery could last (a long time). Charging is a snap and batteries charge quickly enough that even under constant heavy use, you should always have plenty of juice ready to go.- Bag: the bag is OKAY, I guess... a bit of a disappointment when you look at the normal hard-sided plastic cases that normally come with quality power tools. The bag is fine, but not the same as a quality hardcase that protects tools from impact, water/sand, etc. I'm disappointed in the bag, but not enough to lower my review from 5 stars.BOTTOM LINE: these drivers are powerful little workhorses, yet small/light enough almost to be 'cute'. They fit my larger grip comfortably, but will work great for smaller users as well. These aren't going to be the main tool for professional carpenters, but for around-the-house use -- drywall, decking, cabinets, even drilling/mounting in concrete, these are great go-to tools. I recommend for any homeowner looking for some quality lightweight cordless drivers.
I have 3 of these sets and as long as you remember it's a 12 volt system it will perform great. Great for round the house and light commercial. Battery life is great.

WHY MOISTURE MEASUREMENTS ARE IMPORTANT. Wood has an amazing ability to shrink when it is dry and expand (swell) when it is wet. I learned this hard way some 25 years ago when I built a nice rustic table from boards with unknown moisture content... and found a few weeks later that my nicely aligned boards shrank and formed unsightly 3/16" gaps between them. Reportedly, 90% of hardwood floor installation problems are related to moisture content. Usually, moisture content is not something that one can see or feel without a tool, and any error can be quite costly. According to NWFA (National Wood Flooring Association), two conditions should be met. Moisture content of hardwood and subfloor should be within the typical range for the area where it is installed, usually in the range 6-8%, up to 8-13% in the coastal areas. The difference between the moisture content of the hardwood planks and subfloor should be within 4% for narrow planks and 2% for wide planks. If these conditions are not met, one may have to wait until the wood equilibrates with the environment.HOW THE MOISTURE CONTENT IS MEASURED. There are two ways to measure moisture content. The most common one is based on wood resistivity. measured between two pins pressed into the wood. Dry wood has much higher resistivity (typically in the range of hundreds of megaohms) than wet wood (in the range of kilohms).  The second method is contactless. The wood acts as a dielectric between two electrodes in the back of the gauge, thus forming a capacitor. A radio frequency current (in the range of hundreds of kHz) flows through this capacitor, and its capacitance (which depends on moisture level) is measured. The advantage of a contactless meter is that it does not leave pin marks on the wood and can go to a lower moisture content readings than resistance meters. However, it is more difficult to accurately measure capacitance than resistivity. Consequently, contactless meters are are less accurate at the low end but just as accurate or even more accurate than resistance meters at the high end (but their price at the high end is really high).WHAT IS THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE CHEAP AND THE EXPENSIVE. This is the usual  big question - should I buy a $30 moisture meter or a $300 one? What do I gain from buying the most expensive one, and what do I lose if I go with the cheap? My research on this topic revealed the following factors.1. All pin-based gauges use the same principle: they measure voltage applied to the pins and the current flowing between the pins to calculate resistivity. In order to do this calculation accurately, you need to accurately measure current and voltage. Additionally, due to high resistance of dry wood, it is really hard to measure at or below 6%. In the cheapest meters, you get the cheapest components (esp. low end analog to digital converters) and a poor measurement accuracy. Consider this fact: even the best tools just barely deliver the accuracy required to meet the NWFA requirements. According to the statistical study of P.J.Wilson published in Forest Products Journal in 1999, high end pin meters have accuracy (standard deviation) of 1.5% in the units of moisture content (compared to 2% to 4% range recommended by NWFA). I expect a lot higher errors with the low end tools, and some of them can be useless because they are so inaccurate.2. Moisture content may vary from the surface into the depth of the plank. For instance, a board which was rained on may be wet on the surface but dry in the center. Ideally, one has to get pin penetration depth of 1/4 to 1/5 of the thickness of the wood piece to get an average reading.  Low-end gauges may not have pins suitable for deep penetration, whereas high end gauges have stronger pins and pin holders and oftentimes come with external pin holders (probes) connected via a cable. Additionally, they frequently come with isolated pins in which only the tip of the pin is conductive; this helps to eliminate the effect of near-surface conductivity in the wood. This is critical in wood manufacturing. Fortunately, the difference between shallow and deep penetration readings are usually very small with typical hardwood projects, where wood is fairly dry. This mini Ligno comes with two sets of pins for two different depths, 5 mm and 10 mm, but they do not appear super strong.3. Moisture readings depend on the temperature of the wood. You typically get 0.5% difference for each 10F (5 degrees C) deviation from the standard room temperature. The most high end meters get built-in temperature sensor and do corrections automatically. Middle range tools come with a correction table. Low end tools may use a standard calibration for a typical room temperature of 70F and no correction option at all. This mini Ligno does not have a built-in correction but it has a correction table in the manual.4. Wood species dependence. Usually, moisture meters use Pacific NW Douglas Fir as a calibration reference, and apply correction coefficients for each specific type of wood (this has to be entered manually, there is no way for the tool to determine what wood it is measuring). While domestic species are relatively similar, exotic hardwoods may deviate from Douglas Fir quite substantially. The good news is that at moisture level below 10% (which is the typical range recommended for installation), the differences between most domestic species is within 1-2% moisture content which is about the same as error level of the meter itself. Therefore, these differences can oftentimes be neglected for the range between 6% and 10%.The higher end is the tool, the more sophisticated is the correction procedure. This low end mini Lingos like this one group all 54 wood species into two groups, with the assumption that variation within each group is small. Higher end tools may group wood types into 5-6 groups. Finally, one can have individual calibration for each specific wood type (up to 20-40 species). It does not really cost manufacturers that much to incorporate higher level of calibration details into the tool (in some cases, it is just the cost of the paper on which the conversion table is printed), but it results in a substantial price premium for the tools with many types of wood species listed individually. Of course, in order to take advantage of all this accuracy, you might also want to have deep penetrating (isolated) tips and built-in temperature correction and perhaps higher level electronic circuitry, and it all comes together as a unit in the $300+ price range. This advantage of high end models comes at a price of complexity which most people might not like: just imagine, you face a task of measuring moisture of walnut. OK, with an advanced tool, you may have a choice of African, American, European, New Guinea, and Queensland Walnut (go figure which one you got). Then, you need to measure at several different depths... Make sure temperature correction is done... Then, average multiple readings... Will an average user do this all? I suppose this is why not everyone needs (or will properly use) the most accurate tool.4. Ability to store and average readings. It is generally recommended to take multiple readings across different boxes of hardwood or different subfloor locations and average them. Higher end tools can do it for you. Not a big factor for DYI, but might be a nice thing to have for a pro.SUMMING IT UP: It appears that this model of Mini-Ligno falls into the low-mid range of moisture meters. It has adequate electronics to measure resistivity with acceptable accuracy for successful woodwork and hardwood flooring. It has a very basic correction for wood species (just two groups). It does not have a built-in temperature correction, but it comes with a correction table in the manual.  It does come with two sets of pins, but it requires some work to exchange them. My guess is that one can probably expect errors up to 2-4% of absolute moisture content (meaning you can likely may get a reading of 11% for the wood with moisture content of 8%). This gets one in a ballpark of marginally acceptable accuracy for determination if moisture content of the wood is in the NWFA range, and works reasonably well to check how well the moisture content of the hardwood and subfloor is matched.THE BOTTOM LINE: This is probably the cheapest mid-range gauge which you can buy to use as a reasonably accurate measurement tool for working with wood. Lignomat is considered a brand name in the world of moisture meters and has been in business since 1975. Mini-Ligno line is their pocket-size lower end line of meters, and this is one of the lowest end tools in the mini Ligno series. It appears to be just above the low-end boundary which separates tools from useless toys with pins, glowing numbers, and buttons. It is not quite as sophisticated, accurate, and robust to the daily abuse as higher end ($200 - $500) models from Delmhorst or Wagner, but it is about accurate enough for most common wood species for in-home hardwood installations and woodworking.  Very easy to use (just one button to press).  Very easy to carry around due to its small size.  Not a big financial loss if you break it or lose it. Relatively good price to value ratio for DYI people (although I am still puzzled what is in there that warrants the $100 price). You still get only (on a relative scale of moisture meters) as much as you paid for (and the readings can certainly be off by a couple percent or more for less standard wood species), but you might not even need anything more than this for the standard task of determining if the hardwood and subfloor are ready for installation. I've seen professionals using them, and they are certainly good enough for DYI folks.Higher end mini Ligno models with the letter C have a connector for external probe. For extra $10 or so, one can get an S/D model which can also measure moisture level in drywall (which might be useful for home inspectors inspecting flooded buildings).Almost twice more expensive DX model gets a lot more accurate with the built-in correction for 65 individual wood species grouped into 20 groups (and - I am guessing here - might also have more precise electronic components). This will get you an improvement by 1% or 2% in accuracy for dry wood and even more for wet wood.Wood groups listed in the manual of E/D and S/D include (there is no Group 1, just 2 and 3):Group 2: Abachi, Afrormosia, Bamboo, Beech, Cedar, Cumary, Cypress, Dogwood, Gonzales Alves, Ikoro, Jatoba, Koa, Locust, Oak, Poplar, Ramin, Rosewood, Teak, Wenge, Zebra Wood, Hardboard, OSB, waferboard.Group 3: Alder, Ash, Aspen, Balsa, Basswood, Birch, Cherry, Cottonwood, Cypress, Elm, Douglas Fir, Gum, Hemlock, Hickory, Kempas, Larch, Lauan, Mahogany, Maple, Meranti, Merbau, Myrtlewood, European Oak, Pine, Redwood, Spruce, Teak, Tigerwood, Walnut, and particleboard.
summary: Gauge at the low end of high-end tools

reviewText: I purchased these knobs on Amazon for a fraction of the price I would have paid if I'd bought them at Home Depot, Target, or some of the other amazon sellers.  The base on these knobs is slender as shown in the picture.  Initially I wanted something a little bit thicker, but they were triple the price so I went with these. Having looked at various reviews of other manufacturers, and having gotten a feel for different models (...), I finally settled into the Freud JS 102. I am glad I did.(...)The Freud is an all-metal design, except the handle shroud. It is well built, and substantially made. Its price tag belies its engineering and performance. It's 5 amp motor didn't even slow down during cutting. We are not chain sawing oak; we are only cutting a tiny slit on the side of wood. The fence detents of 0 and 45 degrees are accurate. More importantly it does not slip when cutting a biscuit. Dust collection appears to be one of the best. Even with the collection bag off of the unit, the shavings exited readily out of the chute, off to the side, and away from the operator.The only drawback is that in order to adjust the height of the cut, you must loosen the locking nut, and manually move the fence up or down. With this method it is possible to jump to a spot, which may be more or less than is needed. A micro fine adjusting knob would be nice. Some of the more expensive units have that feature. Freud chose to use a precisely fitting (no play) front "sled" with linear measurements inscribed on its face, and a locking lever that is very exact.On the other hand, the depth of cut is easily adjustable, and like the rest of the unit, very precise.If your the kind of person who coddles to the very best, and will be using it for your own projects, no matter how many you undertake, and are not dependent on biscuit cutting for a living, then this unit is for you. The only reservation is the height adjustment. Don't misunderstand me. You can get an exact height adjustment with this unit. A perfect setting as a matter of fact. You may spend an extra 20 seconds getting it there. If you cut a 100 different biscuits a day, that 20 seconds could add up.I am new to this machine and am convinced that with a little practice, I will be able to precisely adjust the height first time, by the way that I hold it, and visually measuring the difference using the measuring ruler on the fence face.All in all I give it 5 stars because of the quality of the tool, and the surprisingly low price. It appears to be a tool that will give you years and years of dependable use. Freud router bits are among the very best, and I believe this tool is worthy of the Freud name.
summary: At this price, the quality of this unit is nuts.

reviewText: HOLY COW THIS LIGHT ROCKS!  I did a lot of shopping for tactical flashlights that could also be mounted to firearms and this one was a pick for quality and value and I AM AMAZED!  I have multiple tactical flashlights and if you want a bright, shock-proof, easy one-click push button, dual beam (spotlight and flood light combined in one beam) appearance for around $50 then LOOK NO FURTHER!  This is it!  Coupled with the CR123A battery multi-pack from Streamlight and you're good to go!  Works beautifully on any 1" ring light mount, not too big for an AR carbine and withstands recoil.  It's rated at 150 lumens but it beats my 220 lumen lights hands down.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

This review is for the LED Reveal version.I've been using GE Reveal light bulbs for several years, replacing almost every light bulb in the house years ago when I first found them.  I've had six incandescent Reveal flood lights in my kitchen for years, and replaced one of them with a CFL Reveal flood light last year.  After getting this bulb, I swapped out another incandescent bulb with this one.For starters, the incandescents, CFL, and this LED provide the same type of light.  With one CFL, one LED, and four incandescents, I can't tell a gradient in colors across the kitchen.  So, to me, this bulb follows in line with the characteristics of the past Reveal bulbs.  Yes, you can tell a difference when you look at the bulbs because the incandescent versions have a colored filter on the glass while the CFL and LED versions are white glass, but the light cast from them is nearly identical.The LED version takes a split second to turn on, so slower than incandescent but almost irrelevantly so, but it's at full brightness once it turns on.  The CFL version, on the other hand, takes a few seconds to reach full brightness.  I was really surprised by how bright this LED is.  I'd heard that LEDs were dimmer, but this one is very bright.  So, performance-wise, the LED is really nice.Cost-wise, that's where the LED still suffers.  The incandescent bulbs were about $7/each, the CFL that I bought was about $11-$12 dollars, and this bulb is currently over $40.  The CFL version is already pretty low in power and costs a lot less.  I understand that LEDs are supposed to last a very long time, but I just can't get past the cost of them.So, if the price doesn't put you off, these are great bulbs.  For me, though, I'm going to stick with the CFL Reveals until the cost comes down on the LED versions.
summary: LED Reveal has great performance, but they're still so pricey

reviewText: cheap enough to take a chance, i was so happy i bought three more. i should give a stress test to one to see how much abuse they can take. the great thing about this light is the option to use 14500 Batteries or AA. in a pinch, i can buy an AA battery anywhere. but with the rechargeable higher voltage 14500, the light is bright enough to be proud of. i did read many reviews and saw prices from 3 dollars to 6 dollars. i went for the expensive 6 dollar amazon prime because it got to me on time in two days, and i know amazon will handle any initial problems. the 3 dollar sellers are all from china with delivery times of over a month. there were many complains from those sellers. cheap enough to go with prime today. recommended

It's interesting to me that you won't find many rave reviews for any spring-driven staple gun. I suppose that's due to the limits of spring power, and the compromise necessary so the effort required to operate them is reasonable. If the spring were strong enough to compete with a pneumatic stapler, the trigger would likely be too hard to pull repeatedly.So, spring staplers are usually limited to light duty, but you can't beat their convenience. No hoses, plugs, batteries. You just grab it, put in the staples, and start shooting.This one is a winner. It's compact, very light, loads easily, and the ergonomic design isn't just for show. You can push with your body weight to shoot the staple, so if your grip strength is limited, it's a real advantage.I tried it on a piece of pine and two types of plywood. It shot 5/16" JT21 staples all the way in flush most every time on the pine, and about 80% of the time with the plywood. A tap with a small hammer would drive them the rest of the way in easily.This is a great staple gun for crafting or for light upholstery. I don't think it's heavy duty enough to stand up to the demands of construction use (installing insulation or such). But for what it is, it's a nice design, and very convenient.
summary: Light duty, but very nice design

I have been a long and loyal Makita patron. I purchased this kit so that I wouldn't have the kind of problems found in other tools, paying a premium for a Makita product. After light residential use one of the batteries failed. Then I read the fine print that, while the tools are warrantied for 3 years, the batteries are good for only a year. I checked the Makita website. They've removed the option to even send them an email. I called them and was told to pound sand. I looked at the review for the batteries, BL1830, and see that there is a known design flaw (?) causing these batteries to fail prematurely. It's too bad that Makita has chose to start making throwaway tools, but this battery failure and Makita's complete and total unwillingness to acknowledge let alone fix the problem puts them in their tools in the same class as Ryobi or B&D.; The tools themselves were fine until they became paper weights. Look for a company with a better battery warranty or that will actually fix a problem.UPDATE: The second battery went tango uniform yesterday. Makita still won't stand behind their defective product.

This is my 4th Dremel 4000 which I use for the 3rd stage of carving wood sculptures. I gave it a 5 rating even though I beat the hell out of them (and I am being kind with those statements) and burn them up usually from armature failure. I hang the motor from a clamp on the bench and then use the flexible shaft relentlessly. The flexible shaft was a Dremel extra and has held up under 3 failures of the 4000. With larger 1.5" diameter sanding wheels the 4000 will run pretty hot. I also use it for engraving into soft stone with diamond bits under a 5" magnifying glass. Normal people will probably not have a problem using this unit. My units get so hot you can't touch them because of butt kicking usage.JJK

This head lamp is much more effective than a regular flashlight. The fact it takes AA's is great because I use high quality rechargeable batteries to save money. This lamp's features make it worth the 60 USD it will most likely cost you. Will alert you when it's about to die and there is a light on the battery pack to tell you how full the batteries are at that time. Comes with 4 different programs as well that give you features like power save mode, defensive mode and a mode that makes the lamp last even longer by dimming the light down as the batteries get lower on power. Very handy and highly recommended to anyone who works on cars, goes out into the wild, works with small spaces that light cannot get into or you just like to hike during the night time. I would also recommend that as a defensive light as well because it works much better than a light on the end of your pistol or rifle, in my opinion.

The Vibe folding lamp with built in speaker can be used as a lamp, speaker or both. To say I am impressed is an understatement. By touch, design, and appearance, it exudes quality. By function, it proves it. In fact I was so impressed I bought one for my brother and it quickly became a prized possession. What I like most is the sheer power of the beam and the optical quality of the focus. The intensity is stunning - in fact the low beam setting is necessary because the high beam can be too bright for some situations. The focusing design permits the light to illuminate with impressive uniformity, instead producing an uneven pattern of concentric rings like many incandescent focusing flashlights.Battery life has been fine for my needs and brightness is maintained during the period of use. Recharging is simple and relatively fast. Although many features have been programmed into the lamp, I find that high beam and low beam settings are the most useful. However, I must say that the strobe function is impressive because it could potentially blind and disorient a potentially threatening person (or animal).To illustrate the usefulness of a powerful beam, I was driving home from some distance away in the winter when the road was closed by the police due to weather. No alternative route was offered. So I called my brother and he used an online map to guide me home but I could never have seen the little street signs, house address numbers, etc. in the icy darkness of that storm without that light. It functioned just like a mounted spotlight.Although there are now less expensive imitations coming on the market, I elect to stick with the LED Lenser line because every one I own has proven to be a winner (I have four different models). Besides, the imitation products even feel inferior when compared with the LL brand. Editorial opinion: quality engineering, design and innovation should be rewarded - not imitation.

These two rubber seals along with their springs, is what stops the water from dripping from your Delta faucet. That is, providing the ball part of the valve is in good shape. Setting the depth on a router is always a problem because the hole in the router's base plate is too large to allow accurate measuring of the tool tip to the router base. The same is true when setting the depth of a dado cut. The Wixey depth gauge solves depth measuring problems. The span of the feet allows straddling the router's base plate hole or a table saw's throat plate opening so that the ruler's edge is directly over the bit or blade. The gauge's legs even have small magnets embedded in the feet so that the gauge will stand upright by itself in applications where the base is a ferrous metal. This feature, along with the thumbscrew lock on the gage allows hands-free for adjusting the cutting tool bit or blade. The digital readout is large enough to be clearly seen to avoid misreading. For slot measuring the Wixey gauge comes with a plastic needle that extends the measuring blade beyond the gauge's feet.Although there are no instructions included in the unit's packaging a free downloadable pdf instruction sheet is available on Wixey's web site. This is a great little tool - well worth it's $25 price.

May not see a dark animal in the yard.Compact, light and great for intended use.The other Dorcy light I purchased and reviewed, is a little longer, almost as light, and a great spotlight for 200 ft, plus.  3 times the cost though.
summary: Very light.  No central focus.  Not a mini spotlight.

reviewText: This tool takes the cake as far as being complete Junk. It is hard to even know where to begin. I guess I will begin with the case. It is a plastic case that is impossible to open. It will not slide open, it will not hinge open, it will not pop open. I am a careful and methodical person, so I really studied the case, and found there is simply no way to gracefully open it. You have to force it open. When you force it open, all the little bits jump out. Then of course, you do not know which bit is which, because they have been scattered all over your table and floor. If you are lucky enough to find them all after this, then you are faced with the task of sorting them and figuring out which one is which size. Good luck with that unless you have a good micron caliper.Well, I did get them sorted, and back in the case, and my next task was to actually use one of the smaller bits. What I found is that the handle/chuck tool was completely useless. It was so poorly machined, and the tolerances were so poor, it was simply impossible to actually clamp down on the bits.Frankly I am surprised that Amazon would offer such a useless tool.Avoid!!!

For the price, this is a decent set of mini pliers. I won't call them "precision" pliers since the tip tolerances are not precise enough to earn that description, but they are more than good enough for light use or craft/hobby work.The build quality is decent. I like that it has a coil spring in the hinge rather than a couple of pieces of spring steel since a coil spring lasts longer and has a more fluid motion. Hard to find that feature in low-priced sets such as this.The handles are comfortable to use with a decent non-slip coating. One of the pliers had a misaligned coil spring when I got it which made the action rather stiff. Once it was adjusted so the coil was seated properly it worked fine.  A bit of WD-40 on each of them was needed to improve the action and stop them from squeaking.They come in a clam shell that is really hard to open. Get the heavy-duty shears ready -- you have to spend some time to free the pliers from their packaging. They do NOT come with a case or holder.The best of the bunch is the Linesman pliers, with nicely machined jaws. The blunt end nippers are also pretty good with a decently sharp cutting blade. The needle nose ones are just OK, as are the diagonal cutters (I needed to sharpen them before they would work to my satisfaction). The bent nose pliers are the weakest in terms of build quality, with a notable gap at the end of the jaws.But, given the price, I'm satisfied. I would not recommend these at all for professional or work use, but for hobby work (such as RBA building) they are handy to have.
summary: Good for RBA work or other light usage
