reviewText: this is ideal for matching luggage items. eliminates the need for having to keep track of multiple keys for multiple locks.

Replacing an old plastic Water-Pik showerhead, this item delivers in spades. My variant in stainless finishDelta Faucet  58471-SS-PK Universal Showering Components, Round Traditional 4 Function In2ition Hand Shower/Shower Head Combo, Stainlesshas a metal shell, plastic inerds, a stainless flexible hose and substantial stainless screw on fittings. There is a three position diverter at the juncture where the wand hose attaches to the main body; 1) halo, 2) halo and wand head 3) wand head only. The wand head has a push button on the wand handle which allows me to select 1) hard pulse from the center of the wand, 2 ) soft pulse from the center and spray from the wands ring around the center, 3) slow drible from both the center and the ring on the wand, (not sure whether this is defective yet or what. I'll update later. UPDATE: all I can figure is for you to use this setting to turn off the wand rather than to change the diverter).The thing that sets this shower head apart is when the diverter is set to head(halo) and wand, and the wand is set to both spray and soft pulse....you feel like you're in a hard rain....you are engulfed in water....Fantastic. And the wand head rests magnetically and snaps into the center of the larger stationary ring. This provides a frim attachment of the wand to the head(halo) but will take me a little getting used to. The ONLY thing the old Water-Pik had going for it was the ease with which you returned the wand to its' attachment point.My wife suggested this type of 'large ringed showerhead' when she used one in a hotel on a trip we took together. I don't remember that showerhead but this one is wonderful and she's elated, (we're older...it doesn't take much :) )**UPDATE** 19 June 2013: We've had it about 6 months now and have had no problems with this shower head. The stainless shell cleans up nicely with Scrubbing Bubbles and a soft non-abrasive sponge.
summary: My best shower head yet...at a price.

reviewText: I purchased this router set to do inlay work and use on the dovetail machine.  I wanted to keep my bosch under the table so I did not have to pull it out all the time (by the way the bosch is a nice machine too!).The Pros1.) The bases on all three are narrow enough to hold brass bushings to follow templates and it was a snap to start the dovetailing like I wanted.  It does have soft start like the bosch.2.) The D handle is nice too I use that the most.  I have had some trouble with the bit coming lose on the 1/4" shank but only because I did not tighten it good from the excitement of having a new tool (no harm done).3.)It does have variable speed which I love to control on various hardwoods.4.)The other feature I like are the cord connectors which have their own plugs and are easy to connect. The ends of the cord twist and latch so you know they're in place.5.)The plunge base has a vaccum port on one of the shafts that I have yet to use.6.)The dial on the router bases are smooth and raises and lowers the motor with precision and locks tight.The cons:1. When routing some stock you can really see the coils and bushings wind up the eletricity through the top vents which is normal but can be distracting, I'll get use to it2.I like the one wrench bit removal with the push pin to hold the collet in place, but it takes some practice. (No more loose bits!)Overall the machine is excellent and I am happy with the purchase and performance.  The cons are very minor.  I would have to choose this machine over the bosch if it were my only router because of how veritile it is (dovetail & inlay bushing bases, three bases,  vaccum attachment, and variable speed) but what serious woodworker can only get away with one router?  Oh yeah, and I did get the free bits......nice too.
summary: nice features, ease of use, ready for inlay, and dovetails..

reviewText: I have other items from the Leviton Renu line and I simply really like them. The removable faceplate is a nice addition that also looks contemporary when it is installed. The plug itself inspires confidence with the tamper resistance and the GFCI. I liked it so much that after I installed the first one in the livingroom, I put two more in the kids room.
summary: Nice, I like the Renu line a lot.

reviewText: It is pretty bright. The pictures aren't misleading. However, the remote...yes, it turns it on and off. But when its on, I use the remote to turn it off, as soon as there is movement it comes back on. I guess thats what its supposed to do. But its almost as if before I put my arm down from pointing the remote, its back on.  No biggie really.
Someone is color blind or they thought they were making a children's tool set. which goes along with the quality.  These work, but they're about as cheap as you can manufacture such an item.
This is a very good bulb!  It is very bright with a small start-up time.  It looks well made and will fit a standard motion activated fixture.Should last a good while.
summary: GE 26 Watt (90 watt equivalent) Energy Smart Outdoor Floodlight PAR 38

reviewText: These wire wheels looked like a deal when I bought them, but they are not very good quality.  They shed wire like mad, and are only good for one or two uses before they are bald. Shop for another type.

I bought two of these. They are nice little lights, using only one AA battery. I'd say they're pretty bright for the size and for only using one AA. Build quality is pretty good, definitely can't complain for the price. The focus zoom is handy. You won't get 300 lumens with regular AA alkaline batteries though. Overall 4 stars.
This stuff will glue anything.  Perfect for around the house home improvement projects.  I highly recommend this product for all your DIY projects.

Amazing soldering station at an incredibly low price! Bought 2 of these stations and am planning on buying more! Quick heating and good temperature recovery when not working with excessively large joints.

As a former painting and home remodeling contractor, I tend to notice the "problems" that this product solves. I have observed that most people do not notice mismatched fixtures and color details in their homes, but most people notice when things look perfect, though they might not be able to say why. This is one of those products that home decorators (and perfectionist home owners) will appreciate. The ability to change the colors of switches and outlets to match or complement the color of the wall, or even accentuate the furniture. With twenty colors to choose from, and a matte finish to boot, we can finally say goodbye to the gauche effect of the ubiquitous shiny white and "ivory" plastic wall fixtures contractors tend to favor. In addition, these switches and outlets are amazingly easy to install and change. The only drawback for most home owners is that the unit cost is high compared to conventional fixtures. However, if you own a home to which you would like to add subtle improvements and value, this might be a wise investment.The only real downside to this product is that incandescent light will be phased out over the coming years in favor of compact fluorescent lighting. And I have not yet heard of a viable dimmer for CFL.
summary: Classy product for the aesthetic perfectionist

reviewText: I found the new blade guide is a great feature - the light is bright enough to see even in daylight.  The LED light cast a shadow of the blade on the wood that lines up very well with the actual cut that will be made.Only complaint would be the lack of slow start.  Saw does jump when you pull the trigger.  Not a concern as long as you're aware and ready for it.  Did not deduct any stars for this issue.Update:After using the saw for a few months now; the dust collection is just as good as advertized.  I needed to cut inside the house and put two shop vacs on it.  One on the discharge port (as is normal) and the other beside the blade to catch the side discharges.  Result was almost no dust in the air.  Still had a bit of dust dropping straight down to the floor which was a simple cleanup.  Very happy with it.Also had my very first experience with a defective blade.  The blades shadow was much more narrow than the actual cut.  Changed the blade out and the laser guide is now perfect.  Found that my first blade had some bent teeth right out of the box - this caused the cut to be much more wide than the shadow of the blade.  I thought it was a flaw of the saw... which it was not.Bottom line... even more happy after using it for a while.  Great saw.Anyway the laser guide is perfect and on the money.  You can count on a perfect cut if you line it up.

I like flashlights, and for the price, I was skeptical that I'd get anywhere close to 300 lumens from a $5 light. I tried using a single AA battery and it was pretty bright - I'm guessing around 100 lumens based on a comparison with a Fenix light.The build quality feels good - it feels well machined and not exactly like the $5 flashlights I'm used to seeing at brick and mortar stores. For the price, you can afford to buy a few of these and keep them all over and not feel bad if one gets lost or stolen.
summary: The price is right for a light that's bright (to use at night?)

reviewText: just ordered this as a replacement for the Greenlight power failure light that failed after 5 months.  Like the design, very slim and the option os using as a lantern or flashlight is great.  Now if it's still working in 12 months......

I have to admit, I'm a big DeWalt fan.  Partly because their products have never failed me and partly because they make products like this.  For the first time ever I am able to use a fence on a circular saw/worm drive that actually works!  If you have a saw that this will work with and rip boards then you will not be sorry.You do have to be careful with it because the rails holding it could bend easily.  IE - don't drop it, etc.Buy it...you won't be sorry you did.

I received this 12-inch double bevel sliding compound miter saw from Amazon Vine for review. Here's my take on it.The Dewalt 12" Sliding Compound Miter Saw (DWS780), has been designed to be precise and accurate enough for fine woodworking, yet durable enough for framing and deck building. It's ideal for a variety of end users including cabinetmakers, trim carpenters, framers, installers and many other professional contractors who require a product that delivers the accuracy, capacity, durability, portability and ease-of-use that this saw offers. This is the description provided, but what follows is my review based on actual use and performance.The Dewalt DWS780 replaces a Ryobi 10-inch compound miter saw that I had used for 3 years and it is without a doubt the best saw I have ever owned. The power, smoothness, preciseness and versatility make this saw a winner. In addition to being comfortable to use, it is very quiet. After owning this Dewalt, I wish that I had upgraded to a 12-inch saw a long time ago. It is great being able to cut large posts without having to flip them over to finish the cut on the other side of the work. The other really outstanding feature of this saw is the sliding action which enables the user to cut wide, flat boards in a single, fluid motion. Without the sliding action, the user must flip over the work and attempt to line up the saw to finish the cut. Adjustments are easy and smooth, and the preset angles are precise. In short, the Dewalt DWS780 is a topnotch saw for professionals and homeowners alike.Useful Specifications:1 - An XPS LED light and cut alignment system that casts a laser-like shadow on the work surface showing users where the blade will come in contact with the material. Unlike lasers, the XPS LED does not require calibration.2 - The dual bevel system allows the ability to bevel right and left from 0 to 40 degrees with positive stops at 0, 22.5, 33.9, 45 and 49 degrees in both directions.3 - Miters 60 degrees to the right and 50 degrees to the left and features an adjustable stainless steel miter detent plate with 10 positive stops.4 -  A cam lock miter button allows users to lock angles between detents for jobsite versatility5 - 15 AMP motor delivers 3800 RPM for extended power and durability.6 - Industry-leading variety of cut capacities include  6-3/4 inch vertical, 7-1/2 inch nested crown, 13-7/8 inch horizontal and exclusive back fence design that cuts up to a 2x16 dimensional lumber at 90 degrees  and 2x12 at 45 degrees. The unit also includes a rail lock latch for holding the head away from the fence.7 - Highly efficient dust collection system captures over 75-percent of dust generated.
summary: Top-notch Saw for Professionals and Homeowners Alike

reviewText: SCREWDRIVER:I've been assembling furniture from Ikea and Staples for the last four weekends, and this little baby has tripled my productivity (compared to the manual screwdriver i had to use the first weekend).DRILL:The needle-like drill bit that's included is fine for hanging pictures and curtains (i used it for both), but this guy was underpowered and undersized when it came to mounting tall furniture to the wall (i'm toddlerproofing and quakeproofing the home).I'd highly recommend it for light-duty stuff, but if you expect to do anything vaguely manly, get Black & Decker's 12-volt drill. I sorta wish I did.***UPDATE 8/19/2012***After five years of regular use, it died. I treated it roughly, and asked way too much of it, and it held in there for as long as it's little heart could, but in the end, I just abused it too much and it started ignoring button presses about half the time, as if a connection between the trigger and the motor had loosened.I gave it a respectful burial, and plan to buy its smaller cousin, who I will only use for easy jobs (now that I have a full-on heavy duty pro drill for the tough stuff).PD600 Pivot Plus, I salute you!

The biggest plus of this unit is that it is small and fits in tight spaces underneath cabinets. It only heats up 1/3 gallon at a time so it isn't wasting a lot of electricity trying to keep a large amount of hot water heated. It heats up water fast enough that if you just wait about a minute or so you'll have more hot water if you actually need more than what is provided.Like others have said, it does tend to spit out hot water at a certain temperature point and you have to be careful or it will spray and burn your hands. I have never had any issues with the faucet handle or the thermostat and heating element, but the tank is a different story. I think the longevity that most users experience of only a few years is due to the fact that it is a copper tank unlike more expensive units that have a stainless steel one. Also, if you have really hard water the mineral deposits will build up quickly in the tank and it will start to pop loudly when heating and will shorten the lifespan of the unit. I have a water softener which I'm sure helps. After about 6 or 7 years, mine started leaking very slowly from a small hole that developed in the tank. Luckily, because it is copper, I just disassembled the unit and soldered the hole shut easily. In the process, I broke up all the deposits that had built up inside and got most of that out as well. It is now running like new again. If it wasn't for the fact that it was easily repairable by someone who is a little handy, I would have given the unit 2 stars instead of 3.The bottom line is that it is a lower-end copper tank and the lifespan will never be that of a $200+ unit with a stainless tank. You have to consider that with what you are paying for the unit. This is one of the cheaper units you can find. You get what you pay for.
Reasonably good. Bright. Cheap. Good for working. Lights up the area. Have a hook and a magnet. Buy the pair. You could spend your money on worse things.

I'm a long-time fan of knee-high motion-activated lights so I can walk throughout my house at night without stumbling or having to grope for switches. The moon-shaped lights I have are pre-LED and went through batteries like a weepy movie goes through popcorn. I went to their alternate plug-in capability. That limits placement. Also they're for interior use only, larger than I'd prefer and, anyway, no longer available (duh). And a room previously night-lighted by a vintage bar-clock needed illumination when the weird fluorescent lights in the clock expired. And outside rather than keep dusk-to-dawn rope light outlining exterior walkways I'd try the motion methods for the exterior as well. Let the search begin. I tried lights that were about palm-sized, square, that bristled with LEDs like a mutant creature from Edison's studio. I would have tolerated their nervousness -- on before serious darkness, off at uncertain intervals --  but they were battery abusers. Costly.  Then I read the report by the impassioned seeker of The Right Light (see above somewhere) and bought several on her say-so.They arrived in short order and were nicely packaged, well-designed, well-made and simple enough that the instructions were not required though welcome. And thorough, even suggesting how to use the back cover as a template if you chose to use the included screws to mount the light. All in all a much more complete product than many off-shore items in my experience. The individual light is  more or less square and not much larger than the three C cells you'll need (not included) to make it work. An indentation on the face provides a lip to aim the light downward and keep it out of your eyes if you use these for stairs.Use a coin to remove the back (inside you'll find the mounting screws and a band-aid-sized swatch of two-sided mounting tape.) Before you hasten to pop in the batteries you have two decisions to make - how long do you want the light to stay on? Find the lever to select either 20 seconds or 60 seconds in the belly of the light, a place that would be hidden if you put the batteries in first. Another switch there will select to have a soft glow from the light all the time (in darkness) or only the brighter light when triggered by motion. I chose one of each in the room where the clock had once been my light to see which I liked best. Soft glow it is...The exterior light I put just outside the sliding glass door where I go from the house interior to a patio. I screwed the light into a wooden wall - not all that easy actually because the provided screws are skinny little imps and the screwdriver that fit was so small it was hard to turn. Ok find the drill and make some pilot holes -- Piece-a cake...  Couldn't wait until darkness climbed out of the trees. Slide open the  door and instantly a square yard of light welcomed my foot. Like a knight throws his cloak over muddy water. I placed a now queenly sneaker on it and smiled. I feared the light might be that too-cool LED blue but it was a neutral just-warm light.The reason I deducted one star: the two-sided mounting tape, though as strong as that stuff usually is, could hold the three-battery weight for maybe 15 or 20 minutes. A where-where search turned up an out-of-the-way perch on the desk for each of the two lights I used here. Designed to stand on end like a travel alarm clock the lights were kept in place with the stickum tape, at last a task it was up to. The desk height, by the way, proved to be a bonus. The entire floor is washed with light as I walk by. The motion detector is very quick to catch an  approach and covers I'd say a full 180 degrees.I can tell you that the lights stay on quite accurately to the selected time and only if it is dark enough to need them. And that the brightness and color suit me fine. What I cannot tell you is how much choosing the all-night glow shortens battery life (but I love that glow)or how long the batteries will last. So far the outside light has already outlasted the square one that bristled with LEDs. All is well in the motion light world. Just don't plan on the sticky stuff to do more than auxiliary work.

This combo kit is an excellent choice for DIYers. The compressor fills up very quickly (~30 seconds at start-up for me), so draining after each use is not a hassle. The finishing and brad nailers have both been reliable for me so far. Through a couple thousand finishing nails, I've had no jams and the only misfires were due to user error. I haven't used the stapler, yet.I was also able to use the compressor with a rented flooring stapler without trouble. I was not moving particularly quickly, but 300 sf in 8 hours went smoothly. As with the included nailers, the only misfires were due to errors on my part. The compressor motor was not running constantly either, so I didn't have to wear ear protection the whole day.While I have nothing bad to say about the kit, don't interpret my review to mean that you should expect 30-gallon, 200 PSI performance from this 6-gallon, 150 PSI machine. Basically, this combo kit is perfect for my home usage, none of which challenges the specifications of the compressor or nailers. However, I could see where a higher work rate or more challenging application would yield a less satisfying experience. Professionals planning to run multiple hoses from a single compressor might want to consider a set-up with a larger, more powerful compressor. Folks looking to use air tools for mechanical applications would likely be more satisfied with a more industrial compressor as well.Update (8/29/2013):Since posting my initial review, I've been running the compressor pretty regularly with a Primatech P240 flooring nailer, as well as a small paint sprayer. The higher rate flooring nailer runs beautifully off the compressor. The paint sprayer works alright, but the compressor motor runs frequently enough that I started wear hearing protection while using it. No surprise there; for me, the convenience of the small, easily portable compressor tank still outweighs the inconvenience of remembering to put on some noise-cancelling headphones before using my sprayer.
summary: Excellent, easy to use compressor/nailer combo kit

reviewText: This is such a nice saw!  It cuts so well and it is very accurate so easy to use. very well made and light enough to handle.  i got the stand later which made a nice addition. it is not for cutting plywood but mode for trim work.

This is a small task light that looks great and is clever in its design.  It uses a 2" X 3 1/2" diffusion lens to provide an even LED light source.  This diffusion lens is very slightly recessed to prevent glare from the sides.  It is fully adjustable through six levels of brightness.  The small round touch circle provides the on and off control.  This same control switch displays small blue dots to indicate the current selected brightness level.  The switch holds the last selected level between on/off cycles.  For practical purposes the lamp may be raised about 13" above your work surface while still aimed down.  The adjustable gooseneck arm is rubberized.The base is heavy and has a rubber edge and bottom that keeps it in place.  I currently use it on a low setting just above my keyboard so I can see my keys in a darkened room.  At its brightest setting it is more than enough for detail work.  The lamp comes with a 6' power cord and AC/DC transformer that supplies 24 volts at 25 amps from a 110-240volt 50-60Hz source.  The transformer is 1.5" x 2.25" (W X H) and exits your plug at a 90 degree down angle and will protrude 1.25" when flush in a socket.I purchased the red OxyLED.  This red is a very classy deep dark red and just happens to match my Logitech mouse.  You have to understand that, in my messy office, having two things that seem to match classes up the place.
summary: Form and Function in a Quality Product

reviewText: Sarah Peyton Outdoor Solar LED Address Plaque Looks good butit only lasted a year . Thru it away and bought some nice house Numbers .
summary: Sarah Peyton Outdoor Solar LED Address Plaque

reviewText: This is a really great charger; it does some incredible things and charges NiMH and Nickel Cadmium  batteries to their absolute maximum. It is far better than the standard Enloop charger that comes with packs of Enloop batteries.But, all is not paradise in Eden. This has to be the absolute most complicated charger I have ever used in my life. Never lose the instructions, it is virtually impossible to use beyond standard charging without those instructions. The pain in the rear is things like, insert the batteries, within 8 seconds of inserting the batteries press this button or that button to make this change. If you wait longer than 8 seconds, no more changes can be made.Bottom line - this is the most confusing piece of tech I've ever used, but dang it to heck, it charges batteries better than any charger I have ever used. Even with all the complexity, this is really well worth it. It charges batteries to absolutely their peak performance.

Saw both the Bosch and this saw in the store and compared them.  If the Bosch had this Dewalt's fence system, I probably would have bought it just to get the dado blade compatibility (even if I never used it).  But, it didn't and this saw is also really nice and I have never looked back.The fence is by far the best selling point.  It's so easy to adjust and has an easy to read ruler.  Put a wood floor in three rooms of my housing using this plus my miter saw.  Still holding up strong and cuts very cleanly, even with very hard hardwood (acacia a.k.a. asian walnut).

My son needed a pair of these type pliers.  I was tempted to get cheaper ones not USA made. Then I noticed that at his welding class, these are what his instructor supplied at each instructional station. Might as well get the good stuff.  The ones at school look like they survive hard use very well. They'll be a Christmas gift so we can't speak to his use of these just yet but I have a lot of confidence they'll do the job.

I ordered this item for a closet for a child who can now reach the pull string to turn the light on.  I am always concerned with the light being left on, and perhaps even items from the closet touching the light, so when I saw this, I jumped at it.  I just installed it today, and the installation was a snap.  Of course, you need to have a junction box to connect the light to, so this item will only work for you if you are replacing a luminary device, but it's an easy 3 minute swap out.  ** For the love of god, remember to turn off the curcuit breaker to the light before you do anything. **  110 volts can, and has, killed.The biggest plus of this light is that it is very bright immediately when turned on.  Despite being a CFL, it is as bright as a 40W - 60W incandescent bulb immediately upon pulling the cord.  Oh, that reminds me, if you have a switched outlet to the light, there a different model number for that one.  This light is operated by the pull string.Two Things yet to be determined:1) longevity of the device2) longevity of the bulbOnly time will tell, but I am a fan of Leviton and am confident this light will be around for awhile to come.

This was promoted to me by a wood carving instructor. After using it to control speed on my mastercraft rotary carver you can control burnout on the burrs by not having them rotate too fast. I have 3 handpieces and so can do a quick change and adjust the speed very easily at the same time. It holds the speed accurately. I would recommend this product for quality. Comes with a plastic dust cover to remain on when in use which is important for longetivity I think. I would recommend this over the foot pedal that came with carver as you cannot retain an accurate constant speed with a foot pedal.

These extentions make all the difference for smooth operation.  Even to the extent that they really should be included with the product.  My only critque is that it the the side of the planer where the table mounts to that has the vacuum port stops the table from folding up and staying up by about 1/2 and inch.  I crafted some black velcro on the planer and a small aluminum hook that grabs the table and hooks to the velcro.
summary: I recommend this add on product

reviewText: Purchased a new planer and wanted the in and out feed tables. Amazon had the best price and with free shipping and no tax was a great deal. These tables are made of steel and are very sturdy they will take all od the punishment i will give them.

This is a luxury tool that will most definitely crap out before my Starrett Protractor head and rule will, but a time saver worth the investment.Would have been 5 Stars if the tenths didn't vacillate.  Great tool for the odd angles.

Sturdy, high quality and looks EXACTLY like the picture so perhaps Southwest products read the other, older reviews from people who did not like the different version than the picture. I bought this for my college student son and he loves it. It fits perfectly on his dresser with his cologne and after shave and he no longer has to worry about being robbed.  Both he and I can sleep easy knowing that nobody knows our little secret.

The tables were easy to install, and they give a bit more surface to make sure the boards are flat and try to avoid snipe.My one complaint is that the outfeed table can not fold into the fully upright position with the vacuum port attached to the blower. There's only so much room back there, so I wouldn't call it a design flaw, but it's kind of frustrating.

I was very happy to find this cutting wheel and use it now in place of the original cut off wheels that came with my Dremel.  For a ten spot give or take, you have a wheel that cuts through nearly anything and allows for precision work when needed.I have cut through metal piping, sheered screw heads that were stripped, and cut some locks open when we couldn't find the keys.  I have yet to be disappointed.  My Dremel and accessories such as the 545 Diamond Wheel are invaluable.
summary: Never buy another cut off wheel - this is all you need

reviewText: Very, very solid. If in a hurry, one can use just the nearest clamp instead of locking both down. Once I raised it a little bit and cleared the cast iron table, it slid like butter across the rails. I grab it in the center to slide it as if you use the end the fence can rack and bind a little.All saws, including table saws, should come with an option to lock both ends down like this excellent fence does. Thumbs waaaay up.

Used this to seal a persistent trunk leak that defied undercoating and fiberglass body filler. Has been working for a few months now. While the product is clear, whether because of my application or not the dried surface has an alligator finish with what looks like entrapped air that makes the sealant cloudy. Since mine is used in an out of the way spot it doesn't matter, but I don't think you can make this work as a visible finished surface coating.
summary: Rust-Oleum 265495 11-Ounce Leak Seal Flexible Rubber Sealant, Clear

reviewText: I wanted a small combination lock with user-settable combination that fits the Pelican 1450 and 1500 waterproof cases.  These locks do the job very nicely.  They appear to be well made and it is very easy to set the combination.  My only complaint about these locks was the packaging; it was quite difficult to extract the lock from the plastic bubble container.Recommended.  RJB.
summary: Good solid lock -- fits the Pelican 1450 and 1500

reviewText: I bought mine as a kit including a bottle of MAPP from a local builder's supply here.  But I thought I would comment.  First the TS8000 is certainly high intensity!  As others have posted one of the quarks of this thing are it's touchy flame control and lack of a true low mode.  I was sweating 1/2" copper pipe and found that in the middle zone it was heating the pipe and flux so quickly (under 2 seconds!) that I was burning it off and leaving these very pretty scorch marks on my pipes.  However after a little trial and error I discovered that you could back the flame off to just before it would blow out and be more of a "normal torch".  At that lowest setting (assuming I didn't bump the knob with the back of my hand) it heated the fittings very evenly and slow enough to where I could sweat them and wipe them clean for a reasonable looking finish.  I gave it four starts since it is a handheld blast furnace, but for larger pipes (most likely it's intended use) I assume it would work do beautifully for you!  I love the one handed lighting and operation.  Much safer than the old igniter torches I've used in the past.  I can't comment on gas consumption yet, but when I run out I'll update and tell you how many fittings I got out of the bottle.
summary: It does the job fast!  Maybe a little too fast!

reviewText: This probably puts out 5x the heat of the most basic torch head. I was able to heat the end of a 1/2" steel rod to orange to hammer out using this--the basic one was unable to do so. This also would have made soldering large lengths of 1-1/2" copper pipe much easier... Turns on at the push of a button and locks in with another. The range of flame controls is great--you can dial it down to a small blue flame or up to a flame that sounds like a jet engine.

This product works OK, though it is not very flexible.  I would say it is good for short runs from dust collection outlets to stationary tools.  I think next time I'll pay a little more.  The hose is worth the price I paid.

Don't waste your money on this machine. It is too light and it is not capable of cutting anything of any size, or if the wood is hard and dense. Even if you work on small projects, I would not advise this band saw, and finally, I will never again buy any other Jet machine.
summary: Jet JWBS-10OS 10 Inch Bandsaw with Stand

reviewText: I spent the last dozen years in industrial controls troubleshooting and repair. I thought.. how hard could this be? Monitor my house from vacation or winter home? Whoa!! So to be fair the industrial side costs don't compare. Spend several thousands for the control and software licenses. Here spend a lot less $$ well, I just spent 8 hours figuring out how to turn a light on and off at different times every day. And I'm not sure I can duplicate it! I could have done it in 3 minutes with the industrial equivalent, including creating the timers. I/O tags and getting the hardware clock tags pulled out.The network set up is fine for use at home, but to check in remotely you are required to have a free account with the manufacturer. Now someone else has their fingers in my home network. To use several(many?) features requires the same or another remote account. Funny... I have 5 cameras and 3 routers with dyndns and can see them all from anywhere in the world but I can't see my home automation controller.I'm going to fiddle with it for another few hours but my hopes aren't high.2013_07_15 I have finally set it ip to be returned.

The only criticism I have for this tool is that it is heavy.  It has more power than any other saws-all that I have used or owned.  Tool-less blade changes encourages you to use the right type of blade.  The swiveling cutting head makes it easier to get into tight places. It lived up to every claim in its advertisements.  I even use it to saw firewood,
worked perfectly with cordless drill.  you only need to keep an eye on the depth and you should have great results!
Dissappointed that I thought these were US made by KV. Wasn't stated in the advert. They work well and did the job. Would have given a 5 except for foreign origin.

While the description says it's aluminum, it's obvious that it's more plastic than anything, but apparently that doesn't matter. I've dropped this thing from the top of scissor lifts (I'll tell you why shortly) countless time, as had my co-worker who has the same level, and both are still fully intact, fully operational.Why 4 stars? The magnet. While in my field (sheet metal) I would really like it to have magnets on both side I can see how some people wouldn't, however, the magnet that they did put on it could have been a little more magnetically attractive. It's like the magnet rolls you get at arts and craft stores for making crappy fridge magnets. Hence the reason the level keeps falling off the duct those times when you're leveling the bottom over the side of the lift. And to make things worse (for me, don't know about other trades that don't work with metal as much) it's just strong enough to grab the little steel shaving, making it even harder for the already weak magnet to grab the metal (a different co-worker has one that'll fly outta your hand before you even get to the metal)

Its a small level, it tells you if small areas are level.  The blue is plenty visible and the magnetic bit is useful wherever you happen to be leveling metal (not often for me).  Fits handily into a tool belt and seems to be dead accurate.  Durable too.
Description should provide or state you need to buy the air connectors separately. Will have to do, prior to use. The coil is pretty strong and the real reach is more like 10 feet.
summary: Real reach is more like 10 feet.

reviewText: Got it to lock muh ladders! Not a high crime rate here, but ya never know! Anyway...4 digit code--can't change but is hard to forget. Long 'nuff to hook up 2 ladders so theft wouldn't be THAT easy! Suppose we'll see!  😉

Like all planes whether new or vintage the first thing you need to do is lap the sole and spend a few minutes sharpening the blade. I have a vintage no. 5 which I adore but I wanted a new one just for comparison. Once tuned up the plane works great just like a Stanley should. Although the tote and fore knob are plastic, its makes no difference when the plane is working right. It has good balance just like the vintage plane it's a good plane for planeing rough stock or smoothing it down. I did have to adjust the location of the frog right from the start but once all the adjustments were made and the sole and blade fine tuned it pairs up easily with my old No. 5. I expect to get quite a few good years from this one as well. It's obvious the plane came down a production line and it's also probable the next plane off the assembley line is a lemon. But for the most part there is still quality in the No 5. It's a good plane and I would recommend it to others looking for a good quality plane to get the job done. I wish I could say that about Stanley's block plane but that's another review.
Very bright flashlight. No complaints here. Cranking isn't too hard but I could see how people could get worn out after a minute or two of doing it.

I rate this half-a-star simply because it was a 'set' as advertised.  That is the only thing the manufacturer/distributor got right.  The push block and the stick can be made at home for cents.  The featherboard mounting system is a total failure.  There is no way you can lock the featherboard to the table slot and have it be a reliable, working accessory. I'm amazed this set is still offered for sale.  In my opinion, the loose and unreliable featherboard is quite possiblly an accident waiting to happen.  Not mine.  It is at the landfill.

Yes, this plane arrived with a lot of work to be done to get the most potential out of it.  It has grinding marks on the shoe, sides and blade that all have to be removed.  What do you want for $50?After a couple of hours with 60 grit paper and my flat granite block, I was ready for the blade sharpening and honing.  The blade actually took the sharpening very well.  It took me another hour to get the face lapped and a sharp edge on blade.Was the work worth it?  Absolutely YES!  The plane is cutting curly maple with very nice, thin curls!A very nice feature on this plane is the replacement of the standard single lever for adjusting the blade angle, with two (2) knurled knobs.  It did not take me long to start liking this plane over my others, just because the knobs allowed me to adjust the angle much quicker than using my planes with the single lever.  The knobs also control the depth of cut, which I find much easier to set, then messing with the single knob adjustment on my other Stanleys.  If you are new to planes, you might find these two (2) knobs easier than the standard single lever/knob combination.This plane is a great value, if you are willing to put the work into making it sharp!  If you don't know how to sharpen blades and tune-up planes, then this is NOT the plane for you.  You might want to invest in a good book on planes (like:The Handplane Book) before purchasing an in-expensive plane like this.There is nothing like the feeling of a well tuned plane on a nice piece of beautiful wood!
I am excited to get this.  I haven't tried it yet, so i'll update you if any problems.  Got it on deal of the day so the price was great.
This is a great kit, but Dewalt blades are not known for longevity.  Worth the price paid, but if I had a choice, I'd go with Lenux.

Still on the first blade and it cut through some cheap cabinet wood and 4-5 door jambs.  It seems to be doing fine.  The teeth on the blade are much larger than the universal blade by .3 mm (they don't really look comparable).

I have a bunch of things that charge off of USB.. iPad, iPhone, bluetooth headset, camera, GPS, etc.... but I don't charge them all at the same location so I find my self moving adapters around as I need them.  Also the family uses them.  In the end I can't always find a charger!With this device the charger is permanently left where it is installed.. and the cables do not tend to get lost or taken.It's also nice that it's higher powered so my iPad charges quickly, even while I charge some other device.
summary: What a great idea; No more searching for the charger!  Hi-power for faster charging & multiple devices

reviewText: Great little staple gun for the price, don't think you can beat it. For the price you think it wouldn't work that good but it does. Can punch a whole in wood and other softer items. Handle has a great feeling and designed well. Would recommend.

Wow!!! I bought the AccuSharp 001 recently and find that it really sharpens! Why should I be surprised? Well, a few years ago I bought a Chicago Cutlery MagnaSharp Mouse Knife Sharpener--it was highly rated back then. I never could get my knives sharp with the MagnaSharp--maybe a little sharper than they were.After being intimidated by the AccuSharp directions for a week, I did take it out of the package, looked at the picture and used it. However, it HAD looked like the directions were somewhat confusing for me to just take it out of the package and use.These directions WILL be useful, so I am saving them and recommend that any buyer do that--I'm keeping the sharpener in the package with a rubber band around it. I know the directions will be used someday. But I finally said, "I can't let these details keep me from sharpening my knives," and used it. Now I am sharpening every different knife as I use it. Yay!I lay my knife on the counter with the sharp side up. I let the point of the knife go over the counter a bit so I can use a long stroke of the AccuSharp. There is a different model for tools, too.I even had used a knife sharpener attached to an electric can opener, and it wasn't as good as the AccuSharp.
summary: Wow. Now my knives DO get sharp.

reviewText: This isn't a cabinet saw. Those that want to compare it to an industrial shop saw need to get serious.This saw is a work horse. I bought mine in Oct 2006. I use it often and it hasnt slowed down one bit.I recently bought a Beall Digital angle gauge. I checked the 90 deg and 45 deg settings on this saw. They were dead on. I was actually suprised it was so acurate.Use good quality blades and this saw will do almost anything you ask of it.For a worksite portable saw I am doubting it can be beat. I have mine setup in my woodshop as my only tablesaw. I dont have a pressing need to upgrade to a cabinet saw anytime soon. This saw is doing great as it is.Your reading the reviews and thinking about it... just get the saw. Especially if your space is limited. Folding up and putting this thing away is easy. Too many junk saws out there, this isn't one of them.

I ordered this for my daughter because she has a full plate and when she gets home, she is sometimes too tired to even get up and turn the light off and had gone to sleep with the lights on. With this she just have to clap and the lights are off.  She thanked me so much for giving this to her. Again another great product.
summary: Oh what a relief it is!!!

reviewText: Like most Americans I just hate buying anything made in China, but the facts are this set is as good as anything Irwin or Stanley makes and at one quarter the cost. These bits are produced on automated equipment that spits out thousands of them in an hour most likely on the same machines in both countries. There is no reason for the well known American companies to charge so much. I have personal knowledge that the workers at the American plants are working for less money and benefits than they were ten years ago. The companies executives are just trying to keep pace with the other millionaire businessmen who are choking our national economy with their greed. As I said these are good bits and worth the reasonable cost, the drill inserts are easily adjusted and are replaceable.
the bitts are strong enough to drill inside wooden surface, but some times the holding ring comes out of the drill, may be the screw is not strong enough to hold it..

First, i would like to thank dcrainmaker web site for providing the most excellent review of this watch and the forerunner series of watches.  Yes, please go to this website.I bought this watch to train  for races especially when I go running outside of the gym.  during these outdoor training, I have no idea what speed I am going at and the distance covered.  So it is pretty much a run in the park and only during the reaches do I get a sense of my progress: not sufficient.  So I was super excited whe this watch arrived overnight (bought it from HRM USA, highly recommend).  Set up was very easy and please know that you need to be in open space for the watch to pick up satellite signal to set the time.  Okay, the experience when I went on my run: hit the 'page/menu' button a minute before my run started to allow the satellite pick up my location and then hit the 'start/stop' button which will immediately record your training. Remember to hit the 'lap/reset' to save your race.  I really enjoyed the pace monitor as it really helped me to see my own performance that day.  I do a lot of training in the gym too, and i bought the pod to allow me record my runs: very easy to use, once you hit the 'page/menu' button, the watch will detect the foot pod and use the right set of two buttons to scroll up/ down to confirm thatnyou want to use the food pod.  Caution: the pod does not work with the elliptical machine!The software leaves it a lot ot be desired.  It does not work with the Mac as claimed and the instructions are nonexistence to help you.  The gamin website was aweful and the one video that was absent was for the 210!  However, patience wins once you get it working on the PC.  It provides more information that I need.I loved the new heart rate strap as it did not rub against my skin and did not cause skin burn that I have experienced with polar watches.  Beside the software, I love this new tool and it is a must for runners.  I loved the spec for the 405, but didn't like the bezel problems that a lot of people were complaining about.  This is a simple watch with enough material for runners to improve on their pace.
Use this glue to glue a board to the kitchen cabinet.  Works flawlessly.  Highly recommend.  Strong, right consistency, and easy to work with packaging.

I will be fairly harsh as I had high hopes for this knife as a gift for buddy.First off "z" means zytel (plastic handle)with plastic spacer for handle scales (on butt end)I was fairly disappointed in that, but granted my own fault.The pivot screw feels like aluminum and looks like zytel as well.Upon receiving knife there was some blade play, tighten pivot screw a bit and flip does not engage blade fully and cannot find a happy medium without some blade play. That is a big downer for me.Steel is soft and not stamped of type...strips of metal appeared on my diamond stone trying to clean up factory's poor grind. Poor edge out of the box.On a brighter note I do like the design and size. This is my first CRKT knife and kinda let down. A more expensive version with quality scales and hardware might be a better buy. I will use this as a work knife prying on door locks and such till it breaks. My daily carry for work is a leatherman wave & Skeletool and a ontario Rat-1 or a S&W; extreme ops. The S&W; extreme ops is a better value for 9$ IMO

Works for my 20 year old craftsman circular saw handed down to me by my Dad.Once NOTE: When setting the distance from the tool to the blade, measure to the edge of the teeth of the blade, not the body of the blade.  Otherwise you'll wind up with a cut that's 1/32" +/- shorter than you expect.Big deal?  In woodworking, every faction of an inch can make a huge difference.I couldn't have completed my project without this tool.

This is my favorite small flashlight. It is perfect for my pocket, shaving kit, backpack, flight carry-on bag or etc.This may sound odd, but as a flashlight "geek", I have been waiting for this LED light to come out ever since Maglite announced it. I have looked intently for a comparable pocket LED flashlight, and to be honest I have had no luck at an affordable price. This flashlight seems a great blend of features and price.I wanted a flashlight that had the following features, this light does them all well.1) LED (currently the brightest and longest lasting technology for a small size)2) Bright (the Maglite Solitaire LED is 37 lumens compared to 2 lumens for the conventional Maglite Solitaire incandescent bulb)3) Small size (takes up minimal room in pocket)4) Runs on a single AAA, for inexpensive and easy to find battery5) Twist on/off, this is so it is not turned on accidently in a pocket like a push button6) Rugged construction7) Has a lanyard hole, for keychain, etc.8) Easy to find, i.e. not a custom product or special factory run9) Fairly inexpensive. Some competing pocket lights fit the bill above, but came in at $35 to $60 or more! Yikes!This Maglite Solitaire LED AAA fit my wish list perfectly. There are many, many small lights out there. Some are excellent in different ways, but looking through my feature wish list, all that I looked at came up short in some way.One note: A company named Fenix makes an LED model E01 that was the best affordable runner up to this Maglite LED Solitaire. However, it is not nearly as bright at 10 lumens (compared to Maglite's 37 lumens).Regarding brightness, according to Maglite this light has a 37 lumen LED. That is more than twice as bright as a larger incandescent flashlight by Maglite. The commonly found 2 AA Maglite regular INCANDESCENT flashlight is 14 lumens according to Maglite.For size comparison, this light is the same size and weight of the "old" traditional Maglite Solitaire AAA light.Added pros of this Maglite LED Solitaire:1) It can be used in candle mode. That is, aim up and rest on tail cap to illuminate a room. While this light isn't going to give you reading light, it will allow you to see the furniture or etc.2) Made in the USA (according to the Maglite website).3) This light has a lens instead of just the bare LED like some other pocket flashlights I've seen.  This is nice for a pocket/bag as it protects the light from getting a lot of lint and obscuring the light.4) The light goes on when the head is twisted just shy of half way (maybe 45%).  This seems a nice balance between too little (could turn on in pocket accidentally) and too much (could prove tedious).Minor con:The light rolls easily when on a flat surface like a nightstand or table. But this is easily and cheaply fixed by attaching a key ring or similar clip to the lanyard hole. It doesn't even need keys on it, virtually any ring will do. A ring came in the Maglite package I got this in.UPDATE:I tested how long a "normal" off-the-shelf alkaline AAA battery would last in this flashlight.  After an hour it dimmed ever so slightly and the flashlight itself got very slightly warm, but both were hardly noticeable.  Then at 2:16 hours (aka 136 minutes), the light quit abruptly, and the flashlight did not give any more light.  These "new" LED flashlights regulate the power so you get the max light for the max time out of the battery, but then when it gets below a certain level, it can't give you any light at all.  Immediately after the light quit, I pulled the battery and it measured 0.9 volts (a new one is approx 1.6 volts).  So it will do well on diminished batteries (in a pinch), but very dead batteries will give you nothing; not even a slight glow.Bottom line, this is a great small flashlight. For slightly larger flashlights, see these other two I like below.  My reviews on both are also under the pseudonym "Spiced Rum":Maglite's XL50-MAGLITE XL50-S3016 LED Flashlight, BlackEnergizer High Intensity LED-Energizer High Intensity LED Flashlight with 2AA Battery.
Hoped this would work on the stove top, but it didn't work too good.  I've resisted using a metal blade, but had to do it.

Although I have some Wusthof knives, I do have a set of older knives (kitchen, pocket) that I'm not quite ready to get rid of yet that are in dire need of sharpening. I'm not a master knife sharpener by any means and it will take me at least a couple months to get it right... so instead I've looked around for a knife sharpener that I can use to be a quick fix on my junk knives. Seeing how this is much cheaper than other knife sharpeners, I decided to buy one from Amazon. The positive reviews definitely help!I'm giving this item a 4-star review because it does work, but there's no way that it can ever make your knife as sharp as it was from the original factory edge.What impressed me though is how it can take any knife, no matter how bad of a condition, and get it back to a decently sharp edge. I had a couple kitchen chef's knives (stamped, low quality) that were marred beyond belief like a butterknife and doing the paper slice test actually ends up bending the paper before any cut is made.The directions say 4-5 passes but I actually had to do about 9-10 passes on my knives before it would get back to some kind of sharpness.  Although it's not razor sharp, I have salvaged probably about 8 or 9 knives now with this thing.I'm not sure how long the blades last, but I do know that they are reversible. Other reviews say that after about 40 or so passes, you need to swap the blades. The replacement blades, also by AccuSharp and sold by Amazon are about $2 cheaper than the actual unit itself.I do like this unit, but I'm not sure if I trust it enough to use on my more expensive knives (like the Wusthofs). But for any other blade in the house, I do fully trust this product and can recommend it simply because it's so cheap and can salvage any blade to a useable degree.
summary: Decent Sharpener, Replaceable Blades - Cost Effective

reviewText: These are the best battery testers for most uses.

After reading an online review, I was excited about getting this. I have a Stanley Oddjob which I carry in shop apron and thought this might be an improvement. It is promising, with one major flaw. You must completely remove the brass knob to change positions. It is a royal pain. The point is convenience and convenience is the ability to use the functions interchangeably, flowing from on task to another. Doing that requires you to remove and reconfigure the tool between tasks. It is going back. I will just never use it. My combination square, although not a shop apron item, can easily perform a 90, 45 and depth gauge/scribe without reconfiguration. Kreg, go back to the drawing board.

reviewText: I did not buy this blade to cross cut plywood, nor did I ever plan on cross cutting plywood with a carbide tipped blade. - but I found myself cross cutting plywood with this blade all afternoon. The cuts have no tearout, and no rough edges. Normally, a blade like this is not very good for cross cuts, but this one is exceptional. I have several saws of varying sizes, and I am buying this blade for each of them. I am not easily impressed, but this blade has impressed the heck out of me.
summary: Best Blade I Have Ever Used

reviewText: awesome.....great gun... I use it on siding and trim... no need whatsoever for a more expensive "name" brand. The magazine is metal and ridgid... beats flimsy and plastic any day. The only peeve I had was that I had to cut/notch the case so that I wouldnt have to take the belt clip giggie off everytime I put it away for a few weeks.

First, I've found all LED lights that make outragous claims of average battery life of dozens to hundreds of hours is either misleading or totally wrong... no matter what brand or where you bought them from. They either go totally dark in much less than half the rated time, or have gone too dim to even read large print with the light pressed closely to the page. To even get close to half the rated life, skip the alkalines, you must use expensive lithium or the highest capacity NiMi rechargables available on the planet.So they all lie about or misrepresent your actual battery life. I'm sure some of them, if you put the most expensive batteries in the world in them, run the light almost to their rated battery life, if you take them into a fully darkend room, & hold the light to your face, strain your eyes, you will find the LEDs are still glowing very faintly... but that's not useful light.I haven't found AAAA rechargables or lithiums, but you won't need them.This is the only LED light I ever found that doesn't give you bull on battery life. It uses a single LED & 3 AAAA alkaline batteries that can be obtained cheap from many sources. Slightly longer than an oridinary pen, I take it everywhere, & is always with me at work. As an engineer, I've used it several times daily for over 6 months with the original batteries. I thought it might be getting a little dimmer so recently put fresh batteries in it. Although it got brighter, not significantly, so I put the old batteries back in. This light just won't die. Lot's brighter than any keychain light, it's as useful as most big lights. It fell 14' from a ladder onto solid concrete, into puddles, snow, & got paint & glue on it. Using harsh chemicals & scraping to get all the paint & glue off, it still looks & works like brand new. I don't know what they used to paint that light with, but there's not a scatch on it anywhere... no dents yet either. Solid & durable. Your best light will be the one that works when you need it to, & is close at hand. Best $14 I ever spent!Update: AAAA Batteries can be found right here at amazon. Just type AAAA or streamlight in the search box. The streamlight AAAA 6-pack runs $6-$7 & are really alkaline energizers. Also if you tear off the metal around a "copper top" alkaline 9 volt battery with a couple of pliers you'll find 6 aaaa batteries inside. But beware... the AAAAs inside the 9 volt battery have the polarity reversed! So you must put those in your light BACKWARDS. You should also stretch the light's spring out a little for a tight fit & better contact. This won't effect it if you go back to ordinary batteries, just make sure to get the polarity right.

You can't beat the value of this package. The key here is that you get everything you need to shoot nails right out of the box, including the nails! This is great for the hobbyist or start up because there's no guessing about fitting size, hose size, etc. - it's all included: Guns (w/ cases), compressor, fittings, hose, tool oil, 1000 nails for each gun and to top it off, a role of joint tape (nice touch). *Everything* is in the box.Arrival -The gentle hands of "brown" didn't do too bad a job on the box. I've seen the same box at my local home center in worse condition (for $50 more too). The box was sturdy and everything was well packed with no missing parts.Setup -Manual was very clear except for the fact that I've got a different regulator on mine than was pictured or explained. No biggie, and as mentioned above, everything is in the box. Just put it together and go. Well, don't go right away - be sure to follow the instructions for breaking in the tank and motor - very important! Run it for 15 mins with everything wide open.Use -I shot three rooms worth of crown with the finish nailer using 2 different sized nails with only a single misfire (which was entirely my fault, I was at a bad angle and laid on the trigger too long). I used both the Porter-Cable nails as well as Paslode's. The Paslodes work great and are slightly cheaper than the PC's at my local home center. The finish nailer itself feels lightweight, but surprisingly rugged. I got more tired moving the hose around than I did hefting the gun over my head. Very comfortable to use.I must admit that the brad nailer hasn't even left the case yet, but if it performs anything like the finish nailer I will be very pleased.The compressor is LOUD but I've never used a compressor that wasn't... What I like though is that it comes up to pressure quickly and recovers pressure during use just as fast. This means that if you're only running a single nailer from the compressor it will most likely be off more than running. It doesn't struggle to keep up with you at all.Conclusion -With nothing really negative to say about the product, the value of the total package, and the fact that everything is included in the box, this one is a clear buy.

I am a chef by trade. I work as a temporary Chef at various food establishments. I no longer bring my own knifes with me (unless it is a special occasion). With this knife sharpener i can put a pretty good edge to a knife to do my job. Dropping bolts and nuts while working on the vehicles is bad enough when they fall through and hit the floor.But, when they come to rest on an obscure bracket or manifold that can be seen but not reached, it's a pita.This tool is also great for retrieving them even when you can't see them.

reviewText: We have traditional incandescent night lights in the master bath and on the stairs. These small pools of light add safety and help preserve night vision as we walk around in the dark. As you can imagine, old fashion light bulbs burn out and have to be replaced. Also, these bulbs are fragile and if the filaments are jiggled when on, they often fail. Since we have big dogs who trot up and down the stairs, our night lights have suffered! OK, not a tragedy but annoying.I popped these lights in as soon as they arrived but had to wait until the evening to see how they work. To my surprise, they were bright, cool and effective - creating wonderful little splashes of light. Because they are made with LEDs, the power consumption is only 1 Watt - a small savings over incandescants. They also have an added benefit of being more rugged than a traditional bulb and - so they claim - will not burn out.Finally, the Energizer brand is known for making quality products. That makes me comfortable recommending this product after only one night.Need a night light? Try these. They are attractive, efficient and bright.
summary: Exactly the night lights I was looking for - bright, energy efficient, automatic

reviewText: From the get go this isn't a bad hand-held steamer, you just have to accept that it's for very small jobs.  I have a slightly larger steamer that was around forty bucks, and in a head-to-head comparison, the McCulloch steamer is severely lacking in output.  Still, it does put out a reasonable amount of steam and pressure for a small handheld device, so if you're looking for a small steamer for little jobs, this might just be a good choice.  Despite the low power output, it feels well made, sturdy enough if not exactly "premium" feeling, and is quite a bit smaller than most alternatives.
summary: A small steamer for small jobs

reviewText: looks great and i was able to install it, but the bracket needed to be rethreaded. it was the wrong thread pitch so the screws included would not screw in on one side. took me an extra 10 minutes to install and i got a little annoyed since i expect it to just screw right in. luckily i have a tap and die on hand.
