reviewText: I had to change my review.  Had a low tire and eventually drove to the gas station to get air.  In part it's my fault because this is not really a consumer's tool.  It is an industrial tool and I should have read the manual before I purchased it.  You have to run it for 30 minutes to prepare the pressure.  Engine will turn off automatically when it's reached the proper pressure.  You have to understand that the smaller gauge is for the tank pressure and the larger one is for the regulator/output hose.  The regulator dial is used to release pressure into the attached hose.  It's recommended that you drain the tank daily by releasing the air to below 10 psi and unscrewing the tap on the bottom of the tank so it doesn't corrode.  Ok, let's get this straight.  Prepare tank (30 minutes) and then drain each day???  So maybe my previous 12 volt unit that took 3 minutes a tire on occasion and cost a 1/4 of this wasn't so bad.  I could even take it with me in case of an emergency.  So this product is probably getting a so so review because it isn't the right tool for the average consumer.  It's probably good for someone that uses pressure tools on the job, or spray painting.  For casual tire inflation it's over-kill.  Too late for me to return it and got rid of the box so can't sell it used/new.  Read the manual about the prep time and the daily maintenance if you don't believe me.  It's available online at the Campbell Hausfeld site.  Also, don't go for the recommended replacement tube.  The smaller tube is more awkward but does better holding pressure I think.  The larger tool is probably almost mandatory if you want to stretch out and do something like painting...

After reading all the good reviews on this Nailer i wanted one. The only problem was they, the company tried to give me the newer model which was the BN200C. I sent it back and tried to locate one from some of the other merchants, although they advertise that the have the BN200b they did not. Not sure they even still make the BN200b anymore.
summary: No chance to see how good it was. Buyer beware.

reviewText: Just installed three of these in our basement. We had a flood a year ago (multi-day rainstorm), and our Leakfrog let us get most of our possessions out of the basement. The Leakfrog's battery compartment screws stripped out very easily, so I replaced them with these. These are louder than the Leakfrogs, which will help (I didn't hear our Leakfrog go off until I passed by the door to the basement).Be sure to read the instructions about how to open them, and how to install the battery: battery placement is important, apparently, in keeping the device upright and floating.I installed one of these in my mom's crawl space, by her sump pump, and I tethered it to the crawlspace ceiling with a thumbtack (into the ceiling) and fishing line (tied to the thumbtack and taped to the leak detector, with a few inches of slack) so the device wouldn't end up in the bottom of the sump, in case the power goes out, crawlspace floods, power comes back on, pump empties water, and the floating leak detector ends up in a bad place.These supposedly emit a signal when the battery runs low, but I'll test them every half year anyway: wet finger, touch the contacts, listen for the SOS beep (dit-dit-dit, dot... dot... dot... dit-dit-dit), and dry off the contacts.

I just threw in the word "laser" to see if I could get your attention. This measuring tape doesn't have anything to do with lasers.I bought this over a year ago. It has seen light duty whenever I need to measure furniture, windows, rugs, and stuff like that. My girlfriend has thought of a few more innovative uses, but I don't dare mention those.The measure is precise enough for most purposes, unless you're a NASA engineer. It's durable. It's practically free. If you don't already have a tape measure, you should buy it just in case. It's actually very good, and I'm not sure how they can offer it for only $6.

I bought this socket to remove and replace the axle nuts on my Mercury Grand Marquis when I replaced the front wheel hubs.  This socket and a long breaker bar, plus a bit of sweat got the job done.  Would have been nice to have an impact wrench, but the socket did it's job as expected.

This table has almost everything you need from a small router table. However, I would probably spend more money next time and get a really nice router table. The firections were not as easy to follow as I woul have liked, but you should be able to figure them out ok.

Well, for someone who expect to sharpen a straighted edge, they will dissappointed. This tool is not meant to sharpen a straight edge. But when you use it to make a curved blade for a smoothing plane for example, it will perform an excellence job!  Out of the box, you only need to a registration jig based on the information supplied ai the side of the tool. Once you made the registration jig, set the blade, tighten it with screw driver, and you are ready to go. Nice product!

i LOVE this Flashlight !! I had considered a keychain light on several occasions, but almost all of them were AAA lights.  I didn't pull the trigger until I found what I felt was an Excellent AA light, with a Bright-Enough High, and a Low low and extended Runtimes.  This Thrunite T10 fits the bill Perfectly! As Luck would have it, the Very FIRST week that I had it on my keychain, I had to deliver some very important items to my Business Partner at night.  He wasn't home, so I had to walk around to his backyard to his back porch in Pitch-Dark conditions.  I didn't know it at the time, but an Iron Plant Holder had been placed directly in the path I was taking in the dark.  If I had Not had my Thrunite T10 on my Keychain that night, I would have walked right into it.  I LOVE this Flashlight; it's Perfect for Pocket carry or Keychain duty !!

I was replacing a GFCI at my rental property. The GFCI must have had a permanent short in it because pressing the test button and flipping the circuit breaker wouldn't reset it. For about $10 at the time of purchase, I didn't want to deal with it and just replaced it. This is a pretty simple change, even if you don't have any knowledge about electrical wiring. First of all, MAKE SURE YOU TURN OFF THE CIRCUIT THAT RUNS THIS OUTLET. It is very dangerous if you do not do this, ESPECIALLY if you are not a trained electrician. After that, swapping this out is very quick and easy work. If you don't know how to do it, just look at the outlet you are replacing and place all of the wires in the exact same position on this new device. It works great and I love the little green indicator light that shows if it has been tripped or not (green means its working, no light means it tripped/there is a problem).
summary: Same product you'll find at Home Depot or Lowes.

reviewText: Today's energy efficient incandescent bulb alternatives (LED, CFL) make environmental sense but they can also flicker when used with your old dimmers.  The Leviton Sureslide LED/CFL Universal Dimmer handles them all (including incandescent and halogen).It's easy to install and there's a handy bulb selector switch that you slide before putting back on your face plate.  We also like the smooth slide bar control (effectively dealing with those hi-tech bulb dimming issues) and there's an on/off present switch.Whatever bulb you've got, this affordable, no-nonsense dimmer gets the job done.
summary: Whatever your bulb preference, this no-fuss dimmer's the light choice

reviewText: The steps are great and it is easily reduced to the desired size by cutting with a very sharp hacksaw. The space size however is rather substantial so do not expect that it will not require the step spacing in your calculations.
These work great on cabinet doors to create a soft, quiet sound when closing the doors. They stick well and I haven't had any issues with them.

I saw all the reviews on this tool...and being an optimist I trusted the better reviews....I screwed up....lolI guess its an alright honing guide for someone who just casually needs to home a chisel to a sharp edge. I wouldnt put anything I value in it though..I tried sharpening an older craftsman chisel that I beat on and while it did sharpen it....and got it sharp....It was a pain to get it to the correct bevel in the jig..and the chisel was hard to get in there staright.I actually built a jig years ago....out of all thread rod a hard rubber roller and some nuts and bolts....and I trusted it to keep the bevel square.... something I wouldnt trust this thing to do..... enough sharpenings with this and you are going to end up with a skew chisel....lolNot that bad...really....Like I said...homeowners...occasional wood butchers....carpenters.....it will do a fine job.Serious woodworkers.....learn to hone by hand like the guys a hundred years ago did or invest in a better jig.I will use this on my beater chisels....because it is faster than honing using your hands and fingers to maintain the bevel....and I have not tried it on a plane blade yet....although I am thinking of yanking the blade out of an old millers falls "beater" I have laying around.But I wont use it on any of my fine chisels.....Id rather just take my time and hone them by hand....takes longer but its also less likely to end up with a screwed up bevel or out of square chisel.

Really isn't giving much protection since I couldn't get it to seal well.  One side was a little better than the other, but you only get one shot at doing it right.  I wouldn't waste my money trying again..

This saw was by far the cheapest offering sliding capability (FYI, it's gone up in price about 30% but it's still a great deal). I read the reviews and figured at the worst, I would have a chop saw that I could at least use to just cut boards and stuff, which is fine. At best, I would have a fully capable miter saw capable of making precision cuts for a fraction of the cost of the more expensive "pro grade."Well, I received the saw and was more than satisfied with the quality of the product. It's the same type of metal you'll find on any of these lower-end miter saws. In terms of build quality, you can compare this saw with anything at HD for under 300 bucks and it will be nearly identical.Blade: not great, but stock blades are never that great, even on $500+ saws. Always a good idea to invest in a quality aftermarket blade like Freud Diablos.Sliding action: functions well and low profile. I was worried this would be a weak point. It is not. A little lubricant would help here, as it doesn't glide effortlessly, but it is still smooth.Power: standard, adequate for just about any job and no different than any other saw in its class.Fence: it was off by a degree or two out of the box, as the directions prepare you for. A few minutes loosening and tightening the bolts that hold it and lining up with a straight edge and you are good to go. For people complaining about this, you really need to be realistic here; few saws are going to be perfect right out of the box.So here's where my review gets useful to most people. After having the saw about a week and using it to make a few cuts--including using an abrasive blade to cut through 1/4" copper bar--I was one day using it to cut a gnarly piece of hickory wood. Cut was going well but then the stock blade dug in and kicked the wood violently against the fence. Fence snapped right in half. Bummer.So here I was thinking I'd relived the ol' "you get what you pay for" adage. I looked around online for the replacement part, but to no avail. Then, I saw the email address for WEN customer service listed on the manual. Sent them an email explaining the situation and had a reply (written in perfect English, mind you) within hours. They asked to see the Amazon invoice and that was that. 1 week later I received the new fence in the mail via expedited shipping. Now how is that for customer service?!You read horror stories all the time on these Amazon pages about trying to get service for devices--long holds on the phone, no callbacks, communication barriers, etc. Things get particularly bad in the tool department. Well, this was the antithesis of all that. WEN completely stands behind their product and has the customer service infrastructure to keep customers satisfied.This saw might not be the Rolls Royce of sliding miter saws, but it is certainly the best value you'll find, and should something go wrong, you'll have the peace of mind knowing that the problem will be taken care of quickly and easily.

The reasons I'm not giving this 5 stars is because 1) it should come with screws and a string and 2) the putty isn't quite soft enough. I have to really mash it in to get a good fit. 3) Additionally I have larger ears and there isn't quite enough putty.Other than that, this is a great product. It dries super fast and of course fits ears perfectly. I've ended up buying extra so I can make new molds with more putty. I want it a little deeper in the ear and more coverage.
summary: Works pretty well, just wish it was a little softer

reviewText: The case is very good quality, easy to store & retrieve the stamps. Been using this for about a year to identify steel tags with and the stamps are still in very good shape.

Bucket Boss is a real winner. They have come up with a great idea and they keep improving and adding to their great idea. With Amazon's prices, it makes for the best tool carrier you can have. And with the cover/seat -- what a handy, helpful part of the Bucket Boss line. You will not regret this purchase.

This tubing looks to be some good quality material, rolled and bundled according to the length ordered.The tubing itself has no markings at all on it, but there is a nice adhesive label attached at one end with the Inner & Outer Dimensions. If you start your cuts on the opposite end, the tubing will always be labeled with the size.
I found this to be cheaper here than at my local pet store. It's a hose. It works. Good price.
summary: It's a hose. It works. Cheaper than LPS

reviewText: I've been using the same pump since the 90s to change the brake fluid by myself in my two cars.  So I don't use it more than a couple times per year.First thing I learned, get a bigger brake fluid container.  They sell bigger ones but you can make your own out of a jar, tubing and good caulk.Second thing is make sure you never suck up brake fluid into the unit.My handle comes apart from the unit now sometimes, but it is easy to put back.  Also, the gauge has seen better days, it's getting harder to read.But I've had one of these, the metal one since 1991.  Hard to complain.Take you time, open the bleeder screw a little.  If you get a clogged bleeder screw, you may be able to overcome the obstruction with vacuum but you may also have to stop, pull the screw and dig out the crud with a tool and try again.  Don't forget to have a container to catch the brake fluid for whatever wheel you are working on.  It gets messy fast.

These make a GREAT Festivus or xmas present for the man about the house. I was immediately impressed with the quality and durability of this bucket organizer. It fits snugly over any 5-gallon bucket and still allows for a seat lid to be placed over it, doubling for aseator step and keeping water and dirt out of the interior. If you need a few more pockets or the same organizer for heavy tools, check out theBucket Boss Extreme Gear Bucket Organizer. As for many reviewers complaining about screwdriver slots, I fit mine along the elastic belt at the rim and any others upside down in the slots if needed -- problem solved (or perhaps that's what Bucket Boss designers hope you'll figure out).
summary: Well made, and designed by people who use it

reviewText: I had a paper towel holder that I had placed on the side of a cabinet that every time you pulled one off, the inner tube would rub the cardboard all over the counter and I was constantly cleaning it up. I looked around for awhile for a paper towel holder and when I saw this one, I knew it would be perfect. It was super easy to install into the side of my cabinet. It looks great and matches the rest of my kitchen. It also will fit just about any size roll you have. If you like free counter space and want your paper towels attached to the cabinets, this is the one to get. It does not look cheap like a lot of ones I saw. I am very happy with this and think it will last a long time.

reviewerName: D. Mark Waldoch "Mark the Guitar Teacher"
reviewText: Had been using regular tools for doing fine work on guitars with limited success. These were exactly what I needed. Small to work only small area and takes off a good amount of material per stroke.

We chose this faucet based on the beautiful design, and the desire for the pull down faucet.  This was replacing an existing Moen faucet so we expected the quality to be excellent, we were not disappointed.  Ours came with the plate to cover the three holes it doesn't sound like all units include this plate..As I tend to break anything related to plumbing that I touch, I had the plumber come to install this.  It took him about 30 minutes, so I recommend having another task if like yours, mine bills in full hour increments.  The installation seemed easy enough.We've been very pleased with the performance of this faucet.  We've experienced no leaks, the handle is easy to extend and retract.  The lever works smoothly.

It seems I ordered two cutters for my workbench. These work as designed but I like the Hakko Micro Cutter better. The Xuron handle springs have less force, which could be advantageous if you were making thousands of cuts per day, but the feel is more secure on the other brand.
powerful when its dark...maybe at nights..but not so powerful in closets..the reason i got it...my husband keeps one by on his bedside if he cant reach the lamp..its got many uses actually.
Nice little bag to haul around small tools for a small job.I was pleasantly surprised to find the 2 stripes besides the Stanley label is retroreflective.

I installed this on an opening that is just a bit wider than a standard bedroom doorway and it feels very strong and durable.  We actually have three other gates that are used at different times and locations in the house, this is one of the stronger feeling ones.  My guess on the reviewers who commented about it being flimsy or getting broken is that they had it on a much wider opening.  When it's opened to it's limit, or near, it doesn't have nearly the support as when it's down to 30" or close.  There were no instructions, but it's pretty simple to figure out, especially if you've used a gate similar to this before.  The adjusters on the side work great, getting it more secure than any of the other non-permanent gates I've used.  You can put quite a bit of weight on it and it won't budge.  The only area I can see having a weakness is the little wooden adjuster pegs that help keep it in place.  I can see those breaking pretty early but if it happens I'll probably just put a screw into both railings to keep it from sliding, since I have no plans on using it in other locations that aren't the same width.  The little opening works great also, and feels plenty secure.

There are a lot of break-ins at my gym, where people are apparently cutting members' combination locks. This lock is shrouded at the top, making it nearly impossible to break into. It works perfectly for me, is easy to use, and my locker has not been broken into.
summary: one of the safest locks around

reviewText: This cups makes a wonderful lighted centerpiece, I placed it in the center of a small flower wreath and how beautiful it made my table! It was like a glowing candle in the center with no real candle wax etc to worry about.Also, I have used this as a drinking cup as it is so easy to hold this cup when liquid is added. For me, I love cold homemade lemonade and it looks great in this cup.Also, I placed some water inside the cup and brought it into my very dark closet and was amazed at how well it light up my closet. So in a pinch, I could use this as an emergency flashlight (like a candle)...
summary: Great vase or centerpiece. Also found a special way to use this cup...

reviewText: Seems like half the tools are useless. Humidity gauge actually reads relative humidity if you can do the math...Toothpick is cool.

Wow what a router. I have an older Sears craftsman that I purchased off of craig's list. This router is flat out a gem. It has soft start, which until now did not even know it existed. It has variable speed which is definitely a plus. I got this router for a dedicated table mount set up. You will not be unsatisfied with this router. The quality is very solid and the operation is super smooth. One of the things that struck me the most is how quiet it is. I have it attached to my new Kreg router table and they work fantastic as a pair, because you can adjust the router and change bits from above the table thus negating a need for a separate router lift. This is one sweet set up that I highly recommend. Yes it is a little pricey but in my opinion you get what you pay for.

I bought this tool to nail very hard acacia 3/4" flooring. The tool nails good, so far has never jammed. I don't like you need to adjust the deepness of the nail directly in the compressor pressure instead directly in the tool. After the fifth nailing after start using it the tool started leaking air from the trigger. This is annoying as this is not only leaking air but oil as well, you need to be extra careful to keep the flooring and base paper clean. I haven't returned it yet because It haven't failed yet and I have a deadline with the floor installation and can't delay waiting for a replacement, but the air leak is definitely a defect. I won't buy DeWalt nailers again.

This is an okay multi-purpose emergency tool.  The two main pros and cons:PRO.  It has quite a few featuresCON: It's difficult to access some of those features.The first thing I found I liked about it is the easily-visible temp and hygrometer dials... as well as the fact that the compass is visible on the end without opening the case.  That's a very neat function.However, the slotted mirror inside is actually glued to the case, making one wonder about the purpose of the slot in the first place.  On prying it loose one can look through the slot and use this as a signalling mirror, but one has to wonder why it was glued in.  I feel like I'm missing something there, and the SPARCE instructions (very sparce) didn't say.Several of the tools are inset into the case and held by tight-fitting plastic friction.  They actually include a cheap "prybar" tool with the case to pry those out of their holes... an annoying process (especially since the "prybar" is basically stiff wire and bends easily).  It does include a very tiny flint and striker (both of which have to be "pried" from the case).The LED light works... albeit one of the dimmest I've ever seen.The whistle is pitiful.  I could whistle louder myself.  Seriously.  If the sound of "airflow" strikes your fancy, this is the whistle for you.The magnifier works well and is fairy high powered, in case you need to uh, well, locate a splinter or something.  And it's always good to have a 1" ruler with you just in case you have to measure out a campground in 1" increments.  ; )I was surprised and pleased with the level.  No telling when you're going to have to make sure something is perfectly level during an emergency.  Not exactly sure what it's intended to be used for, but it's kinda neat nevertheless.Overall my impression was between a 2 and 3, but I decided on a 2 because although it is of use, it's poorly designed and not all that handy.  I don't "hate it"... it's just not all that impressive nor useful.Definitely don't buy it for the whistle.  Worst. Whistle. Ever.
summary: It's an interesting but cumbersome tool

reviewText: I purchased one of these for my sister. I stayed over night at her house and noticed the fan in her bathroom was making a ruckus. It sounded like it was going to come out of the ceiling. It's an old house and the fan had to be as old as the house. I figured I would try to find something on line anyway and low and behold I found the exact replacement for her fan. I installed it last weekend and now her fan is whisper quiet. It only took about 5 minutes to replace it. Hats off to Nutone for still making replacements for their products and for making something that works so well.

As with several of the reviews here, I have this kit installed on a RIDGID bandsaw.  RIDGID offers a riser kit but it costs 3 times as much!It bolted up without any issues; the alignment pins matched right up and the blade guide assembly fits the new shaft without problems. The blade that comes with the kit is nothing to get excited about though--it's just your average cheap spring steel blade and it's thin and flimsy.  I have a stout 3/4" blade on there for resaw work now.Before installing, I hit the block with some steel wool and a shot of silver spray paint to match my saw's frame.  Obviously this was a purely cosmetic task.  I just thought the green block looked funny on a silver saw!
really bright, best direct spot light, longer range then a light bulb, batteries last a lot longer, never seen a led this bright, as in he manual do not look direct into light blub its that bright
Cool lil pack to keep in a extra set of hand tools when you dont want to haul around your main set of tools.

We ordered two of these for our office. They seemed really pretty and got great reviews. The lamps arrived in plain white boxes with black printing. Opened them up, distributed them to the employees who needed desk lamps, and those employees eventually put their lamps together. Both discovered that the on/off switch located at the top of the glass globe was broken off clean at the base of the switch. There wasn't even a nub of the switch remaining to turn on the light.When we received them, both lamps were in styrofoam packing inside white packing boxes. Those boxes were pretty flimsy. Apparently when the boxes are tossed around in the delivery process the "stick-out" portion of the on/off switch snaps off. The lamps had to be packed up and returned, as they were unusable. :(

What else can I say...I love it.  The 'Super Bib' by Bucket Boss is  GREAT!!  It keeps everything I use on a regular basis handy, yet not in the  way.  Its rugged construction tells me its going to take the beating it  surely will recieve while I wear it. And most important it is comfortable,  and easy to maneuver around in.  I can wear what I want, and not worry  about having to change afterwards. I'm going to buy another one, for when I  have someone over working in my shop with me.
summary: I love it...I love it ....I love it

reviewText: I have a Ryobi ZRTS1552DXL 12-Inch Compound Miter Saw with Laser.  This Chop Saw Hood does fit into the "accessory" holes in the Ryobi, but so loosely that I was disatisfied with the wobble and ordered the optional $25 mounting brackets instead.  Even these aren't easy to find a place to attach to the Ryobi saw or portable stand I use, so I fabricated my mounting blocks to which I fastened the bracket.  I could have drilled a 9/16" hole into the 4 inch thick block and spared myself the $25 for the optional brackets, but lesson learned.Ultimately the hood does help to contain a good portion of the generated saw dust, but I use mine indoors in a shop where I like absolute control over dust and debris, and this doesn't quite contain it all.  I'm going to modify mine to incorporate an intake port for a dust collector and to use the rain flap to enclose  more of the area in the front of the saw to increase the draw of the dust collector - hopefully without cutting into the functional space of the saw itself.For work site use, this may be useful in keeping the debris closer to the saw, but don't expect the hood to capture everything.  The saw still spits saw dust at you and the light stuff still gets carried into the air, so it will work its way all around an interior space. If you're using it outdoors, my guess is it's hardly necessary.  I doubt the hood and rain flap will hold up to a breeze, let alone strong wind.  But I'm not a contractor, so can't speak to that issue.As a hobbiest who uses the compound sliding miter saw in lieu of a cross cut sled or hand held circular saw, I find the Chopshop Saw Hood only marginally useful in containing dust and debris.  But it's better than not having one at all.  At least the wall behind the chop saw doesn't need to be constantly cleaned.I hope the plastic bracket components hold up over time.
summary: Good idea, but not quite there in execution...

reviewText: I purchased two of these and I am using one currently. Something to think about, being a powerful magnet, trying to install it using screws and a screwdriver so close to the magnet is pretty difficult. I use it with a Taurus Judge and it works as it is suppose too. The only other think is that when you pull the gun off, the force necessary cause me to sometimes hit the sides of cabinet that I have attached the magnet too.
These are great, just like my other fastcap glasses.  Lightweight, good coverage, these even have UVA and UVB protection.  What else do you need?
summary: Love all my fastcap safety glasses

reviewText: I didn't buy this tool from Amazon, but this might be useful. I make furniture. It's a good powerful tool, within its limits, and good value. BTW, readers must realize these things make tons of shavings and I wouldn't think of using one indoors without a shopvac attached. You also need ear protection. This model is nice because you can choose which side to attach the vac. However, the fence is wimpy, and the tiny fence-mounting area on the planer doesn't help, so even if you extend the fence down (e.g. with a thin piece of plywood) you won't get accurate edge jointing with this machine. (I beefed up mine so it's at least now acceptable.) I use it chiefly for fairing up mildly twisted or cupped boards before putting them through a benchtop planer; and it's also useful for initial flattening of the common small ups and downs in large glue-ups, e.g. table tops, but only on the very finest setting (0). Then you're ready for sanding.

I have tried other brands of Quick access gun safes, and this is the best and highest quality of them all.  I keep this Sentry on my bedside.  I love the electronic keypad.  No more searching for the key in an emergency situation.  It looks great as well.  Very heavy and built to last.  My 1911 fits comfortably inside.  You cannot go wrong with this.

This gets many rave reviews. Having had the router in my hands and at work in the shop, I agree with them.This did a FAR better job at cutting a 23/32" dado with a 1/2" bit than my Trend T4 did. Part of that was that the switch is completely reliable.  But a bigger part was in the precise depth setting and consistent plunging action.I am still coming to terms with the bag. I think I just about have a packing strategy that will get the key pieces in there without risking broken parts. Once I get there, I think I'll be glad to have the bag rather than a hard case.I need to find a new owner for my T4... I certainly won't be using it anymore!

This saw was a big step up from my little Skil saw, and don't let anybody kid you, magnesium or no, it's substantially heavier than an entry-level homeowner's 7 1'4" circular saw. How it compares weightwise to a pro saw I can't tell you. It's manageable, though, and well balanced and ergonomically agreeable.I bought this saw to use with the Eurekazone track saw system. I needed the larger saw to achieve decent cutting depth with the track. It's got plenty of power for trouble-free cutting through hardwood plywood, a pleasant improvement over my old saw. Of course, the tracksaw keeps it dead straight, and I'm able to get cuts as smooth and true--or more so--than on my table saw.Features I like about the Makita saw are the light, which is a lot more useful than I expected, and the dust ejection, though with the track saw I usually end up standing right in its path. I don't have a dust port for it, so I generally chase it with the shop vac, and it catches a fair amount of the sawdust. Eventually I'll install a front-mounted dust port per the recommendation of the Eurekazone system. It's a good saw that I expect to last as long as I need it to.

This is the second one of these I have bought. I like them both but they both have the same problem.  The windage/elevation adjustments are very stiff and difficult to adjust even with the provided wrench.  I have heard others complain that these adjustment screws break easily, I have not had that happen.
summary: Sturdy, well made, just one minor flaw.

reviewText: Pretty basic hardware but I'm happy with it.  No slop or play and feels solid when you pull the door.

As skeptical as I am of (alkaline-battery-powered) electronic locks in high-reliability applications, I've previously steered clear of gun safes unless they are mechanically opening (my favorite is theV-Line Quick Vaultthat's installed behind a picture frame suspended on aHangman french cleat).  I once tried theADG Sports Securepistol safe, but was gobsmacked at how easily the door would pop open accidentally on that one.This Sentry Safe impresses with its small dimensions (it fits into bedside drawers that the ADG safe would not), its pry-resistant door design (the front lip is turned down to rob a pry bar of its upward leverage), and the speed with which the door opens -- after I programmed a combo, I thought I might have neglected to program the last digit, since it seemed to open before I finished pushing the final button, but it's just that fast.I was also pleasantly surprised by the reliability of the fingerprint programming.  I programmed my two index fingers, which took just a few seconds (the safe keeps re-scanning the same finger until it's satisfied -- it only took me four or five swipes for each finger), and then it reliably opened for those two fingers, and no others, every time I tried.  I haven't owned it long enough to know whether changes in humidity, temperature, or injuries to my finger tips (common when you're clumsy) will impact its reliability.My wife's fingers took quite a bit more training before they would register, and still resulted in a few false negatives (not letting her in) although thankfully no false positives, when we tried it on all the family members who were visiting for Christmas.Still, even if the fingerprint scanner doesn't let you in, there's the programmable buttons that you can use to open the safe (and, obviously, an override key).  My gripe with the safe is about how you interact with the buttons:  before you can input your key code (or scan your fingerprint) you have to "wake up" the safe.  You can wake up the safe by either putting your finger on the print sensor, or by pushing one of the buttons.  The first button that you push, however, doesn't count towards your code entry.So, if your code is 1-2-3-4-5 (please don't make that your code), you could not open the safe by pushing 1-2-3-4-5.  You would have to push 1-1-2-3-4-5 or 2-1-2-3-4-5 or X-1-2-3-4-5 (where X is the fingerprint sensor).  Unfortunately, you won't remember this until you've already pushed the first two buttons of your combo, and have to keep pushing buttons until the safe flashes a red light and refuses to open.  Then you can put your combo in again.I imagine this is a battery-saving function (BTW, 4xAA alkaline batteries only, says the manual), but it's a pain.  Why can't the first button wake up the safe AND count towards your combo?  This is enough of a pain that I can't rate it five stars.
summary: Sturdy safe, quick opening, good biometrics

reviewText: After my first use, I had a problem with tool breakage. But, was pleasantly surprised how well TEKON takes care of there customers. Never had a problen with a TEKON product before this. And, now I am sure "not to be afraid to buy TEKON products" Not many companys stand behind there products like TEKON does. Very good company to buy from

I retrofitted a old 4D Maglight with this upgrade kit and the effect can only be described as dazzling. The light temperature is much cooler than the standard bulb and it stays pretty consistently bright throughout its operation. The only 'downside' is that the beam cannot be focused and diffused as with the old bulb. But the advantages outweigh that downside. Highly recommended for older models of the Maglight.

These work in the broadest sense of the term for a few openings and then you will roll to the same combination you've always used and the lock will refuse to open. No amount of jiggling or repeating series of numbers will open it and you will finally have to CUT it off. I have had 5 of these Master set your own combination locks in 2 different sized models and have had to cut every one off eventually. Chinese junk!

Light is very white,  isn't warm when dimmed like our halogens were.  That is not necessarily bad but different.  Wish they would dim a bit more but even on the lowest setting on our Leviton dimmer switch they are still pretty bright.  Our fixture required an exact size match to a GU10 halogen and these are perfect.  I would use these again,  but might try to switch to a different dimmer to see if I can dim a bit more,  using in a wine cellar and I did not want the heat of the halogens any longer
summary: Nice WHITE light, not blue,  not yellow, not warm

reviewText: I REALLY wanted this to work, I really did. No more shaking the glue bottle upside down, A good cap, an even glue line, good for biscuits.. The first couple of times I used it, it was delightful and worked as advertised. Then little things cropped up. The cap fell off three times under the bench... Cleaning the tip after gluing was hard. Even after cleaning it, the glue spout was glued shut with dried glue (the cap was on tight). So I had to use a pin to remove the stuck glue EVERY time I used it (if it had sat for more than 3-4 days). I let it set for a couple of months and the glue dried down the spout tube. Pipe cleaner just pushed the plug into the bottle. Grumble, grumble.The last straw, errr drop, was when the glue was down to a inch or so in the bottle. NO WAY was that glue going to go up the spout! Pipe cleaner did nothing. The spout hole was covered in glue in the bottom of the bottle but it simply would not come out. Put more glue in, of course, but the glue in there was full of lumps and it was my last glue! Still an inch of glue so invert it, except that the glue was mostly in the spout. Rack brains. Stick finger in! too short. Stick pipe cleaner in! Not much glue. So I used a screwdriver to carefully ladle out the glue, enough for a 6 foot glue line with biscuits. Plenty of glue but what a mess.So new bottle of glue. Titebond 3 of course. No losing the cap, the tip is easy to clean and any lumps are pushed out by the tab. Even glue line. I have to shake the glue down or leave the bottle upside down but... And when the glue is finished I RECYCLE it and do not have to clean the bottle out!

I thought I'd be able to use these to grind down an edge on my concrete driveway that had raised up about an inch. It was very slow going. After a few hours I finally wised up and bought a diamond grinding wheel instead, which worked much better (but was also much more expensive, of course).

These things take a serious beating. I had to pound some old races out of a housing and was laying some good wacks on these with a 3lb hammer. They held up perfectly. I will be ordering another set of these for in the bag

The other day I was telling a friend about a great light that I had purchased from Amazon; we compared notes and he said that he already owned several and that he loves them.  I couldn't agree more.  The only difference between this light and the very expensive ones is that it is larger in size.  You'll love it.  You'll love it even more if you enjoy solving the Rubic Cube, because getting the batteries in correctly does remind a person of that puzzle.  If you look very carefully and if you have very good eyesight, you'll see on the inside edge of the barrel a diagram (of sorts) showing you the proper sequence.  The good news is that the batteries last forever (I've owned two for a couple of years in addition to this one.)
summary: A lot of light for the money

reviewText: I bought these to carry tools in my truck.  Recently took them on a 2700 mile trip during which the tools were used for a minor automotive repair and the complete rebuild of two toilets at a family member's home.  The bags held up great and show zero wear.  They are permanent fixtures in the truck now and work perfectly for behind the seat tool storage.  They seem to be very well made and you really can't argue with the price.  Good value all the way around.

Had a big box retail sump pump in the pit for a couple of years and unbeknownst to us it passed away over the winter. Sure enough Mother Nature found our weak link and exploited our basement like Washington exploits our trust. Had Leak Frog been standing guard, there would have been enough time to run down to the local big box store and install a replacement pump on the fly before the damage was done. Purchased and installed a Zoeller M57 and Leak Frog from Amazon. Shortly thereafter, Mother Nature tested us again with a vengeance and overwhelmed our Zoeller. This time Leak Frog sounded and we had plenty of time to add another pump before the basement went under. It has been a few months now and Leak Frog remains poised for Mother Nature's next leap. Leak Frog at $14.95 claims the alarm sounds at "over" 95db with 3 AAA batteries. The Water Screamer at $44.95 claims 130db with one 9v battery. If you need to pierce three floors or a 30k/sq/ft McMansion with sound, then go with the Water Screamer otherwise the Leak Frog should do just fine. If you believe you may sleep through an alarm then go wireless with a detector, transmitter and alarm placed on your night-table. Wireless units can transmit up to 300ft. We now check our pumps on a regular basis for signs of life.UPDATE: Leak Frog set itself off this morning but the sump pit was barely wet. Upon closer examination there was condensation build up on both contact plates causing Leak Frog to sound. I had placed the unit on a level well above the usual small amount of water in the pit but I'm guessing the temperature differential between the masonry Leak Frog was sitting on and the plastic/metal materials Leak Frog was made from caused the condensation build up on the contacts. I placed a 4" square sheet of plastic between Leak Frog and the masonry to act as an insulator. Will report back with results.UPDATE: Plastic sheet between LeakFrog and masonry worked. No false alarms.UPDATE:::::One year, seven months and 18 days later a loud static noise is now emanating from this unit. The test button is functioning and it does sound an alarm when the contacts come in contact with water but the new static sound is beyond annoying. I've installed fresh batteries and same result. It is with deep regret that I have to downgrade my review to three stars. This unit previously set itself off on minor condensation and now this. I couldn't seem to locate any warranty information and leakfrog's website lists no contact information. If someone from leakfrog is monitoring this review, please include contact information on your website. Your fan base would like to contact you with issues that might be corrected in a future iteration of leakfrog. But being made in China where QC is hit or miss, I'll resign myself to the fact that my bad unit was an exception and not the rule.
summary: Sump pump croak? -- Leak Frog water alarm to the rescue!

reviewText: Starrett is known to make great quality precision tools. This punch looks and feels great. The square shank gives it nice feel in the hand and prevents it from rolling off.I was disappointed not to see the Country of Origin stamped on the punch; therefore I assume that it is made in China, like almost everything else sold on American market.The only words stamped on this center punch are: "STARRETT NO.264E" I'd gladly pay more for a US made tool.

I just received this Delta Deluxe Miter Gauge #34-928. You wouldn't believe me if I told you how long ago I ordered it. I guess a fresh batch is in so order it quick. Now on to the item. When they say that it is accurate, the first thing I did, when I took it out of the box, was break out the Bosch Digital Protractor. It measures angles with a digital readout in tenths of a degree. (Equal to 3600 dots in a circle, no matter how small the circle) I put the miter gauge to the test. I clamped an aluminum level onto the face to extend the surface, and guess what? I got perfect readings after trying the detent stops, and even got the same results when I eyeballed a setting just using the pointer. It wasn't even off by a tenth of a degree.At first I was confused, because some of the stops weren't right on the number, then I realized that they have stops at the popular detents, and some of those are in tenths of a degree.Point number two is that I was impressed that the miter gauge bar that rides in your miter slot has little Allen bolts imbedded in it, so you can adjust it perfectly, to eliminate any play. When I put it in my Powermatic 66, it fit so perfectly, without any play, that I don't even need to fiddle with it. It is so snug that you would have to measure the play in thousandths of an inch, as in non-existent, yet it slides along the track like it was on greased wheels. It fit my Bench Dog miter track on their Router table extension for table saws the same way. The Might T track miter track guides had a little slop in it, but that is obviously the track and not the gauge. I guess you can tell where I will be using it. (Although the play is adjustable for any 3/4 x 3/8 track)Point three is that the bottom of the gauge is polished so smooth that it will not scratch your saw tabletop. The front face of the gauge where you rest your work, looks like it was fine ground-polished with something like a 1000 grit wheel. You can see ultra-ultra fine lines going in a circle from where it was fine machined.I strongly recommend that you also get Delta's clamp attachment that works with this gauge. The one that I bought is the 34-568 clamp assy, and it fits and works perfectly. Delta and Amazon feature the Delta cheapy miter gauge with the clamp as a combo package for about the same money as buying this Deluxe gauge and the 34-568 clamp assy as separate pieces. So for about the same money you are getting Delta's best, and in this example it is worthy of that title.The gauge and clamp combo perfectly resolves the problem of when you are trying to cope the ends of your rails in a raised panel bit set. You know the problem, you have to hold that two-inch wide board and run the bit over the tip. Trying to get the bit to not move the board, by either pushing it a little away from the fence, or run into the second fence face causing a stop is a major accomplishment. Many use sleds with clamps on them, but then you are raising the work piece off of the table to make up for the sled base plate. With a router, that is a major consideration, because that oftentimes leads to having to raise the bit higher up out of the collar, causing more vibration and potentially a dangerous bit flying condition. This gauge and clamp combo locks it in just the same, but keeps the work piece flat against the tabletop. The other advantage to that is if you are running some larger pieces at the same time, you can do it by removing the gauge, and not have to change a bit setting. Wow! I'm getting off on this, I don't know about you. :-)Another point is that the picture doesn't do it any justice. The fit, the finish, the accuracy of the deluxe gauge is better than any other miter gauge I have seen, even the one that came with the Powermatic saw. I can't recommend this high enough. Is it because it is a waxed Ferrari sitting in the garage? No, it is because it is as accurate and fine as a miter gauge can get. Buy one, you won't be sorry. Hope this helps.
I like these pins I have used Starrett  for 20 years they are the best. I like the quality of the work on the grip.

I read the reviews!  1 & 2 stars, and then a couple of 3 and 5 stars.  Well, I can't speak to any other product than the ones I received, and those were 5 stars.  I started by turning off the water, then I flushed the commode.  After the flushing, I took the tank lid off, splashed the water into the center hole as best as I could, took a small cup and emptied as much more as I could, then I dropped a couple of wash clothes into the tank to finish drying it out.  At that point, I unscrewed the water supply line from the old valve and pushed it aside.  I removed the old valve at that point, careful to dry up any water as I proceeded.  After I removed the old one, I installed the new one, very easily done.  At that point I reconnected the supply water line, turned the water on, and proceeded to adjust the little screw until I got the desired depth of water.  10 minutes from start to finish, and my wife is happy with me now, no noise of running water!

i have the sensor mounted to a tree outside. through my brick home the signal can reach it.  if its put on alarm it is sure to make u get up.  the range is awesome.  this thing does work.  the rain has not bothered it yet.

reviewText: It was kinda tricky to setup but I called support and they seemed to know every possible scenario and gave me exact steps to get it working. In my case I did not have an RC wire so I had to send power to unit thru a separate transformer that I got from Radio Shack. I put that transformer in my heater closet and used a spare wire already going to thermostat. The program on my android phone is excellent as well. I travel so much and keep the unit on hold at 62 degF and change it when I get to home airport. Not cheap but for me its well worth it.

I bought these bulbs because my CFL bulbs burned out after a year or two.  These may use more electricity but they are brighter and probably required less resources to manufacture than the poor quality CFLs.  They fit my chandeliers.  By the time these all burn out maybe they will have figured out how to make CFLs that last as long.

I just bought a 14 inch band saw from Grizzly and I was going to buy this base to go with it, then I read the negative reviews here.  When I got to Grizzly and looked at it, it is indeed a nice heavy duty base.  It uses rectangular tubing for the rails instead of stamped sheet metal like other brands.  I did not buy it because I shopped around and found that Western Tool Supply sells this same base for $49.99.  Then I found the HTC mobile base on sale at Rockler for $49.99 and that is what I ended up bringing home.Several reviewers complained that the base does not roll well, and I think they just don't understand the dynamics of the mobile base.  If you have 300 to 400 pounds of cast iron tool on 4 small wheels, the floor has to be clean and smooth for the wheels to roll.  Wood chips, saw dust, power cords, or any small item will stop the tool from rolling because it is a lot of weight on a very small wheel.  I have 3 tools on mobile bases in my shop now, and they all are very picky about wanting a clean unobstructed surface to roll on.A couple of reviewers complained that the screws for the side rails would strip out.  Since I didn't buy one of these I can't say much, but I can tell you that those screws are not load bearing.This base does not have a quick release lever for setting the brakes, and I think that is a great feature to have.  The HTC mobile base has big levers that you can operate with your foot to set or unset the brakes.
summary: Looks very sturdy, but cheaper elsewhere

reviewText: As stated, this is a quality tool set from Starrett. What else do I need to say? Their name speaks for itself. I got their set of brass  punches as well, and they are perfect. There are some tools you just have to spend the extra coin on to avoid getting Chinese garbage that will let you down when you need it. This is one of those instances.

The picture maked it look larger than it is, It comes from China and took almost a month to get here, It does take a special battery which they do not sell around here so I would have to order from the internet and they are not cheap, So I would not recommend it,  It may be good in China but not really here,

This is a lighweight, mounted scroll saw.  It cuts great, for light duty, and is handy to move around.  For a couple of quick cuts, it is easier than setting up my table saw or miter saw.  I bought some better blades, and it works great!
Reasonably strong and well made, but not excellent.  The finish is a little rough, and the tips of the jaws don't meet when fully closed.  Some tarnish on handles when brand new.

These came with Duracell batteries which was an extra bonus.  They have three modes (dim, bright and flash).  They say they are impact resistant up to about 3 feet.  I dropped one accidentally on a concrete garage floor from about 3 feet and it still works.  :)  They are pretty bright on full strength.  I bought them along with bike flashlight mounts and will use them for our family bike lights.  Note:  the mounts I bought say they work with 2.4 - 4 mm lights.  These didn't fit in those holders correctly so if you're buying them for universal bike mounts, they may be too wide.  Even though my holders wouldn't close (couldn't tighten clamp screw) with the flashlights inserted, I was still able to use them in the holders without the screw.  Luckily, they still fit very tightly in the holders I bought so we'll still get good use out of them on our bikes,

Was worried at first after reading the other reviews. Well some people shouldn't mess with power tools I guess. This isn't a top end contractors version for sure. But its a great addition to any ones shop for little one cut deals. Its fast light and cuts smooth and straight.The fence is ok for thicker stock. for thin stock just clamp on a piece of 0.125 straight edge plate and voila great little tool for the money. and yes I have cut 0.250 nickel/silver bar stock with this. that tuff enough?

I love Gorilla Glue. It holds like mad and has done some amazing things for our home. But it has it's limits and it expands all over the place which can be a mess. So when Amazon said I could this glue for free if I just tell you my experience, I thought "why not?"So then I didn't just do the things that gorilla glue can do and see how it compares..I gave it two tasks Gorilla Glue would NOT be able to do (and didn't do when I tried before).First task. Plastic toy chair. (see pix above) Now, to you and me this chair looks like a clear throw-away, but to my little girl, it was worth fighting for. It's an awkward thing to glue (it's so thin, it's like walking a tightrope and the seams didn't match up exactly, leaving gaps). I don't have a clamp that can hold it so I simply put some packaging tape on the front and ran a line of Advanced ProBond on the back. I waited until it looked clear before moving it (about 30 minutes). It worked! And worked well. My daughter didn't love the faint blue line where the glue showed through the gap to the front, but it stayed together well and she will quickly overlook that. The back looks clearly like a dried line of glue.2nd task: Ceramic mushroom. This one was super tough. It not only was near impossible to line up the surfaces (being randomly bumpy) but there was NO clamping it. It is on a spike you put into the ground, so the only "clamping" is gravity. Turns out I didn't line it up well (I couldn't see that low to the ground to adjust it) but Advanced ProBond still worked. It lined up poorly but held its own! The things I could repair with this would save us a good amount of $$ over the years. See picture section above.If you have only some small tasks to repair, the 2 oz bottle should be sufficient, but you don't save much in $$.My one criticism is the color. It dries pale blue.Although I received this product in exchange for a review, this review is honest and no one is pressuring me to vote positively. I would recommend this glue to anyone. If this review or photos were helpful, please click "yes" below.

I put this clamp to work shortly after it arrived.  It performed exactly as advertised;  clamped all 4 corners of my room divider cabinet like a champ.  Because of this clamp,  the project only took 30 minutes and an overnight drying for the glue to set up.  I just love kit!

reviewText: This thing is less than 6 bucks, is very well made, and the magnet is very very strong. Great addition to the toolbox...if you don't mind pulling tools off the magnet every once in a while!

This glue seems to be non-toxic since it had no smell, and it is easy to apply.  We clamped small pieces of wood and metal to a smooth metal bracket angle.  They were bonded nicely to the metal when I removed the clamps.  Although the glue states it is NOT for use on submerged surfaces, after 24 hours I submerged the metal and wood (which were still bonded to the metal angle) overnight.  I could NOT pull them apart forcefully but eventually tapped them lightly with a hammer to remove them.  This glue seems like the perfect solution for our pergola.  The decorative top pieces frequently get knocked down by squirrels.  As soon as our weather gets to 60 degrees, I plan to sand smooth the surfaces and replace the missing pieces.  More creative experimentation will be done with ceramic pieces on concrete and on metal when the weather warms.Update: 'Our' peavey hook, used as a lever in moving large logs, suffered a fractured handle. This glue was applied along both splintered surfaces. The tool was back in use the next day!  We will definitely purchase more of this glue.
This worksite table saw is fantastic!!  I love how simple and easy it is to move from place to place!!  Great product from Bosch!!  Highly recommend!!!!

This is the second angle clamp I bought. The first one (I forget the brand -- it was a ratcheting clamp) was so poor quality I sent it back. This is high quality. I bought extra angle corners (Bessey VAC-6 Angle Plates) so I can use the strap with work pieces with up to ten sides. I will definitely buy more Bessey products.

I had a fairly indepth review of this light, but my opinion of this light has faded more and more.While the Light output on an 18650 is OK, it is no where near what is claimed.It is more blue than I like.3 new Nimh's in the holder are perhaps 75% as bright as the 18650The provided battery has no where near the claimed capacity.  It actually says shelf lief 10 years on the shrink wrapping.  I get about 1/10 the expected runtimes when run in a Nitecore HC50 when using this battery.  I bet this battery is just taken from a used laptop battery pack and re shrink wrapped.There is no way it is water resistant, certainly not waterproof.It is annoying to use as there is no memory and you got to cycle through the different settings each time to get the one desired.While zoomable it is not wide enough at its widest, and not narrow enough at its narrowest, so less throw than expected.I regret this purchase.A note to those shopping for lights in this price range that think they are getting a deal when it is provided with a battery and a charger....  The battery is likely used and rewrapped with a fraction of the claimed capacity.Li-ion batteries can be dangerous if overcharged.  DO not trust these junky cheapo packaged chargers.  If a battery fails serious lasting injury can result.  If your first Foray into Li-ion batteries, do some research first on their correct treatment.  Do not trust cheap chargers!!!Check candlepower forums for sticky's about proper Li-ion care and charging
summary: Bigger than expected/needed.  Junk battery, questionable charger, keep shopping

reviewText: This is my first nail gun so I am obviously no pro with these toos, but I was impressed how feature-rich, effective and easy it is to use. As long as you have access to an air compressor, I can't imaging using a hammer for most of my jobs after using the Bostitch BTFP72156.  It has many useful convenience features and feel like it is built to last (like other Bostitch tools I own). I really like the oil free design a nail depth selector. Its lightweight body is a welcome addition to my power tool inventory and can help make quick work of a job when used properly.If I am going to hang a photo, I'll use a manual hammer and nail. If I'm going to install flooring or build a frame for a counter or some stand-alone object, I'll reach for this nailer. If you've never used a nailer and can't think of an instance in which you'd need one, then stick with your hammer. It uses FN nails so you need to be sure you can get them locally or order ahead. If you are DIYer and weekend warrior working on various home improvement projects, or a professional handyman, then this should be on your short list. To top it off, it comes with 7-year warranty AND a pencil sharpener, hah!~ Kort
summary: Professional Level Tool for the Experienced DIYer

reviewText: Compared to some other Plunge Router attachments for Rotary tools I had looked at this one was the best,better construction,ease of use,& smaller in size making easer to work with.

I'm glad that it payed for itself so soon because the speed control broke after very little usage.  It seems a little cheaply made, but I would buy another because it is so useful for the general handyman.
summary: Good tool; speed control is broken.

reviewText: In our house we have 4-watt nightlights in the two bathrooms and the hallway, with battery-operated emergency lights in several locations. They work as they're supposed to, but the nightlight bulbs burn out occasionally, and the emergency lights are very low-power incandescents that only illuminate a tiny area.The Hipe Multipurpose Lights will replace the emergency lights and possibly the nightlights. I tested the light's functions, and it worked well in all three modes.1. Emergency power failure light. I tested this function by unplugging the unit from the AC wall outlet, and the large, very bright 15-LED light came on instantly and stayed on until I turned it off.2. Flashlight. The on/off switch turns on the 5-LED light (straight ahead like a regular flashlight) or the 15-LED light on the side (like a lantern).3. Motion sensor light. Passing in front of the sensor in darkness turned on the 15-LED light, which remained on for about 20-30 seconds. It illuminated a surprisingly large area for such a small light. The sensor appears to be effective for distances up to about two feet with a coverage angle of about 90 degrees. I tested the motion sensor light in several locations under varied lighting, and it consistently performed as advertised.The unit is very compact, weighing only six ounces and standing about seven inches tall in the charging cradle. The built-in batteries are charged by induction, so the flashlight unit lifts out of the cradle easily without having to be unplugged from anything.My only slightly negative comment is that if the unit had an always-on low-power light, it would be more useful as a nightlight. As it is, the nightlight doesn't turn on until you approach it.I really like this light, though. It does a lot for such a small, inexpensive unit.Note: A sample of the product was provided by the manufacturer for review purposes.
summary: Three useful functions for the home - 4 stars

reviewText: I have had this lamp installed into an outdoor fixture for about a month now and so far everything is good.  The ''face-value'' quality also seems to have made a good impression upon me as well.  This lamp seems to be an exact replacement to the competition!

reviewText: Accurately marks the cutting line, just like it should.  The cut is make to the right of the line, so, make sure that is where your cut should be made.

reviewText: For under $10, I have no doubt that these are about as good of mini bolt-cutters as you can find.  Keep in mind, these are not so much 'bolt' cutters, as they are heavy-duty wire cutters.  If you are building a chain-link fence, for example, and want something that will cut the fence to length relatively easily, that won't break the bank, these will fill the bill nicely.  The little clip at the bottom of the handles, that hold them closed when not in use, yet folds out of the way (and STAYS there, until un-folded) is a nice touch.These are great for occasional use, like putting up a chain link fence for yourself, and other uses like that.  Now, if you were in the business of fence-building, and wanted a true pro-quality tool, go with something like the Knipex Co-Bolt cutters, but keep in mind they are about 5X as expensive, as well.I'd say that these work well for cutting unhardened bolts up to about 1/4 inch (although it WILL take some effort to do it in one snip) and maybe 3/16" for a grade 5 bolt.  It works great for stuff like chain link fence wire, barbed wire, as well as hogwire or the horse fence that comes in the big rolls.
summary: Good small cutters for the cost

reviewText: I found this unit on Amazon and ordered as I wanted more capacity than the std 12V bike pump.  The unit was delivered promptly but did not work properly.  I contacted Amazon and arranged for another unit to be shipped with this unit returned.  Amazon provided the shipping paperwork by email and irt was easy and free to return.The new unit arrived promptly and worked well.Over all I was satisfied and really found not ask for better service.

If you've never used a pull saw before, you'll be surprised.  These saws have thinner, more flexible blades than traditional western-style push saws with little or no sideways "set" to the teeth.  As a consequence, they turn less wood into sawdust as you cut - translating into a smoother cut and less need for muscle power.The small saw is the most flexible making it perfect for flush-cutting dowel plugs.  Both saws have a spring-loaded button on the handle that allows the blade to be removed and replaced.These saws are a valuable addition to my tool box.
This is a sturdy door-lock that I use to lock up my office.  I like that the key is large so it's easy to find in your key ring.
Pros: Excellent for taking our black dog for night walks and the battery is replaceable.Cons: None.Conclusion: Works great to alert drivers and prevents you from bumping into you dog at night.

You can't go wrong with this item for the price. Mine did come with butane, and lasted a good while. It has 2 modes, the "torch" mode and the "flame" mode which is like a standard lighter.The flame adjuster has to be set in about the middle for the flame to actually start, otherwise it works fine after the flame is lit.There isn't really any safety on this switch, a friend came over and turned the gas on, not even thinking about what it would do.Refueling is very simple and very easy. I just held a pen tip to the inlet a few times and let all the gas out, put the gas can upside down, and pressed for about 15 seconds. Waited about a half hour, and it worked fine.

So I'm not a contractor, just an average DIY homeowner. I didn't want the cheapest nailer I could find but I didn't want the most expensive either. I got this for a remodel and really have no plans of much future use. I have to say this thing is great. I've been shooting round head 16D plastic collated framing nails (3 1/2 inch) with no issues. I've got a pretty heavy duty air compressor but I think a 5 gal pancake compressor would probably be just fine. I find I need to run it around 100 PSI to get the nails driven in all the way. A few drops of oil before you start and your good to go. The case is a nice extra feature. It's lightweight and easy to get the hang of after a few rounds of nailing. Much better then hand nailing and a whole lot faster. Do yourself a favor and just get this or at least something to speed up your framing.

This is a very good storage bag for your jumper cables.  It is of very good quality in both materials and construction.  It is also relatively inexpensive. The title states that this provides a "ground shield".. I thought this meant that it provided a 3rd prong on the power connector (ground), but it does not.. this uses just 2 pins on the power connector and does NOT have a 3rd pin (ground wire).. reviewText: As a shop teacher I have a lot of cheap Stanley 60 1/2 block planes lying around. I only use them when this is just too big for the job. This plane is a joy to use. I use it to true up stock, as a basic smoother and for general planing purposes. I have never used a high quality smoother so I can't compare it to those but it seems to fall short in the final smoothing category. I typically plane a piece of furniture flat with this and then do a final sanding or scraping with a card.Lie Nielsen suggest that you make this the first plane you buy and I can't argue with them. This will allow you to plane all but the most difficult woods.
Simple, works much better than my fancy electronic one. Nice strong magnet so it will cling in place on the wall.  I like it!
Perfect under-sink extinguisher for my kitchen. Fits the standard holder already there so was easy change out. Arrived fully charged and ready for use.

In a pinch, this little emergency light could come in handy but-- and it's a big but--you could do better.If left plugged into an outlet, the light will come on if the power fails and will serve as an interim flashlight until you can locate your emergency supplies.  The light takes 15 hours to charge initially although it's not clear if it requires that long for each subsequent charge.  Of course, you can choose just to leave it plugged in when not in use as a flashlight.  The company indicates that this would not cause any damage.If you never experience a power loss, the light should work just fine for you.  It's powered by internal rechargeable NiMH batteries and  Energizer says that they will last one hour when used on high mode and two hours on low.  When faced with a power failure and assuming there is no way to recharge the batteries, that just isn't very practical.I recently bought a pair of similar lights but instead of NiMH batteries these use Li-Ion.  They not only seem much brighter, they charge in less time and will run for up to 8 to 10 hours on a charge.  Like millions of others, we recently experienced a massive storm and power failure.  Our power was off for about 48 hours and we made use of these Li-Ion lights extensively during that time without the need to recharge.  So while the Energizer light does work and does do what it promises, there are better, longer-lasting options.

This is a good choice if you have to hunt in a dark room or closet to find the light switch.  One square of the rocker switch face lights up with a yellow glow.  It's bright enough to be immediately visible but not too bright, so it wouldn't be distracting in a dark bedroom. I've been using this style of switch for over 20 years and the lighting elements never seem to die.  If you know what you're doing, you can replace non-illuminated switches youself in 5 or 10 minutes, although there may be states where you are supposed to have a licensed electrician do the work.
summary: Illuminated switch is a nice feature; easy to install

reviewText: This is exactly as advertised. They are very sturdy and will stand what every your peg board will. Would buy again.

Good:the price is right, and it perfectly fits the best selling zoom led flashlight on Amazon too, Only thing I don't like is there is no end cap for the screw on the end which looks badBad, sort of:I have this mounted on the skewer as a bottom light, you need an adapter to do that, anyways the bottom of it hit cement or something and it snapped off the bottom where the screw would need a thread to tighten into. I say sort of bad because the thing was still hanging on as enough of it remained in tact to still clamp and not too loosely. I was able to easily pull it off though. A solution to this would be to super glue it on but I ran out of glue. Though broken, it's still not a worthless piece, because the entire thing with the broken piece could still be glued back and onto the adapter so that it would function just as it did before, and better in a way since it would be much harder to steal.
summary: you get what you pay for

reviewText: Very nice update, buttons now light up rather than on my older style unit which just had a red LED indicator.  Used this to replace my older garage remote which had worn out.
