reviewText: I used mag-lites for the past 6 years for working on aircraft. I think they are one of the best out there. Ive dropped them from a 25 foot aircraft wing, kicked them, stepped on them, sat them on extremely hot turbine engines(600+ degrees C), dropped in puddles of water, left out in the rain, etc. you name it, I proably done it to them. They still turn on and work. Of course they are dented up pretty bad, but the quailty of light hasn't changed. What can I say, they are made of excellent/durable quailty. Would recommend.
I wanted something small and light that I could carry with me; this fits the bill.  Surprisingly hard-working dfor such a small tool.  Highly Recommend.

I think like most people I first tried robust gardening gloves but they just weren't long enough and I was always getting burnt when unprotected arm touched some piece of metal on the stove. No longer, using these, or often just one I can safely add wood even if it means reaching over red hot embers. Its even possible to briefly handle coals or burning logs. Does the heat soak through eventually? Of course it does but these gloves offer lots of insulation. They have already held up through one season and are well through their second with no visible signs of failure but when they do I will be buying another set.
summary: Get these and stop getting burnt loading wood into your stove

reviewText: I used this to clean and remove rust from my truck.  It works much better than a dust mask and hopefully it helped me to live longer.
summary: I used this to work on my truck

reviewText: It does fit in my wallet without being too bulk and it has features that I like.  I would recommend it.
summary: One of the better wallet tools

reviewText: Had bought many of these for my students.  Out of the twenty five pens, three did not work properly, showing inaccurate readings or no numbers at all.  The seller from China was very gracious and sent replacements at no additional cost, sending them express shipping which came the following week.  Careful because there is fragile glass bulb at the bottom, some of the kids had accidentally broken these by simply dropping them on the floor.  I had been using a $100 multi-reader and this cheap pen is actually superior because the more expensive pen took up to a minute to read the PH, while this pen takes only seconds to get a final reading.Updated: end of the year, only 5 out of 25 pens still work.  If dropped and fully submerged in water the pen will no longer function.  Extremely fragile glass bulbs.  Overall not as durable as higher priced pens.

It was thinner than I expected but then again when it's diamond you don't need a really thick layer. Seems to work very fast, and blows right through my VG-10 steel 8" chef's knife. Started cutting through tomatoes cleanly again. I hope it lasts.

Amazon gave me credit for these although I had opened the plastic case to try the headband on. The product description made it should aa if the would fit my size 7 head but it was way too tight. I appreciate  Amazon's return policy.

This seemed to work very well.  I didn't put it to a huge test, but it seemed to get the job done.  It fits well and is very easy to adjust.  The head and neck straps are actually very comfortable and easy to put on and take off.
Covered a cord that was always getting tripped on out on the porch.  Had to lay it out in the sun for a couple of days so it would stay flat.  The tape was useless.
I ordered some in 400 lumen and some in 300 lumen, I paid more for the 400 lumen ones. When I received them they were all the same. I hate lies.

I rarely give negative reviews but this think just doesn't last long.  I even bought a second one to verify I just didn't get a bad one, and six months later and it's broken...  Again.  It just stops turning on.  The battery holder is weak and do much as touch the case and the unit shuts off.  I really wanted this product to work for me but after the 2nd one going bad I have to give upI decided to open it up and see what the problem was.  The solder connections look like a 3 year old did it. Cheap flimsy wire and secured poorly
summary: This is a peice of junk

reviewText: these filters would great with the breathing device that they were designed for.  I purchased these when my wife was pregnant with our second child.  I was remodeling the basement and a lot of particles were in the air.  Before she was allowed to come down there and supervise she was instructed to wear this.  She had no problems breathing with these on and hopefully they protected her and our baby girl from the elements that were floating around in the air
summary: keeps the good air in and the bad out

reviewText: If you are reading this review because you're struggling to get this tester to work properly, let me offer this advice:  Don't use the POWER button.  If you turn it on with the POWER button you'll likely be frustrated.The INSP-3 is a professional hand-held tester that checks GFCI, AFCI, Polarity, Voltage Drop, True RMS voltage and Ground Impedance on 120 volt single phase circuits. It does not check the condition of the insulation.It has a standard NEMA 5-15 three-prong plug you insert into the receptacle to be tested.  If you want to test a circuit with old-fashioned 2 prong receptacles, you'll need to supply your own adapter.The instructions included with this tool are rather brief.  I struggled for 10 minutes trying to test for voltage drop on a GFCI circuit before I figured out that I should NOT turn the tester ON before using it!  To be clear, the instructions don't actually say "Turn the tester on".  I just assumed that pressing the POWER button was the first step ..... my mistake!After that, the tester worked great.  I went all through the house testing receptacles and found the living room circuit, which is the farthest from the service panel, has excessive voltage drop (11% @ 20 amps).  That explains why my chop saw functioned so poorly that time I used it on the front porch and powered it with an extension cord from the living room.GFCI testing reports the milliamps required to trip the device as well as the time (in tenths of a second) that elapsed before it tripped.  This tester found one GFCI in my home that consistently tripped during the 15 amp load test, never allowing me to proceed to the ground fault test.  That GFCI device has never given me trouble, so I'm impressed that the tester identified the problem.Sorry that I was unable to test the AFCI function of this tester.  My home was built long before AFCI devices were required, or even available.This tester will become a valuable part of my DIY tool kit and I highly recommend it.  I deducted one star for the brief instruction pamphlet.  It seems that a tool this expensive should have a proper manual.Mike
summary: A very good tester with poor instructions

reviewText: I am new to home repair and was not sure if I wanted to do the installation of this garage opener.  After I reviewed several YouTube videos (and they are available for this specific Chamberlain opener), the installation seemed "straghtforward" but more involved than what a novice home owner may want.  I instead hired a handyman to do the installaion, which actually seemed almost as straightforward as the YouTube videos.The opener is extremey quiet and although I always close the garage door when leaving, I know my wife used to frequently forget to do this.  The auto-close feature makes this opener worth it for that reason alone.
summary: Extremely quiet and with an auto-close feature

reviewText: A good mixed set of blades. They have all worked well so far, and cut clean. A must have for any jug saw owner

I have a knife that is a favorite because of all the accessories it has... It has a corkscrew, knife, screwdriver and an LED flashlight... The down side is it won't stay sharp... With this thing handy, I can quickly put a fresh edge on the junky Chinese blade that won't hold an edge... The second time I use that knife to open a package, it's dull and doesn't cut very well. Without this, it probably would no longer be my favorite knife...

Love this little door bell.  I purchased two, one specifically to "call" my kids upstairs from the playroom (haven't opened the other yet.)  It is super loud, even on the lowest volume.  I considered putting some sound dampening over the speaker, but ended up putting it inside a china cabinet that's down there.  It's perfect.  We have it set to randomly choose a chime every time I hit the button from upstairs.  It also has a green light that flashes when the chime is going. The range is great! It has WAY more than 10 chimes...at least 25.  I can't speak to durability yet, but will update my review after a few months.

I asked for this blade as a wedding present and actually got it.  I could not justify spending $100 on a table saw blade.Well, now I know that I can never justify buying a $50 blade.  This is not just a saw blade.  It is a piece of equipment.  It just happens to mount to another piece of equipment.  We all spend lots of money on things that just dont measure up to what we expected.  Throwing down the extra money on this bad boy will reward you in ways no other piece of woodworking equipment will.  I've used DeWalt, CMT, and Freud blades and the Forrest is the top of the line.  The CMT and Freud burnt up the wood and the Forrest didnt, all with the same setup on the saw.Well worth the money.Update:  Now that I've had this blade for a while, it is even better than I originally thought.  It's been great for cross cuts, ripping, and plywood.  I use this blade when I rip boards that will be glued up.  Seems to make a better surface than a jointer for glue-ups.  So far, no burning with this blade.  It's top notch all the way.

I purchased this product in December 2011. I am still pleased with the functionality and safety aspects but I am very disappointed in the overall construction for such a pricey item. After what I would call light use mowing my yard on a tractor, the webbing and face shield have broken. If you check the price online the headband is about $50 and the visor a little over $30... that's a lot of money for thin plastics parts that SHOULD last a life time.Other items that previous reviewers mentioned are valid. It is a bit top heavy and will tend to ride down on the bridge of your nose, and tighten it too much you'll end up with a head ache. It is over priced considering what it is, but what price do you put on healthy lungs and eye safety? It does perform those duties very well.This is intended as just another 'buyer beware'. I'll keep patching mine with rivets and tape, it is just a shame that something this functional safety-wise should need to be repaired so soon.
summary: TREND AIR/PRO Airshield and Faceshield Dust Protector

reviewText: I am a fairly new lizard owner and I started with just a heat lamp for the day and a heating pad for the evening.  After a few weeks I noticed my steppe runner had become lethargic and had poor color.  I spoke with a local expert that told me I also needed a UVB lamp to help my little guy synthesize vitamin D, a fact I had not been made aware of when I got him.That being said, I didn't really like having two lamps sitting on top of my tank and especially didn't like how the UVB bulb stuck out of the lamp fixture and tilted the whole thing to the side.  That being said, a deep dome, two lamp fixture is exactly what I needed and it fits the bill nicely.  The inside is polished in order to make sure the most amount of heat and light actually makes it into the tank as possible.  The unit accommodates the CFL style bulbs well and I have no complaints.  Great product.

ThePocket Chain Sawis a truly portable tool that can serve so many purposes.  Out of the package, one sees the impressive quality build of this tool.  It's pre-oiled and ready for immediate use.I sincerely like the design of this product.  It seems safe, with cutting teeth about every third link.  Of course, safety really is up to the user.  The unit easily folds up into a nifty pouch, which is included.  The pouch even has a belt loop that's great for those times when you're out camping.I tested the Pocket Chain Saw on some dilapidated trees and shrubs near the edge of my property.  This saw was quite effective at taking them down, and left a very clean cut.  This could also come in handy in the garden for removing tough, hard to reach branches.  Much easier, safer, and controllable than using a big powered chain saw.Overall, thePocket Chain Sawis extremely portable and designed well for camping or survival purposes. It can also be very useful on larger jobs, or in the garden.Disclosure: I received a sample product from the manufacturer for the purposes of providing this review. A review in exchange for the review sample was not promised. The views and opinions expressed in this review are my own, and in no way represent the views or opinions of the manufacturer or vendor.
summary: For Home or The Wilderness, A Great Portable Tool...

reviewText: Being very picky about thermostats because of my occupation, I was looking for a replacement for my 15+ year old Tstat.This one was fairly easy to install and get programmed.  Minimal instruction reading needed (we all know men hate to read the instructions) and I had this sucker cranking the A/C in just a few minutes.I love the features of this that many won't appreciate- like the 5-minute setting to lock the compressor out in mode change, the 1/4 degree of comfort range across 2 degrees (and yes, it is accurate), the humidity sensor and ease of programming.Buy with confidence.

There comes a time in every man's life when he decides to stop buying crappy tools. I've had Chinese stuff that broke or chipped in the most mundane applications and so I made a promise to myself to Buy USA Tools whenever possible. This basic claw hammer is American made and you can tell the difference. The grip is solid and controllable. The claw is at the correct angle and the overall geometry is perfect. Balance is terrific and will make it easier to swing this hammer like a real man.  All of this comes at a reasonable price. Do yourself a favor and spend a little more for a tool that won't let you down.

I recently moved into a house that was built in 1959 with an attached garage. The door is a solid wood 18x7 door. The old opener had stopped functioning reliably long ago from what I was told and this one looked like a nice one to try out. I did get to see and hear the original open work several times so I would be able to compare the sound and smoothness of operation later.I got my dad to help and we set about pulling the old opener down and installing the new one. We took our time and followed the instructions and we had it all done in a couple of hours. I was lucky that the old ceiling bracket worked perfectly with this opener as it saved a lot of time, money, and effort because I didn’t need to purchase and install a new one.  The sensor mounts didn’t want to clip to my track as it seemed to be too big. I cut off a couple of pieces from a 2x4 and mounted the brackets to those and then used construction adhesive and a long screw to mount them at the bottom if the door on the frame just outside of the track. The only real issue I had that I didn’t think I should have had was that the sensor wires weren’t long enough.  I could have used just a couple more feet but it wasn’t there.  Luckily I had just run new thermostat wire in the house so I had extra. A couple pieces of wire and some wire nuts and I was in business.Setting the travel, aiming the safety sensors, testing, and then configuring my car remote was no problem. I have a 2013 car and everything worked fine but I understand some older cars may need a repeater in order for the home link controls to work. You get a couple of remote units for in the car so if you don’t have controls built into your vehicle or if yours don’t work you aren’t totally out of luck. You also get a keypad with a cover to mount outside that you can easily set a code on and use for external access. I had read that the Liftmaster Internet Gateway would work with the Chamberlain as they were the same so I opted to get one. It was easy to set it up so I could also run the opener from my Android phone.The first time I heard the opener operate it was pretty amazing. I had never heard a belt drive opener before and when compared anything I had heard before the difference was huge. It is so quiet that most of the sound comes from the door track. I also like that the opener shows down as it approaches the end of its travel so the door doesn’t slam open or closed like the old opener did. Another great thing is that the wall panel has that motion sensor that will automatically turn the lights on if you want. We go out into the garage frequently as we have storage and keep recycling out there and the automatic light is a very convenient feature. It turns the light on as soon as we step foot in the garage and shuts them off shortly after we leave.So far this opener has been working about a month now without incident and I am very happy with it. If this unit looks like it may be something you are looking for I’d definitely recommend it.

When I was a kid growing up, I would often help my dad with various projects around the house.  Especially at first this mostly involved me standing around a lot and running and getting him tools and supplies when asked, and one of my earliest memories of fetching a tool for my dad was getting him a hammer.  I went down into the basement and grabbed the nicest looking hammer and came running back with it.  "Oh, no, sorry, but I wanted your grandfather's hammer--the one with the brown leather handle," he said.  "Could you please run and get that for me instead?"  I was perplexed.  I knew the hammer he was talking about, and it was a rusty, beat up looking thing with a weird handle!  Why did my dad want THAT hammer?  Just because it had been his dad's maybe?  I didn't know, but, I ran down and got him that hammer instead.  I soon learned that when my dad wanted a "hammer" he wanted THAT hammer--evidently his favorite hammer.The hammer in question was, of course, a 16 ounce straight claw leather handled Estwing, and later, when I got old enough to do more than fetch tools--when I actually started swinging a hammer myself--then I understood.  That Estwing was just plain RIGHT.  It felt right, it struck right, it was absolutely rigid and true, and despite the way the old leather handle may have looked to my childish sensibilities, the thing just felt really good in your hand.  There was no contest.  It was by far the best of the half dozen or so hammers my dad had scattered about.And it was, apparently, already one generation old!I don't know where I got my gene for organizing and taking good care of my tools, but it certainly wasn't from my dad.  That Estwing hammer got left out lying on the lawn in the rain more than once; it was literally used hard and (not) put away wet!  So eventually, long after I had graduated from college, one of the rings in the handle broke apart thus allowing the rest of them a great deal of play and slippage, thus practically ruining the hammer.  I honestly don't remember whether I asked permission, or if I just stole it, but either way, I took that hammer--MY favorite hammer--from my dad.  I carefully cut some sections of thick leather to push into missing section to get rid of the play and fill in the channels of the tang (it's like an I-beam) and then I wrapped waxed linen cord around and around to finish filling in the void and bring the hammer back into working order.  It worked out really well, and the handle was firmer and more secure than ever.I went to all this trouble because I just assumed that it was no longer made and I loved it!Then, one day, I saw a 16 ounce leather handled Estwing with a curved claw in a hardware store and did a bit of looking into it, and found out that Estwing still made that exact hammer--my grandfather's hammer!  Who would have believed it!?!  So I had the store order me the straight claw version (because who in their right minds wants a curved claw?  Anything a claw hammer can do, a rip hammer can do better.)So, I now own my grandfather's Estwing, and my own, much newer (and much better cared for) version of the exact same hammer.  And both make me very happy.I have used many dozens of different hammers over the years for everything from roofing to framing to finish work, and this Estwing is still one of the best hammers ever made and I love it and would never ever part with it.  It is beautiful, functional, and of the highest quality.  Forget all the fancy new fangled MIG welded, titanium, fiberglass, death-on-a-stick, carbon fiber, replaceable face hammers out there.  This is the one you want.  Once you have this one, go ahead and flirt with others--you will always come back.It's just plain right.  And it will last a lifetime.  Or longer.
summary: The best hammer ever made - still

reviewText: A little low on power but I can't complain condsidering it didn't cost me anything but the margins on the other tools I bought--woulda paid bigger margins at Home Despot or Lows. Nice that it comes with an assortment of extra blades. Too bad stupid DeWalt makes all their tools in Mexico...pay a little more and get a 7 lb., 10-amp corded Milwaukee Sawzall made in the US.
This hammer is just the right size. Feels really nice in the hand and not too heavy at all. I am thinking of buy the next size up for bigger jobs.

Bought to replace a wooden handle hammer that split.  This is really well made.  The grip of the handle is good and the hammer is well balanced in the hand.  This should last a long time & is made in the good ole USA.

[Important caveat: The Leviton Mobile Device Station is easily your best bet providing you can first locate an unobstructed, conveniently-located AC receptacle in your dwelling. If so, simply select your preferred Leviton wallplate (see images and videos above) and seamlessly "sandwich" it (no unsightly screw-holes) between the pictured two-piece Leviton Mobile Station (consisting of mounting bracket plus cradle). If not, the Leviton Mobile Device Station is still potentially useful but will require a new screw-hole (or 2) and some creative gerrymandering to conceal the mounting bracket.]After collecting several mobile devices, I soon realized that I needed a better system for organizing them.  Attaching one to a computer's USB port and another to a speaker dock helped me avoid the appearance of clutter but did not solve the problem of making my primary device accessible when I needed it most.One solution that I was already familiar with is 3M's Command Recharging Station, which uses adhesive strips to mount a holder on a wall, within arm's reach of your favorite iPhone or iPod TouchCommand HOM-11 Recharging Station with Adhesive Strips.  It's fast, less expensive (but not by much), and reasonably effective (I have yet to experience a station falling off the wall, so I can't comment on damage, if any, to the underlying surface).  But it's neither decorously understated nor reassuringly secure (I've noticed that the thin, brittle plastic cracks and shatters quite easily).  In short, the Command Station is more of a "provisional workaround," useful in a dorm-room setting, whereas the Leviton Station is a lasting solution for the home.Compared to the thin and breakable plastic "cup" of the Command station, the Leviton is a durable "fixture," offering its owner a choice of decor-matching colors.  Moreover, the Leviton cradle provides two stabilizing "arms" that pinch lightly against a phone or iPod, holding it securely in place.  Given the several "apps" on my Touch that are configured to serve as remote surrogates, running everything from my iTunes library to my Roku box to a DVR, the Leviton station has become a necessity.  In fact, anyone who's tired of hearing, "Where's my cell phone?," would do well to purchase extra stations for other members of the household, especially if available AC outlets are conducive (see above "caveat").As for the installation of the Levitron Station: once a user-accessible AC outlet is located and a wall plate selected, all that's required is a screwdriver (but no new screw holes). The back of the cradle can be offset on either side to provide sufficient space for a squarish or bulky power adapter.
summary: The best bet for the home.

reviewText: You have to be careful when buying LED bulbs. It's way too easy to get the wrong "color" temperature, the wrong function (dimmable or not), or the wrong amount of lumens to replace an incandescent.So this Philips bulb marked my third attempt to get it right for one particular use. I want a long-life bulb, roughly equivalent to a 60-watt incandescent, that does not look like it is used to illuminate a police interrogation room -- I hate the very "cold" white light that some LEDS put out.But most important, I wanted one that will work with an X-10 home automation timer. Supposedly bulbs which are dimmable will work, but this Philips arrived in a package which warns, "not compatible with ... timing devices." It does say it is dimmable if used with "leading edge or trailing edge dimmers" -- whatever those are. Luckily the package appears to be wrong. Other LEDs I have purchased, when installed in the lamp I wish to control with an X-10 timer, will flicker badly when the lamp is on and the timer off. This one does not, but I plan to continue to test it and will report back if it malfunctions.it sure would be nice if these details were available in product descriptions BEFORE you buy.This bulb feels a lot more substantial than some of the others I have tried and puts out a nice "warm" light (2700K), which is just what I wanted. If you are buying it to use in most sockets, I can recommend it. If you want to use it with a timer or home automation setup, the jury is still out, but so far the prognosis is good.
summary: May be the LED I am looking for

reviewText: I won't say to much because with all of the other positive reviews, it's already been said.I like the daylight color, & although the specs say the soft white and Daylight both put out 830 lumens, the Daylight LED does appear much brighter.Right away I noticed they work very well with my old dimmer switches, they're about 15 to 18 years old.No dimming problems at all.Now I'm real close to completing the changeover to all LED lighting.Just about another 12 or so E12 LED's and I'll be done!I've decided to use thePacLights Cand50 Dimmable LED'sGreat bulb, high quality, very bright, and high energy savings!Highly recommended!!!
exactly what the wife wanted at half the price of home depot. i bought the multi pack which worked out for me.
holds my bikes just the right distance from the wall. sturdy construction. flips down flat against the wall if you need the space. Of course make sure you nail it into a stud.

I bought this for occasional use as a work / project light. It spent most of its life unplugged on a garage shelf.When it was finally drafted into action to illuminate my attic during an extended cable-pulling session, it initially worked extremely well. I ran it on a long extension cord and used speed-clamps to attach it to ceiling joists to illuminate the vicinity of my current task. After maybe an hour or so of work the lamp started going out, but a quick tap of the case brought it back online. However it only lasted for a few more minutes before dying completely.I'm not sure what it died from as I've yet to take it apart, I assume it's something solid state if not the LED itself. I live in Florida, the temperature in my attic during the session which it failed could definitely have been a deciding factor, but you never know with such cheap products, it could well have just been a weak solder joint due to a manufacturing defect.It worked well at first, and it was disappointing that it failed when I needed it the most.

I just purchased one of these as a gift for my Dad.I have owned one of these for years and love it.  I especially like the two position handle and the adjustable drive clutch.I am an avid do it yourself type and use this driver almost every week.  I use it with a set of drill bits with hexagon quick change tips to drill pilot holes, then quickly switch to the driver of choice and adjust the clutch to drive in the fastener in place.I am glad DeWalt still makes this driver.  When my Dad asked what kind of power screwdriver he should get I immediately knew what to get him for Christmas and was glad to find after all these years it was still available.Bottom line... if I you are looking for a comfortable, versatile, well built screw driver with the ability to do light drilling work this it the tool I would highly recommend.  It will last for years and get the job done quickly.
summary: Have had this Screwdriver for many years

reviewText: I really like this handle.  You can really apply the torque.  I find I use it quite a bit more than I expected for those hard to loosen fasteners.
summary: The T Bar is great for stubburn fasteners.

reviewText: I installed my own 60' sewer line to the street and the inspector said this is the level I am going to check you work with.  The level has increments of 1/8 and 1/4 that is easy to see in a slight blue color when laid on the pipe in the hole.  This made the pipe easy to level and pass inspection.  It would have been a lot more difficult without it

I have a few Leatherman multitools but this is the only one I carry with me every day.  The blade is easy to reach and the pliers are good enough for most every day jobs.  For example, my dog knocked a cord out of the wall the other day and bent the hell out of the prongs.  I straightened them out no problem.  I've also used the pliers to pull staples out of heavy cardboard, open bottles, etc.  Works perfectly.As a whole, the knife is very light and the blade is sharp out of the box.  The handle feels sturdy and I don't have any reserves about putting the tool through some abuse if the job calls for it.My ONLY gripe with this knife is that when you remove the pocket clip, the screw that held it on does not sit flush with the knife and it looks kinda funny.  I'll just deal with it though - no biggy.

Well designed and feels of quality construction and packaging. Like all Philips LED bulbs I have purchased, they work perfectly and actually dim like an incandescent bulb. They only negative is they are usually one of the most expensive, but you get what you pay for. The only other LED brand I have been happy with is Tuwago.
This is not a heavy duty drill but I bought it for working in tight quarters and putting up cabinets and other things where the adjustable head is really valuable compared to a large rigid drill!
summary: A great unit for the cabinet workers.

reviewText: I have several light fixtures that are narrow enough that while a regular light bulb fits and works, a CFL bulb will not screw in far enough to light.  These extensions add just enough to the length of a CFL to allow them to screw in without any issues and to work as they should.I screwed these bases onto the CFL and then into the fixture.  If the extender does not come off with the bulb, you can still remove it easily.  They placed an indent on both sides of the porcelain to allow you to use a non-metal item to unscrew it if you need to if your fingers cannot get ahold of the unit.I would highly recommend this product if you need to extend a standard light socket.

This is a great lock.  It took only 15 minutes to install and looks great. The smart key feature on Kwikset locks is awesome. It fit my door perfectly.  I had a regular knob and wanted the added benefit of a combination.  Just in case I am in the garage and lock myself out.  It you are in the market for a combination lock this is a great lock.  You can program up to 4 codes, so everyone can have their own combination.  It took me less than a minute to re-key all my kwikset locks in the house.  Now one key for every lock.  This Kwikset feature is awesome.

I already own a couple of Philips LED light bulbs Philips 409946 12-Watt A19 LED Household Light Bulb, Dimmable so I'm already biased.[Good]Bright: It has a pretty decent lumen output.Efficient: It saves energy and depending on usage, it may pay for itself within 2-3 years or sooner.Speed: I do not see any difference in terms of speed to fully activate, between LED bulbs and normal incandescent lightbulbs. While CFLs have gotten way better in this department, the lag time to fully turn on is still apparent.Durable: Unlike a normal lightbulb or CFL, this bulb is more durable. I believe the outer housing is mostly plastic.Safer: CFL's emit UV radiation. However so does the sun and tanning beds. The effects of CFL UV radiation probably depend on placement of the bulb and factors like how close people are to it and how long they hang around the bulb's area of effect. I could be wrong, but LEDs do not have this problem. Continuing the safety discussion, this is a really minor point since I've never personally broken a CFL bulb; nor do I know anyone else  who has. However if it happens, CFLs contain approximately 1000 times the lead of a normal lightbulb. With this LED bulb, I do not believe you'll have that problem. I don't know what LED light bulbs contain, but I do know that they're much harder to break. Someone may or may not correct me on this point.Normal looking: This is another really minor point, since I personally loved the weird yellow Phillips LED bulbs. Even now, I don't think even this bulb can match the latest generation in terms of lumen output. However, they look really weird. It's hard to use them in places where you can actually see the bulb. Yes they look normal when turned on, but depending on the light fixture and the style of your home, it may or may not work for your aesthetically. With this particular LED bulb, you won't have that problem. It looks completely normal with a neutral off white color.[Bad]Price: While these type of bulbs are going down in price year after year, they are currently about 4 times or more expensive than an equivalent CFL for the same lumen output and about the same energy savings. Phillips is also even more expensive than other LED bulbs. In Phillips' defense, they have the best LED bulbs in terms of lumen output.[Verdict]If you value quality and safety over price, you can't beat the Phillips line of LED lightbulbs. As of today, I am not aware of an equal. (When I last saw GE's LED line, I felt that they were overpriced but things may have changed.)
summary: An evolution of a great product

reviewText: I love not having to carry around keys.  And if you ever wonder "Did I lock the door?", just turn on the auto lock feature.  The styling matches most current door hardware out there.

I had the opportunity to review this tape measure. I think it has a kind of cheap feel to it and the calculator is of the type I would never use.  It is hard to press the smooth bump buttons.  The package if very hard to open.  The tape doesn't look the same as on the package, but if you have it in your hand, you can pull it out to see it before you buy it.  The tape lock does not move smoothly and adds to the cheap feel. For the casual user, this is a fine tape measure especially if low cost is your top criteria. If you need a tape measurer and a calculator together, this could be the tape measure for you.  I like the tape measure I already have better.
summary: It's a tape measure. It's a calculator.

reviewText: THIS IS THE BEST FLASHLIGHT I HAVE EVER SEEN. LOTS  AND LOTS OF POWERFUL LIGHT BUT VERY SMALL AND AA BATTERIES. WOW. AT A CHEAP PRICE. I USE IT ON CALLOUTS FOR FIRES. PEOPLE ARE ALWAYS SHOCKED WHEN I TURN IT ON IN A DARK HOUSE. THE OTHER FLASHLIGHTS ARE NOT EVER IN THE SAME GAME.

My King Arthur 45814 Lancelot carving tools arrived on schedule and in good shape. Installation was a snap with the special nut, as simple as installing a standard grinding blade. Really removes wood in a hurry. Easily controlled and simple to use. I suppose because of the rpms and 4-inch  blade it seems to dull quickly. I spend what seems to be a lot of time sharpening. I've already got my money back from small items I've sold. I wish I had spent the extra and purchased the other brand with carbide teeth. Maybe the King Arthur folks can come up with 4" round carbide tipped chain saw blades?

reviewerName: A. M. White "Just a regular person."
reviewText: After years of using the convention extension ladder, I decided to buy the MT-17 from Amazon. Wow, this is a seriously well-built ladder that is easy to set up in a number of different configurations. It works great as a step ladder with extendible legs, or as a fully open extension ladder. Made the gutter cleaning work on the single story garage and the two story house a snap. I really like the locking mechanisms, they are very solid. I did mark the UNLOCKED and LOCKED positions with red and blue Sharpie, just to make things clear at a glance. I did pick up the standing platform AC-18MT to give a more secure stance when using a power washer on the ladder and it works nicely. So all in all, a very nice ladder that folds into a compact form for storage in your garage, and a ladder that will take the place of the usual quiver of stepladders and extension ladders typically used by homeowners.

I have been experimenting with LED lighting for the last year in an attempt to reduce our electricity consumption enough to offset my Chevy Volt plug-in hybrid car. Additionally, as an engineer, experimenting with LED lights is also weirdly enjoyable and appeals to my "Dilbert" core.This Philips LED bulb is about the fifth LED bulb in the A19 size that I've tried. These bulbs are supposed to more or less substitute for the common 50w-60w incandescent bulbs that have been the home lighting mainstay for many years now. I've used this bulb for a week and have the comments below:Pros:1. Small enough to fit in any fixture that will accept a similar output incandescent bulb.2. Looks more or less "normal" compared to the bulbs with strange shapes and finned heat sinks on them.3. Throws a nice, even light pattern, even to the sides as well as the top or front end.4. The "Daylight" color balance is nice and white. I have posted a comparison photo on this page that compares this bulb with two other LED bulbs and incandescents which are "tungsten" or indoor balanced.** It is important to know what color balance you want because LED lights are targeted for a certain "warm" or "cool" output. If you pick the wrong one, it will look out of place or give an undesired effect.5. Appears well constructed and not tremendously fragile.6. The packaging does not require tools to take apart.6. It is not as heavy as some LED bulbs, so it does not cause the light fixture to become unbalanced.7. Dimmable. Compatible with my solid state, X-10 remote computer controlled dimmer. Many LED bulbs are not. If you are using LED bulbs in a multiple light fixture, it is often necessary to use at least one incandescent in the mix to keep the trickle current from powering on the LED bulb. This Philips bulb does NOT seem to have the problem.Cons:None so far.My ranking of A19 sized bulbs from my personal use:1. Philips 425264 (Subject of this review) - nice little light that doesn't exhibit any abnormal behavior. White daylight color balance.2. GE Lighting 68017 Energy Smart LED 11-watt 800-Lumen - Mostly well behaved, although it is not fully solid state dimmer compatible (stays partially on). Big plus is that it looks like a normal light bulb in almost all ways, especially the shape.3.  Feit Electric 13.5 Watt LED Omni 60w Incandescent replacement - Nice light output and great price ($10 at Costco). But, it looks weird and is heavy. It has the poor "off" characteristic mentioned in the review.4. LED Light Bulb, 900 Lumen, Warm White, 9 Watt (65W Replacement) by G7 Power - Good light with efficient output. It looks close to a regular light bulb, BUT it is BIG. This is not explicitly mentioned in the product description. I found it would not fit inside of some glass globe fixtures that would accept more normally proportioned bulbs. Does work with a dimmer, however. Relatively expensive.5. Lights of America - these are the crappy lights that were available at Costco under the "Lights of America" name. Pure crap. Avoid - faults are too numerous to list, but the big one is it doesn't provide enough light to be usable for most purposes. This is the one light I returned to Costco.
summary: Clean, white light and good form factor

reviewText: When I first received this product, I was excited with its potential.  First I tested it on several bonafide squares, but the Bosch consistently measures off by .3 degrees.  Not huge, but enough to be concerned about when buying a precision tool.  I searched the instructions, only to learn there seems to be no method an end user can set it to a 90 deg benchmark.  In my opinion, this is a shortcoming.  Nothing that is flexible like this, which can also get banged around, will maintain pefect calibration.  Of coruse, one solution is to always add .3 degrees to the reading.  But I am not sure how it will fare at 45 degrees, 23 degrees, etc.I will not repeat much of what has been written about other shortcomings such as size the inabillity to hold data, etc.  But every tool has its limitations, so its the users responsiblity to match his/her needs with a tools capabilities.  The reason I gave this 4 stars is, the market place is lacking highly accurate angle finders.  So this product fills that void well, and although it could use some improvements, overall, its still very useful vs. any other device I have found.  And although others find the price high, I would disagree, as for a precision instrument such as this, I consider the price fair.  Measuring angles in high precision is much more difficult then making other measurements such as distance, depth, etc.ultimately, a more accurate device would probably be a  dial type scale, which gains huge accuracy from gearing.  The digital aspect can easily be incorporated into such after the reading is had.Also, if you are using angled cuts for short width pieces, tiny inaccuracies such as this, are not an issue.  The issue arises when the angle cuts are long as the slight inaccuracies become visible in the finished product.Update, 1/20/06.....  I was fooled....  I spent $95 for a high precision CNC square, which is checked for accuracy to .05 Degrees.  This was my new benchmark to test the Bosch, and I was much surprised to see it read 89.9 Degrees, making it well within its specification range of .1 degrees.  This demonstrates you only get what you pay for, and not all squares are square, even though you spend good money for them.  Now, the Bosch is quite the tool, and very accurate, which is critical for me.
This is incredible for the price.  It is amazingly bright and the batteries last a very long time.  Very rugged.  You can't buy a better flashlight for the price.

The recall mentioned in the one star review was for product made during a single month in 2006.[...]Mine was made in 2013, hence not part of the recall.The bit change out system is clunky. That is the reason for the missing star.
Get it if you want it. There is no problems with it. They are sturdy and well made. Two words.
summary: See my review on the near identical item.

reviewText: I am happy with other Black & Decker cordless tools I have purchased through Amazon.com (and I love Amazon.com), so I ordered this cordless saw.  Unfortunately, this saw would run for only a very short period of time (10 minutes?) -- and took hours to re-charge.  I ended up sending it back and buying (again, from my favorite online store - Amazon.com) a saw with a cord -- the Bosch Model 1640VS "Finecut" saw.  It was much more expensive, and for some folks it might not be as useful as a cordless reciprocating saw, and the blades are not cheap -- but I am hopeful the Bosch will take care of my needs.
summary: Perhaps I go a lemon -- or perhaps these are just wimpy!

reviewText: I love this tool. It will save you a lot of time and hassle when compared to marking with the standard square or tape measure. With the standard way you have to make sure that your eyes are right over the mark to ensure accurate cuts but this tool takes that variable out of the equation. I will definately buy the 18" set next and I hope to see a long 48" version or if possible a tape measure with the same hole type marking. Hey I can dream can't I.
summary: Best money I have spent this year

reviewText: This light appealed to me because I really needed something like this a few weeks ago when our electric was off for an extended time due to a storm.  I have a couple of Coleman lamps but the are rather clunky and they only have basically an on and off switch and a white light.  This lamp had 3 different lights, a flashing red light, a solid red light, and a very bright white light.  The number of hours that the 4 D-cell batteries provide is equivalent to several days.  This light is light weight, compact, has an easy grip handle.  I am very please with the light itself.  Although made in China, I really do like it.Now for the parts I do not like.  When I received the light, there were no instructions with it.  I'm not sure if it was an error with this particular light or if the manufacturer just does not put in the instructions.  Maybe it is supposed to be so easy that you don't need them.  Leave it to me though to have trouble.  I was having trouble with the batteries.  I was looking for a guide with the positive and negative indicators but saw none of this.  By trial and error I finally got it right.  I also did not realize that I needed to not only turn the dial to the various light settings but I also needed to push the center yellow button for the light to come on.  I finally found this by trial and error.  If I had instructions, this would have been less frustrating.  However, the light is a good one and I expect many good hours of use from it.  I finally did find a number to call if I needed help but had already figured it out.  There is a nice offer that comes with the light, if you go online and pay the $3.50 S&H;, you can get a free flashlight.  Sounds like a good offer to me.

This is a very attractive ceiling fan (the blades are a nice chestnut color)....was very easy to install (I had an electrician do it and he said it was very easy!)and runs very quiet.  It moved the air well in my family room which is sized 20 x 14 and has a 9 foot ceiling.  It does take candelabra sized bulbs, but...who cares?  (Anyway, it came with bulbs!) It is very attractive, priced very well and is a HUNTER!  This is a great deal and I am very happy with the fan.
summary: Nice ceiling fan at a great price!

reviewText: Leave it to the Brit's to put this handy package together.This belongs in an emergency outdoor kit with other survival gear.Well worth the purchase.

I have a number of battery-operated LED flashlights that have similar brightness but don't require 4 D-cell batteries or anything like the amount of space that the Coast EAL@) 375 Lumen LED Lantern requires.  The lamp is remarkably ugly at a time when attractive LED lanterns are available.  I could only see keeping it in a car trunk or a garage.  There is no need for a lantern shaped like a candle-filled hurricane lamp with current technology.  On the other side the lamp is remarkably bright and includes a red safety blinker.  It would be useful for reading or signalling cars at night if your car breaks down.  Bright as it is, I gave mine away.

I don't know why I waited so long to buy these but they are great! Perfect for keeping your sockets organized and no more going crazy looking for a certain size. A quick glance is all it takes to see if anything is missing. My only gripe is as a DIY guy I didn't have all the sizes to fill out the trays so I had to go on the hunt for the missing sockets. After purchasing these I noticed Harbor Freight sells a set which doesn't cover as many sizes which probably makes it a better purchase for someone like myself however they are nowhere near the quality of this set...
This ladder is very well built and is useful in many applications around the house. Only down side is that it is very heavy. Keep a short lighter one around for small jobs.
summary: Good ladder at a great price.

reviewText: These fit into a 3" high drawer and the socket size marking is fantastic because I have trouble sometimes reading the markings on the sockets themselves. There are no instructions but I know you put the sockets onto these top-down (upside down) and then they sit real well. I was able to identify missing sockets, then I ordered those individually from a supplier I found on Amazon.

Keep it with a cheapo 300 watt power inverter in your trunk.  Lights up everything if you need to change a tire or help someone on the side of the road.  Must have equip for the dangers of the road.  If you are prepared, you are never sorry...
summary: EMERGENCY LIGHT WORTH IT's Weight in GOLD

reviewText: I have a tropical plant green house.  During the winter nights temperatures often fall below freezing.  This product allows my heat system to come on when needed, only when needed; stay on as long as needed and then turn off as the temperature goes up.It is simple to set up and has separate low and high circuits (for heat on and cool on).

I used these TwinTask lights as my go-to flashlights for several years.  These aren't top-of-the-line lights, but they do provide a great compact flashlight for the price.  These were the lights that I kept in my glove box or thrown in with my camping gear before I discovered the PackMate lights.One of the best things about these lights is the multiple output levels.  They can be set to the low brightness setting that will give you excellent battery life for standard use, or they can be bumped up to a higher brightness if you need to really light something up.  Unfortunately, this is also the most irritating thing about the light since the switch to toggle modes is a sequential push button; so you have to cycle through all the modes every time you turn the light on.Just to be clear, the brightness/focus of this light definitely isn't as good as other lights that cost several times more money.  But, for the price, I don't think they can be beat.  If you are used to using any size MagLite (or comparable flashlight) instead of a top-of-the-line SureFire or Streamlight, then you will be amazed by the brightness of these.Even with the irritating switch, I would still recommend the TwinTask flashlights if you absolutely need it to be black.  If you are OK with either green or orange camo I would recommend the Streamlight PackMate lights instead.  The PackMate lights are the same size as the TwinTask lights and they don't cost much more; but they have some improvements - including a much better switch and better brightness/focus.
summary: Nice light, but I prefer the PackMate

reviewText: I'm using these clamps as end supports for my work bench.I like the size and adjustable levers. They come in handy when securing long boards. Although they are smaller them most clamps they do support the boards well enough where as only a minor clamp is needed when securing most of the boards before cutting or using a jig. I set up two clamps at the end of my 2ft wide table less than 1ft apart from each other close to the center. After raising the height of the clamps 1/2in off the table by securing a 2in X 2ft X 1/2in board underneath, it allows for thicker boards to be used and gives me a nice fine edge to square the boards for cutting. The clamps can be adjusted and locks in place and so far they have done their job. I use a lot of 3/4in wood and the clamps seem to hold them well enough on the one end.
summary: Small enough not to get in the way

reviewText: Delivered on time and in good condition.  Rechargeables holding up well and easy to charge.  My first time with this size battery, but I'm satisfied.

This is a great starter set of bungee cords. They are durable and have strong plastic hooks (except for the mini cords). They have a good mix of sizes, which are color-coded for convenience. You get:1 - 40"1 - 32"2 - 24"3 - 18"3 - mini2 - canopy strapsThe minis are probably better for use around the house, or maybe in the garage, but not for tie-downs. The canopy straps are basically a hard plastic ball with a bungee loop on it.Certainly not the best out there, but good enough and a smart mix of sizes. Also well worth the price. Recommended.
The nails were fine and functional, but the nails were not glued together like they normally are. A real pain when you're loading the nail gun. That's why I only give them 4 stars.

reviewerName: Tommie "An expert is a former drip under pres...
reviewText: The fan is attractive but very hard to install and operate. I had it professionally installed by a contractor who is used to hard work. When it proved to be too much for one person, another had to be called in. If I want to change the speed, I have to get a step stool and manfully (womanfully?) pull on the chain. It tips the fan almost sideways before it will engage. On the highest speed, the fan sways until I'm afraid it will work itself loose from the ceiling so I use either the lowest speed or the mid speed. I've had Hunter fans before that were great but I wouldn't buy another one of this type.

Blade is not serated, which I prefer. Solidly built and looks professional. What I like the most is that it is big enough to get the job done with basic tools, yet still small enough to fit in your pocket. I also like the clip on the side so it can clip over your pocket. I held off on purchasing this thinking with such a light looking frame it would not be durable, not so. You will not regret.

reviewerName: Joel K. Schooler "Retired On Active Duty (ROAD)"
reviewText: These batteries recharge well and do work in all types of flashlights.  However, I have 2 other Manufacturers batteries and they last longer and charge faster.

I replaced and older Broan brand with this Panasonic. It works fantastic. The old fan was rated at 110 CFM also, but the Panasonic seems to move more air - with less noise. Also the heater is two stage. When you first turn it on it blows on low speed until it heats up (about 30 seconds) and then kicks into high speed. Nice feature because it avoids getting blasted with cold air until the unit warms up. Overall a fantastic unit.

This is really light, and has an outstanding solid build construction.  The screw driver is very solid and tips are the most common sizes.Knife has a good clean edge to it, easy to open and locks open, and easy to close.Belt clip is nice to clip it into a pocket.Pliers are very strong.

Having a complete set such as the above will make a good addition to my tool bag. I will have all these bits if I come across any application needed to do the job at hand. Having a variety of sizes make sense and adapting to any situation that one would come across. This compact set is handy and small enough to be carried in my EDC or BOB . Been prepare is essential to handle any thing one come across in any situation.  Good price and USA Made unlike Made in China. BUY USA MADE Products..
summary: Bondhus 12533 GorillaGrip Hex and Star Fold-up Triple Pack, 12587 (2-8mm), 12589 (5/64-1/4-Inch) & 12634 (T9-T40)

reviewText: So, I was shopping for a small utility/multi tool that I could put on my belt, and have handy wherever I go, mostly at work. I tend to borrow my friend's a lot while at work, and was noticing how it was very handy, but the only features we ever use are the screwdriver, pliers, and on occasion I borrow his knife. Never use the little saw blade, fingernail file, can opener (except for once) or the cork puller.I also took note that most tools similar to his were pricey. However, I came across this one, which was both on the lower end of the price scale, and was a top of the line brand name. That, and it had all the tools I needed! The pliers, screwdriver, knife, and a bottle opener so I don;t have to use the one on my keychain all the time! (I like my Coca-Cola in the glass bottles). I thought it was a little too good to be true, and in places (Allsparetools website) it claims it is not going to ship until Spring of 2008 - so I was worried I would have to wait a month or two for it. However, it is shipping from Allsparetools already, because I got mine on March 8, 2008!I took it out, and played with it thoroughly, and am impressed! Just over 4 inches long folded, a hair over 6 inches unfolded, and has a 2 1/2 inch blade! The knife is on the outside, so you do not have to unfold it to use it (works like a pocket knife) and it kind of locks/clips in the folded position, so it does not feel like it is going to manage to fold out and cut something when not in use! It has a very nice look, feels solid and rugged, yet is light as well. Also, it came with a 5 inch tall Nylon pouch so it will attach to my belt. The pouch keeps it in place firmly, and has a velcro flap. The screwdriver is not hard to fold out, it is actually the end of one of the handles, and has a strong clip to secure the bit in place. Also, I love the combo bottle-opener/clip!Overall, I am very happy with this purchase, and I think I am going to send for a few more! Finally, a tool made for me! No bloat, just a solid tool!

We recently moved to a new home with a pool and were concerned about our little kids going in the backyard without our knowledge.  In our previous home we had an alarm system that chimed everytime any of the doors were opened, however this home is older and isn't wired for an alarm system.  We have the standard pool barrier around the pool to prevent kids from getting in, but knowing when the door to the pool opened is critical for peace of mind.This door knob is perfect as it can be set to chime anytime the door is opened or even touched!  The old knob popped right out and mounting this into the existing hole was easy.  The knob requires two AA batteries which Schlage claim will last for 3 years!The wife loved not only the fact that the door chimed everytime it was opened, but that the aged bronze matched the existing hardware (no hodge podge mix-n-match here!)While it's a new product I think we'll start to see more technology like this incorporated into home automation, etc and since Schlage includes a lifetime warranty I know this purchase will be covered by the industry leader in American locks.Looking to outfit the rest of the house with similar products given the success and ease of this one!
summary: Perfect door knob for our pool door

reviewText: After many years of tightening things by feel, I decided that as I was able to do more work on my cars that I would have a nice torque wrench for my toolbox.  I needed one pretty quickly because of some new aluminum wheels I was installing and didn't want to over-torque the wheels.  I picked this one, despite its relatively high cost because the digital readout with its instantaneous reading seemed very appealing and it had a nice range of 20-150 ft/lbs.The tool itself is long (as all torque wrench are) which can be an issue in tight quarters or even if you're torquing lug nuts since it will bump into the fenders at most angles.  But the advantage of the length is that you can be much smoother when tightening which is essential to getting an accurate torque reading.  For lug nuts either a deep socket or an extended will be necessary on most cars.The tool seems made well, and work well.  The plastic body leads me to treat this a bit gingerly, but I don't know that its necessary. I suspect I will drop it at some point accidentally and I'll know for sure).  It requires 3 AA cells which are not included.  The instructions provided are brief and to the point.You set the appropriate scale (ft/lbs or nt/m) and then set the desired torque amount.  The numbers are shown on a backlit LCD display.  As you use the tool, there are 3 LEDs that tell you what's happening.  Green means you're applying torque, yellow means you're close (within 20%) and when you hit the red led and you hear a beep, it means you're hit it.  The tool will display torque applied as its being used and will display peak torque.It couldn't be simpler.The one flaw comes from the auto-off feature.  The tool will power off in a couple of minutes, which is fine, but when it does, it forgets everything, most annoyingly the target torque you've set.  Its not a huge deal, but every time you set the tool down and come back to it, you start all over again.  It didn't seem right so I looked through the manual and there seems no way to save your torque.That said, the tool works very well at what it does. I just wish it wouldn't forget the torque settings so easily.
summary: Easy to use, but it has some annoying flaws

reviewText: New 18 volt portable saw. Uses the new slide type battery, with available power. Suggest using only the 3.0 batteries for additional time. Very satisfied with the operation & quality of this 18 volt portable saw.
summary: Perfect saw to keep with you.

reviewText: Had a friend with one come over to show me how to operate the ladder. Very flexible design which appears to be all the rage now.  Well constructed, a bit heavy though.  One does need to watch out regarding pinching fingers when operating the ladder.

I've used Bosch 4410L over 3 years. But I haven't had any problem yet.I don't understand some people complaining about quality problems.The cut is so smooth that if you use 60T or higher, don't need sanding on cut side. And the cut is extremely accurate all the time.When I purchased this unit, I saw one comparison test. The test used 6 different brand miter saws and made hectagon with 1x4. All other saws created big gap between first and last pieces, but Bosch made it perfect.The cut is very accurate all the time and also has a function for micro adjustment too. There are multiple power switches on the handle that I can use either left or right hand.Slider is very solid. It never shake or get stiff to operate.Dust collection is not working well but I think this problem is same on all other miter saws. Saw itself diffuses dust to all direction, so there is no way to collect it all from one direction.Dual beveling is a real time saver in crown moulding jobs and it's easy to operate. Frequently used angles are already set up in the saw, it saves time and can get accurate cut too.When working with other finish carpenters, my Bosch always cut all the pieces more precise than DeWalt and Makita.I believe this is the best miter saw on the market.
As stated, the seat it very nice and made of quality materials. It is very easy to install and easy to keep clean.
summary: Very nice and easy to clean.

reviewText: Good airflow and not a power drain. Has powered two framing nailers but need to give compressor a breather when going fast.  While using one framing nailer no problems even while using the hitachi pneumatic stapler for fastening sheathing. Also good air supply for cleaning tools and inflating tires.

We ordered these screwdrivers to open up the hard drive enclose on a broken 360 so we could use it with our new 360 Slim. Be aware, if you are wanting these tools for this reason that these are not the right size. They are too big to open the hard drive enclosure. There is nothing wrong with the tools themselves, but the product description is a bit misleading, as this is certainly not a "complete" disassembly kit.

I got rid of my Lithiumm battery flashlight,it was costing me to much to replace them.With AAA size battery it was inexpensive.Dorcy Flashlight is also durable,I drop it on my basement floor and no damage to it,especially the Cree light.Its reliable,small,AAA size battery cost less then a lithium battery.The Cree light (200 lumen) is ver bright.I got two,one for each car.I am planning of ordering a third one for me to carry,when I am taking a walk around the park,along with my sword cane.Thanks for a great product.

I've used many brands of drills over the years and this is the best I've had. It  has a comfortable grip, good balance, lots of power and compared to my DeWalt cordless it seems to never need re-charging. Good product.

The battery was shipped quickly and arrived promptly.  I installed it in my home alarm system and it works.  I'll probably have to replace it in another 5-7 years.  The price was considerably lower than local retail sources.  What's not to like?

Welcome to winter hunting in NW Ohio... needing WARM gloves to shoot with that can blend with my Multicam rig I improvised with these.Knowing that Mechanix run a tad large (as the size medium of Mechanix mpt-72-009 md; m-pact glove fit snug). I ordered these in large knownig they would be loose and flex without the added padding the m-pact have. I now can wear my Under Armour - Cold Gear Liner gloves (with awesome grip) inside these and have the added layer to protect again the cold while still being able to sight in my rifle and draw & fire my Glock with ease.Problem solved
summary: Improvised solution to cold weather problem

reviewText: I wash dishes several times a day & clean around the house daily. Last week i noticed that my hands have been really dry and started to itch. I decided to start wearing gloves while doing dishes and cleaning. I have very small hands, the size small fits me perfectly. The rubber gloves from the supermarket are too big, get water in them and tear too easily. I don't mind paying a little more for thicker better quailty gloves.

I use this for coax connections and for refurbishing my TV remote contacts.  I like this stuff and it's why I bought a big bottle of it.  It needs very little and it goes a long ways.  I just never want to be without it.
I have used this rope for many different applications and it has never let me down. From tying by boat to the dock to tying something on top of my car, to lifting things, it works great.

I've owned a few bondhus folding allen wrench sets over the years and they were always the best quality of the type.  This torx set is even better.  the tools are properly hardened and tempered and the fit it perfect in the screws in my knives.  T6, t8, and t10 are quite common and the t6 is hard to find in a tool that isn't ridiculously soft to the point of twisting the end off (like my craftsman screwdriver in t6 that I bought specifically for this purpose)
High quality hose. Tough. No leaks. Should last a long time. Does pick up/show dirt etc. but it's easy to see the hose on the floor and lays flat.

I got these for my first aid kit and they are highly rated so I thought great replace the silly plastic tweezers with these.  First they are very, very tiny.  If you have large hands you will get frustrated trying to use these.  Also, they are so small they disappear in my kit and are hard to locate.  I decided to put them in a long zip lock bag and mark it so I can find them in an emergency.  Basically it is a piece of steel rounded without any springs and nothing special.**These would be great for a backpack where ounces count but the size and the design are not desirable for anything else I can think of.I won't buy these again but it's not worth sending back.
I bought this originally for a single project (window seat) and it was so easy to use I've been using it for other projects around the house too. Definitely recommend.
summary: Bought as a weekender, now looking for more projects to use it on

reviewText: This strip of LED lights was disappointing, I expected much brighter lights. The light output is just barely the equivalent of a 40W light spread out over about three feet. For underneath a cabinet in the kitchen, that is a fairly dim light that just barely fills in the shadows. The color of the light is very close to a regular light bulb, just slightly warmer.The kit is as pictured, three strips of LED lights encased in a clear plastic, the wall wart with an on/off switch (very handy), and two short connector wires. The kit also includes a mounting bag including double sided tape, some screws, and clear plastic U shaped clips. There are no instructions included in the box.The quality of this kit is excellent. The plastic is crystal clear and the strips look well built. Each light strip has an open end for the electrical connector. The opposite end is covered with a tiny clear plastic plug. To attach the strips together, remove that plug. The strips can be connected together directly and form one long solid bar, or the wire connectors can be added (two wires can be connected together to make a longer flexible connection).Assembly and mounting was very simple. For my application, the double sided tape worked perfectly.The lights are a lot dimmer than I expected. Although LED Christmas lights might not be as discreet, they give off way more light than these bars and are a lot cheaper. The other problem is the light cast by these bars. Because these bars are made up of a bunch of light sources, each lamp creates a shadow. If the light is pointed directly down on the counter, each object has about six different shadows. The effect is really ugly.For a kitchen under counter application, these lights are way too dim. For mood lighting, or a night light, these are perfect. This will work out just fine for my vinyl LP station in the basement. These have just enough light so that I can see if the records are clean, but not so bright that it is annoying.Overall, this is not a bad kit. I was hoping to replace a band of fluorescent under counter lights with these. Unfortunately, they are way too dim for that purpose.

This is a good one for wedging under the door when you are AT HOME, (or in your hotel room too, for it will travel easily with you) (oops, but do turn it OFF and maybe remove the batteries if you pack it).  You'll just want to remember to turn it off before you open your door to leave, or for guests.  This WILL startle the bad guy, get your attention, and your neighbor's attention also.
It's a little cheap feeling and the ratchet isn't as fine as I would have liked for times when you have limited range of motion.
summary: It works but isn't as solid as I had expected

reviewText: I currently have several comparable electric screw drivers I keep around the house. But this one added some new features that none of the other screw drivers had, so I decided to add this one to the collection to see how well it did. So far, it has worked quite well.As far as power, this is your standard B&D; 3.6V rechargable screw driver and is about on par with the competition. For light duties around the house, it'll do just fine. Just keep in mind these aren't drills or high powered screw drivers. If you find that it runs out of power, you probably need a more powerful unit.The light works. But just barely. It's not very bright, but does help out in certain situations. It will also dim if the screw driver starts to have to work harder than usual. It also features a swivel adjustment so it can be used as a normal straight screw driver or at an angle as pictured. However, since it is rather bulky in either configuration, I normally just kept it in the angle position.It's very easy to grip and hold on to thanks to the rubber moldings at key locations. It's also light weight and even has a place for 1 extra bit. Battery life, also right about average for other B&D; 3.6v screw drivers. Just charge it up over night and it'll last quite awhile. Li-Ion would be nice, but that would also cost a lot more. For basic use around the house, fast charge times and super long life aren't a priority. At least not with this model!One important feature that's missing is a torque setting. This prevents me from using it with more sensitive electronics where even 3.6V can be too much. But at this price point, I guess you can't expect too much!Pros:* Built-in Light* 2 Angle Adjustement* Descent battery life* Rechargable battery* Powerful enough for most jobs around the houseCons:* No Torque Setting* Somewhat bulkyOverall considering it's price and features, I would recommend this screw driver.

I have only had this for a few days now but so far it has worked great. Its already been through a couple of rains and still working. I have a really old house and total distance from the door is probably about 25 feet or so. There is no line of sight, its going through a back room area, through the kitchen and into the living room on an angle and its worked great so far. Goes off every single time!

I started off by purchasing the Kreg R3 Jr. Pocket Hole Jig. I spent too much time trying to decide between this and the full kit.  The low price convinced me to start with this one.First, the kit and case are amazing.  The case has spots for holding the jig, bit and drill.  The case also has the adjustments and measurements on the side for knowing where to position the stop collar on the drill bit.You set the drill bit and stop and you adjust the legs on the drill jig to your material thickness.  Then you clamp the jig onto your material (little feet on the legs go over the end of the material).  I started by using my own clamps.  You then drill the hole.Because the jig guides the drill bit, I was even able to let my 7 year old drill the pocket holes.  The wood chips come out of the holes in the jig so you don't have to go back and forth to clear it. Clamp the two pieces of wood together and drive with the nice long square drive bit included and it will actually pull the wood together.The system is actually much more flexible than I thought when purchasing it. What I didn't realize was the legs can come off the jig and can be positioned so the feet don't hook over the wood but instead can fit into a corner to do repair or retrofit work. They even have a size guide on the other side for just that reason.We actually had so much fun working on projects that I ended up buying the K4 system as well. This is a good thing.  You end up with an extra bit and extra drill and a jig that you can position anywhere. Buying one actually makes you want the other.ProsIt does what it says remarkably wellOutstanding case / you will want to keep it in there foreverGreat starter system that's still useful if you decide to upgradeLow costConsThe screws aren't free (but aren't ridiculous either)The jig isn't as wide as the bigger system so for wider boards (say 3 inches) you have to reclamp the jig on both sides instead of drilling both without reclampingOverall one of those purchases that brought a smile to my face.  It made me want to do more projects. It is a real winner.

reviewerName: Wood B. Hermit "Seeker of the one pure and cl...
reviewText: I purchased an original Verilux desk lamp by mail order more than ten years ago and it has really proven itself to be an extremely reliable task light while consistently being used for at last 12 hours every day (7 days per week) and emitting a most productive type of bright white light that mimics natural daylight.The lamp has only required a bulb change once every 2-3 years and this bulb right here is the one that I have always purchased. Never any problems with this original quality Verilux replacement bulb; this is now my third time purchasing this item from Amazon.com.You can usually tell when a bulb replacement is in the offing since the bottom section of one or more of the four fluorescent tubes will start to turn dark.That's just the right time to order a replacement bulb via Amazon Prime two-day delivery in order to be prepared when the bulb finally gives up the ghost in the very near future.
summary: Quality, reliable bulbs and lamps for long-term use

reviewText: The Kreg system is great. I've ordered a wide range of products online because my local sources are either too far from my house or have a lousy supply. All Kreg products I have used are well designed, we made and easy to use.
I love this solar light!! It is really good and brightens up our dark driveway. My neighbors even love it because it shines on there side.

The LCD is great when you need to have a precise idea where the studs are. I used this over drywall and the only problem i had, being an old house with uneven 'bulging' walls, it messes up the sensor if you lift it off the service. Also, when you calibrate it, make sure you do that in a few different spots, otherwise you might be calibrating it over a stud!Hope that helps!

This is a very nice looking fan, especially for the price.  The installation directions were very clear, and I encountered no issues during the installation.  I did have to replace the ceiling electrical box with one that is fan rated.  I also installed the Westinghouse 7787500 wireless control unit (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000WEIJ8O/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_14) and it worked great with this fan.
