reviewText: I would have rated this a 5 star but when I saw the manufacture date as being in the middle of 2009, I was disappointed. Why is Amazon selling 2 year old batteries???????????? The date is stamped on the battery.

I've had this fence for a week now and have had time to use it a bit. These are my impressions based on what I observed during the installation and using it for the past week.Installation - there are two brackets that hold the front fence rail to the saw. I have a Jet contractor's saw, and the brackets didn't line up with the pre-existing holes on the front of the saw. The brackets are about an inch closer together than the holes, which means one bracket slides on completely while the other is barely over the hole. Instead of boring out and tapping new holes, I went with that. Boring out and tapping would also have to be done too close to the existing hole. The back rail went on just fine, and the fence went together very easily. When I brought the fence right up to the blade to set the "0" mark on the indicator, I found that there wasn't enough play to adjust the indicator window to the "0" mark. Instead, I had to peel the measuring tape off the front rail and move it down about half an inch, after which I could zero out the fence.Performance - overall, I'm very pleased with the performance of the fence. It slides along the rails easily and locks down securely using the main locking mechanism. The fence is rock solid with very little deflection. One thing I would like to have seen are fence sides, either laminated MDF or UHMW. They include long wood screws for anyone who would like to add an auxiliary fence side.There are two locking mechanisms on the fence: The big main one and a smaller one for use with the micro-adjuster. The way you use the micro-adjuster is you lock the fence down with the small lever, then release the big lever. This frees you up to make micro adjustments to the fence position. When you have dialed in the correct distance, you then lock the big lever down and unlock the small lever. The micro-adjuster locking mechanism on mine slips very easily, however. When I lock the small lever down and start dialing, sometimes the fence stays put and the micro-adjuster moves. If I push the fence from side to side while the small lever is locked down, it moves with little effort. I am going to see if cleaning with mineral spirits and roughing up the locking cam with some sandpaper will fix this.Overall, I think this fence is pretty good. It's certainly better than the stock Jet Fence that came with my saw (bigger, beefier, and more solid). I gave it a 3 only because it didn't fit my saw properly (which is a common saw) right out of the box and the micro-adjuster slippage. Otherwise, I'd recommend this fence to anyone upgrading from a stock fence.
summary: Good fence for a good price

reviewText: Never thought I'd consider spending a lot on an item such as this. But after I received it, I really like knowing it's ACCURATE!! For that reason alone, it was worth the price.

I bought this to help with installing some heavy-duty floating shelves. They did the trick for smaller bits, but it's hard to keep in place by hand with larger speed-bore type bits (which was half the reason I needed this thing to begin with). While I'll allow this may not be the right tool for that scenario (and shouldn't mark it down for that), the holding in place aspect still stands. I wonder if it's be better if it were a little longer so I could grab a hold of more of it while drilling?
summary: A solid helper, but with some limitations.

reviewText: It does everything it's advertised to do and does it well.  Light level is easy to control, it has one "preset" dimming level, and the remote works well.One thing they don't mention that I love is it's stable with varying voltages.  We have central A/C and lots of line voltage variations in general, and with the previous dimmer, the lights would always be changing in brightness - quite distracting in a media room when trying to watch a movie!  With this dimmer, the brightness is rock solid - it stays where you set it.  MUCH better!

I'm just a homeowner that likes to do as much of my own work as possible.  I'd say I'm an decent intermediate woodworker and cabinet maker, not a pro by any means.  I'm in the middle of remodeling a kitchen and bathroom and will be making some new base cabinets among other things.  Stock fences have always been a problem for me so, I decided to take the plunge and buy the Vega fence.  I picked up a beautiful old Craftsman 10" saw last year for $100 (model 113.29920, made in 1956 according to Sears).  You know, the ones with the nice heavy cast iron table and side extensions (they don't make 'em like that anymore).  So, this fence was more than double the price of my saw, and so far it's worth every penny!!It took me a couple of hours to set-up from the time I opened the box but that's no fault of the Vega fence.  I was proceeding very deliberately so as not to screw it up.  After removing the stock front fence rail, the Vega front tube brackets lined right up on the existing holes.  I only had to drill two 5/16" holes in my table for the back fence mounting tube.  They definitely thought this design out and it shows.  Once you square the fence up to a miter slot, you crank down on four heavy socket head machine screws to secure the fence to the very solid head.  There's plenty of adjustments all around to fine tune the clearance above the bed (about 1/16" seemed to work for me) and to get the scale zeroed out. When you have everything set and cranked down, I can't see things being able to move out of adjustment.  Every piece is very solid, the fence rides smoothly on the tubes and all adjustments are easily accessible.The unit arrived by UPS Ground and was very well packaged and protected in a heavy cardboard box, stapled securely and further protected with heavy cardboard spacers and 2x4 wood blocking inside the shipping box.  I agree that the instructions leave a lot to be desired.  But, it's a very logical set-up and not that hard to scope out.  If I can do it, I think most anybody with a reasonable degree of tool sense can do it just as well or better.  Love that it's made in the USA!All in all it was a fun afternoon and now my old saw makes dead-on cuts including ripping an 8' 2x4 just to see how things worked - right on the money the entire length.  The scale is pretty easy to fine-tune to a high degree of accuracy if you take your time.  The micro-adjustment is a very nice feature and works smoothly after a little break-in time (a little stiff at first but limbered up nicely after only a couple of uses).  I am very pleased with the sturdy construction and ease of use.  I hope this is helpful to anyone considering this fence.  I would buy it again and would recommend to a friend.  Now, to build some new table extensions and get started on those cabinets.
summary: New life for an old saw

reviewText: there are areas of my yard where there isnt much sun exposure. i want light without wires but solar isnt going to work too well i imgaine. so i purchased this. so far it works fine. i used entergizer alkaline batteries in it. it has been mounted to a tree for at least 3 days maybe more. it still works. coverage area is real nice too. i would have to say this is a good buy. i have two already and ordered 3 more. i am determined to have my yard with light without all the wires running to my house. this product helps me with that.

This is the first time I've installed a garage door opener.  We had an existing Chamberlian in the garage, so I think that saved quite a lot of work.  This took my wife and I about 5 hours to install.  If we would have had to install from scratch, I would estimate it would have taken about twice that long.The drive is super quiet, much more quiet than our old one (which was about 10 years old).  Installation instructions were clear and reasonably easy to follow for the most part.  All parts fit together as described.  Overall this was a good upgrade from our old one.  Here are some pros/consPros:1. Ultra quiet and smooth belt operation2. The key access opener is a great feature and should come in handy when someone needs in the house that doesn't have a key3. Programming the opener is straight forward (finding the stopping point for the opening and closing of the garage).4. The motion detection for having the lights come on works wellCons:1. The belt drive is about 9" shorter than our old opener.  Because of this, the garage door does not open all the way like our old one used to.  I don't know if that's just the way this one is supposed to work, but we lose about 7" in the opening of our garage now.  Not an issue with the cars we have, but I was surprised by this when we were all done with the installation2. The belt sags a lot when opening the garage door.  At times, the belt can actually twist slightly sideways and get caught under the pulley drive at the end of the run.  It will eventually correct itself when the garage door is closed, but I wonder if this will eventually cause pre-mature wear on the belt because it is rubbing against things.  Maybe this is OK and part of the design, but as far as I can tell, we installed it correctly, and there are no adjustments than can be made to correct for this.  I guess time will tell here.3. So far I am unable to get the homelink function in my 2012 Subaru to connect to the opener.  I will keep trying, but I would not call this a deal breaker.Overall I like this opener and it's a nice upgrade from our old model.
summary: Great quality opener with some nice features

reviewText: One of our baths is an art deco modern with retro accents.  The existing wall light sconce is something you may have found on a theater wall in the 1930s.  However one of the glass pieces broke and until we can figure out a way to have another piece made the fixture had to be taken down.As inexpensive at this light fixture is it does a great job of complementing our décor.  The chrome part does not look like a cheap fixture; it has the look and feel of heavy highly polished chrome.  And the glass globes also look and feel very solid.  They do an excellent job of diffusing the light.  Rather than use thumbscrews the globes are attached with a large nut that screws around the bulb socket, so it is 100% secure and can't possibly work loose.  Although the manufacturer illustrates the globes as having their open end pointed downward, because of the way they are attached it is also possible to point the open end toward the wall (or even upward if you wish).  It gives the fixture an entirely different look while also completely hiding the bulb from view.  By the way, it uses two candelabra bulbs rather than standard bulbs.The rest of the fixture is pretty ordinary; the only thing worth noting is that high quality materials are used throughout.  If you like the design, this light fixture can give your room a new look for a very low price.  The fifth star, in fact, was earned because of the high value for the money.
summary: An excellent value for the price

reviewText: This is the perfect size and easy to hold and clamp into tight spaces.  Since there are two readout displays, the display is rather small and can be tricky to read in dimly lit conditions, such as when crawling around with a flashlight in a dark attic.  I like this probe, but I recommend instead one of models with a larger backlit display such as the Amprobe ACD-15.
summary: Nice multimeter, but the display is small

reviewText: i bought this drill because of the 9 amps,  screw in handle and the great reviews. got it and burnt the first one up in two days of moderate to heavy use. im hoping it was just a bad drill. waiting on the replacement now

This is very easy to install on a wood floor.  The down side, you need to drill through your nice wood floor.  But it's quick and easy to install.  This will accommodate thresholds that stick out a bit, as the part that slides in can be place right side up (to give room for a threshold that sticks out) or upside down (to push right up against the door if no threshold is in place).  It glides in the holder very smoothly as well.The plate is a mild eyesore, but you can see at a glance whether it's installed or not.  I like it more than a 2x4 bar across the door, though it's only going to secure the bottom of your door.  If someone keeps kicking it in, eventually the hinges at the top will fail.I'm using this on a double door because there are not too many options to reinforce the mating seam between doors.  I wish they had something similar for the top of the door, but that may end up being a fire hazard if you have kids or shorter adults in the house.  Overall, highly recommended for the price and ease of installation though.  About 3 minutes to install if you know how to drill.  Setting in concrete or tile might take special tools and take longer though.

Ordered this item, but received 6pc Diamond Hole Saw Set instead. They are tiny hole saws. Not sure why someone would want a hole saw that small when they could just drill a hole, but whatevs. Probably not worth trying to return given the price.I still want a wheel set though...

I was pleasantly surprised to find that this item is a two-pack of clamps rather than a single.  I have used them on a recent project and after I figured out how to adjust them, they worked perfectly.  Highly recommended.  They are easy to move around and tighten/loosen off.  I had some trouble using them on the bench dog holes closest to my bench edge but that's because the lip of the table got in the way of the adjustment piece on the threaded section.
summary: Great item, and two to a pack

reviewText: Looking for a disposable brush for a quick job that you can just toss? You've found 'em! I use these in my woodshop for applying glue in smaller/tight spots, and then just toss 'em when done.Highly recommended if you're in search of a similar solution.

I expect Mag lights will come with LED bulbs one day, not only do they seem brighter and draw a less current than the standard bulbs (so the batteries last longer), they will not break if the light is dropped or receives a hard bump like the standard bulbs do.
summary: Big improvement over the OEM bulb.

reviewText: THE IMPACT WRENCH WORKS REALLY WELL. SLIGHTLY HEAVY, BUT I GUESS THAT'S TO BE EXPECTED (WELL BUILT). THE BATTERY LIFE IS SOMEWHAT SHORT, BUT THERE IS ENOUGH JUICE IN ONE BATTERY TO TAKE OFF AND REPLACE FOUR TIRES. THE SECOND BATTERY COMES IN HANDY. I WOULD RFECOMMEND THIS PRODUCT.  ALWAYS MAKE SURE THE SECOND BATTERY IS CHARGED. I WOULD HAVE GIVEN FIVE STARS IF THE BATTERY CHARGE LASTED LONGER, BUT IT IS SUFFICIENT. NOT A PROBLEM! ALSO VERY NICE CASE.
It would be 5* for the money if the prongs were polarized.  It's a grounding plug with the slots not polarized.  This encourages some dangerous behavior from the inexperienced user.  SAFETY ISSUE
This lamp will give your room a nice warm glow if its the only light on.Great for creating a nostalgic look on an existing lamp or make your own lamp .

Mine came with one battery labeled 'UltraFire 4000' and one labeled 'AfuntA 2700 mAh' After the first charge, I ran both batteries with a resistive load discharge and got less than 1000 mAh out of each. If you are using this in a Cree T6 type light, you will get about 45 minutes of bright light.45 minutes of really bright light is not bad for a Cree T6.I did not have time to do a complete test. If these are indeed knock-offs, they probably do not have the low voltage cut off circuit. That means (if true) you will be able to discharge these batteries well below the recommended cut off voltage and that will possibly prevent them from being recharged, in a standard quick charger.Charge them often and they will keep your light going.

I wouldn't buy this unless you want to buy 2 of them. They work well I just think you need one on each end to make sure your joint is really 90 degrees personally and they are pretty expensive but you have to admit Kregg makes good stuff.
summary: a lot smaller than I expected

reviewText: I have had a lot of these nut driver sets, including some older DeWalt and newer Milwaukee.  This set holds and drives the screws and nuts as good or better than the several I've owned and used.  So far, the durability is better than most. This is the first set I've gotten with a 1/2" socket, as most off the sleeve sets don't have it.  I really like having that 1/2" driver for driving small lag screws.  Another nice feature is the socket size lables on them, which show even in dim light.It could only be better if it included a metric set too.  I could really use a good 10 MM driver.

This is a great tool belt and not only for electricians. I am a handy man and I find myself going to my tool belt quite often when I know of the any small job I may be tackling rather than grabbing all my tools that I may not all need. The belt itself is strong enough to hold my drill holster. Its a great buy.

I had thought about ordering one before the holidays as it was in stock. I was short on money and had to wait until the new year. When I did, it was out of stock with a 1-2 month delivery. I ordered anyway and received it within a few weeks. It arrived as described. Would recommend.My only complain is some of the pieces don't fit into the clamshell very well and are difficult to get out and put back into their places. They are marring the case so it will eventually have a hole.I don't know if this is a complaint or normal with these types of tools (because this is my first) but the tap wrench becomes loose and must be tightened several times during a tapping event. One handle tightens one way and the other in reverse so as you tighten one, the other loosens. I fixed this by putting threadlock on the one that is supposed to be stationary.
summary: Wonderful product at an awesome price!

reviewText: I use this almost every day.  I gave to to a friend for his birthday.  This is lightweight can hold a lot of tools, and has compartments for fasteners.
I've used this to hold small work pieces while filing and/or grinding, and it's worked ok.  I noticed that if I secure the work piece at the end of the jaws, it doesn't grip them very well though.

I bought this saw some years ago, before I had discovered Amazon. This saw has more than enough power. Even when powered down to a slow number of strokes for increased control it muscles through. The quick change tool less blade changer has worked great. On occasion I will get a blade that is not cut quite right and I have to knock the burrs off. Never has happened yet with high quality blades. You can turn the dust blower on or off. On helps you see your pencil line. The orbital feature settings are great for faster cutting. I think when cutting thicker metal the orbital feature helps the blade last longer, as long as you don't force feed it. The long stroke also helps blade life by using more of the blade's teeth rather than a few teeth doing all of the work. The base will pivot for miter cuts and has stops. I did have to tighten the hex bolt on the base once. With repeated use it was looser and would not hold the bevel lever in place. After tightening, it was ok again. I bought a rip fence for it (Dewalt 1004501-00). The rip fence will allow rips from 1 and 1/2 inches to 7 inches wide. I love this little saw.
This is a great little vice.  I installed it on one of my workbenches and add some wood inserts inside the jaws of the vice to protect the clamped material.  Good quality vice.

Admittedly, there are many companies that make quality router bits. Buying from any of them should be a good purchase. I can never understand someone buying router bits that are a fraction of this cost.....do you really want a hunk of inferior metal spinning that fast by your hands and face???Buy the best, and you'll have it for life.I personallly have about 45-50 CMT router bits and/or router sets. I also own some Freud, Infinity, Sommerfeld and Whiteside (they are all great companies), MLCS and Rockler bits; in my opinion, are junk.It's better to buy a few really quality bits than a bunch of cheap bits that give inferior cuts.
This nylon spudger works exactly as advertised, but it is very overpriced at $5 each. The sharp tip end does get dull after extended use.

I love this system. It was a little bit of effort to install because I had to get a pressure regulator for it  (which are not cheap +- $50) but well worth it! I can taste the difference when I drink filtered water compared to the regular tap water! After seeing how dirty the filter was after a few months, I am very glad I got this system.

Really liked this timer. I bought it to make sure my 1500 watt heater was turned off in my shop. At least one review said it was great for heaters. I should have paid more attention when I got it out of the box. It's a 1000 watt unit. My fault I killed it but it would have been awesome if it could handle a 1500 watt oil heater.I docked a star - not for the unit but for the specs on amazon. It should really say what it's capacity is.

reviewerName: D. Deutsch "Chance favors the prepared mind."
reviewText: I recently replaced a Moen Positemp cartridge. Pulling the old cartridge was difficult and it may pay to invest in the cartridge puller despite the expense. I actually bent the stem on install and needed to replace my replacement. As long as you go slowly and carefully the process is actually pretty painless. Also make sure to keep the side gaskets in place as you push the cartridge in. I found mine on Ebay for pretty cheap, $20, as opposed to my local hardware store which sold them for $60.

The price of blades for these tools is ridiculous. This package is fairly reasonable and the blades are of good quality. Just remember that if you hit a nail it's history....regardless what the blade is supposed to cut.
summary: This is the only way I can afford to buy blades for this tool.

reviewText: Arrived on time and was easy to install. Light is enough for the room we are using it in. Now we can turn on the light as you enter the room instead of entering a dark room and going to the lamp on a table to light up the room. Fits the decor and the price can't be beat.
summary: Just what we needed for the room

reviewText: work well seem to be built well so it should lasti would buy again if this set went missing
Not much you can say except they work well even on heavy furniture.  Makes moving large chairs and couches on carpeting a snap.  Good Value.
summary: Works for what they designed for.

reviewText: This thing is really light and took me all of about 20 seconds to unfold and lock in place.  It feels a little wobbly with nothing on it but I now have about a dozen different boxes on it from top to bottom and it's not going anywhere.  The top shelf folding over is kinda neat and I can see it making this thing versatile in the future.It appears they sell the feet separately for $20.  I have this on a carpet so I don't need them but if you are going to put this on a bare floor you should consider getting them.
Excellent product, I have owned these for quite some time now and they have performed quite well. I can recommend these easily.
No complaints. Easy on the hands, well-padded grip, and the working surfaces are sharp and well-tooled. A great tool for the price.

I havent had mine very long so it gets 4 stars .I have fired 1/2" , 3/4" , and 1" staples in various materials without fail thus far . I strenghtened a 250 year old dresser made of old oak and hickory ( no jams ) .I wish it had a empty mag lockout and was oiless but I can live with these gripes .I favor the double action trigger and have not had any double fires to date. I run 80 psi line pressure and then use the depth wheel for tuning further ( If firing lots of staples on rapid fire it will creep a little. In all I love this unit ( Mine came with 1000 1" staples ),oil and a case.

Having used this tool for one year, I definitely recommend this 90degree angle drill. Whether you are a homeowner who occasionally need a power drill/screw driver or a DIY or a trademan, this tool is for you. It is versatile in tight confined spaces, too. It has enough torque for most screws, otherwise pre-drill a hole is just as easy and prevents shearing off the connector with a higher torque power tool.
Suggest you read those reviews before you buyAO Safety 90541 WorkTunes AM/FM Hearing Protector with Digital Tuning and MP3 Input
summary: These are the same as the poorly reviewed WorkTunes

reviewText: Wera knows how to make screwdrivers and bits - they are the best I've owned.To me screwdrivers are a tool I wear out pretty frequently.  I pry with them, I hit them with a hammer.  I grind them into different shapes.  So I go through a set of screwdrivers over time.For years I got by with a set of clear plastic handled Craftsman screwdrivers.  Then I found a used set of hard-handled Snap-ons which were good, but a bit uncomfortable in my hand.  Then I just started buying the Cheapo StanleysThen I found a set of German screwdrivers - my first set was a set of Felos and they are very very good.  Recently I picked up this set of Wera's and they are the best yet.  The Wera handle fits my hand like it was made for it.  I've never held a screwdriver which I can get a grip on like these.  They seem to be made of high quality steel, and at least early on the etching seems to work.  The only downside is the green seems to show dirt pretty prominently.  They clean up pretty easily.  .

Very easy to use instead of using a screwdriver or nut driver.  However, you can't tighten too hard or probably take loose multiple times, it feels as though the plastic would break on the keys if used too much or too hard.

I bought this lock set to be used on my security door that I bought from Home Depot.  This lock set was very easy to install.  There seems to be a bit of play, or give, in the handle that I don't like.  Enough to make me wonder if I couldn't snap the handle if I applied enough force.  This is why I gave it three stars.  The deadbolt turns a little harder than I am used to, but that may be because it is new.  It looks very nice and I am confident that it is secure, especially the deadbolt.  I would probably purchase this product again.  The color of the security door is copper and this lock set matches perfectly with it.
This is my second unit which I will use an my second investment property that only has a heater. Real simple and clean.

I used it to re-upholster a motorcycle seat, and it worked great. No problems. Don't expect the fit and finish of a precision-engineered tool; remember this tool was made as cheaply as possible. However, you can expect it to perform very well for the price.
I like this stuff, it's easy to work and doesn't get lumpy, sands nice and quick.  Just prep properly and apply in thin coats, sand almost all of it off and do again til you get it right.

I like this "fake" candle, a lot.  I was looking for something that wasnot annoying to have in the TV room, so you could still see and notbash your shins on the coffee table and not distract from the movieyou're watching.This is excellent around little children. No worries about candles/openflame.  Actually, this makes a great night light for baby/kids rooms thatyou can leave on.My only complaint is that you have to pick up the unit to push the onbutton on the bottom of the base.Not a big deal, but if you have both hands full that's not an easything to do.  Otherwise, it functions great, even has a slight flicker to theLED light.Want a different colored base?  Unscrew the clear shell from the baseand pull off the "yellow" color shell, use some painter's tape to cover theworking mechanisms/light and paint it with some spray paint for plastic furniture.Worked for me, but do it at your own risk.Make certain you get the correct spray paint or it will remain tacky, FOREVER!

I like the style, brightness and just about everything about these except they seem to be incompatable with my older 12 volt, halogen track lights.  My current system users 5 halogen bulbs but when i replace all with this bulb I get a flicker.  Keeping at least one of the older bulbs seems to take care of the problem but i would rather use all the same.  Please comment on this posting if you have any suggestions.  I plan to keep the bulbs and check for compatibility with newer fixtures.

I Bought Many Packs of this one and many packs of the Waxman 4738495N Round Gripper Pads, Black, 1-1/2-Inch and now I have so many packs of these things I'm set.They both are fantastic, and let furniture and Décor slide stably so they don't tip over. Some things just stand straight and the minute you bang the table it falls, that's because it needs these things.This one allows sliding and so does the other one I got but it's also good for sponging and gentle grips, padding and protecting.The Gripper I bought may be a wrong name and should be slider or sponger or protector, but it's wonderful and everyone needs this one and that one as far as I'm concerned, just get the gripping from someone else.Just today I used this one for a furniture unit that is against the wall, and even these stop it from sliding because the unit is heavy. These Pads are thick and hard to cut so you know it's great. And so I'm set and thank you Waxman.
summary: Big Thick and Sturdy, The Way I Like Them.

reviewText: I love this drill... I've been using it since 2004, but I did just buy a new one - just to have.  The power is great, the feel of the handle is really nice for reaching up and bending down.  The best part of this drill (besides the 8 amps) is the carbide-teeth endowed keyless chuck.  All metal construction, and it will hold on to any bit as if its life depended on it.  Plus it unlocks super easy, just turn slightly to the right, and then back to the left to release.One time I had an issue with the chuck (it happens), and Milwaukee was quick to replace it and get it right back to me.  Great customer service!
This is absolute junk. Placed in a drill press these bits wobble.  They're not straight. Quality is garbage. Dont waste you money.

Not much to say that hasn't already been said by most of the other reviewers. These are good, calm night lights. Single LED in each unit, so nothing super bright, but enough to give a nice little circle of light (for me, on the floor) and a very cool line pattern on the ceiling from the light shining through the top vents. I got two 4-packs for a total of 8 units and placed them in every outlet in my upstairs common area. Kinda feels like I'm in a theater at home. Photocells are fairly sensitive so they will turn off when they should, for the most part. Anyway, good units!
summary: Majority of reviewers are right, MLN-10 are good

reviewText: Instead of buying the Chamberlain kit, I bought this and the LiftMaster 828LM seperately and saved $40 to do the exact same thing.  Happy to say this device works fantasically with the Chamberlain Whisper Drive 3/4 Power Belt Drive Opener.  The install was very easy.  I even can use the Chamberlain MyQ app with this LiftMaster.  I use the Chamberlain app because it was blue in color and look better than the red LiftMaster app.  It is the exact same app.  The neat feature about the 888LM is the Light feature that turns on the opener light if the beam sensor is broken even if the motion sensor doesn't pick up the person or animal if the door is open.  Also, being able to turn the motion sensor off is a very good feature to have during the day if you are working in the gargage/yard.  No need for the light to keep turning on and off during the day.  The loud beeping prior to the door closing when using the app is very good to alert whomever the door is about to close.  I highly recommend this device.
summary: Works Fantastic with my Chamberlain Whisper Drive 3/4 Power

reviewText: I haven't used the kit yet but purchased this kit after reading that you shouldn't chase threads with a regular tap or die (they tend to actually enlarge the hole or reduce the threads on bolts).  I wish they also had smaller sized tools available.

I'm glad I have this blade for use with the Fein Multimaster. The only problem is that when you are doing a job like trying to cut through a 3/4" cedar wall to install an outlet box, it is hard to keep a perfect corner. I am not talking about keeping a perfect line, it is great for that, but when you are trying to cut an exact corner with a wide angled blade, it is hard to determine the edge. Consequently the edge of your cut can go a little wider than hoped for, leaving a tiny slit that can run out of the outside circumference of your edge lines.For making those kind of cuts the straight blades, without the angled sides makes for a perfect job. Knowing where the edge of the blade is, even while it is sinking into the wood is the key to getting your corners exact. With the 2 1/2 inch E cut blade, the tip is harder to get a bearing on where the vibrating edge is going to leave its mark. I'm not saying that you can't do the job with this blade, but for that type of application, the square rectangular blades make it easy to do a perfect job.I'm not knocking this 2 1/2 inch blade. As a matter of fact I like using it for covering a wide area. I can angle the face of the blade along a line, and as the back of the edge is sinking deep, the front edge is starting a new edge of the cut. All in all highly recommended. PS: Get a square-rectangular style blade as well.
summary: Great for making wide surface cuts but.....

Come on guys, what's up with all the 4- and 5-star reviews?  Let me lay it down for prospective buyers: this is not a quality lamp.  It is no better and no worse than other lamps in this price range that you might encounter on a pallet in the middle of the furniture aisle at [unspecified]-Mart, being made out of cheap sheet metal of dubious quality.  It will be trucked off to ten thousand different dorm rooms and home offices where it will hold together for a year or two--very probably less--before either the mounting hardware or the lamp head attachment breaks, whereupon it will be trucked off to a landfill to be forgotten about and then replaced with another lamp of comparable quality.  This is strictly a throw-away type of item for the casual user and certainly not for a production environment.

This comparative review is for:- Klein Tools RT200 GFCI Receptacle (Outlet) Tester- Gardner Bender GFI-3501 Outlet and GFCI Tester- Extech Instruments ET 10 GFCI Receptacle Tester- Triplett 9610 "Plug-Bug 2" GFCI Receptacle TesterOVERVIEW:-----------All 4 can be used to look for common faulty wiring in common U.S. household outlets and GFCI outlets, as well as test if GFCI functionality is operable, aka it will trip and cut things off when called on to do so.All except the Gardner Bender have the mini-LED for GFCI testing to confirm the test button made contact, though that alone shouldn't be a deal breaker I would think.All 4 work.Let's find a way to help choose one over the other.(1) INSTRUCTIONS:-------------------Klein's Instructions:The Klein's instructions are excellent, probably the best.  However, after reading the others instructions Klein's instructions could further benefit from much more detail on cautions/warnings/limits and useful commentary.- EASY-TO-READ details broken out by 2 USAGE SCENARIOS and done STEP-BY-STEP flow chart style.- MINI DATA SHEET spec info you normally don't expect, and some would argue need, from such a cheap tool.  I liked it's inclusion.- Printed on quality multiple page folded white cardboard pamphlet, certainly the nicest, most durable presentation, folks might actually keep it.  Its contents and its look belies a more PROFESSIONAL IMPRESSION of the product.- One negative is I think is the THINNESS OF THE CAUTIONS/WARNINGS as is obvious when you read the Triplett instructions (See below).Triplett instructions:- CAUTIONS/WARNINGS ARE THE MOST DETAILED, most useful.- The actual INSTRUCTIONS ARE THE WEAKEST and hardest to read of the three, almost no granularity or flow to the step by step.- The instructions and warnings were fitted into one side of a very thin sheet of paper the size of an index card.  SCREAMS CHEAP.  But again, the Cautions/Warnings are the best.Extech instructions:- The instructions are better than the Triplett's, though less detailed and usable than Klein's.- The Cautions/Warnings/Limits are perhaps tied with Klein's, though significantly less detailed and usable than Triplett's.- One-half of a cardboard backing the size of an index card is what you get for instructions and/or warnings.Gardner Bender instructions:- I like the separating of regular outlet and GFCI outlet testing instructions for the layman.- I like that there are some environmental engineering specs noted.- I like the list of what products like this don't do, the suggestions to use a qualified electrician to fix issues, the reminder to shut the power off to the outlet if you are going to work on it, and other safety advice.- The instructions are on glossy black&white; and show some care.  Not quite the attention to detail for instructions that Klein showed, but certainly adequate and quality enough not to detract from the product impression.If this is important to you, I give Klein, and in second place Gardner Bender, the edge here.(2) BUILD QUALITY, FIT & FINISH:--------------------------------The plug PRONGS for all of them don't wiggle, their ground prongs are fully formed, not the cheap looking u-style some have, and they all push into sockets easily.The CASES of all except the Gardner Bender are almost exactly alike except the Klein case appears better manufactured, next best manufactured was the Extech, and finally the Triplett.  The pieces fit together best and more flush with the Klein than the other two, there are less gaps between the plastic pieces and fewer surface imperfections.The Gardner Bender CASE is different than the others and its build quality is excellent, at least on par with the Klein, it looks the least cheap of the four.The Gardner Bender instructions announce that the unit is double insulated, "the tester is protected throughout by double insulation or reinforced insulation".  I don't know how this compares to the other three.I give the Gardner Bender and the Klein the edge here.(3) ON-METER LEGEND LEGIBILITY:---------------------------------The text describing the meaning of the LEDs is easiest to read on the Gardner Bender, Klein, and Extech.  The colored circles that match to the text are easiest to read on the Extech, next is the Triplett, then the Klein, then the Gardner Bender.  On none of them is the text or colored circles too difficult to make out, though the text on the Triplett is pretty bad.I give Exatech the edge here.(4) TRYING TO GET PEOPLE TO READ INSTRUCTIONS:---------------------------------------------------The Gardner Bender says in easy to see white text on black, and Triplett says in big bold black text on white on the products to read instructions before using.  On the Klein and the Extech the same warning is near invisible molded into the case in the same color as the case.I give Gardner Bender and Triplett the edge here.SUMMARY:----------Overall I choose the Gardner Bender or Klein due to the quality of the instructions and a sense that someone cared more about their manufacture.They all appear to work and none of us are going to test a random sampling of 100 of them nor probably break them open to examine them, so we'll probably never be able to estimate their true comparative durability.If any of the manufacturers wish to comment here on having addressed any issues raised here I will adjust the review accordingly.TRIPLETT'S PUBLISHED "CAUTIONS/WARNINGS":---------------------------------------------To help users of all these kinds of outlet testers I've included here Triplett's good list of cautions/warnings as they may prove informative to the casual user of most of these type of outlet testers.- To help avoid erroneous readings, all appliances and equipment must be unplugged/disconnected from the circuit being tested.- Do not press the TEST button on (this meter) for more than 6 seconds.  Now this is interesting as pressing it for 7 seconds is one of the steps on the Klein Tools test instructions.  Note:  Does it go into why you shouldn't press it for 7 seconds?  Why of course not :).- This tester does not indicate the quality of a ground connection.- This tester may not indicate the presence of a hot wire.  That is, it is possible for a hot wire to be present when none of the indicators light.- This tester will not accurately indicate a combination of wiring problems.- This tester will not test GFCI's installed on 2 wire (non-grounded) electrical circuits.- This tester does not perform a comprehensive test.  It only checks for probable common improper wiring conditions.- 120 VAC is dangerous and may cause user injury of death.  Use all appropriate cautions.  Note:  Does it then go into appropriate cautions?  Why of course not :).- Use only on 110 to 125 VAC receptacles.- GFCI receptacle or GFCI branch circuit protector must be installed in accordance with the manufactures specifications.- All corrective action must be made by qualified electrician.  Note:  Amen.SOME ADDITIONAL EXTECH'S PUBLISHED"CAUTIONS/WARNINGS" THAT MAY APPLYTO YOUR MANUFACTURER'S UNIT (reworded):-------------------------------------------I'll add these additional ones from the Extech instructions.- If the circuit doesn't trip after hitting the GFCI button, either the GFCI is operable but the wiring is incorrect, or the wiring is correct and the GFCI is inoperable.- Tester will not indicate 2 hot wires in a circuit.- Tester will not indicate reversal of ground or neutral conductors.ADDITIONAL GARDNER BENDER PUBLISHED"CAUTIONS/WARNINGS" THAT MAY APPLYTO YOUR MANUFACTURER'S UNIT (reworded):-------------------------------------------I'll add this additional one from the Gardner Bender instructions.- The more the other appliances or equipment on the circuit are unplugged the less chance there is for an erroneous reading.
summary: Review: Klein Tools RT200, Extech ET10, Triplett 9610, and Gardner Bender GFI-3501 GFCI Receptacle Outlet Testers

For crafts or projects that require outstanding lighting, this lamp has several features that will be of benefit. The height is great for someone sitting at a worktable- whether horizontal or tilted. If you sit in a chair you can also position it so the light is right on your work. The light itself is pure white so you do not get a color distortion. It is not so intense that the bounce-back bothers your eyes. These has been unforeseen problems with other lamps trying to provide the same results.The height and flexible neck lets you position the lamp so that it is close to your work. Best of all, the base is very heavy so that if you accidentally bump it, the lamp will not fall over. The flexible magnifying glass is very clear with good magnification and an addition fisheye spot that zooms in like a microscope.At first I questioned the price as being a little high. But after seeing it in person, I would say say that it is worth the expense.
summary: Specialty light a great help for projects

reviewText: I collect coins and as the years have gone by it's gotten a bit harder to inspect them closely without a magnifying glass. The OttLite floor lamp makes this chore much easier and more enjoyable.I've adjusted the light so it's at a comfortable height above my desk, and can easily move and position the magnifying glasses gooseneck arm at the perfect angle to take in the details of each coin. I admit I also use it to read some fine print on occasion (though I am still too stubborn to get bifocals).The lamp comes in a surprising compact box and fits together in a few minutes - I think it took me 5 minutes. The base is heavy enough so it won't fall over easily.I've also tested this lamb from my easy chair in the living room and again it adjusts to the ideal height there too. Perfect for reading and I imagine knitting or any other sort of craft the entails intricate details.
summary: Ideal for inspecting my coins at my desk

reviewText: After enduring cheap, loud, and annoying compressors, I figured it was time to save my ears and nerves by investigating and purchasing a quiet and portable replacement.  This is a great product and is truly quiet and efficient.It is somewhat heavy, but manageable because of the well padded and placed carrying handle.  I decided to handle the extra weight which I feel is offset by the added features (higher capacity, twin gauges and outlets) as compared to Makita's lighter MAC700 model.The compressor arrived in pristine condition and without any shipping damage.

I don't know what use others find for Sugru Hardware Sealer, but personally I use it to build up the height of my saxophone palm and side keys, to build them to an optimum height for my relatively large hands. Sugru allows customization which is even better than buying those ready-made black key height adjusters which may or may not work for any individual who might need just a little or really a lot of adjustment.Sugru is a useful compound for a variety of situations and now that I have it, I can't imagine my workshop being without it. Yes, I'm one of those people who wants materials handy for as yet unknown projects and delights in products like Sugru.

I was in the market for a new compressor and wanted something that would be versatile for most applications, relatively quiet and had a decent reserve tank.  I compared all the various models in this class and finally settled on the MAC2400.  I'm glad I did.  I was a bit hesitant to order it from Amazon versus the big box store, but my unit arrived in perfect condition and I didn't even have to consider a return.  As usual, Amazon Prime insured it arrived quickly, saving me the trouble of having to go to the store.First, the unit is really simple to use and maintain...a little bit of oil, flip a switch and away you go. (I've yet to do an oil change, but that doesn't appear too difficult.)  It's ready to go after just a short time, so you don't have the long wait that larger compressors do.  The MAC2400 is not nearly as loud as most compressors this size, which is nice when you're working within an enclosed space.  (My friend's large PC is almost twice as loud!)  It's had the power to do everything I need so far - finish nailing, impact wrench drives, stapling, filling up vehicle tires and cleaning things off.  This unit probably doesn't have the capacity to run higher demand applications like sanders, paint sprayers and so forth, but I was aware of that and accepted the limitations.  While using it heavy and fast, I've noticed it does kick on a fair bit...but that doesn't bother me since it's not too loud and I expected as much with the portable size tank.  The size is just about perfect, too...easy to build a rolling cart for, complete with hose storage.  About the only thing I don't like, and this is true for virtually all compressors, is when you release the air tank...it's ear-bleeding loud...I don't even like to be in the same room.I've outfitted the unit and all my accessories with quick disconnects, which is practically a necessity.  I also hand-selected my accessories as opposed to getting a kit, I think that's a smart way to go.  (Most of the accessory kits are cheap and you'll end up replacing them anyway.)  Again, Amazon has a great selection here.Overall, I would recommend this compressor so long as you don't require a larger tank or the use of greater CFM tools.  (If you do, you shouldn't even be looking at this unit!)  But, for the common home compressor, this was a good buy at a great price.  I hope to see many years of service from this Makita!

Very bright and massive flood. This is not a spot beam at all, it's mainly a huge beam of light, that illuminates a very wide area. Use indoors is somewhat difficult if you have light colored walls or lots of mirrors. If you catch a direct mirror shot to your eyes it's physically uncomfortable for a little while. It would be great defense against an intruder, mounted under a shotgun or rifle! I am using this on my rifle for night shooting/ short range hunting (<100m)One gripe, and maybe it's just me but I was expecting a rather uniform beam shape out of this light based on reviews I've seen. The beam on mine at close range is sort of a circle with an obvious square shape in the middle of it. Also the square extends down from the corona which makes it look asymmetrical. I called Streamlight about this and the guy in sales I spoke with said that is normal. Seems odd to me but it is what it is, I guess.Overall the rest of the light is amazing!
More than enough light, easy installation, and the ability to point the beams.  I bought two.  Highly recommend this product.
summary: My wife installed this while I was upstairs

reviewText: I needed a carrier/storage for my many camera lens [30 of them], and this is perfect!! Why? you might ask?- light weight.- lockable in not only one, but two places.- secure, due to quality metal clasps, and multiple handles [side, and top] for transport. No noticeable sharp edges on metal parts, to cut, and/or scratch.  Side handles are spring loaded to stay in the close position when not being used.- usable minimum interior size for the "Large" carrier is : 18 1/4"L x 9 1/2" W x 10" H [when the removable tray is removed]. Leave the tray in place, and the usable HEIGHT is reduced to 6", in the lower portion of the case.- pressure relief valve.- very durable looking hinge, similar to a modified "piano hinge"Will add more later, if the use of this carrier justifies more info..UPDATE as of 11/30/12:For those of you who are interested primarily in the "HIGHLY WATER RESISTANT" & "PRESSURE SEALED" qualities....IT FAILED, MISERABLY!!There's a product defect that occurred during the molding process, and poor design QA "quality assurance". The raised lip on my "LARGE" box has a profound "dip" in it. It's on both sides of the lower half, and it's found directly above the side handles. If you run your thumb across them, you'll feel the dip. It's even more dramatic when you sight down the length of the raised edge, from front to rear...on both left, and right side of the box. When the lid is closed, the lip, at that low point, will not compress the yellow plastic gasket in the upper lid.How did I test it? I took a piece of writing paper, about an 1" in width, and a few inches long, and placed it across the raised lip seal on the lower half of the box, directly above the side handles, so that part of the paper is hanging out, and the remainder, hanging inside............. closed the lid, and secured the metal clasps. Pulled the paper out, with absolutely no effort/no resistance, which proves that the raised lip was NOT contacting the upper yellow seal. Perform that same routine anywhere else on the box, and you cannot remove the paper without giving it a good hard pull......meaning that the seal is doing it's job.UPDATE AS OF 05/16/14: Here's an easier way to check it: You can just put a very bright flashlight inside [and try to aim it toward either one of the side seams], latch up the lid, put it in a dark room, and see if you can "see the light"!! I saw it in both cases...a large, and a small. Other than that, they're fine cases....just not water/pressure proof!So much for being water resistant, and pressure sealed. Other than those two highly touted qualities...... it's still a good tote box. Just don't expect to keep the contents dry in wet conditions. Of course, now it's a bit hard to swallow the price, since it's now in a lower grade class of case.HERES' A SUGGESTED "FIX"!: For anyone who already has this unit....I've worked out a "fix" for it. Just add about a 5" long bed of silicone caulk at the base of the yellow gasket groove [BTW, the gasket is not glued in place, so it pulls out easily], directly opposite where the side handle supports are located. Gently push the gasket back in place, and allow about 1/16" to 3/32 of an inch to be visible from the exterior side of the case. Normally, it would be recessed, and out of sight, viewed from the exterior side of the case. Needless to say, let the silicone cure for 2-3 days before closing the lid.
summary: Reasonably well made, and waterproof as well. UPDATE BELOW: from 5 stars to 1 star

reviewText: My only complaint about these Tiki torches is that they do not actually produce any ambient light. They look great flickering away but they will not provide ANY light what so ever to the surrounding area. One of the things I loved about real Tiki torches is that the flame actually produced a fair amount of light to the surrounding areas (I think it might be a man thing to have fire producing light) and if that is what you are wanting, These will not provide that. Other than that, they do look very nice just sitting there flickering away. They do not last me all night, probably only around 3-5 hours worth but thats due to where I have them, as there is some shade in that area so its not getting full sunlight all day long. When I first got them, they were already mostly charged and what little bit of time they spent outside in the sun, they did actually last all night long, so I know they can do it, its just my placement of them that is causing them not to be able to work all night long.One other minor issue I had with one of them was the step to push them into the ground, One of those broke off on me when I was pushing it into the ground. The other 3 made it fine, so I don't know if I just pushed to hard on that one or what. Still love them though.
summary: Love the lights with one exception

The peripheral sensing range is minimal, and the sensitivity is just on this side of acceptable.  All told, this is a serviceable basic light, and it is priced appropriately.

reviewText: I was upgraded to the ESP25 when they ran out of stock on the ESP15...sounded like a good deal to me!When I finally installed it, there seemed to be trouble with the float switch; the pump seemed to work but the float switch wouldn't trigger it.Customer service sent me a couple replacement float switches (perhaps out of some combination of generosity and experience with float switches going bad ;)....After a year, I performed a routine test on this unit and nothing happened. I tried 3 float switches, tested the battery, fuse... one of the float switches got the unit to make a sound but the pump didn't do anything. I think the unit ran one time the whole year so while it gave me peace of mind, it wouldn't have done the job.I went with a ZoellerZoeller 507 0005 Zoeller 507 0005 Basement Sentry Battery Backup Pumpwhich works great.

My two old pancake compressers wouldn't keep up in the heat even hitched in tandem and a quick tool search was necessary to keep the job moving as local purchase isn't an option here in the sticks. Reviews pointed me to this unit and to be prepared for sorry wheels and packing.Most of the other complaints seemed riskable. People that whine about the weight , noise and such must not study the specs as that's all in there.Anyway  I bought the compresser reconditioned and it arrived via fed ex with the box showing some damage which is less than the train wreck expected from UPS. The box was heavy cardboard but inside there was about no reinforcement to protect the tool. The only thing preventing total destruction  was the rugged design of the tool itself, which was mostly unharmed save  bunches of paint chipped off the handles and one wheel which was not only off the tool but the rim was seperated from the tire! Well it was a recon so the paint is no biggie but the wheel is inexcusable and not worth blaming on the shipper. Hey, did I mention I needed this thing for work? All the mechanics seemed good so I fired up for the break in and set about pounding and prying the miserable excuse for a wheel back to some semblence of function. The compresser itself has been a joy to use on the job and my only regret is I didn't do this a long time ago. However others have pointed out the pathetic wheels and packing going back far enough for the Makita folks to have straightened this out way before now. I go way back with Makita tools and can't figure how they can have such a disparity in quality within one product so be advised at Makita I'm keeping out a skeptic eye.

I needed to replace the smoke detector in my rental after the old one broke, and while it sure works, it's SO sensitive! I could almost swear my heater gets this thing going - it's always going off. If I open my oven to check on something I'm cooking it goes off, if I'm steaming vegetables it goes off. While I'm glad it works, I wish it had an easier time telling what should set it off.
Definitely worth it as is the Kreg jig pocket drilling system. even the most basic system will accomplish more than you'd think.

I have been waiting for them to come out with this for a long time.I have been using the WEMO outlet plug switches for a while now for LR lights and they are fantastic so I could not wait to get my hands on this one which is also an actual light with as well!Belkin has a fantastic website with videos and everything explaining how to install and hook this up properly. it is not difficult to do it all and only took me about 30 minutes from beginning to end..After you install the physical light switch you install the WEMO  app onto your  iPhone. Then you log temporarily into the Wi-Fi of WEMO  switch itself. it will ask you the Wi-Fi password for the main network and automatically get it set up onto your network working properly.and it does !!Mine alerted me of a firmware update( which took about 10 minutes) and then everything was working perfectly.One of the neat things about the WEMO switch as it will work with the website "if this then that" atifttt.comI have mine set up with a trigger that automatically turns the lights on 15 minutes before sundown.Overall it is an inexpensive way to get into home automation of your house.The Belkin website is extremely helpful and has lots of tips and the "if this then that" integration make it even better.I hope they keep expanding the WEMO line of products. Can't wait to see what they come out with next.Hope I helped you !!

I think this is a great idea but it sometimes doesn't work.This review is for the outlet plug. Oddly, Belkin has teamed up both the light switch and the outlet plug under the same product page and UPC number and they are two different items. This is the plug review.This is designed so that you can operate something that is plugged in from your smart phone...while you are at work you can turn on the crockpot to start dinner, while you are away on vacation you can turn on lights in the home so it looks like you are there, while you are downstairs you can turn on your child's bedroom light to wake them up for school--or music, etc.And that's all good. Anything that can be plugged in to this can be operated on the app.It does work--download the app and set up plug and you are good to go.Most of the time.It does not always work--sometimes it does, sometimes it does not. So that made it lose a star. For the most part I enjoy it and it's a pretty cool thing but I'm willing to bet it will be better next year when they fix some bugs, or hopefully sooner. If the bugs are simply in the app, hopefully this will carry over and fix things for those of us with the current model. A fun idea--just not quite 100 percent yet.
summary: Works well most of the time

reviewText: I keep a pair of these gloves in the trunk of the car for emergencies and they work just fine.  The palms are rubber-faced providing more than sufficient grip for handling wheels, jacks, wrenches and so forth while the permeable backs provide some modest ventilation.  There are cheaper versions available but these particular gloves appear to be made of a higher quality and more pliable rubber.
summary: Great gloves for emergency car repairs

reviewText: As others said, these do what they are supposed to do and they do it as well, if not better than others I've bought.  Add to that the fact the price is reasonable.  I will buy again.
summary: Good Quality and Quantity for the Money

reviewText: One could easily debate whether or not one should even try to clean a "standard" roller.  They are cheap enough and most of us don't roll all that often so that maybe one should just throw them away after use.  In my case, I have a Wagner Power roller system that uses a "custom" roller.  On the outside, it looks like all other rollers.  On the inside, however, there are lots of little holes that feed paint from a core tube into the roller nap on the outside.  This system works very well and you never have to go back to a tray to "re-load" paint on the roller.  This roller cleaner is intended for other than my Wagner roller.  It basically forces high pressure water along the outside of the roller to quickly clean it.  In my case, I need the inside of the roller cleaned as well.  Knowing this in advance, I wasn't really sure that this product would be of value.  But, it did do a pretty quick and pretty thorough job on my Wagner roller!  The product quality was very good and it comes with an additional sleeve (which I didn't need) for smaller diameter rollers.  It also comes with a "plug" that you're supposed to insert into the back end of the roller.  I'm assuming that this plug prevents water from going into the center of the roller and thus reducing the pressure.  Since I wanted the interior of the roller to be cleaned as well, I didn't use the plug.  Summarizing, the price was good, the quality was good, and even though I wasn't cleaning a "standard" roller, I thought the result was good and faster than I have achieved manually.
summary: Works Well for a Roller Not Intended

reviewText: I don't like blue labeled products which these are and can find the matching items sold by the MFG directly here on Amazon. The bits are wiggly in the driver I had the same issue with another iFixit toolkit. I returned it not for everyday use.

Rejuv-a-roller is good for an initial clean.  It still requires a bid of cleaning once clean water starts coming through the end.  But, I will say, it speed up the time to clean the roller and it was better to clean a pretty clean roller than one still loaded with paint.Don't get rid of the 5-1 paint brush/roller cleaner quite yet.  Still a time saver.

Tore my clutch apart on my quad in my cold garage.  Kept these gloves on for most of the job and they did great.  They aren't a winter glove.  They're on the thinner side, but fit great like Mechnix gloves do.  I picked up a washer off my garage floor and I was surprised by that.  I'll likely stock up on a couple more pair of these.

I was doing work in my attic over several weeks. Got to the point I was having bad allergic reactions, hard to breathe, very itchy for days, as everyone knows, pink fiberglass insulation will do that to you. This things are great for that, and also for painting.If you are always ruining your clothes working like me, these are cheaper than replacing clothes, and they are reusable and washable up to a point. I mean they arent going to last forever, but they aren't one use and chunk it in the trash either.They are also relatively cool. In a hot environment, I put these on without a shirt and was cooler than the same conditions with a shirt and no suit.
As many times as I tried, it still leaked a lot.  I was really disappointed because Nelson products are usually great.

Unfortunately I recommend that you do not purchase this product.I've had good luck with Belkin's products in the past, and I'm disappointed that this product does not perform its primary intended function.Physical installation was fine.  You need to know what a neutral wire is, and most light switches do not use one (but most light receptacles in modern homes have one).  Google the issue if you're considering buying any advanced light switch, and check your light switch wiring before purchase.Instead of accepting the wires like any old light switch (they normally screw in or clip in to even the cheapest light switches), this one has wires that extend out which you connect to your existing wiring with twist-on wire connectors.  This left a lot more loose wire than I had expected, but it all stuffed in the hole without a problem.It looks attractive, with a faint white light when off, and a green power icon when on.Then it was time to use my Android phone to control this device, and things went downhill.I downloaded the "Wemo" app, connected to the wifi network this device produced (which is totally unprotected and will grant access to your other wemo devices, such as a baby monitor, if you decide to get the full range of products).  I then entered my home wifi network and was told I had successfully set this thing up.And then nothing.When I went to the Wemo app or looked for a way to turn on the light from my phone, it acted like nothing was ever set up.  Worse, now the setup mode won't go forward with setup.  I never could figure out how to fix it.  I deleted everything and reset the switch many times, but was never able to get that 'successful setup' message again.  Then I saw the "beta" Wemo app (which is newer than the official one), and saw that one of its bullet points invites me to find the bugs in their software.Oh.  Belkin is still working out the bugs.  I tried the beta app.  It was the same as the official software for me.After several hours of trying, I have not been able to get this device to work via smartphone even a single time.  I tried two phones (both Android 4.00 and slightly higher).There are some other concerns that I have: this device will be broadcasting wifi the entire time it is in setup mode.  *UPDATE: it has stopped broadcasting the setup wifi when I checked about a week later.*  And after it's setup it will be connected to your wifi network.  So it uses much more power than a normal light switch (which technically doesn't use any).  So if you are "Green" or simply wish to keep the power bill down, you are probably better off with a normal light switch that doesn't itself use power.Also, the software is designed for an extensive ecosystem of "home automation" products, just like the software for my home automation thermostat (Trane) and door locks (Schlage) and cameras (another brand).  If you go all the way with this, it's going to mean a lot of software on your phone and a lot of switching around.  Trust me, as someone who has actually gone quite a ways with a lot of this stuff: it gets to be a hassle when they don't keep it simple.The software requires you to enter the program to operate the switch.  In my opinion, they should instead use a simple icon on my phone's screen that I hit once to turn on or off the light.  The icon would then change color to indicate on or off.  I would never enter an app environment.My impression of this software is that they shouldn't have put it on the market for Android in this condition.  (my review has attracted a very detailed criticism from an Apple user who had a completely different experience, so apple users are probably in luck).  A ton of other reviewers on Google Play have been unable to get setup to work, among a host of other problems.Update: I have been contacted by Belkin in the comments to this review, by email, and by phone.  They are polite and professional, but they are not native English speakers, the connection is usually very poor, and it was clear from their tips that we weren't going to succeed at troubleshooting.  After I asked these calls to stop they kept calling.  A lot.  My phone shows 29 calls and they will often call, go to voicemail, and then call again, over and over.  Not cool when you must leave your phone on 24/7 in case of emergency but you work a night shift.  Trust me.  Not cool at all.

There's really not much to say about an outlet extension (unless it fails...) but I have this in my kitchen plugged in upside-down with two cords plugged into it and it doesn't slip out of the base outlet (part of a light fixture probably needless to say...)  Of course a little tug will pop it right out, but left to its own devices it's nice and firm!
summary: Perfectly OK Swivel With Good Grip

reviewText: This is my favorite hazmat disposable coverall suit. A good price for most protection needs. Note booties are included, making it a good price value.It fits me just fine, but anyone over 6' will need XXLarge size.

I recently began working a seasonal part-time job with Coca-Cola and bought these to handle the boxes, bottles & cradles. The gloves didn't last, by the end of week one they looked like hobo gloves. I had a pair of Craftsman light-to-mid duty gloves that lasted for over a year of moderate punishment before they tore up and found *CLC gloves that are identical (other than color & strap) to the afore-mentioned Craftsman mitts. On the plus-side, these are comfortable, machine washable, dexterous and carry asthetic. Mechanix Utility might be great for gardening or tactical/law enforcement use but any kind of light, repetitive friction or strain & they're toast. For $11-$12.00 there are other, much more durable gloves available that don't sacrifice a-lot of dexterity.*http://www.amazon.com/Custom-Leathercraft-125M-Handyman-Gloves/dp/B0002YPZKY/ref=pd_cp_hi_1** Updated: The glove sold & pictured now is a newer version than the one reviewed here.

So yes with tax the max this should cost is $17.00.  I love Amazon items but you need to watch shipping and pricing when items are sold by other vendors. Good item but it is plastic and we will see how it holds up over the next year.  If it makes it past a year I would give it 5 stars.

This is the nicest case of the many I've purchased.  I love the removable compartments, a real time saver.  The construction is plenty strong enough for most any use, and quite a large number can be stacked without a problem.I only have two complaints and they are small.  The latches don't have a real good feel to them.  The sizes of the compartments don't really match the uses I have.  You may need to purchase two or even more to get your cases to have the set of sizes you really want.
summary: My favorite case, and I've bought a bunch...

reviewText: I use this to cover a custom PVC kayak cover in the back yard. After about two months, it started to tear at a point that isn't even on a stress point. I had my previous tarp for two years without any issues. Oh well, I'll have to move on.
summary: Started tearing after about two months

reviewText: This is a great thermostat so far!! No issues, super easy and fast to install. There is a jumper included so the system will accept multiple setup scenarios. I have a 4 wire system and this is perfect! Allows set up for Mon-Fri with 4 time periods / temps all user set. Same for Sat and Sun settings. It is fairly intuitive and the instructions are very clear. There is also a handy printout on the inside cover for quick reference in case you want to change your setting after tossing the instructions. Comes with 2 screws and the drywall anchors. Uses 2 AA batteries, haven't had it long enough to report on the drainage though.

I like how this works. It has a power cord and 2-speed switch, which was perfect for our application - moving air around in a damp basement.  The install instructions could use a bit of work - getting it perfectly aligned is not real easy.  But once in place, it works well.
Works like it should, no kinks or thick spots or anything bad.
Compare these to the stuff you can get at the big home improvement stores this tarp is top notch.  Do a little planning and order these - you won't be sorry.
Well made, fits well, and agility with fingers is pretty good for such thick leather. Agility should only get better with use.

Flame less LED Vanilla-Scented Candles are wonderful. They are a perfect Christmas tree replacement if you are not going to have some to light up.  They will go as long as the batteries last.The package and shipment were great.  When I ordered them, they came packaged separately within a cardboard box with other items.
Got these for my IFAK and first aid kits.  Yes they smell terrible but I guess that's the point.  Just buy some already....
Poor quality garbage taiwan branded sockets you might buy at a dollar store. Any other set of sockets would be better. Avoid.

I am an electrician, and this is the best built voltage sensor I have used. Great design and built to last. No audible alarm, but I have a circuit finder I use to find which breaker I need to turn off. I only use this tool to check if the power on wires or at power/lighting outlets is OFF. This tester is not good for much else.

These sockets grip by the sides and make it less likely to round the corners off. This is a good and will help with bolts that are tough to break free and a lot of brands have started to do this now good quality and in a case which is nice

Good timer switch. Easy to install and easy to operate. The only thing i would of liked if it had a different way to turn off instead of going through all the time settings. Besides that it does the job.

I have a rack full of these clamps and I go to them before anything else.  They are sturdy, heavy, reliable, and American made.  With all of the negative reviews, they must have had some early manufacturing issues with these in 2003/2004.  But I haven't experienced any of it.  In fact, I keep resisting the urge to buy more.  I have:  4 x 18", 2 x 24", 2 x 48", and 2 x 60".  I just placed an order for 2 x 12" from Amazon.

I have very large hands and I expected that at XXXL these would be plenty large enough for me.At XXXL they are not any larger than many XL/XXL gloves I have tried on elsewhere. Assuming you can squeeze your hand in, they are very comfortable to wear.  I use them while doing wood work and quickly forget I am wearing them.  They take forever to get on and off because of the "small" XXXL size, but are definitely worth it.Just a point: They look exactly like the picture.  They have Mechanix written all over the outside of them.

I came across Stanley digital timers a few years ago...absolutely awesome, small, and troublefree products.  I use them to automatically turn on lights at dusk, to reboot the router once a day, and various other activities around the house.  Simply set it and you're done.

You really can't beat these for the price.  They hold up well and I use them all the time for home projects and working in the garage.  I have a second pair I wear for outdoor projects.  These really do seem to provide great hand protection and are very durable.  I have large hands and often have trouble finding gloves with a good fit.  Not so with these.  I particularly like the fit as it affords great dexterity.  If you want a tough, affordable work glove, you can't go wrong with these.
summary: Typical of the high-quality that is associated with Mechanix

reviewText: I decided to get this timer to replace a mechanical timer that was way too noisy to have right behind my couch. Obviously, this digital timer is silent, so it fit the bill. It was easy to program and holds the time and program in memory during power outages. It is small and less obstrusive than many other timers I have around my house. I have been using it for two years and have not had any issues with it.Some features that are missing on this timer that I would like include having an override switch to turn a light off (there is only an on override). Also, being able to program more than one on/off cycle per day would be helpful. For the price though, the timer is certainly worth it.
Metal diverters are reliable and will pay you back in the long run: no leaks and the valve handle turns easily.  Plastic often cracks and the threads are never as accurate.
Nice little addition to your key ring, can come in handy when your in a desperate situation. well made and light weight.
summary: you may need it one day

reviewText: It looks great with my new Moen Velocity 8" rain shower. It's a luxury item and is totaly unneccesary but if you can afford it, why not! Life's short, enjoy little things while you can.

I never use the rip side of two sided pull saws so that part is always a waste for me. Love that there's two blades and a case. The blade is thin enough to get into so odd angles but strong enough not to fold under some pressure. We'll see how long this thing stays sharp. I'll try and report back in a few months of use..

These special clamps work perfect for me.  I have only used them as a "bump block" with a scrap piece of mdf when crosscutting several pieces for cabinet rail and stile pieces.  Put the clamped scrap of wood (maybe 3"x3") just before the blade against the fence, and make your cut using your standard crosscutting miter gauge.  This way when u can cut several pieces by bumping your board against the block and they won't bind against the fence after cutting it...

I keep one of these by my table saw.  Great as a spacer when making multiple cross cuts of the same length.  Because they are accurate dimensions I can still use the scale on my table saw and just add 1" or 2"
summary: A machinist tool for the wood shop.

reviewText: From the tips here I bought mine at home depot for less, plus it comes with a case. I read the directions and at first nothing really worked. Connector fell off the cable after compressing. I then realized that the metal sleeve inside the connector has to fit under the cable outer layer while you push it in. Also, to save some people some grief, the stripper works better when you place the metal blade on the bottom while using it. I first had it on top and for some reason it kept slipping off the cable while turning it. all in all does what it's supposed to do pretty well.
summary: Does what it's supposed to do

reviewText: I agonized for months over the price, and finally did it.  All the way.I've added mine to a Delta Left-Tilt 10" contractor 36-982.  There were a few minor problems on the install (nice tip on the extension roller). I pulled the left extension plate from my saw, replaced it with the Benchdog plate, and was then able to bolt the spare Delta left plate directly to the right side of the existing right extension plate. All of this takes up no additional space in my very small shop.  That all took about a hour, fiddling with the roller, moving the saw, working the bolts, leveling, etc., mostly due to the weight, plus a small fudge factor for operator ineptitude.Next I started to assemble the other parts including the miter gauge guide track.  In screwing the track to the plate, I found that either the  counter-sink holes for the screw heads had not been drilled deep enough, or they shipped screws with heads too high. In any case about 1/16 - 1/8 of an inch extended up into the track making it impossible to move the miter gauge bar in the track.  I called BD and they attempted to talk me into drilling the countersinks deeper, but for $329, I expect them to ship properly machined components.  I'll report back on how long it takes them to ship the replacement, and if it's any good.
