So I would advise dancing the thing to set the shaft to the base, unless yours fits well and slides easily--lucky you!LIGHT:A also bought it hoping it would do a good daylight over my drafting table, where purple looks brown at night and vise-versa. I do illustrating. It comes at my shoulders when standing up, so I guess that is ok height but would have been better higher. It would also have been nicer with a longer flexible portion to give it height that you could lower as needed. If you need one like that--look for a longer flexible shaft portion!The light itself is actually very nice. It has two settings: one high light and one dimmer. It illuminates what I'm looking at and I use my magnifier for intricate work that is closer to the work than this lamp could get. The battery powered little mag lamps are great for this in case you were wondering...I may take out the hokey plastic 'grill' over the bulbs to make it brighter. But I think any brighter light from this lamp might obscure colors or be too glaring too.So, summary:1. For 75.00 plus, I didn't expect plastic  grillwork over the bulbs and squishing wiring up inside it being so hard.2. The flexible portion is shorter than I'd like for ideal worklight in both standing and sitting positions.3. The shaft doesn't set into the base without disco dancin'.4. The light is actually great with 2 settings, not 'hot' light, and gets the job done.Aloha*if anything untoward happens, like it falls apart in a month or shorts out...or burns my house down...I'll revise this!
summary: a bitch to assemble, too short for a drafting table, but great light

reviewText: I absolutely love this little guy. The machining and accuracy are superb!! I personally don't have a problem reading it like others have mentioned. It's my go to square now!!! I know there are other squares on the market that are less expensive but that is not what we are reviewing here and I cannot speak of them. reviewText: I purchased this soldering station to replace a crappy Radio Shack 20watt/40Watt soldering iron.  I solder mainly for hobby/repair applications and this soldering station is a REAL step up from my crappy soldering iron.Review Update:  I've been using this soldering station for the last 1.5 years.  I love this soldering station!  I actually look forward to soldering with it.  It is really not even fair comparing this soldering station with my old Radio Shack 20watt/40Watt soldering iron.  My old iron seemed to take forever to heat up and the tips were GARBAGE.  I love that the Hakko FX-888 soldering station heats up from cold in just a couple seconds.  The transformer is nice and heavy and has great rubber feet.  The power cord attached to the transformer is heavy weight, and as a result, is rather stiff.  Even with a stiff heavy weight power cord, the weight of the transformer (plus the grip of the rubber feet) is enough to keep the transformer where you put it.  The pencil holder also stays where you put it.  The pencil holder is all metal and is nice and heavy.  While in the pencil holder, the heated portions of the iron are almost completely covered.  The cord on the soldering iron is a decent weight but the cord is not stiff.  It's nice and floppy.  The soldering tip is amazing and is very resistant to oxidation.  By using the sponge and the wire cleaner built into the pencil holder, it is very easy to maximize the life of the tip.  The selection of tips that can be purchased and used with this soldering station, in my amateur opinion, is really impressive.  I love this soldering station!  Using this soldering station and proper soldering techniques, I am able to consistently produce high quality solder connections without overheating components.
The new batteries actually work.Most solar lights I've bought worked for about 2 months and went into the dumper.These seem to be holding up just fine and run for hours... even in December.

I just received my new Hakko FX-888 solder station and what time I have spent with it, I am very pleased with the purchase. I would highly recommend it to anyone. I am glad to be able to acquire the analog knob style unit and not the new revised digital unit - too many whistles and bells.

Look, this patch panel isn't anything special - your run of the mill 24 CAT 5e ports. You can certainly save money elsewhere.  But if you're working within the confines of a Leviton Structured Media Panel, you simply can't do better.  The Leviton ecosystem is tightly integrated, primarily by the shape/size of devices, but also because of their proprietary plastic mounting clips.  I had initially planned on purchasing two less expensive 12 port patch panels for my Structured Media project, but decided against it when I realized how much room they'd consume.  Not to mention that their holes didn't align to the preset holes in the media panel, meaning I'd be drilling more holes into my wall (my panel was surface mounted).This panel was easy to install, has a sturdy build, and has functioned flawlessly ever since.
summary: High price, but a Must for Leviton Structured Media Panels

What a difference 300 MPR makes! We upgraded to the 3M Filtrete 2200 MPR Elite Allergen Reduction Filters and immediately noticed an improvement in our home air quality.We live in a non-smoking home with two indoor dogs. Our youngest son is the most sensitive to air quality. We change filters based on his sneezing, which can come on like an attack of the hiccups. We had used the3M Filtrete 1900 MPR Ultimate Allergen Reduction Filterfor years because it was the highest rated filter available for sale at the local home improvement stores.We found the3M Filtrete 2200 MPR Elite Allergen Reduction Filteron Amazon.com. They run about $4 higher per filter than the 3M Filtrete 1900 MPR. It would be fantastic if Amazon made these available through their Subscribe & Save program (hint, hint) but we have no other complaints. Amazon sells these filters in 6-packs, which is common among online filter sellers. However, I found Amazon's 6-pack price to be at least $15 cheaper than competitors' prices.Consumer Reports ranks the 3M Filtrete Allergen 2200 MPR the best Do-It-Yourself filter. It receives an excellent rating for dust/pollen removal, a good rating for smoke removal and a very good rating for airflow resistance. This high-performance filter also meets the American Lung Association of the Upper Midwest Health House Program's indoor air quality guidelines.According to the 3M website, the company "developed the Microparticle Performance Rating (MPR) system to demonstrate a filter's ability to capture the smallest airborne particles--from 0.3 to 1 micron in size from the air passing through the filter. The MPR system helps you compare Filtrete filters based on the level of air filtration you want. The higher the MPR, the better the filter's ability to capture particles from the air as it passes through the filter."Rating: Five stars.MARCH 2012 UPDATE: Our family continues to use the 3M Filtrete Allergen 2200 MPR filters with great success. Unfortunately, Amazon has discontinued offering these filters through their Subscribe & Save program. In our community, you can't find filters with the 2200 MPR level and, if you do, they are more expensive than Amazon's everyday price. The one advantage is that you can buy one filter at a time instead of the six-packs offered by Amazon. If you have any questions, please feel free to send me an email.
summary: The 2200 MPR Elite is the best Do-It-Yourself filter available

reviewText: This is a good (but not *great*) floor lamp to place next to a chair or desk for reading.  It definitely has its pros and cons, which aren't easy to discern from the product photo.___________________PROS:* The 27 watt compact fluorescent bulb (included) provides a cool light source and uses less energy than an incandescent bulb.* The hardware is very sturdy and well manufactured.  It's frustrating when parts aren't machined right and an item is hard to assemble.  This is very well built though.* The on/off switch is easy to reach and it's very large (probably an inch and a half long).* You can adjust the height up and down.  Just make sure you tighten the thumb-screw tightly, or else it will fall back down.___________________CONS:* The product photo makes the lamp look black, but it's actually a dark antique brown.  It's a nice finish, but make sure you're OK with brown.  If you're looking for black, you'll be disappointed.* It's hard to tell from the photo, but the arm of the lamp only goes up and down.  It doesn't articulate forwards or backwards.  (But yes, it features both up AND down!)* The photo doesn't show the power cord, but this is actually a big detraction.  If you look at the photo, you can tell that there are two pieces to the lam's arm.  The bottom piece screws into the base and is stationary.  The top piece supports the head of the lamp and has the power cord threaded through it.  If you look at the product photo, look at the bottom end of the top arm.  That's where the power cord comes out and dangles freely.  It's not pretty.* The lamp is only usable for a seated area (a desk or a reading chair).  The height only extends to about four feet.  If you need a taller light source, you'll have to put it on a stand.Conclusion:  Except for the ugly power cord, this is a handsome lamp.  It's a shame the photo isn't more detailed, because you really can't discern the classic style of the lamp from the picture.  The picture looks a lot more modern (and black), but it's not.  And the cool hue of the bulb seems to me to be at odds with the antique finish--a warmer bulb would have been more fitting.If the dark bronze finish fits your decor, then this is a nice lamp.
Although they bring in everything from China these days, Dewalt still has the best value available in their class. I have 5 drills of this make.

reviewText: I purchased this set because I wanted t include a flashlight in my gift bags to my nephews. It seemed a logical choice since I was also giving them books, and books, boys and flashlights just go together, right? Also, I think it's great to have a flashlight near every bed in the house, just in case. In fact, I have them everywhere!I placed the smaller ones, which seem to be very sturdy, in the bags for the boys. The larger ones are hung on hooks, one at the top of my cellar steps and one at the inside of my attic door. In fact, one of the larger ones was dropped and it came through with no problem, reassuring me that they would hold up to whatever the boys handed out.recommended.

I gave this product one star only because I couldn't select "zero" stars.  The idea is not a bad idea, just poorly implemented.  Despite reading several reviewers' reports that these clamps easily broke, I ordered them anyway since they looked like a solution to a common problem and I expected that the defect would have been fixed by now.  Wrong!  Without actually seeing the clamps, it may be hard to understand how they are made.  There is a polycarbonate "base" with two "spring steel "clamps" attached via a separate polycarbonate "lid" which is screwed on.  The lid is not strong enough to hold the clamps leading to stressing (bending) of the lid and potential failure.  I did not actually use the clamps.  One clamp looked "okay" in that the polycarbonate lid was not obviously stressed and deformed.  The same was not true for the second clamp.  I'm sure it would have failed the first time I used it.  So, I returned the clamps to Amazon for credit which they did give.  For awhile, I thought about remaking the polycarbonate lid out of something more substantial, thicker, or stronger, like aluminum.  The lid is secured to the base via screws so this may have been possible.  But, why should I have to do this, especially when I really would have to buy three more sets to use on any four sided box?  At $10 per set, maybe I would have done this.  But not at $25 per set!  The manufacturing fix would have been at least to make the lid thicker.  I usually read most of the reviews with a grain of salt and discount some where I think maybe the user was at fault.  Here, I was at fault for not listening to other users.  Conclusion:  Good idea, bad design/manufacturing.  It really should have been fixed by now.
summary: Poor Implementation, should have fixed by now

reviewText: I was finishing a remodel to our Master Bathroom.  Not wanting to spend too much, we chose lighting, mirrors, and accessories, like this towel bar, from different manufacterers.  The last thing needed was a dual towel bar on a wall next to a sink.  The wall where the towel bar would attach was less than 24 inches wide.  Additionally, if the towel bar "stuck out" too far, it would interfere with a mirror.Since I have used a fair number of Moen towel bars, mirrors, and paper holders, I started looking on the Moen site for a towel bar, preferably one with two bars and 18 inches wide, and, to whatever extent possible, similar in design to the mirrors and light fixtures.  I found this towel bar and it fit all of my requirements except that it was too long.This was not a problem because I could always cut the two bars shorter.  It didn't appear that this model was available in a shorter length.  Looking at the specification, it was not exactly clear how far the towel bar "stuck out" from the wall so I called Moen.  They clarified things and this bar would easily work if I just cut it shorter.When I searched for it on the internet, not surprisingly, Amazon had it and at a good discount.  Since I have Amazon "Prime", shipping was free.  The quality of this towel bar is excellent and, like other Moen accessories, easy to install.

Being a self-confessed flashlight nut, I gave this headlamp a try when I saw it offered on Amazon.  I own a lot of flashlights (torches to those Brits out there) but none of them are designed to wear.  My assessment is based on my inspection of the product and brief use.  Whether or not it will be durable and reliable in the future cannot be determined at this time.Bottom line:  I like it a lot.  There was one glaring problem with the light that I immediately discovered.  There were no instructions in the nice little box, only a multi-fold advertising sheet for other Coast products.  Maybe instructions were supposed to be included but were inadvertently overlooked, I can't say.  But a little basic information would have been helpful.  Such as what type of batteries are needed, how to operate the controls (on/off switch and focus).  It didn't take a lot of time for me to figure these things out but we live in the information age and I like information with products I use.The unit takes 3-AAA batteries that fit in the little battery pack at the rear of the headband.  You peel off the rubber cover to access them.  The lever at the top of the pack controls the power of the light.  On the light itself, the button at the top is the on/off switch and the knurled knob around the lens controls the flood/spot arrangement of the light.  Everything works well although all the controls are a little stiff.  They probably will loosen with use.  There is a small Velcro-closured pouch included with what looks like plastic clips inside.  I have no idea what these are for (another reason an information sheet is needed).  The elastic headband is adjustable and it fits snug when adjusted to the right length.The light works well, providing hands-free operation.  That's a big plus when you need a third hand or you're trying to work in a tight space.  For general nighttime use, I still like having a standard flashlight so you can shine light into the darkness around you and only have to move your eyes instead of your head.  But this is a handy tool that I like a lot.  I reserve one star due to the unknown future reliability of the product and the fact that there is a serious lack of information about the product included.

I bought several of these along with a canvas stretcher with hand straps, with the idea that I could find two sturdy poles in the woods where I hike to make a travois in case of an emergency.  I've got 2 dogs that hike with me everyday, and one I can carry in my backpack if she is injured, but the other dog wouldn't fit in my pack and he'd be too heavy to carry.  They both got into a yellow jackets nest in the woods once, and my little corgi/jack mix got stung several times on her feet and couldn't walk home, but my shepherd was able to run away faster and didn't get as many stings.  So my idea is for my dogs but if a person were hiking with me and was injured I could carry them as well.  Recently broke my foot on the trail, but I wasn't able to carry myself.  Good thing I had hiking poles.  Anyway these ties are great for alot of uses more practical than my hairbrained ideas.  Keep your cords together, wrap around the glue bottle and attach the glue brush, helps keep the blade guard on my tenon saw, and shaped into a hook can hang things off my pegboard.

I really like this buffer at first, being a Novice and not wanting to Burn my paint finish with a Rotary Buffer.I have had my 7424XP for about 2 years now, but after only a total of 16-20 hours use, the pad will not spin if you put any pressure, whatsoever on it. It's hard to tell, so I put a mark on the pad with a Sharpie.  The pad just vibrates and does not work the finish at all.The unit is way out of warranty, so not worth sending in it for repairs.So...save your time and money and buy a more proven buffer.

This SentrySafe SFW123FUL comes equipped only with a digital keypad - it does not have a manual key backup option.The safe is a good size to store the average family's important documents and small valuables. The safe is opened via a digital keypad that uses 4 AAA batteries. The batteries also power 2 white LEDs on the inside of the door. The LEDs are not completely adequate to shuffle through the safe contents in a dark room, but they do help.The inside of the safe is made of hard plastic with 1 shelf an 1 tray which can be raised on lowered by inserting them into the appropriate wall slots. The inside of the safe is 12" D x 12" W x 13.5" H. It is large enough to store file folders, jewelry boxes, etc.  There is also a small open storage compartment in the door that can accommodate small documents (passports) or valuables.There is an option to bolt down the safe - which I feel should be the de-facto standard. Even though the safe is close to 90 lbs, it is not difficult for professionals to steal. Bolting down severely decreases the likelihood of theft. However, bolting down removes water resistance. This is a con for the safe as there are many options to ensure water seals for bolted down safes.Lastly, the lack of a backup key and the ability to reset (remove/program over) the factory set code really makes this a less desirable safe. I have to register my safe with SentrySafe for the warranty. It might be a long shot, but someone could access my registration and have the master key code to my safe along with my home address. Not cool!Pros:* Free replacement if safe experiences a fire* LED light in door is helpfulCons:* This model does not have a backup key* Cannot disable factory set code (Can add 2 new codes)* Bolting from the bottom causes safe to lose water resistance
summary: Decent Safe with a few key lacking features

Let me say that I own the Festool ETS150/3 eq sander and in my opinion this sander is a bit nicer in a few areas. For one the vibration is definitely less in this Bosch than the Festool, no question about that, and that is very important to me since I have developed severe carpal tunnel in both my hands, this is why I decided to try this new Bosch and I'm glad I did. I can sand off and on for an hour and barely notice it, If I use the Festool for an hour off and on I'll know about it and will have numb hands that will ache badly. Don't get me wrong the Festool is a fantastic sander and the best I ever used before I bought this, but I really like this much more after using both in my shop.. Also the ability to use a 5" and a 6" pad on the same sander is fantastic and a money saver. The dust collection on board (without a vac) is super, the dust collection canister uses an automotive style pleated filter that can be used over and over again, and it just works very well and is also very easy to empty.. Dust collection when using my Fein vac is a bit better than with the canister, but not by a huge amount, that's how good the onboard dust collection is. This sander is a bit large compared to other  sanders including the Festool but it's not cumbersome at all and fit's my hands perfectly. It's also feels like a very high quality tool and is built in Switzerland. As far as the finish it gives, it's effortless to achieve a nice smooth finish with no noticeable swirl marks if you use the correct grades of sandpaper and quality paper. I hate sanding as most woodworkers do but this makes the job a wee bit enjoyable.. I think it's a great deal considering all that's included and also considering the quality of the tool.
summary: Best 5"-6" sander out there at present

reviewText: I bought this saw to replace a 10" Delta double bevel miter saw that served me well for many years, but was too small for a lot of work that I do.What I like:It's heavy enough to stay still without being bolted down.The digital display is a joke to some people, but I found it helpful when the scales were covered in sawdust, if I wanted to double check my settings, or when there's dark shadows on the scales.It glides very nicely and all the adjustments were dead on from the factory.The saw does not need to be running for the laser to be activated.Lots of power, it cuts almost anything without getting bogged down.Detents are nice and tight.The fine tuning knobs help tweak settings so they're dead on.The vertical handle is comfortable when the saw is at bench height, though I could see it becoming an issue if the saw is placed on the floor.What I didn't like:The weight.  It's great for keeping it still, but this sucker is a back killer to move around.This saw can't make a cut when placed at a 45 right miter and 45 left bevel - a tab sticking up from the left fence is too high and doesn't allow the saw to move.The laser is a tad narrow, and doesn't go a full 1/8" for most blade kerfs.There's no detent override.It makes a mess with sawdust.  The collection port is really high, and the bag is angled downwards, so when it becomes over full it'll drop a big clump of dust if the saw is lowered when not running.The deck is 4-1/4" high.  This is taller than some miter saw bench support brackets, and may become an issue.Side supports arms are not included, unlike most lower-end saws.Something that's a little silly is that unless the digital readout is turned on, the laser can't be turned on.  The readout resets itself to zero every time it's shut off and turned back on, so unless the saw is set back to 0's, the display will be incorrect, though it can be reset.Overall, it's the best saw for stationary work, unless you're a workout junkie and want something heavy to lug around instead of joining a gym.
Just hooked it up in dark hallway. So far so good. Works liked I hoped it would. Don't know how long batteries will last. If I have a problem will let you know.
I've been using this fan for several months.  It is very quiet so I can keep it close so it blows directly on me.  I use it more often because there's no noise to annoy me.  I'm ordering another.

Hipe wireless doorbell consists of the main unit that is mounted inside the house and the remote button that is mounted outside.  The outdoor button is water tight since it will be exposed to elements.The main unit operates on three AAA batteries (not included), the button unit operates on 12V 23A battery (included).  23A battery is one of the lesser common batteries, but it is available on AmazonEnergizer A23 Battery, 12 Volt - 2 PackI am attaching a collage of three photos, the first shows both units on a gridded mat for size reference.  The  second photo shows the back of the main unit with the battery cover taken off, and you can see the speaker and the mounting holes.  The third photo shows the HIPE wireless button next to the current wireless door bell.The size of the main unit is 3" by 3 3/8". It has screw holes but does not come with mounting hardware.  The button unit 1 3/4" wide by 3" wide and comes with sticky tape mounting, no screw holes.  This button is a bit wider than my current door bell, and is wider than the flat wood area near the door. (I am attaching a collage of three photos, and photo #3 shows this button near the current button for comparison, you can see that the lip of the storm door takes up some of the room needed for the button to fit).  My current door bell is mounted with screws, which I think is a better mounting method for an outdoor unit.The button unit battery is rated to last 1 year. When you have to change the battery you will need to pop the cover while it is mounted.  Care needs to be taken not to damage the blue gasket between two sides as it is this blue gasket that makes the unit water tight.The door bell sound can be selected from 48 musical tones and 16 cords.  The sound is fairy loud, the tunes vary from 50 to 80 db.  The sound however is not high quality, all musical tones sounded a bit hissy.The range of the receiver is pretty good, the box specifies range as 200 meters (656 feet).  I walked into the back of the yard and was able to ring the door bell while I was several hundred feet away.  That was pretty impressive.  This means this door bell can serve not only as a door bell for the main house but perhaps placed by the gate or next to the mail box which is not near the house.To summarize: The positive are excellent price, excellent range, good loudness. The negatives are I would have preferred screw mounting to the double sticky tape and a slimmer button unit. Note that if the button had screw mounting the thickness would not be an issue, as I would not need a flat area to mount the button.I received this door bell from the manufacture to share my experiences with it (positive and negative) with potential future buyers. I have no financial interest or business relationship with the manufacturer, and this review represents my independent opinion of the product.The photos referenced in the review can be located by following 'customer photos' link under the main photo.Ali Julia review
summary: Excellent range, only sticky tape mount for outdoor button

reviewText: I used to be able to buy blue LED night lights from a big name local retailer in my area.  For some reason or other, they stopped carrying the blue LED's about 2 years ago.  So when I happened to spot these on Amazon, I snapped up 5 of them.  And, I must say these are MUCH brighter than the blue ones I had originally purchased from the big name local retailer.  I much prefer blue light for several reasons.  Primarily, it doesn't disturb my eyes when I wake up in the middle of the night to go to the bathroom, and because it's lower than the head of my bed, the bright LED's are not shining into my face, so it doesn't disturb my sleep either.  In fact, I seem to actually sleep better than with the light I had in the same plug before.  (that light was one of those rotating color swirl LED bulbs that changed slowly from red, to green, to blue, with occasional lapses of almost no light - some might not like moving light on their ceiling, though it did not bother me, as I found it kind of restful as I was falling to sleep - that is, it was "pretty" and mesmerizing.)An interesting side note on this blue LED Waterfall light... (now, this is TOTALLY unscientific, so take this with a grain of salt, as they say).  We've had somewhat of a problem with tiny ants in the kitchen.  Since I put in the above blue LED light, I have not seen a single ant.  Usually, the ants are worse at night and in the early morning.  I've checked each night and in the morning, and not seen a single one (usually, I would see up to a dozen or more).  Is it possible that ants don't like certain wavelengths of light?  I have no clue as I've never seen or heard of any studies on such things.  Perhaps there are other reasons and this is a coincidence.  I do not know.
summary: I really love this shade of blue!  (excellent price!)

reviewText: DREMEL EZ402 LOCK MANDREL FOR ROTOR TOOL HOLDS GOOD IN CHUCK WELL MACHINED EASY TO TAKE WHAT EVERY YOUR USING ON OR OFF.BM

A woodworker's review:As some others have said: if a clean hole is important, consider these bits dedicated for use in a drill press. In a portable drill they WILL self-feed and tear into the wood. But, in a DP, they are capable of holes that are second only to Forstner bits for precision. I use these almost exclusively in my drill press and the rating is based on that usage. If the rating was based on use in a portable drill, 3 stars, maybe. See the image I posted of a 15/32 bit in red oak using my drill press.Summary: Fast, but crude in a portable drill. VERY clean in a drill press.
summary: Ideal for a drill press. Rough in a portable drill

reviewText: I did not expect much from a $3 pair of gloves (which is what they cost individually at this price,) but wow: the leather is soft, the fit good.  they are comfortable and sturdy.  These have gotten a serious workout since I purchased then.  I have pulled up a coupkle dozen cubic feet of fern, some with thorns, all with rough bark, gone after thick underground vines, taken out weeds the size of trees and they have held up beautifully!  i had a pair of goatskin gloves of which I was rather fond whgich developed a hole due to the amount to heavy work we have been doing.  These have lasted! and are very comfortable, much more so than the ones sold at local hardware stores and garden shops.  I have since ordered a second and third set.  the first because I can not believe the quality at this price! 9and we always have a lot of yard work) and the second set for my husband, who had been using mine though the fit was too small.The set we received in large was not the same.  It more resenbled the ones we get at the hardware store (but, I believe the picture reflects that).  the leather was not quite as soft, but the palms reinforced... still a great value at the price!

Old methods of layout and leveling seem so... old.  3 buttons now give you near-instant vertical leveling, horizontal leveling, and square & plumb.  200 arc angle, good track clearance, and it's mountable on a normal camera tripod - which you should be able to get for under 20 bucks.The little extras stand out in a big way, a metal roll cage, yaw adjustment on top, magnets on the back so you can put it on steel, adjustable wall mount, and a great case.It comes with free service for a year, which includes two free calibrations.  Thankfully mine didn't need one out of the box.

Got this to replace standard hose on my Porter-Cable small compressor.  It is much more compact and easier to store.My only issue is that the tension on the coils is a bit strong  and I must move compressor closer to the work so I do not fight the hose with my nail gun and still line up my shot.

I bought this compressor to run nail guns, air sand and spray paint.  It is much more compact than other units of similar capacity.  The controls are conveniently located and easy to operate.  There is an on/off switch located behind the main control that will turn off the unit if you leave it plugged in.  (I always unplug everything before leaving my shop.)  The tank pressure gauge is just behind it.The main panel has a working pressure gauge with a pressure adjustment knob next to it.  This regulates the pressure that reaches the hoses, not the tank pressure.  If you work at lower pressures, the unit will not cycle as often.  It is also handy to limit the pressure to safe levels for your various air tools.  The two quick connect hose couplers are located on this panel also.You do have to "break it in" before working with it; just open the drain valve and let it run for 15 minutes.  Shut it off, close the valve and turn it back on; you're ready for action!  The unit really is portable, especially with the well balanced carry handle protruding from the top.  I can easily carry it with one hand from the tank side.I plug it directly into a 20 amp circuit and have had no problems with breakers popping.  I wired my shop area with 12/3 to carry enough current for power tools.  The unit does not stay on too long when it cycles, so the noise is not really a problem.  It is not as loud as large upright compressors, but it does make a fair amount of noise, although not as much as I expected.It will keep up with nailers and other "burst" applications without cycling too often.  I use it with a Souix air sander and it does run longer when I am working.  I like to take a break every minute or so to clear dust anyway, so this is not a problem.  I don't think it would keep up with two continuous flow tools.  Painting on furniture sized projects is no problem.  If you take on a tractor trailer, get a bigger compressor.Overall, this is an outstanding unit with few limitations for the average user.  I also consider it an great value, given its capacity and well thought out design.  It will be a great addition to your shop.  (It will also inflate tires!)
Stays compact when not in use. Does not tangle on itself like my old yellow hose. Would buy it again.

I strongly recommend picking up this accessory pack.  The rubber cover for the lens end that helps prevent the lamp from rolling and also absorbs some impact if dropped. The wrist strap lets you keep the lamp close at hand.  I usually put the strap around my wrist when I slide into my sleeping bag--if I need to get up quickly during the night, the lamp is always available without requiring me to feel around on the tent floor or in the storage pouches.As noted by other reviewers, the plastic lens colors have changed.  There are now blue, red, and clear lenses. I've found the red one useful when I want to rummage through a pack when my tentmate has already turned in for the night. It gives you illumination that is not as harsh as the non-filtered white light (and it doesn't reset your night vision either).My only complaint has also been mentioned in other reviews--there is no place to store the other plastic lenses.  I keep the red one on all the time, and I stow the other two in the sheath for my multi-tool.  To me, getting the rubber cap and the wrist strap make this purchase worthwhile.  The filter lenses are just gravy.

Nicads are getting cheaper and cheaper because they aren't as good as Lithium Ion batteries that are becoming the popular battery.  Lithium batteries have many advantages over the old Nicad batteries, they hold their 100% power to the end, which Nicads slowly lose their power.  Lithium batteries are lighter, the Nicads are really heavy.  Lithium Ion batteries keep their charge better when not in use, offer more power, and don't have "memory" problems.  They last longer than NiCads, too.  I think it's dishonest of this Amazon seller not to mention that these are NiCad batteries, although I can understand why he would do it, he's hoping people won't realize there is a difference so he can make higher profits.  VERY dishonest, in my opinion!  I have both the XRP Nicad, and the smaller lithium ion Dewalt batteries, and the Lithium Ion batteries are far superior, let alone making your cordless tools much lighter.  It costs much more to make Lithium Ion batteries, and thus a higher selling price,  but you get what you pay for.
summary: Nicad, something this seller is avoiding mentioning.

reviewText: I was looking for an affordable replacement to my killawat meter that got lost somewhere in my house.This one seems up to the job of monitoring. It's very basic!Pro's:- Works on 110-120V for sure!- Reads Wh use- Reads $/year on electricity usage- Reads CO2 output; value can be adjusted (depending if you know how much CO2 will be produced making the electricity you're using), and can be read in LBS or KG.- The wired display allows you to see the display even when plugging the base somewhere behind a closet's (or a difficult to reach) wall socketCons:- $/Year electricity use is just a calculator. One can set how much electricity 1kWh costs, and the device will be multiplying the value of Watts hr usage x price/kWh x 24hrs x 365 days, and display that value in $$/Yr.- The $$/kWh value only accepts one value, no day/night time calculations.- Display does not have back-light- The base of the device (that plugs in a wall socket) is quite wide. It covers more than 3 sockets in width.- Anything with a cable (headphones, laptop chargers, cellphone chargers) are prone to wear. I don't expect this device to last forever, but the cable makes it a lot weaker! As long as you're careful with the cable it'll last a long time.Other thoughts:Both the left button (world icon), and the middle button (Dollar sign), can be pressed long (+3 seconds) to customize some values. The left will allow you to change the CO2 usage from LBS to KG (by pressing left or right; confirm with center button), the middle will allow you to set the kWh price (de-/increase in steps of $0.01 / kWh); increasing using the right button, decreasing value using the left button, confirming using the center.The device uses ~0.5W by itself to power the display, or would cost you ~$0.5 per year plugging it in 24/7.It reads actual watts, can't read I over U phase shifts on AC.The device supposedly has a bar on the bottom showing when electricity is used, however unlike a mechanical watt meter, the bar won't blink faster when using more electricity. It's just has 10 pixels going on, one after the other when electricity is used; more like a thing for looks, not really to show accurate electricity use.Conclusion:For me, I don't care about the extra stuff that comes with it. I just wanted a Watt meter, and for that purpose it works just fine! I'm not fond of the wide base covering up multiple sockets, and the cable design. But I like the idea of a remote display.For the price, it's a good watt meter!
Every now and then I run a cross a product that is both inexpensive and attractive.  This product is just that, AND it works well.  I must say that I am pleasantly surprised and very happy.

Followed wire check on my iPad to see if unit was compatible with my 15 year old A/C and heating system. Told to take picture of wiring and send to tech. support then call them. Called them in two minutes after sending pic. They had pic, said Yes there is no problem with my regular 4 wire system. Went to Lowe's and bought it, installed unit and iPad app. in one hour. .......Days later.....In Hawaii on the beach.....Senior Mother calls and wants to go swim in my pool at home and stay the night since her A/C has failed and it's 112F. I said sure Mommy.......and using my iPhone I changed the temp in the house from Away 98F to 72F for her.  That alone was worth the high price of the unit for me..  Works great, looks good, saves time and money!

Using these, they will provide the calories and some other nutrients to help through an emergency.  The shelf life seems adequate for these, as it will be quite a while before I need to replace them.  The manufacturing date was within the past 2 months, so I get to take advantage of nearly the full shelf life before replacing these.I have not opened the packages (for obvious reasons), but the dividing lines between the 9 portions is obvious through the packaging, so they should be easy to break down into proper portion sizes.A good addition to the emergency kit in my car.

I read some of the reviews of this product before writing my own. First of all I'd like to say that these bars aren't meant to be a nutritionally balanced, filling, enjoyable snack. They're designed to give someone in extreme conditions much needed calories so they can wait to be rescued or walk out of whatever emergency they are facing. Our own 72-hour bags contains Mainstay Emergency Food Bars, some mylar packets of drinking water, a small jar of peanut butter, some mylar packets of tuna, some beef jerky, a personal water purifier and other items. Since we may have to carry those packs on our backs for a long distance, how much it all weighs is important.  Mainstay bars are the most calories you can pack into a little packet.The bars themselves aren't bad. They taste like a dense lemon shortcake breakfast type bar. They're a little pasty, but totally edible. And if I'm hungry enough, they'll taste great.  They don't leave you feeling thirsty, which is also good in an emergency when water might be rationed. Each person's backpack should have one packet to see them through to their next hot meal. Because they're sealed in heavy mylar packaging, they will last for several years without spoiling, which adds to my peace of mind.Each 400 calorie portion (there are 9 in each packet) contains 400 calories, 3 grams of fiber, 46 grams of carbs, 69 grams of fat, vitamins A (16%), C (30%), D (16%), calcium (16%), and lesser amounts of niacin, iron, folic acid, magnesium and thiamine.If you really don't like these bars, try Datrex Emergency Food bars. They are coconut flavored, and have similar packaging and calories.
summary: Quick energy in emergency situation, long shelf life

reviewText: At -15 degree's last week, Colorado, the gloves performed well and my hands were kept warm.  The fingertips are effective when manipulating your smartphone, even in cold weather, and the product arrived on time and unmolested.  Excellent gloves!
