reviewText: Good product.  I've used several different types and lengths of ratchet strap tie downs over the years, and glad I have this one now, as I've often needed a longer strap than I had available.  More often than not a simple 8ft strap will do for me, when when it doesn't, well, there's not much you can do other than bust out the rope.  This 16ft length is great if that's what you need -- something long.  If you need something much shorter than this but want to buy the 16ft just to have some level of comfort, I'd advise against it -- in my experience the extra length just gets in the way and is a pain to deal with.I found the hooks on this strap nice, "J" hooks that seem to be nice and firm and unlikely to bend/break easily (like with some of the cheap-o models you find in the discount bins at the hardware store).  The ratchet works easily, without much drag.  Great that it slides, so that you can adjust where you want to use it. Nice touch.  Overall, it does what it should, and how it should.  I have no complaints, and would consider getting another one of these in the future (but probably at a shorter length now that I have a nice long 16ft'er!).
summary: Decent LONG rachet strap tie down.

reviewText: I have been very satisified with this drill.  I purchased this because I wanted additional batteries for my Makita tool  set.  The price for batteries and the price including the drill was no contest.

My last several tool bag purchases have all had something in common: The company who made them put a lot of effort and focus on how the bag looks on the shelf, and from there they seemed to cut corners on the small details that eventually results in it falling apart or disappointing me in some way.Not this one, not Milwaukee.  Finally it seems that someone had a person sitting at the design table who had actually spent time working with tools, and carrying toolbags.Evidence of this is in the PROS:-  Metal clips for the shoulder strap. They look better and will last longer no doubt.-  Padded bottom.  Eliminates the chance of damaging tools resting in the bottom of the bag when you throw other heavier tools on top of them.  It's very padded, more so than most.-  The pockets are well stitched.  They are not too loose, not too tight (a major complaint of mine with most every other bag I've owned).-  The larger pockets on the inside of either end appear to be made for a drill battery, or something of that size.  But, I've found they are perfect for a 30' tape measure or keeping plastic jars of small items like wire nuts or crimp on connectors in.  This is a major improvement because previously I was unable to fit those items in any kind of pocket at all and they frequently got damaged by the other metal tools.-  Looks great.  Not many others have this bag so it gets a lot of looks.-  The handles are not flimsy, they are sturdy, stiff reinforced handles.-  Wire reinforced top and base means it won't look like a dirty, wet bag of rocks in 6 months.CONS:FYI - I still gave it 5 stars because for the price of this bag the CONS are acceptable compared to the price (for under $30 they can't give you the world), and these things are secondary to the pros:-  Shoulder strap has a rubber piece on it to protect your shoulder.  It is too thin and slides all over the strap and rarely ends up on your shoulder.-  The bag is big enough in size that unless you store light objects the shoulder strap is not a good carrying option.  The handles are extra strong, but the strap seems extra light.-  Zipper could be better quality.  This is not a big deal to me personally because I keep it opened 99.9% of the time for easy access.  If you are in a harsh environment AND need to use the zipper often then weigh this CON heavily.Highly recommend.  For the price tag it is a very high quality item.
summary: Very Good Tool Bag.  Suitable for a Heavy Industrial Environment.

reviewText: This product can only go to 9.99 for the cost of a kilowatt Hour but my electric company charges 10,02 so this product is obsolete. Because at a lot of energy companies are already charging more per kilowatt hour than the product can calculate. So wait and get a latter model, don't buy this model.

I have a 5 piece combo kit from Makita as well as the multi-tool and jobsite radio. The tools work well and feel well in your hand.  They are ergonomically designed and the batteries charge fast and have a long lasting charge. I use these tools in a construction environment and they get used daily, all day.  I used to use a different popular brand and did not like the design or batteries on those tools.  This impact drill is awesome, as is the hammer drill. Reciprocating saw, circular saw, flashlight, multi-tool and radio are also great.Although I did have my duffle bag from the combo kit rip on the front zipper seam after about a year. I'm working on getting a replacement for that.  Also after about 2 years and 6 months one of the batteries from the kit went bad and no longer charges.  The batteries have a one year warranty so I can't get it replaced.So here is why I bought this kit.  I was looking to buy a replacement battery as I only have one left.  I figured I might as well buy the 2 pack of 3.0 Ah batteries for $170.  For  $130 more than that  I can get this kit which includes 2 batteries and an impact driver, better version of the hammer drill driver, pus another charger and case.  Since I'm going to use all of these tools anyway and it would be nice to keep these new drills around the house as the other ones are in the work truck, it makes more sense for me to buy this kit than just 2 batteries.Of course to top it off Makita is having a battery promotion that started the day I bought this that offers a free battery by mail in rebate for buying this kit.  So now I will get another $100 value battery with this kit.  I could always use another battery, so for the cost of 3 batteries plus $30 more I bought this kit.
This was used to secure a propane tank to a hand cart.  It  alone would not do the job.  I used a tie down with this and the two of them together do th job.
Inexpensive, and functional.  Funny enough, my previous remote just needed a new battery.
summary: Funny enough, my previous remote just needed a new ...

reviewText: The handles are very well designed so your hands do not slip, they are very sharp and cut great. The only wood I have used them on so far is pine. I will see how they do on a harder wood in the near future but I doubt I will have any problems.
I love this set.  It's everything I need to get started on some home projects.  I love the design and the amount of selection is fantastic.  Well worth the price.  I would buy this product, again.

After using a Fat Max, you will not go back to the other flimsy tape measures.  The standout is outstanding!  The 16' is the smallest (although still FAT as the name implies) and for most jobs, the most useful.  I also keep a 25' & 30' in the toolbox, but the 16' comes with me.  I usually do not have to measure anything longer than 16' and this is great to keep on your belt, or in your car.  If Stanley made a FAT MAX mini maybe slightly thinner, and 12' but still sturdy and with a nice stand out, I would be all over that also.  I keep buying these because they keep disapearing from jobsites. Annoying, yes, but a testament to the fact that once people use them, they don't want to let them go.
summary: My all time favorite tape measure!

reviewText: THESE ARE HIGH QUALITY BUNGEE CORDS THAT COME IN MANY ASSORTED SIZES..THE REAL SMALL ONES ARE USELESS FOR MY NEEDS BUT THE LARGER ONES FIT MY NEEDS.PERFECTLY..

This Maxxima 2-LED nightlight is a good choice for those who wish to save energy over the traditional incandescent light-bulb nightlight.  Of course the light is a bright white color instead of a warm yellow that you can get from an incandescent bulb.  But it stays cool and uses a lot less energy.This nightlight is excellent at sensing motion and coming on only when needed, should you choose this setting.  The glass front is frosted to help keep the LEDs from being piercingly bright.  If you must plug your nightlight into an outlet, I would recommend this nightlight.If you would like something a bit more compact, consider Maxxima's 3-LED nightlight, which is smaller and even brighter (but requires batteries as it cannot be plugged in.)My chief two complaints about this 2 LED nightlight #1 - it is large and covers both outlets on a standard AC/DC wall outlet.  #2 - this nightlight can also operate on batteries, but NOT rechargeable batteries.
Nice gloves but seem a little tight. I've used other brands that fit better but this one is fine for the money.

I have owned another dado set for many years, it was time to replace so I had to choose between this set and a same replacement for my old dado set. This set won out due to the very good reviews on Amazon and other woodworking sites. It is what Oshlun claims it to be: Sharp, sharp and so close to chip free cuts. Had a few very very small chips at the very end of the cuts but they were so small and will be hidden anyway with the shelves in place.The dado is virtually dust free and very very clean cut. I recommend this set to all fellow woodworkers; you can't beat the price for the high quality.As many other reviews stated, the set cuts under the stated size of combined blades; but this is a common trait of dado sets and enough shims are provided to size for the too varied of thicknesses in today's plywood, even the high price hardwoods are not uniform from the same pallet. So be patient grasshoppers and use the shims. Buy this dado set, you will be pleased with the performance.

I purchased these lights to help illuminate those hard to light and reach places: closet shelves, deep kitchen cabinets, over my stove to better light cooking surface, etc. The light is very bright and is of a bluish hue which is a bit cooler than I would prefer. I did find that if the surface the lights are applied to is in anyway uneven, the light does not stay in place. In those applications, the adhesive does not seem to be adequate. A bit of glue solved the problem since the light's base does not have to be moved when changing batteries.
summary: Bright lights, easy to install and use but may need extra glue to stay in place

reviewText: I bought this from Amazon after having bad luck with the brands available at the local home improvement store. It worked exactly as advertised. It was easy to mix and set up in about 5-minutes. When fully cured the product holds very solid just as you would expect.

I have this watch dog float switch attached to a small sump pump to pump out water in a shed when we have very heavy storms and water blows in.  It activates the pump when water is a little over 1/4 of on inch deep on the floor. Seems to work well now - hope it will continue to function for a long time.

I have four of these and have not had a problem with any of them yet. All of them supply equal power. They all hold a charge and have held up to many charges without any decline in power. They work as well as they did the day I took them out of the package. Home Depot has a special now where you get a free one when you purchase a Hammer Drill / Driver kit. I might have to act on this to get 3 more!

I haven't used this set a whole lot.  It comes with a lot of blades and shims.  The blades are sharp.  It comes in a cardboard box that doesn't hold up very well.  You might want to make a box to store them in.  The cuts are clean and I'm happy with it.
summary: Good Dado Set at a Good Price

reviewText: I really like this unit.  It is very smooth in its operation.  The ability for it to reach out farther is reason enough to buy this unit.So many times with other tape measures I have tried to get a rough measurement when alone buy pulling out the tape in mid air and when I get to that last foot, sure enough the tape flops over.  This tape gives you that little extra length to keep the flop from happening.  I can get out almost 10 feet. I highly recommend it.

I use disposable gloves everyday in the process of doing business. I have purchased a multitude of different glove brands and was disappointed by all of them. SAS Ravens are the best I have ever used. The color is awesome and they are extremely strong. It maybe a coincidence but I also noticed that ever since I have been wearing these gloves my customers are very willing to pay their bills.

this saw is hard to get used to. it has a spring loaded guard that you need to hold a trigger to release it, while using the saw you need to push down all the way, and forward. this combination is actually more dangerous than having the guard there in the first place. because you have to focus pushing downward, it's easy to slip out of the cut, i'm temped to pull out one of those wheels and replace it with a thumb screw.its also uncomfortable to hold, the device flares out and digs into your hand, something else i have to modify.and the laser is battery operated, leave it on and it dies. the laser is also far too bright, i can't see the pencil line and for the most part is a useless feature since it really only works well for long things, and if i were cutting something long, i would use a real saw.  the saw is strong enough to push through 3/4" plywood and the small size makes it easy for an afternoon job, or a plunge cut.  all the dust shoots out the bottom of the cut. because you can only use one hand to use it, there is still a chance you'll cut a thumb off if your holding the board in place.i love the bag, i wish all tools came in bags. it's about the size of a shoe box, and you can put other tools in there. right now i have that and a rotozip, seems like a good combo. i wish the bag has straps for a shoulder though, it doesn't even have rings for one. but it's sort of a bonus so i shouldn't complain.it was between this one and the dremel max thing, i didn't get dremel due to the terrible blade design they had, grinding wood will just start fires. this saw actually has a blade.oh and while small, and seemingly perfect for cutting things like lattice or thin stock. you still need to put it on a table, because of that darn guard, pushing it down and forward is too hard. so the dremel would win cutting that kind of stock.
summary: like the saw, hate the gaurd

reviewText: It seems to be accurate and well made.  I seem to be unable to judge for myself when water is appropriate for my indoor plants and have over watered them in the past.  This gauge will help keep my plants healthy.

Let me first say that like the K3 idea and I've had a K2000 for years and loved it.  I like the idea of a single tool being utilized in two holders for both benchtop and portable work.  It's also great that you can choose board thickness by just by a simple adjustment without having to remove or add parts.Now, what I didn't care for was that the new benchtop system doesn't hold stock near as firmly as the K2000.  This is true because I still have a 2000 and I've tested it because I thought it was odd that I could rock the material in the new K3 system benchtop system.  The same stock (especially 1/2" material) was rock solid in the K2000.  It's not enough to make the K3 unworkable, however it is enough that I noticed it right away.  I wrote Kreg and they admitted that it doesn't hold the stock as firm but feel the other benefits outweight it.  I'm glad I kept the old K2000 for benchtop work and use the K3 system like I did my old Rocket.  In looking at the system, it became obvious to me why it doesn't hold stock quite as well - there is no lower support for the board and the face of the jig is now a polished aluminum instead of the glass re-inforced plastic which provides more friction.  Additionally, the K2000 has a single ram which doesn't allow the clamp portion to move from side to side, where the K3 system does give a little.I'm not down on the new tool, however this is a review of my experience and it defeats the purpose if I don't call it like I see it.  If I had it to do again, I'd have remained perfectly happy with the K2000 and then just bought the K3 standard pack.Edit as of 03-10:  I stand by my review but will admit that I have used it a great deal - I simply hold narrow pieces with my left hand while drilling with my right.  I was at a woodworking show and a Kreg rep was there.  I posed the question as to why the jig does not hold material as solid and while they did admit that this is the case, my reasoning may be flawed.  He said that it is due to the "spring" built into the K3 that allows for small thicknesses of wood without having to readjust the clamp.  That makes sense to me, it's just too bad because the forward features of the jig such as that are certainly worthwhile, it just has this little side effect.  If you never had a K2000 or earlier model, you would never notice it.
Easy to lose the balance. And the other con is the metal hand is so strengthy. I really afraid my PCB hurt by them.
this product does not hold up to a small amount of use I am understanding what you pay for is what you get.
It is here and unpacked, untested and not installed.  It is intended to be part of a 12v lighting system in a garage with no mains supply.  It's too cold to do it now.

This blade is awesome. When I opened it up just the heft and size of the blade were nice. The plate thickenss was great and prevents blade deflection when cutting large hardwood items.  The carbide on the teeth is also HUGE and made of quality carbide.  When cutting you will notice this thing is SUPER quiet, the motor of the saw makes more noise then the blade cutting the material. Its unreal.The only downside if you will is I am more a fan of HATB blades, and this blade didn't have enough bevel on it....so I sent it out to my blade sharpener and he changed it to 40 degree ATB.... now cuts super clean, super straight cross cuts in plywood, but it wasn't horriable before.

Has a nice long screw to hold it into the outlet.  GE branded but this is a PRC product that seems to be of serviceable quality.  The spacing between the outlets is pretty tight, but standard plugs fit, though very tightly and right against each other.  I use them in the office to plug in various printers, cable modem, router, etc.

Perfect for our kitchen. I removed faceplate and pluge/screwed this over and it's great! I like to leave appliances plugged in so I don't need to hunt for the plug/outlet. This way I can leave them plugged in all the time. It does NOT increase the wattage so you will still be limited on how much your particular circuit will allow. I just like the convenience of not having to plug/unplug each time I want to use the can opener or toaster. Great item! btw ... someone complained that they were too close together? I have 3 plugs in the top row and it's fine. My telephone "adapter" is a wider square and so only two will fit on that row but it's not a regular plug.
The Neiko 40290 Super-Bright 21-LED Aluminum Flashlight, Gunmetal Silver is perfect for my roadside emergent kit.  has tremendous light output, is lightweight and very compact.
summary: Neiko 40290 Super-Bright 21-LED Aluminum Flashlight, Gunmetal Silver

reviewText: for the router bits that i have used they cut with ease and very clean edges.  really like this set better than  the 1/4 inch shank set

I love this thing. I rip laptops apart with it all of the time. I like that you can just push down making it easier to not strip screws. I liked it so much I sent one to my friend that does computer repair. He has other tips that fit it so he even uses it on iPhones.
This pry bar arrived with sharp points and has been great for removing plywood in my attic and pulling up nails.  Have not had any problems with it, and it seems like it will last forever.
At last!  A broom that does NOT take three swipes to move dirt and grass clippings.
easy to install and the bottle is a nice size for a good amount of soap. the material it is made out of looks sturdy and i hope i have this for a long time. for now it looks and works great.
Be sure you understand the size of this lamp.  It is TINY and the spotlight it puts out is small.  Not expensive, but also not very useful unless you need cordless and a small, focused light.
it does what it should but you  need ear plugs or go deaf again order quality over unknown brands verry loud
summary: not expensive but good an loud

reviewText: This came fully assembled and the cost was surpringly very low. I glued it to my workbench and I'm happy with it. Try it you'll like it.

I only use this for soldering small wire.  It's OK, but it's a lot smaller than it looks in the photo (my fault, the dimensions are on the Amazon page).  The base is weighted, but it's so tiny that it tips easily.  Like another reviewer said, you have to use the magnifying glass as a counter-balance to keep the thing upright.  You need to plan to attach it to a board or workbench to use it.  Cheap, though.
summary: Wish I had paid more attention to the dimensions

reviewText: 12 oz. is now my prefered mallet weight. The head is small, relative to wooden mallets, but the fact that the head is so close to the hand when striking makes, careful, controlled strikes a breeze.I knew for the price that there would be some kind of issue with this mallet.The handle I received was birch, which is fine by me, but it is such a quick, fun job to make one single handle that I went for the cherry scraps and whipped one up. The way I like it.Making a new handle was not a necessity. Unless, like me, you find that polyurethane should not be used on tool handles. Poly just does not work for me when my hands clam up in the heat. So I carved a new handle. Rubbed some walnut oil on with some XXXX steel wool. Wax, then buff.Now I have a wonderful tool, just the way I wanted it. Perfect weight. The head stays on without any issue (I dropped a little titebond down the screw holes before installing the new head). Just what I wanted for smashing and taping all my chisel handles.Lost a star from me for the poor handle that came with it. But for what I paid, that is exactly what I expected.

I have a airless paint sprayer that I use for the bigger jobs with 5 gallon paint buckets but I also wanted a smaller, easier to use unit for the little jobs, and one that cost under $100.  After reading reviews for a variety of sprayers on several sites I settled on this one.  While I've only used it a couple of times for touchups and blendings I think I made the right choice.  One of the benefits I didn't anticipate is that when painting deck rails under overhanging trees the air that's rushing out before I press the paint trigger helps blow off any small debris that falls constantly.UPDATE: I recently needed to paint a gate with several not-easy-to-access surfaces.  Using this sprayer made it easy and cleanup is easy enough that small jobs are no problem.2nd UPDATE:  While I continue to find that this works great with paint I tried to use it to spray KILZ primer and found that it couldn't handle the thick viscosity.  I doubt if any small sprayer could and it's something to be aware of.

I was impressed at first, by the look I needed for my wife's small bath. her old fan was clogged, noisy & didn't seem to move air at all. I ordered this model since her original fan had a built in light in her shower with the fan unit. After a difficult install, (tin ceiling under the sheetrock & tile), I was glad to get it finished. The problem is that it does not have the fan power the old unit had, which seemed tiny & old.After her first shower, she raved about the better lighting but the fan doesn't have half the power the old one had so it leaves the bathroom steamy. I contacted Hunter & they said I would have to  return it to where I bought it, get a refund, then order a larger CFM fan type. Well I tossed the original box, so that's where it stands. Poor fan unit & there is no model upgrade to a bigger fan as he fan boxes are 1/2 inch or more bigger. So we are stuck & a new ones is even more money.
summary: Not what I had expected from Humter

reviewText: I received these today.  Put one in to the furnace, and made sure to put a reminder on my telephone calendar to change the furnace filter.  Good thing to put in a reminder.  Hadn't changed my furnace filter in over a year, and it was black, and coming out of the carton.  Will be ordering this product again in 5 1/2 months.  Great value for the money.  Definitely recommend this product.

reviewerName: Adrian in Phoenix "No Time for Fantasy"
reviewText: Slip-joint pliers have been around for a long time.  The new pushbutton feature on these is convenient and useful.These pliers feel good in the hand, appear to be well made, and function as expected.I haven't used them enough yet to make them my "go to" tool, but it looks like they'll earn that status.
A+++ Just as described

This 4 louver vent works well.  It has a sturdy mounting frame and well designed max opening stops.  Simple.  I used it to replace a broken plastic vent in a greenhouse.  Added some eyelets and chain opener to open the louvers manually instead of going with the added cost of a thermostat and opener.  This is exactly as pictured; gable vent, aluminum frame and louvers.  One comment I appreciated by another reviewer was about the noise in the wind.  I did have the same problem, as the vent was installed on the windward side of the building and did flap from time to time.  I solved the issue by epoxing steel washers to the back of each louver to make increase the mass.
summary: 4 louver alum vent works as noted

reviewText: Good tools for engraving. Has the usual Dremel quality. Fun to learn to engrave and practice carving with this descent set.
summary: Dremel 689-01 11-Piece Rotary Tool Carving and Engraving Kit

reviewText: where I work I use these every day, several times a day.  The only drawback I found is there isn't a belt clip on the little guy, so I end up carrying it around in my back pocket, which isn't the most comfortable thing to sit on.  If you do carry yours in a pocket make sure to check on the thumb screw every once in awhile cause it tends to work its way loose and fall off in your pocket. This is a bit of a problem because you then have to hope the nut is still in the pocket too.  I haven't lost any parts but have spent a few minutes cussing myself for not checking more often.  The other little annoying thing is the razor has to but exactly perfect for the little guy to close right.  If its not just right you can't get the protective cover back in place.  I must say though, its so much better than the retractable holders that are always letting the blade slide back into the handle when you try to scrape something off a window.  If I could clip it to my belt I would give it five stars.

Ours kept falling off the faucet because I messed up the installation, and for some reason we decided to replace the whole thing when it really wouldn't stay on anymore rather than simply ordering a new faucet adapter.  Glad we did.Feature-wise, this is no different from our previous one, but it's soooooo much more well made.  The switch from straight tap to filter moves easily whereas the old one was kind of stiff so we had to hold onto the whole unit to keep it from moving.We filter a lot of water, probably more than most people, and we only need to replace filters about once a month.  I suppose normal users can go at least three months before needing to replace a filter.TIPS:When installing, do not use plumbers tape on the threads.  You don't need it; the whole unit installs as is, out of the box, without addition.Buy your replacement filters on Amazon where you can get two for about $20 instead of in your local store where they will likely cost you $20 each.Don't wait to see a red indicator light to replace the filter if it's only giving you a dribble.  If it's dribbling, it's time to replace the filter.Every few months, take it off the faucet and clean the screen because it's likely clogged up with particles--this is the same type of screen that is there regardless of whether you have a filtration system or not.BOTTOM LINE: Like the commercial says, buying bottled water is a waste.  The Brita pitcher isn't really useful though because it's too slow, but this filtration system is great for making full pots of coffee every day in addition to filtering any other water you consume--such as for cooking.The water in New York City is exceptionally clean, but when you run it through the Brita filter it's clearer than crystal and you can taste the difference.Forget bottled water, the Brita pitcher, and all other handy filtration systems--this is the best.
summary: Bought as a replacement and it turned out to be much improved.

reviewText: I bought the M12 hackzall from home depot but returned it after purchasing the M18 hackzall in a combo kit... The M18 is alot faster and more powerful but MOST importantly it vibrates less than the smaller less powerful M12... the M18 has an antivibration mechanism that really helps in making cuts... if the item your cutting isn't held really rigid the item just shakes back and forth and you go nowhere thats why the M18 is so much more superior than the M12
summary: Don't bother with the M12 get the M18

reviewText: Any of these kinds of accessories eventually get used and they work. I have not used them so far, but not much has been happening with my handtools
This is the flashlight to have. Remember they use plastic lenses so be prepared to get some better glass ones.

The instructions for this block plane are pretty weak. Butafter sharpening the iron and getting it set up, it works very well. The iron seems to take a good edge. I've used it quite a bit, and I haven't had to fiddle with it again. It shaves nice long curls of maple and douglas fir.

I bought these for BBQ and mechanic work, so far only have used them for BBQ.  They worked great and kept the hands clean while prepping meat.  Only reason that they aren't 5 stars is that they run a little small son it takes me a little effort to get  them on right.

I gave three stars because the bit appears to be well constructed.  But, the cutting edge of the bit is rebated.  The cutting bit is smaller in diameter than the bearing.  Maybe, hopefully, someone with more experience will leave a comment explaining this. I may be wrong, in that case I think the bit would be worthy of five stars.

This is a great saw that is very powerful and cuts very fast given its size and intended purpose . It's very well made and fits the hand nicely . This little gem will be a favorite of a good many tradesman once they buy or borrow one . The features like the built in lite , battery meter , tool free blade changes and overall quality is proof of milwaukees continued commitment to making the best of the best .  This saw has a fixed base rather than a swivel base found on the bigger saws . This is not a full size saw however capable of doing the things full size saws do . It's a saw you use in places the full size saw won't fit . It's what you use on light weight stuff when the big saws are not needed . I love it for drywall ,cutting traps and sink drains etc.. As for the complaints by some of the Mary's that have written reviews about excessive vibration I don't see it . It is  necessary  to always keep the saw base firmly against what you are cutting . Start your saw slowly and then bring your blade into what your cutting with lite pressure at first . Increasing the speed of the saw once you have established a straight cut . Running the saw too fast at first and or allowing the blade to bind up is what causes the vibration in any saw . In the right hands this saw is a pleasure to use and very effective . I'm surprised by just how smooth this saw is considering its size and weight . It doesn't vibrate nearly as much as  a full size saw when you hold it in one hand .  While I don't like seeing made in china stamped on the side clearly it's still milwaukee quality .  Milwaukee has been forced to go with cheaper labor because everyone else already has due to the number of foolish consumers in this country buying up as much foreign made products as possible . Even though the American made products while a little more exspensive are almost always better .

I've had one of these for about eight years. It's been useful for setting finish nails when there's not room to swing a hammer or a hammer isn't at hand. It's basically a nail set tip attached to a spring attached to a length of drill rod (all nicely machined of course). You pull back the rod and let it go to drive the tip onto the nail. It's a great design and couldn't be simpler or more foolproof.

There is no lock to hold the blade shut when its not in use  so if its laying around or in something thats moving around the blade can start coming out.  Metal is pretty flimsy and i bent it the first time i used it.

This sander is what I needed. It really takes away the wood if your not careful. It's powerful. Easy to assemble. The disc is true with no wobble like the cheaper ones. The tilting table really came in handy. Can't ask for more
I liked some of the hooks, but it needed more special  hooks, like the loops two wire hooks.  The single wire hooks were loose in the broad and pulled off as you removed the tool.

you get what you see and it works. it is a nice piece of hardware - not too heavy and not too light - designed to carry the weight of a bike..don't let your kids play with it and use it as a climb rope or similiar..

Wow this thing is bright. I wanted one of the most powerful and compact lights I could find and I cant imagine getting anything more powerful. At night this may cause temporary (or permanent?) blindness. When I'm in my master bedroom and shine it out the tinted window to the back yard it looks like daylight. I am really impressed and the product feels solid. I also have one of the cheap 1000 lumen knockoffs and it is not only brighter but has better flood.

THESE FILTERS FIT THE AC UNIT VERY WELL. SEEM TO BE WELL FABRICATED AND WILL SERVE JUST FINE. THE PRICE IS ALSO MUCH BETTER THAN SOME OTHER ONES LIKE HONEYWELL. I WILL BUY THIS PRODUCT AGAIN WHEN THE TIME COMES TO REPLACE THEM. DELIVERY TIME WAS REALLY GOOD.

These are comfortable all day long, and allow me to blast my music in my shop or garage and still enjoy the music.  You really don't feel disconnected like using most ear protection, and people sound like people when they need to get your attention.

This model came with a different cone design (the reflector aspect). This different cone design made the beam uniform as it was projected on a wall. The previous ones I bought seem to have a brighter more focused beam-----subjectively speaking. No light meter to guage the lemens/brightness of beam.

I bought two of these to light up my campsite in the desert (no more Coleman propane lantern). All the other folks with regular flashlights or expensive headlamps were caught off guard when I turned it on. It's bright! It does chew batteries - both the batteries AND the metal casing around the LEDs run warm (but not hot) to the touch - but if you want lots of light you can't expect batteries to last forever. The 4 AA batteries are in a holder that slides into the handle and provides 6 volts to the switch. If you're handy with tools and solder, you could adapt this quite easily to run on 6V lantern batteries. That's my next project! A diffuser would be nice for area lighting (like a picnic table) instead of the beam the LEDs put out by default. It's not tight focus. If you want to spotlight a very distant object, get one with a lense. On the other hand, no lense and LEDs recessed in a metal grid mean you can set it down anywhere and not scratch the business end.

This bulb provides very nice light in its area. Perfect for reading or working on less detailed projects without the aid of a lamp or spot light. I also appreciate that it throws off a bit less heat than its counterparts since we usually have to spend additional energy dollars counteracting the heat with air conditioning.It's nice to see more products like this become more easily accessible on the consumer market.

Not much more to say than you get what you pay for.  There are many cheaper versions of this knife that I have accumulated over the years from bank give aways etc.  All of them have fatal flaws.  The tinker has none of that.  It is a solid perfomer for everything.  I've used it camping and the can opener and knife are really useful.  I've used it in the office where the knife and screwdfivers are useful.  I still have yet to use the hook, but I am sure that is coming.The only flaw I see to these knives are the toothpick and tweezers.  The toothpick I will never use on my teeth though it is great for resetting electronics.  The tweezers in past swiss army models I've owned has become stuck, but this one still works well.Overall, you can't beat a classic and I own three versions of the swiss army knifes and alternate them with my leatherman wave to use for miscellaneous tasks.MM

I have used one like this in the past. It makes getting the AC in correctly easy. I have never liked trusting the window to hold the unit correctly. On the smaller units, because they weigh less, it is probably safe. On the heavier ones, I would not trust the windows to hold them in place.It is not quite so easy to put them in as they ads usually say. There are three screws that are quite long.  A drill to pre drill the holes would be most helpful. You must also be able to lift the unit to see if the motors weight is to one side of the other. Also, the widow should have a sill that projects out from the outside wall 3-4 inches.

Ive had this set for about a year now and these tools are great. I had a small issue with the drill chuck comming out but it was covered under warranty and I suspect it was a rare occurance, partially due to using the drill to mix thinset with a paddle mixer. I use these tools on a daily basis and they have held up well. I have had employees drop them off roofs, ladders, and general bouncing around with no issues. This is a professional quality tool and can handle tough situations and some abuse. The impact driver is a thing of beauty and everyone who uses it is amazed at the torque the tool puts out. Its also really compact. The batteries are the compact models but seem to last a fairly long time and charge quickly. The larger batteries will also fit the tool if necessary.  If you arnt familiar with lithium batteries, these are the way to go. They have pretty much full power untill they are completly drained.For the price of these tools I would recomend them to anyone. They are clearly professional grade, but these are two tools you will use often even if you dont use them professionally. Its also really nice to be able to drill with one and drive with the other if you are working with hardwoods.

I've had a love/hate relationship with halogen bulbs for a while now. I love the look of the light itself, and hate the heat and maintenance. Most of the lighting in my house is LED, and what I wanted was an led light that would work in pendant lamps in my bedroom.This is perfect. The light is easy and comfortable with the right amount of spread. The heat sink does get very warm, but it's not outputting heat the way halogens do. Because leds last longer, and aren't as fussy as halogens, it's easier to change bulbs and bulb changes will be a lot less frequent.Great choice, and my husband and I like it enough we are recommending the bulbs to friends.
These work well, the rope is more than big enough to hold any bike that I might have.  I wish I had bought a few more at the price I got them at.

reviewText: There are three screws by the prongs which attach very quickly (like 1 revolution) where you can unscrew the unit and attach the wires.  The other two screws are for clamping down on the cable you pass in.  Bought one to replace a UPS power supply that was puppy or rabbit chewed, the other for a vacuum cleaner end (same damage).  Because you can attach a wire so quickly (in under a minute), it's handy to use around the house (testing out pumps, motors, etc) - backed  by a GFCI outlet, of course.

This is my second one. My first I got for Christmas several years ago and I wore it out. I keep it in the kitchen to keep my kitchen knifes sharp. I don't really use the diamond steel but it seems to be functional.
works better than a Porter cable FN lighter too like the style and how it works turned up the air pressure to 90 lbs and shoots every time like clockwork!!!!!

I am a beader and found this 64-drawer craft cabinet to be perfect for those small items. I store beads/crystals and findings by color or type, label the outside, and everything is easily retrievable.  Each drawer is removable but cannot fall out easily.  The drawers have slots dividing them into two equal sections, and dividers are available for purchase, however, cardboard the thickness of the back of a tablet works equally well.  Just cut it to fit.There are extra dividers at the rear of the cabinet, but these help stabilize the unit and the cardboard works perfectly.The only negative might be the tipping factor.  But the cabinet can be secured to a wall to avoid this.  I placed a strip of rubber shelf liner under my unit and it seems stable.The fact that this storage cabinet is American made rates a big plus, also, the units are stackable.

Some day LED technology will improve enough that larger bulbs won't be necessary to get plenty of light, but until then, these extenders will find good use!

reviewText: I rated Crawford-Leigh Raawling Vertical Storage Organizer 4 stars because it is a good product. This storage organizer is built well and I like the mulitple see through pockets that save time and looks neat. I had spent quite a bit for candelabra LED bulbs. This socket adapter works great and allows me to use the bulbs in a standard lamp socket. I'm pleased.

13 months later than the below review.This is an update to my original one star review.  Need seems to figure in the performance of this heater. I woke up after a night of exceptionally cold temperatures for our area to discover that my well-fed home water system had frozen overnight and we had no water. The idea of sitting around holding a hair dryer on my pipes for who knows how long was not an attractive prospect, so instead I retrieved the heater and a full LP cylinder. Hooking it up was easy enough with the assistance of an adjustable wrench to ensure a tight connection on both ends with the hose. I double-checked the directions which were both printed on a small booklet attached to the unit, and printed on the side of the heater. There are many warnings to make sure the fan is running before starting it, so being sure to heed that I started it right up. While maintaining safe clearances I had the heater warm up the area where my well pump and pipes leading to the the house are located. The fan/blower was nice to maintain a directional heat right onto the frozen pipes. In no time at all the area and the pipes were warmed and the water system operational again.I've used smaller propane heaters in the past that lack blowing systems and are rated for way fewer BTU's - this heater was a whole different ballgame with the blower and a large tank. I'm impressed.  I did not do anything different this time except... I needed the heater and wasn't just testing it.  I know that makes no sense but I felt it only fair to revise the review.Mr. Heater Hero Forced Air Propane Heater 30,000-60,000 BTU/Hr. MH60CLPI probably shouldn't write reviews right after unsuccessfully testing a product.  Feeling is starting to come back to my fingers but it is slow.  I read manuals.  I read them multiple times with products I am unfamiliar with as opposed to computer related stuff where I have a high comfort factor.  Propane is flammable and not so good to breathe so I read this manual several times through before connecting anything.The connections were straight forward.  The admonishment to fully charge the battery was quite clear as well.  It looked pretty clear cut.  I charged the battery.  I connected the gas line to the tank and to the heater.  I turned on the fan which again you are cautioned to do, I did like all the cautions.  I let the fan run a bit and then I "slowly, this is another admonishment, pushed the orange starter button down.  The heater ignited, I got startled and the heater went out.  I tried again and this time was prepared for the sudden noise.  I let go of the ignition button and the heater went off.  After several attempts with no ignition, I recalled that there was an interlock and if you hadn't gotten it started, turn it off, turn the fan off and redo the starting process.I did this multiple times to no avail.  As soon as I let up the ignition button the heater stopped.  I did read that you should hold the ignition button from 30 to 60 seconds after the heater ignites.  I brought out a clock to make sure that I was actually waiting the appropriate length of time.  Due to the garage door being open, the garage was very chilly and I thought that maybe I was rushing my 1001, 1002 etc count of seconds.  I timed the length of time I was holding the ignition button and 30,60 and 90 seconds made no difference.  As soon as I took my finger off the button the heater stopped.I reread the manual and could not discover anything I was doing that was not part of the appropriate start up procedure.  At this point I had little feeling left in my toes and hands and decided that I had tested this product as far as I was physically able to stand it.I can't imagine that the coldness of my propane or garage had an impact as this is a heater.  It is supposed to be used in cold conditions.  The manual does not recommend use below zero degrees but my garage was no colder than 31 degrees according to my thermometer.On a plus note, if you get one that runs, it is substantially quieter than the ones I dealt with back in my construction job days.  The noise when it ignites was similar but a lot less loud than I remember.  The unit seems nicely constructed.  The manual is detailed as to how to do your start up.  The size is great compared to the old ones I remember.  If I could have got it to stay running I probably would have loved it and gone 5 stars.  Since I (and admittedly I could have screwed something up) could not get it to continue running after thoroughly reading the manual, I can't recommend it.
summary: Mr. Heater, Not So Hot, 2nd look Update!

reviewText: This is a great selection of bungee cords. I immediately used several to hold in place the cover I bought for my electric mobility scooter. The scooter is outside and the cover keeps the weather out, except when the wind blows it off.These bungees keep the strong gusts of wind from tearing off the cover.I am sure I will find additional uses for the others.
summary: Never Again Will I be without fasteners for large items.

reviewText: The XPR batteries hold a charge much longer than the standard 18v batteries that come with most tools.

When I showed this unit to my wife, she took it around the house and checked all of the batteries that seem to end up in our drawers.As others have stated, you need to test the batteries more than once.  But the instructions recommend this due to various factors.Since this device tests the battery under load, it should provide a more accurate test than simply using a voltmeter.There are a few issues though - albeit minor ones.First, the battery box is a bit difficult to open. Not a big deal, but it could have been a bit easier to open.Next, the instructions do not state to depress the button on the side of the unit to turn it on. And you cannot turn the tester off - it turns itself off after a minute or two of non-use.Lastly, the tester is a bit harder to use for left-handers because the negative test lead exits the right side of the battery, favoring the use of the right hand to hold the lead. Left-handers would naturally hold the lead in the left hand. When you do this, you have to almost turn the tester upside down and read the display at the bottom.It would have been better to have the lead coming out of the top or bottom so it would be easy to use with either hand.  Most folks would not notice this, but left-handed people (like me) immediately notice it.I still gave the tester 5 stars as all of these things are minor, and I like that it is made in the USA. I'd gladly pay a few dollars more for something made in the US these days.

Easy to install, (assuming you have a spare hole in your sink), and refills from the top by simply pulling the nozzle up and out of the way. I bought a matching faucet from the same company and it has a built-in pullout sprayer, so I put this in the hole where my old sprayer used to be.Ideally you want one person above and another below the sink to install, but I did it by myself by duct taping the bottom piece to a tube so I could pull it up through the hole and screw on the top piece. Then you simply screw on the bottle from underneath and it's good to go. Fill it with your favorite soap (Dawn works well), drop in the nozzle, and pump away.

reviewText: This filter does what it says, it makes the water nicer as it removes chlorine. It is not a water softner, but it does help ameliorate the drying effects to your skin/hair by removing chlorine and other chemical form the water. Nicely made, super easy to install. I bought 2 after trying one for the shower, now I have one for the tub which has a spray wand sperate form the spigot.

The unit does apply a small load when testing a cell (5-ohm for 1.5V cells, and 55-ohm for 9V cells) which is a good thing.  I compared the resistance to that of the free battery testers that used to come inside Duracell battery packages, and it's about the same.  The unit was bigger than I expected, but it does the trick.
I have some beefier Milwaukee drills, but this one fits the bill for a small size.  I've used it for years with no problems.

Many reviewers talk about how much cleaner their household air is after installing 2000 filters, I hafta laugh. If you need air cleaning, you need a cleaner in your Room!The leaky, noisy ductwork of your house allows so Many 'particulates' in after the filtering, you'd Never know you Have a filter at all. High density, High MERV filters are Really Good at One thing - severely changing the median air pressure in your HVAC system so that your blower is full load/off load within seconds. Analogy, get a friend with a manual transmission car to take you to the store in first gear, and tell him jokes all the way. Ask ANYONE with a new HVAC system what their installer recommended for a filter -- if you find one in one Hundred that Do Not reply "PLEASE, buy the cheapest you can find" you are in an environment of installers that want to help you wear out your shiny new furnace/AC quickly, which is to say HVAC techs say 'buy the cheapest (lowest MERV) filters you can'.The filter is there to protect the fins and blower. That is All. With no filter, the works of the air mover get trashed up with gunk (pet/human hair, carpet junk, kitchen-oiled airborne dust) and wear out more quickly. Any benefit that you as the owner receive is purely coincidental. But What a marketing opportunity.The 600s (over the 'cheapest I can get') offer structure to keep them strong for 30 days (the Total Lifespan of Any disposable filter, usage exceeding 30/31 days is at your HVAC's peril) and I highly recommend them, as the MERV hasn't increased appreciably (~1), and the structure makes them very steady in their unavoidable resistance to air-flow efficiency.Didja' hear the one about gramma buying a 2000 high-MERV filter and freezing her AC pipes because the air-flow was 25% of normal? nope, who wants to tell their customer that they broke their own expensive HVAC sh-tuff and that's why they need a new one. Google MERV, you have been warned.
summary: a MERV my system can live with

reviewText: this thing is handy. i carry it everyday and it put it to use all the time. for  the money this thing rocks.

I'm really glad I chose this one.  All garage door openers should have this.  This is really well-made product, well designed and has the open-detection system worked out better than the competition -  the other brands could leave you with an open door, so check reviews on other types before buying or else just go with this US made brand.  I thought I had a problem and the Company was ready to stand behind it, but it was an installation issue.One criticism is that the "door is now auto-closing" alarm is too loud, too long and no way to adjust it.  They erred on the side of safety and you can't fault that in a litigous society, but to make it perfect,  I'd love to have a way to tone the alarm down and/or shorten it's duration.

I'm not sure how to really rate this, I have not exposed it to Carbon Monoxide or Explosive Gas and I hope never to do so for the rest of my life.  All i can really attest to is that there have been no false positive alarms since I installed this.  I have two gas furnaces and a gas water heater all crammed into one small utility room.  Due to  water leak I had to strip down and completely rebuild one furnace.  I already had a CO monitor in the room and another in the living area just outside the utility area, but no combustible gas detector, which I wanted after the rebuild job, just in case something came loose somewhere.  None of the CO monitors ever go off, so I think I'm OK there, and this tells me I have no gas leaks either.  I never smell any leaking gas, so I'm fine with that, but its hard to say if this will detect and alert me to a gas leak until I actually have one.  If nothing else, I feel better having something that will potentially alert me to a gas leak than having nothing at all.
summary: No false positive alarms after months of usage

reviewText: Pretty decent thermostat.  I've lived with it for about 6 months so far.  I just installed the outside thermometer probe today and the screen went blank.  Changing the batteries didn't help.  If this ever happens to you, note that you need to disassemble the thermostat and remove the backup battery on the circuit board, in addition to the AAA batteries.  This doesn't require tools and isn't a problem for someone skilled in taking things apart.Also, it cannot display outside temperature AND inside humidity at the same time.

It is set up on an office desk and works well as a regular lamp, with the bonus of the option of using magnifying when necessary. We have had our Ghost investigation group now going on 30+ years, my specialty in the group is equipment & new equipment reviews & do they work or not, well this one is just about the only piece of equipment, we've ever purchased that never registered the presence of a spirit in any known haunted location where we had verified with other equipment that something was there, it just never worked, it's great in detecting your microwave or power lines or something, but to top it off, you have to plug into it and use the long wire with the sensor on the end, so it's inconvenient to carry, & none of our members ever wanted to fool with it, get a ghost meter or K-2 meter or any other cheap EMF Meter that works, but not this one, I even modified it by adding a long antenna to the sensor to give it more range, still nothing.

The stand is very strong, and packages up into a nice 4x8 with handle to boot!  The leg releases are quality levers, and the balls that snap and hold the legs in place appear very sturdy. I ordered these goggles for using a fresnel lens outside. They are comfortable over my own glasses, plus they provide eye protection as well. I ordered one each for my kids also, and they love them. These are easy to adjust also. I am very happy with my purchase!

I purchased a Delta 14-650 a few years back.  At that time I only had a garage shop so I didn't have much opportunity to use the mortiser, and it spent a lot of time sitting on a shelf.  A couple of years later I built a new home with an attached shop. I built a roll around stand for the mortiser and began to use it.  I noticed that the heavy handle would not remain in place and kept falling down, missing my head by a few inches on a couple of occasions.  I took the stabilizer (little shock absorber) off and tested it.  Sure enough it had failed.  I could easily extend and compact the shock arm with ease. Since this part keeps the handle and therefore the hollow chisel from slamming down on your work it is a very important piece of the machine.  I can still use the mortiser but I have to make sure to constantly keep my right hand on the handle which makes it difficult to work with the material being mortised.  I am currently looking for a replacement part but so far have had no luck. I suppose some authorized service station exists out there that carries a replacement for this part but I haven't found one yet.  Other than this inconvienience I think the Delta mortiser is a pretty darn good device.  It appears that the Stabilizer has a short shelf life in that it tends to deteriorate over time whether its used or not.  It worked good fresh out of the box but didn't stand the test of time ( a couple of years)  There was no mention of preventative maintenance required for the mortiser in the Delta user manual.
I really loved how easy this was to set up.  Just match the dip switches with old remote, push the button 13 times, and presto, its programed for my 1990's genie garage door opener.

This really is a do it yourself item! I'm not mechanically inclined by any means but I was able to install, program, and use the SimpliciKey set all by myself. I felt the instructions were self explanatory and easy to understand. I'm not really sure why other reviewers have rated this so low. I'm really enjoying this set and have had no issues what so ever after following the instructions. Overall it is attractive, durable, safe, and user friendly.

reviewText: For years, I propped my miter saw up on various things: saw horses, tables, flipped-over trash cans, you name it. Upon finally getting one of these stands, I was amazed that I waited so long.This stand is a bit pricey, so it took me years to buy it, but I now see it as completely essential. This stand should be sold with the saw in every case, because it's that awesome. The arms slide out well, allowing you to cut 16 foot boards without a problem. Lots of micro-adjustments can be made to control the height and placement of your boards, and with some scraps you can even level the sucker on uneven ground. Once collapsed, the stand is easy to carry via the handle. Seriously: this stand is awesome. I would buy another one today if mine walked off.
