reviewText: Update 2/28/2014***Warning***I have lowered my rating to 1 star from five! Failure rates on last years purchases are running around 30%-40% with less than 12 months (2000 hours)of use. Quality control has dropped WAY DOWN! I will not be buying these ANYMORE. It has cost my company hundreds of dollars in lost hours to warrant (replace for free) faulty bulbs for last years' clients. This is crazy! I should have paid double it would have saved me a fortune. What a huge mistake! If these are for your personal property, it is an okay purchase. But do not place these bulbs ANYWHERE that would be inconvenient to fix/replace. Also, bulbs will turn from warm white to cool white after about 18 months of use. It is as if the manufacture used yellow marker to tint the LEDs and it starts to 'wear off/fade' causing the lights to lose their warm white color. Unacceptable! I have purchased over a thousand of these and I expect it to haunt my company for a long time. Sorry I purchased these. I left my previous reviews/updates for all that care to see what i previously wrote. Torchstar also only warrants these for 12 months for original purchase time. The packaging states they are rated for 20,000 hours, Which translates into 4.5 years for 10 hours of use per day. They also state bulbs are for indoor use only! Latest batches are not lasting 6 months!Update 8/20/2013I have increase my rating from 4 stars to 5 (Should be 4.5 Stars) because Torchstar has really improved their shipping speeds. Failure rate is less than 2% which is very acceptable.Torchstar has FINALLY hit it out the park with fast shipping now. I have bought several batches lately with each with at least 30 bulbs per order and have been getting them with 2nd day delivery from CA to Charlotte, NC in two days!!! Well done TORCHSTAR! Keep up the good service!Review update on 3/10/2013Torchstar is STILL having a problem with reliable shipping times... my previous order came in less than 5 business days. That is Okay! NOW...The current order is going on over a week, and still nothing. I see the post office has JUST received the shipment. Not happy about that... Post office DOES mark when they actually receive the product, so why are you waiting SO LONG to ship out from your store? Yall need to take note from Amazon and ship orders out the same DAY. If you do not have it in stock, do not try to sell them!Let me just say I have ordered several "hundred" of these MR16 LED bulbs so far... (I am a lighting installer contractor) they seem to have excellent quality. I have found only about three bulbs out of the couple hundred that I ordered with the PIN problem, But I have figured out how to unscrew the bulb apart to 'fix' the problem. The light output is VERY good, I would say it is easily over that of a 35 watt bulb and very close to a 50 watt. *** Please note *** that I have found the wattage of these bulbs to be off. This may play into your transformer and wire size calculations. These bulbs have an intial start-up wattage draw of around 6 watts each (10.5 volts at fixture with 0.57 amp draw=5.98 watts) , and then slowly drop down to around 4.5-5 watts each after about 15 minutes. On one clients property they had a 120 watt transformer with 20 fixtures on it that should have been drawing about 80 watts of power plus the wire friction loss of about 10 watts. It was drawing around 120-130 watts on initial start-up and causing and 'error' shut-down . I ended up upping my transformer size to 200 watts to stop the over-load problem. All-and-all these are GREAT BULBS and I will continue to buy these. They did ship to North Carolina from California via Priority Mail. Though it did take over four business days to get to me... I think that was mostly due to the handling/post-marking than the post-office. I think if you buy these you will be happy like me.Update 1/17/2013: I have found that I have had about 7 of these bulbs fail. I think they have about about a 10% failure rate at most. Still not bad for this new technology. And at this extremely affordable cost they are still worth buying extras just in case. My last shipment took over TWO WEEKS to receive. This was on Torchstars part too. I only like to wait about no MORE than five business days from the order day.Note, the color is pretty good. Note, as Halogen bulbs get brighter, they get whiter too. The kelvin on these is around 3000-3100.
summary: Nice LED bulb, probably the best choice for the money, BUT...

reviewText: I've owned and used this tenoning jig for several years now. It's well made, accurate in use, and the best value among all tenoning jigs currently on the market. At this price I can't understand why any one would buy another brand.

It is a good showerhead for low pressure area, but it might be a bit strong if the pressure is high. It conserves water very well. I will call it Eco. The concentration of water will make it like a jet to thrust off your hand, but the amount of water could be more to have better shower experience. Overall, you can save a lot of water with it and you don't need a scrub (Water jet is strong enough to clean off anything you had on the skin and more.....)

This is the second one I've owned.  Unfortunately, the first one died after about three years.  But I liked the old one enough to buy an exact replacement.  That's about as good an endorsement as I can think of.The default program features an energy efficient schedule that keeps the house temps moderate during the day while you're gone and then turns on the AC/heat in time to make the house comfortable when you get home.The installation is extremely simple.The daily use isn't quite as simple if you want to override the set program.  You can bump the temp up or down without too much trouble, but cancelling the override isn't quite as intuitive.  Also, making your override "stick" doesn't always seem to work for us.  For example, we don't usually sleep with the AC on unless it's too hot to open the windows.  So in those cases, we close the windows and override the program to drop the temps.  That's fine at bedtime, but then in the middle of the night when the program switches to the next time unit, the override expires and the house heats up.  It's not impossible to prevent that, but it's nearly impossible for my pea-brain to remember how to do it without re-reading the manual.All in all, this controller is great for my household and has saved my family a ton of $$$ during the hot seasons when we have to use the AC.

I've used these Klein cutters for years and find they work great for cleanly cutting things like SO and SJ cords, coax, twisted pair and other types round cables without compressing or distorting them. I also use them often to cut copper and aluminum conductors like #4 and #2AWG. They can handle up to 4/0 AL or 2/0 CU, but I have ratcheting cutters that I normally use on conductors that size, which are much easier on the hands. I wish Klein would make a hardened 2000 Series version of this cutter like they do with their Lineman's and diagonals, because the blades on these are fairly easy to damage. I know I've gone through a few pair myself over the years. Even so, I really like the way these cutters work and would buy another pair if they get damaged.
summary: Klein Tools 63050 9-1/2-Inch High Leverage Cable Cutter

reviewText: These shelves need to attach to the joists.  If your garage ceiling is covered, the joists are almost impossible to find.  Good "locating joists."Once joists found, the shelves are easy to install.
I use this goggle for mowing and weed-eating . It is great ... the best part is stuff doesn't fly in the side like safety glasses.

Awesome timer. Well made and as noted above has a setting to come on/off at a ever changing dawn or dusk time (based on where you time and can also be a fixed time on/off. Can also do a hybrid meaning on at dusk and off at 10pm. These settings mean you "set it and forget it" as you never need to adjust for the time of the year. Easily overridden for immediate on time as needed. Enjoy!
summary: Great timer with options to set by a ever changing dawn or dusk time based on where you live!

reviewText: Despite the fact that it pained me to spend what I estimate should have cost a third as much, this is a worthy home for your Petzl headlamp.  It does offer more protection than a zip-able sandwich baggie and it does have some features that make it worthwhile.First, the case itself is reasonably well-made.  It won't stand up to bear bites or hydraulic presses, but it keeps your headlamp tidy and free from all that would poke, scratch, scuff, or otherwise damage your light as it's living in your pack.  It is made out of the same semi-rigid material as cases for portable hard drives and should easily protect your headlamp from falls on hard surfaces.  (providing the light is in the case and not on your noggin)Secondly, it has some useful features.  There is a tiny pouch inside that accommodates your AAA batteries.  This is great not only for storing the batteries when you put your headlamp away for a bit, but also to keep a set of spares when your headlamp is in use.  There is also a tough, wide nylon strap on the back of the case that works really well for lashing the case to the outside of your pack or for wearing on your belt.  I have found that it is actually wide enough to be useful, too, a detail I appreciate.  The clamshell design of the case has webbing near the hinge so that if you open the case while you are wearing it on your hip, it won't just fall open, dropping the contents on the ground, or into the crevasse - Another nice touch that shows some thought went into the design.  The zipper works well and smoothly and the small pull is covered by textured rubber, making it easy to grasp by gloved or cold hands.So, while I have lots of good to say about this little case and have been impressed with its design and quality, I've got to ding it one star for the price.  It is still, after all, only a very small case.  (Using a small sock would work pretty well, I think, but it might look funny tied to your belt)  Would I recommend it?  Yes, I absolutely would, and I've gotten two myself.  It's an accessory, however, and not an essential.  I LOVE Petzl headlamps and I do want to take care of those investments, so I don't feel terrible about the price...  It's just that I'd feel better paying five bucks or so less.

I purchased the extra 55" guide rail because of the long planks/boards I was truing up.  I seriously considered buying the longer 106" one piece rail, but it just seemed too expensive at $285 and I was worried about it being difficult to maneuver, difficult to store and so long it was more likely to get damaged.  Using the connectors is a bit of a pain, but they work well.  Take your time, make sure the tracks are straight and aligned when tightening the set screws and you're good to go.  In doing this I've had no problems and excellent results with clean straight cuts.
summary: Good Accessory that you will need sooner than later

reviewText: Comes with extra dividers that can be rearranged. Clips shut fine. The sticker on top left residue, which is annoying. But not worth docking a star. It's a storage box.

I've been using things like these for years --- mostly for fininshing triggers parts and retouching fine tool edges. This is a really, really nice set, and it wouldn't take too many mor pieces to get into every nook and cranny. (I have medium/fine .125" rods deliberately scavenged from an x-sharpener.) These are great for gently de-horning stainldss edges ... slow, light, and steady.
summary: Slick set of very nice alumina files

reviewText: Make some room in your garage...love the adjustability on this bike rack. It give you the option wether to anchor this unit...unless you want to find your bike on the hood or side of your vehicle...my suggestion is not to skip this step.  Takes an additional 10 min and takes the worry out this unit falling.

Cool forward thinking lock. Someone could still probably kick it in. It's nice that you can walk up to it to open but I like the touch button smart code ones better. At least those will connect to home automation systems.It runs on blue tooth and is nice looking, if a bit overpriced. I think zwave is a future feature, while that sounds forward thinking it feels like they are trying to move forward without doing it. You can download a kevo app for iphone. I'm still tinkering with this lock and may return it to get another push button one.Whatever you do don't get biometric locks from samsung. I did that before this. The instructions are in Korean and I was hung up on multiple times because Samsung will not support the product. Uber annoying. In comparison this lock's company is a 9-5 dream.
summary: Doesn't connect to zwave or zigbee

reviewText: I think we went in and out of our door more after the initial set up than we do in an entire month.  Its pretty cool to have your door unlock for you.  Feels futuristic.However, I do wish it worked from farther away and did not require an awkward movement sometimes to get it to work. Other than that its exactly as I thought it would be.Now if I could get all the other things in my house to run off a cloud or something I would be in business.  ;)

My Amazon purchase records show that, last December, I purchased this light for three dollars under the current price.  Am I going to protest? (Yes, but quietly. The light is clearly being sold by independent vendors, whose enterprise is facilitated by Amazon.)More importantly, this one is the "right" light at any price. It's the equal of the original in fit, brightness, coverage, and durability.  I'm just glad that it still represents a mere fraction of the cost of the floor lamp (though closer to 20% than 10%).  If it's so good, why am I purchasing another?  (It's next to my bed, not anchored to the floor boards, and I tend to be clumsy, bumping into and knocking over things during my nocturnal navigations. Warning: this light will not survive a drop of 4-5 feet on to a wooden floor.)Given the light's cost last December, I now wish I had purchased two at that time?  Is now the time to purchase two?  Perhaps so, but on 2nd thought I wouldn't base the decision on cost.  As the economists keep saying, world-wide inflation isn't something to fear: it's inevitable and something to be expected.  Based on such logic, purchasing two on the basis of a "good price" would betray fear and pessimism "going forward" (economic jargon for "in the future"). Purchasing just one light, on the other hand, is a vote of confidence. It represents a belief that the escalating cost of living won't be a match for yours and my increased increased income power.  President G.H. Bush once said, after being grilled by the press about the economy, what counts most is "the vision thing."  This replacement Sunlight Lamp validates the President's point at any price (though I'd still like to see it listed closer to 5 than 10).

This is a very attractive fan. It is also quiet and provides great airflow. However, in making your decision there are two things you should be aware of:1. We bought 2 of these fans, and they were slightly different in color. One was more bronze, and one was more of a 'brushed chrome'. For us, that was OK because we put them in 2 separate rooms, and we contacted the seller (who has been very responsive and understanding) and they assured us that wasn't supposed to happen. Just check before assuming you have 2 like fans!2. The remote control means you can't wire this to work seamlessly using a switch on the wall. We learned that the hard way from our electrician. I was thinking a remote control was a positive because you could lie in bed and adjust your fan speed and light, but it's a bit confusing to turn the light on/off when you come into the room if you're also planning to use this as a primary light source for a room. For example, if the button on the control is on, the light switch works for both on/off. If the button is off, the switch doesn't work when you walk into the room. It is a bit annoying/confusing, but not awful, and does come with some pros. Just think through your own use case thoroughly before purchasing.

At less than $5 a snip, this tool set is a great value for the money and is cheaper than my local hardware store. These no-frills snips are handy to keep around the house for casual fix-its, wire-cutting jobs, and repairs.Quality-wise, they could stand to be a bit better, but you get what you pay for. The plastic grip gives off a chemical smell that lingers on hands, but I'm expecting this to go away after airing out. The metal surface and black paint on all three tools in my set showed scuffing and scratches, likely from the manufacturing process where all the tools are tossed about during sorting or assembly. I also wiped off a bit of lubricating grease the joints of the tools. These are purely cosmetic flaws and do not at all impact the functionality of the tools. Otherwise, they are definitely feel sturdy enough for light cutting work. I did find the latches to be a bit of a problem as they not rotate as freely as other tools I've owned. There is not enough clearance and they scrape up against the side.If you're looking for a cheap snip set and aren't too fussy, this will get the job done for a good price.
summary: Good value for use around the house or garage

reviewText: This is an amazing flashlight. I read many 1 star reviews and they complained about brightness, they may have gotton a lemon or used rechargable batteries which are lower voltage. I can't imagine more brightness and love the zoom, using just the regular batteries recommended and nothing expensive. Do not use rechargable batteries as they are only 1.2VDC. This is a very nice flashlight, is very comfortable to hold, has bright, medium, low, flash, and SOS, and I recommend it and would buy again; probably will get a couple more. I hope this helps someone.

I bought this to remove water spots from my shower glass, and from my car windshields.  This has perfect for those jobs.  I wanted something inexpensive but still powerful enough, and this fit the bill.One thing I will say is that the RPM number is meaningless...don't use that to compare this to similar products.  As other reviewers have pointed out, when you apply pressure, this slows down considerably.  For comparing the power with different products, the only thing that is meaningful is amps per square inch.  This is not the most powerful polisher, but I think it is plenty powerful enough for the intended consumer usages.
summary: perfect for occasional use on shower glass & windshields

reviewText: Granted, for $12 you're not going to go far wrong.  All three tools open and close; two of them are a bit stiff but they are certainly usable.  The needle-nose pliers were not even close to being aligned and for the price that's expected.The reason for the poor review is that you can do a lot better for not much more money.  I checked a web site for a National Department Store chain know for it's line of tools that comes with a lifetime guarantee.  I'm not sure I can mention it by name so let's just say they're very popular with Craftsman.  Anyway, for maybe $10 more you can get tools that are made much better (and in the US if that's important to you) and will be replaced free if they are ever damaged.  If you want an Amazon-available alternative try eitherStanley 84-114 3 Piece Basic 6-Inch Slip Joint, 6-Inch Long Nose, and 6-Inch Diagonal Plier Set(one different tool and about the same price) orStanley 84-058 4-Piece Pliers Set(one additional tool for a little bit more).That said, these are serviceable.  If you want to have a few pliers to leave someplace. not feel too bad if they get lost or stolen, and cut costs then these would probably be a good choice.
summary: Servicable pliers.  Consider spending a little more and getting a lot more

reviewText: Quality is your average walmart stuff, so dont expect sears craftsman or better. One the bright side these have great feeling handles. Pretty tough but new already starting to rust. Made in China

I like its power, size, and quality. It is a good looking flashlight.  Dislikes= The locking mechanism on the sliding focusing hood should be more posative, like having a clicking or detent position to signal when the hood is locked in positin for spot or flood.  I would recommend the unit to anyone looking for a good compact flashlight

This is a small, lightweight work table that can certainly help the occasional DIYer or carpenter. It is by no means a professional quality tool.Assembly was fairly straightforward, once I figured out how to interpret the cryptic diagrams in the sparse manual that accompanied the product. My first task for this shelf was to see if it can accommodate my Skil 12" Miter saw, as I was led to believe by the `product photos' on Amazon. No dice. The feet of the saw are too wide for the maximum width of the work table. A 10" saw or smaller might be OK. Forget about putting in a sliding Miter.In addition, I found the vice formed by the two work-surface planks to be of limited value. The sides of the planks that form the jaw of the vice are too narrow to hold anything with any stability. I tried to hold down a 4x4 vertically so as to cut a tenon at the end of it. The piece kept rotating or sliding down. You'll have to use more clamps to get any kind of stability at all.On the plus side, it seems strong enough. I tried standing on it, and the table did not seem to strain or show signs of buckling.
summary: Strong, but won't hold a 12" Miter saw

reviewText: I tried a Pedi-Paws when they first came out.  I'm a Certified Dog Trainer, Vet Tech & a Dog Groomer.  The concept of the Pedi-Paws is a great one & made perfect sense to me.  Problem was, it is just not powerful enough, even for my small Jack Russell "Terrorists".  I was really bummed out about it too.Then one day my Dad came home from a local hardware/home improvement store with this product!  BEST INVESTMENT IN THE WORLD for me!!  It works WONDERFULLY on dogs nails!It's powerful enough to do the job quickly without putting the dog thru the torture of holding them there while these inferior (my opinion, again) products that don't have strong enough motors to do the job quickly & well.I have 2 Jack Russell "Terrorists", one HATES having her feet handled & the other, who's been very fearful of anything new since she was 12 weeks old. After introducing them to the Dremel I mentioned, my JRT who hates to have her feet handled, will now let me use the dremel I have to do her nails, (she still doesn't like it, but she now lays still & lets me get it done.) If I get the old fashioned nail clippers out, she runs for the hills. My other, fearful JRT loves it!Once she got used to it, she now lays on her back & actually falls asleep while I'm grinding away at her nails!The model I bought, came with a carry case too. I love it, because I can also keep combes, hemostats & lots of other "doggie" items in it.It's become my "Doggie Doctor Bag"! I got my Dremel at a local hardware/home improvement store & it's much cheaper than the "Pet Grooming" Dremels I've seen here. Because it comes with lots of extras, especially the case, which is worth it's weight in gold!I was looking for a replacement battery for my Dremel & saw all the other Doggie Nail Grooming products & just had to let all of you folks know that you can save money & get a BETTER model Dremel or about the same & sometimes, LESS money than the inferior ones that are just packaged differently to draw in pet owners! They get the job done better, much quicker with a faster RPM that won't bog down & most dogs will happily tolerate, because it takes less time!!What I did to get my dogs used to these, was (BEING PATIENT WITHOUT GETTING ANGRY IS THE KEY HERE FOR SUCCESS FOLKS!1. When I first brought it home, I attached the battery & set it on the floor, to let the dogs "approach & retreat" at their own pace. Dogs always use this method when they are unsure. They will approach something new & then retreat, checking to see if it's safe.After the first couple times of approaching it & they actually started to sniff it, I used a clicker, but you can also say "Good Dog" AS THEY ARE SNIFFING IT! (Timing is SO IMPORTANT) then treat them. Do this as many times as you need to, until they get more comfortable & get to the point that no matter WHERE you set it on the floor (put it in a different room on the floor, so they will get used to it in different rooms. Dogs don't generalize well.) Do this until they get to where it doesn't seem to be such a "weird" thing to them when they see it. You'll know when, they will start to pay less & less attention to it. VERY IMPORTANT ~ DON'T turn it on yet!2. When they are used to seeing it sitting on the floor around the house & seem to be OK with it. (You'll know), they'll pay less & less attention to it. It's become a part of the 'scenery'. Now pick it up (STILL DON'T TURN IT ON!!) and rub it on their bodies. Just for a second or so & if they are calm about it (they can look at & sniff it, which is GOOD), praise them I give them a treat. Then work on lengthening the time you rub it on their bodies (with the side of the Dremel) & treat each time they are calm about it. If at ANY TIME they seem stressed or try to run away, back off & go back to shorter contact times. Make sure you stay calm yourself. Use a 'sing-song' or happy voice when talking to them & DON'T FORGET REALLY YUMMY TREATS!!Next turn it on in another room. Sit on the floor & hold it, LETTING THE DOG APPROACH YOU! NEVER go towards them with it, drag them to it, or hold it out towards them! When they start coming a little closer (remember, this is a new sound, so they will keep their distance, but if they don't run away, toss a nice yummy treat to them that they can get without coming closer the first time. WAIT & LET THEM APPROACH YOU! It's a good idea to have the best, smelliest treats that your dog loves with you (Make sure they know you have treats before you turn it on. Let them get a good whiff of the treat too. As you toss the treats to the dog, try to get the dog to take just one more step a little closer by tossing the treat so it lands a little closer to you each time.This takes patience, but BELIEVE me folks, the benefits outweigh the time this takes initially. But in the long run, you'll be SO GLAD you did it!When you can get the dog comfortable enough to come close, let the dog smell it. Maybe rub something nice & smelly on the outside casing, like a hot dog or some other food your dog LOVES!.(Keep the sanding band away from their body & don't let it get tangled in any long hair!The goal here is to get the dog to come close to you WHILE the Dremel is running, on his own & eventually, rub the Dremel housing on the dogs body while it's running.It's helpful to have someone to help you & feed GREAT treats while you are doing that. The dog will develop GREAT associations with the running Dremel, which is your goal! After a time & your dog will let you know when he/she is ready, to use it on toe nails. Quickly take just one "swipe" over the end of ONE NAIL & immediately let the foot go! Praise your dog like he/she just won you a million dollar lottery! Then feed some AWESOME treats & give MORE PRAISE!!Many dogs are too intimidated still to lay down & let you handle their feet with the dremel running at first. That's OK. Pick up a paw & just barely do the end of one nail at first. Work your way up to 2 nails, eventually doing a whole paw at one time. Make sure to reward LAVISHLY! You know your dog, so if you think that he/she is ready to try to do more nails at one time, go for it. Just don't push for too much too fast! I promise you, the patience will pay off!It WILL work if you invest the time to intitially introduce them correctly, WITH OUT FORCING THEM at any time. The years that will follow that you are able to get the nails filed down well in a very short amount of time, because you are not fighting with a dog pulling their feet away from you constantly, it's WELL WORTH HOWEVER LONG IT TAKES!!Believe me, I KNOW it works! My JRT was a very fearful puppy when I got her at 12 weeks old. I've NEVER had a dog, especially that young, that was so afraid of EVERYTHING! She's going to be 3 the beginning of November & I've very patiently gotten her over 99% of her phobias. She was afraid of EVERYTHING! Sheesh!!)If anyone needs any other advice or help, please feel free to leave a comment. I will be notified of any comments left on this post & I will respond. I'll GLADLY HELP IN ANY WAY I CAN!!This is a super over-simplified version, but I think you get the idea.Good Luck Everyone!!Since Amazon is currently out of this particular Dremel (with the bag) here is a link to the same Dremel, but this one is more expensive, because it has an end or adapter that you would never need if you are only buying this for doing your dogs nails.Dremel 7700-1/15 MultiPro 7.2-Volt Cordless Rotary Tool Kit
summary: BEST PET NAIL GROOMER AROUND!  GREAT PRICE TOO!!

reviewText: While putting together my emergency supplies and researching out to store clean water and test it before actually using it, I came across this tested.  Kinda pricey for something I will not use every day but important enough to still need to buy it.My municipal tap water is about 330ppm.  Granted I live in a home 45 yrs old my pipes just might be really old.  Arrowhead drinking water, 310ppm.  My Culligan water softener and drinking water filter system, ~ 010ppm.  Costco's Kirkland brand, that I used to avoid because I thought it was too generic (my stupid fault for falling for marketing), also around ~010ppm.Do your own research about the major brands of bottled water and you will be surprised how clean they AREN'T!!
summary: Has completely changed my mind about the bottled water scam

reviewText: LEDs have come a long way. They still maximize battery life, but now they really put out bright light. The Coast HP2 66 is compact, durable and maximizes battery life. Did I mention it puts out a lot of light? You can focus the beam too. The pocket clip keeps it secured in your shirt pocket.It leaves my old pocket Maglite far behind.

This installed easily and has good water pressure at each setting. The hose is longer than I expected (longer than my two previous units) but that is not a bad thing... just an observation.Why 4 not 5 stars? The connector to the shower spout (also the mounting for holding the shower head) is more cumbersome than previous units I have used. This one was so much so, I had to remove the shower caddy that held the shampoo, etc. which hung from the shower spout in order to angle the shower head properly for my height 5'4". Now, my husband 5'10" had no issue though it was still a higher stream than he was accustomed.One note for why the unit might be more "cumbersome" than others is the reason I had to buy a new one in the first place: Where the threads would be to connect the plastic unit to the shower spout on the wall cracked after several years of use. This one is thicker plastic than the one I am replacing and is less likely to fail in the same way the previous unit did.If you have no shower caddy hanging from the shower spout so sitting just beneath the unit, this is a 5-star shower head for the price.If you need a shower caddy hanging from the shower spout so sitting just beneath the unit, continue to look for another.
summary: Great unit, each setting consistent water flow, easy installation... one issue if you use a shower caddy

reviewText: I keep this in my kitchen drawer--pretty basic tools but all work well.  These come in handy all the time!
Not the hardest steel but for the money they're great.  I'm using for keys and they seem to be holding up pretty well.

We have a white laminate Ikea kitchen table.  You may be familiar with the stuff, pressboard covered by a layer of shiny white material?  My daughter dropped something sharp and heavy onto it and caused a small gouge, the white laminate was chipped away and there was a small, darkly colored dent.Fixing it took this pen and a couple layers.  I applied the first with the brush and let it dry for a couple days.  That built up the indentation a little bit.  I put on a second layer with the rollerball, allowing me to apply less paint in a smaller area.  The results were not an invisible repair but certainly good enough to not notice a defect if you didn't know it was there in the first place.I got the rollerball working by removing the orange "separator" (just like it says in the instructions).  The trick was finding it and that may be the problem some reviewers encountered.  When you unscrew the top sometimes it stays with the bottle and sometimes it comes away with the cap and brush.  Wherever it is, grab it (with a paper towel to keep your hands clean) and toss it away.  After that, either the brush or rollerball will work just fine.
summary: Works as cover up on Ikea white laminate furniture.  Rollerball *does* work.

reviewText: I was looking for more speed and massage and found this one which is affordable.  It is really, I mean, much better than I expect it to be.  I would recommend it to everyone who need more than a speed.  It is 7 speed, 2 of them massage.
MY new house has low water pressure, this fixed the problem, I am buying one for all the bathrooms as we speak.  Huge difference!
The alarm isnt as loud as I would prefer. Wondering if it would wake me from sleep.

I am a home builder. Anticipating some close quarter work, I picked up the Makita DA3010F. It sat in my tool box for a few months while I was putting up walls, beams and joists. As I progress into more detailed internal framing, I've been going to the Makita for what I will call light Hawg work. Like the other reviewer says, its lighter and won't break your wrist like the real thing. The Makita will turn a 3 or 4 inch hole saw but it is not happy, becoming too hot to handle. Within its design limit, it will easily turn 1" flat bits and long augers to around 3/4" dia. I can corroborate that 1) the feel and sound of a precision tool, and 2) you can dial the no-load speed down to like one minute per revolution. Yes, the LED light is useful for working where the sun don't shine. One problem, not specific to Makita, is that when a angle drill with paddle switch is used close-quarters and breaks through the work, the tool can get jambed up against the work with no way to turn it off. Occupational hazard I quess. This tool is recommended to those who have everything else.
summary: Quality, for special apps and some general use

I have owned the WESD51 Digital Soldering Station for over 10 years now.  It has been flawless as I put it through its paces with DIY audio projects, prototyping, PCB population, reworking, and fixing numerous electronics over the years.  Very comfortable, reliable, easily adjustable, serviceable, and works awesome!  If you are using a cheap-o iron with a ac plug hanging off the back you will really enjoy using this.  The quality of your work increases and you are less likely to burn or destroy the work you are doing.The temperature control is something that if you haven't experienced,  once you use it you will not want to be without.  If you are considering the (non-digital) WES51...spring the extra money for the digital temp control that the WESD51 has. You can fine tune the temperature to your liking and it will stay there!  Say you are working on really fine 28awg wires, you can dial it back some as to not melt insulation.  If you are doing a job that needs higher temp with larger components/ connectors, just crank it up.  It remembers what the temp was when you last shut it off as well.  When you fire it up, it says the temp it was last at, then tells you exactly what the temp is as it heats up.  As you are soldering, the temperature fluctuates on the screen a few degrees or so but its very stable once you dial in your preferred temp.It also has an auto-shut off feature to help you not burn your house down if you accidentally leave it on...happens to the best of us and on more than one occasion I have found the iron saved my posterior.  Weller has a huge assortment of different tips (sold separately) which are cheap and easy/fast to replace and its a great idea to have several on hand for different applications.  I prefer the really narrow and long screwdriver tip (Weller model: ETS)Long Conical Tip, 1/64"which helps get into small places on PCBs (which is mainly what I work with).The only issue I have had with the iron is actually my fault...I bought one of those combination soldering iron stands that has the spool holder for your solder.  It looked great, had the solder right there, and I thought I had it made.  Unknown to me that it would be a problem, the design of the aftermarket stand let the tip of the iron come in contact with the spiral metal holder.  After the iron sat on and touched the stand (with the tip in contact) the stand acted as a heatsink and the soldering station kept trying to increase the temperature as it thought it was cold.  As you can guess what happened next, the actual iron (PESD51)Weller PES51 50-Watt Soldering Pencilburnt out.  Good thing that it is very easily replaced and actually not that expensive.  I simply bought a replacement and expect to get many more years out of the unit.A final fun tip:  Forget the sponge and water for cleaning the iron.  Take the sponge out and replace it with a soap-less copper scrubbing padChore Boy Copper Scrubbers: 2 Pack(similar to Chore Boy or copper/brass equivalent without soap).  I picked up a two pack at the dollar store for $1.00.  I attached the scouring pad to the base with a few alligator clips.  When you need to clean your iron, just dip the tip in the pad and it comes out clean and ready to use...no water and sponge required.
summary: Great Soldering Iron - Just be cautious of non-OEM stands!

I got this to replace my old Honeywell thermostat which had no programming ability. This unit was super easy to install and program. I had it up and running in just a few minutes. I don't have air conditioning in my house but I do have central heating and we are gone for much of the day so it's nice to program the unit to come on shortly before we return from work. I also have it warm up in the mornings before work. It's worked perfectly with just one small annoyance. This may be common with modern thermostats, but if you want to override the setting and turn on the heat, you need to adjust the temperature at least 2 degrees higher or nothing will happen. In our house, it's fairly small and we have the temperature dialed in exactly where we want it but sometimes we just want it half a degree warmer. So it's a little annoying to have to turn it up 2 degrees higher and then remember to turn it down later or it will be too hot. Kind of a silly thing but other than that, this is a great unit at a good price. It looks great too. Very clean looking in our modern house.

reviewText: This wire collated nailer, once it is tuned and adjusted, sends most of the nails to whatever depth is needed. In my last roofing project I had to hammer in about one in fifty nails. And in the rapid fire setting I seldom had any double firings. This is pretty good, all things considering. It seems to do well despite use in temperatures ranging from below freezing to over 110 degrees Farenheit, I'd guess the steel wire collation to be the reason that it works so well in varying temperatures, since steel won't get soft nor brittle in this temperature range.Lubrication need seems very consistent. A few drops of oil every time I added a new roll of nails seemed to be about right. Unlike a framing nailer I reviewed recently there don't seem to be any lubrication-related problems.Air pressure need also seems consistent. It seemed to run best at about 85 PSI, i.e. varying between 80 and 90. This is a good sized air pump for those who are interested:Makita MAC2400 Big Bore 2.5 HP Air CompressorThis is a lightweight tool, so has some plastic parts which would not bear dropping nor banging around too much. Hence the 4 star instead of 5 star rating. I also wish they would separate the various languages in their instruction manual so they were not physically attached together. It would be nice to throw away all the unused multilanguage instructions.(Centigrade lovers: you can do the Farenheit to Centigrade calculation yourself C=[[F-32] x [5/9]] or some semblance thereof. Metric-philes: I don't know how many kiloPascals equal 80 PSI, nor do I care - I don't like to calculate powers of ten while on a roof. In fact I really don't like to calculate powers of ten anywhere, any time. It is unnatural. Think about this the next time you're lying helpless in the hospital and your young nurse comes in at the end of her 12 hour shift to interpret your doctor's handwriting and decide whether to give you 100mEq or 100mg of KCl plus either 10 or 100 or 1000 or 10000 or 100000 units of Heparin in either 1 or 10 or 100 cc of saline into your central  I.V. line. Is that a decimal point or a spot on the paper?)

I am a medium-level do-it-yourselfer, taking on more and more projects at a 200+ year old house that always needs attention. After replacing windows recently, I needed a saw to cut and complete the casing portion of the job. Rather than continue to beg and borrow from my neighbors, I opted to increase my tool collection. I pored over reviews here and elsewhere and finally decided to take the leap-- to a Bosch sliding compound saw here on Amazon. However, when I saw the hefty shipping/handling charges, and with a price increase moments before I clicked "Buy," I rethought the purchase and opted for the Hitachi from another online vendor with a much more reasonable shipping charge.The saw came quickly and was in fine shape after travelling halfway across the country. I can see with less-than gentle handling the saw could punch a hole in the packaging, but mine survived the trip with no such effect. The saw is relatively compact, not too heavy, and the miters were right on right out of the box.  The slide is smooth and the cuts are good. While some have raved about the OEM blade that ships with the saw, I am not 100% thrilled- some cuts have been so-so, making small chips in the pine I was cutting. I also cut some oak base molding, and the cuts were again good, but not perfect. At this point, I want to attribute that to my own learning curve, rather than to the saw or the blade. I want to swap the original blade with a finishing blade I have, to see if there is improvement in the smoothness of the cuts.One gripe, and the reason for the 4 star rating, is with the safety button and handle. I do not have huge hands, and I find it somewhat awkward to depress the safety button and then grab the horizontal D-handle comfortably with the same hand to start the saw. Luckily for me, I am right-handed, as the handle controls are designed that way. Left handers had better be ambidextrous, or especially nimble with their pinky to be able to depress the safety button. Again, it could simply be getting accustomed to the saw. I did not experience this problem when using my friend's DeWalt sliding saw, however.I purchased a Stablemate Plus 100 saw stand (built like a truck) from Amazon, and because the mounting holes on the Hitachi are in a triangular pattern, I had to mount the saw on plywood first in order to then mount it on the saw stand. Not a big deal, but worth noting.

Sometimes, it is neccesary to use a propane torch indoors. Soldering, etc...Suffice to say I am VERY glad I got this.It gave us a very loud stern lecture about my wife's practice of pre-warming her car for a minute in the garage, also.We always had one in the Furnace room, of course, but the lesson here is sometimes one needs several.I find the "Peak Level" readout to be very helpful, as well.Another benefit is now I can blame all my typos and misspellings on here on the effects of CO."What do you expect?  The CO level was 32ppm!"
summary: I am VERY glad I got this.

reviewText: I own two of these, both have malfunctioned in different ways.  I gave a generous 3-star rating because this is still my preferred charger due to the amount of numeric data it gives you about your batteries and the charge cycle.Buyer beware however:  The computer controls the charge termination, under normal circumstances this is fine since it has triplicate protection from overcharging, namely -dv, a charge capacity limit, and temperature shut-down if all else fails.  HOWEVER, these three factors only feed as input to the computer.  If the computer crashes, which in my case may have been caused by a bad connection of the power adapter to the unit, the PWM charger can crash into "full on" charging, which basically completely melts down both the unit and your batteries, causes a lot of nasty smoke, and could easily cause a fire.  I documented this with photos et. al. for the company, and never even received a reply other than to reiterate that the molten remains of my charger was no longer under warranty.  I'm surprised the whole line didn't get recalled.  You can see more about this problem by googling it, or even pictures others have uploaded on Amazon, though there is a lot of mis-information and speculation of user error and bad batteries, which I assure you is not the issue.  It's a shame the company still denies this problem despite clear documentation and evidence from many users, many who just like me still love the charger.
summary: Catches on fire, but otherwise great charger!

I bought this to go on my DW716 (the double-bevel non-sliding model) to take the guesswork out of mitering. If I didn't have some projects coming up that would have me working outside in the sun, I would've gone with the LED light instead, the DW7085, for less money and less hassle.Installation was easy as can be. It's two pieces, the power supply which mounts on the handle, and the laser assembly, which mounts above the blade. Six screws and five minutes, and a little wire-wrangling, and it's done.Then the work begins. Namely, the work of calibrating the laser so it points where it should, and you know where the blade's going to cut in relation to the light. A friendly tip here: just get a big framing square and do the advanced calibration setup. The instructions for that calibration are a lot easier to follow, weirdly enough, and are much more precise anyway. One of the big problems I had was how loose the adjustment screws are - it's far too easy to over-adjust, and worse still, running the saw seems able to knock the laser out of alignment ever so slightly. The beam itself is very narrow, which means it needs to be adjusted depending on which side of the material you're cutting off. It's almost more trouble than it's worth.The LED, by contrast, throws a shadow of the blade onto your material. It's always accurate without adjustments, the shadow is exactly the kerf of the blade, and it's ready to go as soon as you install it. On the other hand, it's not bright enough to be seen in sunlight, and I'm planning to build a deck with angled deckboards, so the laser was really my only option. I'll live with it because I have to, but I really wish DeWalt had done a better job with this laser. I'll likely wind up buying the LED whenever I get around to finishing the crown molding just so I don't have to fool with the laser any more than absolutely necessary.

You have not used a Makita Miter saw, no tools needed, laser line. This is even worse than  the new DeWalt saws "71.'s" line up it goes onto. I have a dw706, great saw, a tank in build, I am not a DeWalt hater. I own many of their tools.I bought several 718's and 716's and all went back w. the laser attm. which is also a pain to install.It simply is not consistently accurate and you need to use an allen to move the kerf line and this also changes the other axis too. The plastic is cheap quality and the case begins to crack with the constant adjusting. You can see the line wobble with the adjustment b/c the case is made so poorly.When I did get it close, the line hits the blade plane, and you can not see it on the work piece. Again what a pain.My Makita ls1013l, no installing, factory placed, accurate, loosened BY hand a knob, slide over ,now you are on the other side of the kerf without any changes in the axis. What could be easier. The line is right on either side of the blade within seconds.This product looks like an after thought add on and is not excuted very well.  I guess it is a match for the saws it goes on. I will be keeping my older, made in USA DW706 for a long time.
summary: If you think this is good..

reviewText: if you can find a lamp that works well for this bulb, it's amazing how much light it throws. This one is a bit more blue/white instead of yellow, but I love it's lumen/cost ratio.
summary: throws a ton of lumens around, whatever they are.

reviewText: I bought this flashlight a few months ago to take to Egypt so I could pretend I'm an explorer and crawl around inside of things and illuminate dark areas. Compared to a regular flashlight I was using and that I thought was bright, the Fenix L2D completely obliterated the other flashlight.True story: I got to go inside the Great Pyramid of Cheops in Cairo and since it was dark (and extremely humid, but that's another story), everyone had their flashlights out. I pulled out this flashlight and overpowered their flashlights so much that I attracted a few people who were interested in what I was shining my light on and even got a few "wows" out of how bright this was. And this was even without it being super bright!I haven't used the other two modes - the rapid flashing or the super bright mode that much. The rapid flashing will literally cause disorientation if you shine it at someone (good if you're a police officer, bad if you're a robber.)I never thought that I'd care about flashlights or just thought that Maglites were the awesome ones. Ever since I got this, I'm extremely happy and overwhelmed at the sheer awesomeness of this.
summary: The brightest flashlight I've ever owned and well worth the investment.

reviewText: This is a very good light. Portable, light weight, bright, can use AA rechargeable batteries. Every home, backpacker, hunter, camper should have one for emergencies along with AA Battery Solar Panel Charger by PowerFilm.they could supply you with light for a long time.
Irwin makes great tools and that is why I use them.  Rugged, tough, built to last.  Just wish they were made in the U.S.A. instead of china.

I am very pleased with the performance of this flashlight. The very bright setting is great, when you need it. I use the lowest output over 90% of the time and the battery seams to last forever on the low settings. This is small enough to carry in your pocket or purse. On the 180 lumen setting I can light up a pasture behind my brothers house.The quality of construction is as good as or better than big name lights that cost 3-4 times as much.I have another model of this light that uses 2 AA Batteries. Both have the same bulb unit and switch unit. The battery holder in the middle is different for each battery type.

This bag is strong, spacious and has sufficient pockets.Amazon now wants me to further describe it. If younare a proffesional handyman, it may be too small for me it's just right to fit in the bottom drawer in the kitchen so I dont have to go to the basement or garage to look for a big bag.

I upgraded to this freud dial a dado switching from the freud SD508 set.  All in all I like it.  However I do find it annoying that if you want to make a standard size dado (say 3/8") you have to look at the chart no matter what to figure out how to set it up.  Rather than use three 1/8" chippers it says to use the two outside blades, the 3/32" chipper and 16 clicks.  I find it annoying to have to pull the chart out every time to find out how many clicks each setup needs.  Also the included wrench does not fit a Sawstop table saw.  This is really not that big of an issue tough because the Sawstop arbor nut is wide enough to fit inside the dial a dado knob and still get Sawstop's blade wrenches on it.  I did install the full width dado on the Sawstop only to find that the arbor isn't quite long enough to support it safely, but that's ok too because I will never use the dado set to its full width.  I find it a little dangerous and would much rather use a smaller setup and make more passes.  The pros: The cuts are flawless as you would expect from any freud product.  Also not having to use shims to micro adjust your dado is great.  The carbides are also larger than the ones of the SD508.  I would recommend this set to any woodworker ... just don't lose that chart.
summary: Great Cuts but has small annoying issues

reviewText: Not overly bright, but I like the features and it has a good range.  It is good for walkways and driveways.  It is bright enough that you don't need to turn on the car's interior lights when getting things out.

I gave it 3 stars solely due to the high price, performance is amazing. I was very pleased with my purchased that is tell I used my friends cheap Home depot $99 dollar Ridgid 14 Gallon shop vac. I was rather impressed how quit it is. To tell you the truth the power and the quality was not like my Fein but it was close enough to make you feel foolish paying $200 dollars more for the Fein.  I returned my Fein and replaced it with the Cheap $99 dollar Home Depot vac and spent the extra cash on a 20 volt Dewalt combo drill set.If you don't mind over paying for great quality I recommend the Fein.
summary: Great and over expensive shop vac.

reviewText: Well, I had this tool for about a year without complaints.  I wouldn't use it as a production gun but is good for small jobs where it's a hassle to bring a compressor with hoses.  It does require a little more care than a ordinary nail gun but it makes up for it with convenience.  I give it 5 stars.

I did not pay attention to this product description:"Capacity: 18 AWG"That means it should not be used to cut thicker than 18 gauge wires. I however cut 16 AWG many times (no problems) and then attempted to cut a 20+ bundle of 16 gauge wires at once. One of the two shears snapped off.Xuron sent me a replacement for free. Feeling guilty that I cost them money due to my irresponsibility, I decided to buy another Shear cutter (an LX model, which is stamped out of thicker metal and is heat-treated to a higher hardness. It's designed to cut 16 AWG wires). Very happy with their products and service.The LX model is physically the same size as this 170-II. The LX weighs 54 grams and the 170-II weighs 49 grams. I can't feel the weight difference in my hand. I'd probably recommend the LX as it costs less than three bucks extra.

I can't believe that you can get such a quality hose for the money.  These are really solid feeling and easy to coil back up.  It seems like my other 1/4 hoses are always twisted like pretzels.  Will be getting a couple more of these.
summary: These are well worth the money

reviewText: For those beginners this is a great set to get, has everything that you need to start your own projects.

This device was delivered to my house yesterday, which was Saturday. I opened the package and right off the bat I saw problem #1. Rather than the three outlets described and pictured, there was one. Also, the outlet base is HUGE and a tremendous power strip space hog. I thought I'd try it anyway. Now, I have two of the Stanley remote light switches (HIGHLY recommended but Amazon was out of stock when I ordered this crazy thing). One runs three lamps in my livingroom and the other two lamps in the master bedroom. They've worked great for a long time. It was daytime so the lamps on the Stanleys were off.I plugged this new monster into an outlet in my office, plugged a lamp into it, popped the nine volt battery into the remote and pushed the on button. From six feet away without obstruction, nothing.I checked the remote outlet. Its lights were on and all looked well. Only when I stood directly in front of the outlet from about 18" away would the lamp turn on and off occasionally. I decided the item was not only not as described but faulty too and that it would be the second thing of hundreds I've bought from amazon that had to be returned.I had some food shopping to do so I laid the outlet and the remote on my desk, left the house, walked to the my which was parked in the street 35 yards away from my office, hit the door unlock button on my key and NOTHING! It was stone dead. I tried a few times and finally gave up, opened the lock with the key itself and drove to the local service station to show this to a friend there. When I got there the remote lock/unlock on the key worked fine. I did my shopping, came back home, parked in my driveway this time, hit the lock button on my key and again, NOTHING! I thought "Something, there is, in my neighborhood which is shutting down my car's remote switch!" So, I walked into the house and because by this time it was getting late, I decided to put the house lamps on. I picked up the livingroom Stanley remote that controls three lamps and DEAD as a doornail. I walked into the master bedroom, grabbed the bedroom Stanley to turn the lights on in there and again, DEAD! Like pushing a stone with my thumb.Well, thank goodness I'm in Mensa! I had a little thinking session with myself. I thought "What new things are in my home today that could be causing this? Can't be the new toilet seat, even though it's a fancy one. But HOW could it be the new remote? The outlet is unplugged and no one is pushing the button on the remote itself." On a whim I packed up the remote for return (I SHOULD have removed the battery first!) and carried the package out to my car. I unlocked the door with my key, drove up the block a way, locked the door again, walked back to my house and tried the Stanley remotes. They worked PERFECTLY, as they always had! When my wife got home later on the first thing she said when she walked through the door was "Guess what. My remote door lock is stone dead!" I told her.A friend feels this thing might be worth keeping just in case I feel like screwing up the neighbors for fun but I want it OUT of here and tomorrow, being Monday, I'm giving the package to my mailman to carry far away. Bottom line? If this thing didn't work at all it would be a vast improvement. DO NOT buy it! Really. DON'T BUY THIS!Anyway, gotta go now. I'm driving the return package over to the local Costco parking lot to watch shoppers as they try to get into their cars and realize their remote door unlocker doesn't work :-)
summary: Wow! Do NOT allow this thing into your home! You HAVE to read this!

reviewText: I decided against distillation, since there are many cons with that process: it produces acidic water (I used to buy distilled water from the store until I started noticing my gums were getting itchy from it), and recaptures chemicals with lower boiling points than water.  This was unacceptable to me since California's municipal water sources are heavily chlorinated.  It's so nasty, you can smell the chlorine coming out of the taps.  I can't stand the taste or smell of it.  I decided against reverse osmosis because of its costs and the amount of waste water it produces.  After much research, I settled on a gravity based microfilter, and Big Berkey came with lots of recommendations.So far, after nearly filtering 200 gallons, the Big Berkey is pulling all free chlorine out of the water.  Here is a pic that demonstrates:[...]The water on the right is tap water mixed with a chlorine/bromine indicator solution.  The color indicates that the tap water in Monterey, CA has more chlorine than a healthy swimming pool.  YUCK!  The water on the right is from the Big Berkey.  The indicator solution shows there is no detectable chlorine!  SWEET!
summary: I did alot of research before buying the Big Berkey

reviewText: There are more detailed reviews here that cover all the features in greater detail and I won't even try to top those. When my decade-old cordless drill died I wanted something with power. This Hitachi came well-recommended from those CR people and most of the reviewers here and I found a great deal on a refurbished unit on Amazon. All I can say is "wow!" The keyless chuck clicks onto even the smallest bits with minimal effort. The 18 volt battery and the gearing give you plenty of power to drill through hardwood, concrete, metal - whatever. The instant rotation brake gives you great control. And the worklight/belt hanger arm is amazingly effective at both uses.  A great feature is the included 2nd battery. The ONLY problem I've had with this unit is the worklight arm: the screw holding the battery cover in place is of such soft metal the slots grooved out before the screw broke loose. I finally had to drill the screw out and put in a stronger one. (Yes, using the old drill. OK. Laugh.)

I used this blade to cut 3 large holes in a metal building (R panel) to install 3 28,000 BTU through-the-wall air conditioning units.Cutting was smooth and consistent with minimal vibration. It made the job quick and easy. Highly recommended.

This has made such an incredible difference in what has otherwise been a basic bathroom. My mirror had always hung on the sink side, while a big blank wall occupied the space over the stretch of vanity between the mirror edge and the shower door. Once mounted atop that flat, blank wall, the Eva towel rack immediately added significant visual warmth within the room. The curves of this beautiful rack add an ambiance of depth when viewing the reverse through the mirror next to it, while the medicine cabinet's mirror on a perpendicular wall showcase its beauty even further.Installation was simple; though I called Moen to make sure that it was only supposed to have the four included screws with anchors, since each of the two mounts has four holes. I used the 3/16" holes drilled into the wall as guides for the further gentle carving necessary to get the anchors through the wall without brute force. Then once I had the mounts gently holding against the wall, I referenced my level one more time for some fine-tuning before finally tightening the anchors in place.I think that of all the optional fixtures that have gone into the bathroom, this towel rack is the most influential. It looks gorgeous and I am very pleased with the results.

Very nice.  I enjoy using it.  Feels like better quality in your hand than other brands.  Thinner gauge nails don't seem to split the wood like the 15 gauge.  Nails are readily available from the big box stores.
I like this light the 16 foot cord is a good idea too. The only problem is that the light doesn't cover a very large area. It would do better if it had a wider angle and was more of a flood light.

My grandmother called these - train racks; because they resembled the rack over the seats in train compartments to place your luggage. We have them in our bathrooms. They come in handy to put extra towels on for guests, if they need them, or to put clean clothes on and keep them dry, that you wish to change into after your bath.I originally wanted this to add to our half bath on our main floor, thinking it would be good for extra guest towels or even as a place to put wet hats or gloves to dry out. When we received this I was very pleased at the nickel finish. It looks very rich and goes with almost any décor and does not have the overly shiny appearance of chrome. The problem occurred when we tried to put it up and discovered that we did not have enough wall space where I wanted it and still allow the bathroom door to open. When I went up and measured our other 2 towel racks they were several inches shorter. So we had to take down one of those, patch holes for the molly bolts it used and put this in the larger bathroom.So with that, the dimensions should be given. This is almost 25 inches wide and 7 inches tall. It also sticks out from the wall about 10 inches. It is large. The installation was relatively easy, after we figured out that an Allen wrench (provided) was what would open the back to allow it to be hung. The directions are really not complete. However, I have used Moen before and their customer service is very responsive in helping if you do have a problem in installing one of their products.This is a lovely accessory for bathrooms or even mudrooms; but the dimensional size should be stated, especially for online purchasing.

I love the look of this thing.  It's gorgeous.  Very functional, very exotic looking.  Classy, timeless.  Looks even better in person.  You will not be disappointed.  Also  Very easy and fast to put together.  This is my 4th fan I've put up and this one took maybe an hour  but I took my sweet time.  I did this by myself too..but it would be better to do it with another person.

The battery doesn't get heated up while charging!  The battery has been very powerful until the very last minute so you don't get those feeling that it starts getting tired and under powered.  Highly recommended.
I'm very pleased with this switch and have purchased 4 of them for various lights. They are easy to install, have a nice soft glow when off, and are attractive enough for in home use. AAAA++++

I've owned eight Streamlight flashlights and only one still functions.  My original Scorpion is still going strong after years of use as a Peace Officer.  My Key-Mate quit after just a few months of intermittent use.  Five of the eight Streamlights used LED's and the electronic guts in them just didn't last.  Don't think I'll ever buy another Streamlight LED flashlight ever again.

Got this for a TV room that we only wanted a fan and no light kit.  The fan took about 1 hour to install and the instructions were VERY easy!.  There was not one unclear moment.  They use symbols on the bags that contain the nuts, bolts and screws so it makes it very easy to identify which bolt is needed - not like those pictures were you are tying to size up the various bolts by laying them next to a picture!  Additionally the color is very true to the picture - they are double sided with a light color on one side and a darker color on the other side.  Very quiet and the breeze is comfortable and really cools the room down.  Additionally the antique brass unit is very classic, there is an embossed stamp showing Hunter 1886 so it just adds to the classic look.  Can't go wrong with the price and ease of installation.
summary: Great fan when you don't need a light kit

reviewText: I bought this fan for my living room.  I wanted something that would blend into the ceiling because the other colors and lights in the living room were already "obvious".  I'm using this with the white side of the blades down and a 3-speed in-wall control with no light kit and no chains hanging down from the fan.The fan is fantastic--I've had it for about 4 months and it's completely silent, even on the high setting.  It has no hint of wobble and mounts relatively close to the ceiling, unlike some other fans that have a bit more of a drop rod.I bought 5 new ceiling fans this year, so I have something to compare this too and I love this fan, especially for the low price.
summary: Great quiet fan with innocuous looks

reviewText: My goodness, these gloves are just so, well just so nice...so pretty, so comfortable, so safe, so, oh, my dare I say so cute?!  Thank you so much I am just so maxed happy!!!!

I LOVE the type of light they emit, it's kind of this blueish whitish very clear yet relaxing light. It helps wake you up but not to the point of making you annoyed.You *MAY* have to take a few days to get used to it if you're used to old depressing yellow lighting everywhere you go.I would highly recommend buying these, my only problem is there price as if they were cheaper I'd buy them for the entire house.
I ordered this for my husband for Christmas.  He loves dewalt products and wanted to add this to his collection.
I got one. But there is a off brand one for under $10.00 on Amazon, no names starts with N. That is the same deal, and I like it better. This one is over priced. Go Shop.  SW
my level arrived with the center insert piece busted. its pretty much useless now i wouldnt but a level online ever again. the packaging was terrible as well.

I needed high RPM drill in order to restore my car's headlight and I been looking for decent cordless drill that would work well.It worked really well and somewhat better than i expected but battery didn't last as I expected.  However, it looks like it lasted at least 30 minutes (Can't remember exactly)I guess I can't complain too much since it was not built for car work...I would recommend standard drill and long power extension if you are planning to use drill for your car work.

reviewText: This was made to turn your rotary tool into a drill so you don't have to carry 2 different tools. This is not meant to be used in hammering or concrete drilling in my opinion, if thats what you need to do buy the SDS plus bits.  Used as a drilling chuck it works ,tightens and loosens fine. If you expect it to hold up for anything else don't buy it

I've used these through out the house, a couple of them died after 3 years.  I guess this is common, as much as they advertise longitivity of those over the incandescent bulbs, I'm not convinced.  Maybe the ones that are still lit will live up to the promise.

For the price, this is a nice set, but the quality of the set is not top notch.  I have some pictures that show the sub par fit and finish at ediblefrog.com/topics/frogblogger/stanley_stht71839_folding_metric_and_sae_hex_keys-_2-pack_review.  The functionality of the set does not seem to be affected by the fit an finish so for all practical purposes this set will do the job.
