reviewText: A Nice Safety DeviceI have several of these in my house and business in key locations. I have been using them for years and am very happy with them. I even have given them away as gifts.I also have several of the  professional emergency lights as well. The big kind that you see in restaurants.These little lights throw quite a bit of light of course not as much light as the big ones but they don't cost a hundred dollars a piece and you can put them all over the place if you like. These little lights actually stay on longer than the big ones do. A few of them have provided light for over 12 hours before needing recharging.They throw enough light to do the job and they double as very effective automatic night lights.It is true that they take up the whole out let but I solved that by buying some $1.50 out let 3fers so I still have two outlets available.It is also true that these lights only last about 2 yeas but the big expensive ones last about the same.I have a big automatic generator that takes 3 minutes or so to come on line during a power failure and these lights are great for automatic and instant light when a power failure occurs.I often recommend these to my friends.Dean

The HL21 from Fenix is one of the brightest 1AA headlights available. It's a great deal for $35.The light itself detaches from the mount; it simply snaps on and off. I thought this would adversely affect the pivoting system, which is a series of notches in the plastic housing, but it doesn't. The headlight stays where you put it, unless you bang it on something. A few reviews cited the plastic C-shaped arms breaking, but mine has held up nicely. The entire headlight is made of plastic, except the battery contacts. The light runs on one AA battery, although it doesn't include one. Alkalines, NiMH, and lithium primaries are all okay, but no 14500 or 14550. The screw-on battery door is located on the left (if you're wearing the headlight) side of the unit. Loosening it 1/4 of a turn prevents the light from coming on while in a pack.The switch is on the right side of the light. Press it once to turn the light on in high mode (90 lumens). Hold and the light quickly dims to low mode (3 lumens). From low, hold the switch to turn on medium mode (43 lumens). From medium, hold the switch to go to high mode. In any mode, double-click the switch to turn on the SOS mode. The SOS mode signals "SOS" in Morse Code in the medium mode. A single click in any mode turns the light off. The light will come back on in the last mode you used.The headband is wide and fully adjustable. It's comfortable to use.One of the key features listed is: "Aluminum alloy features a Type III hard-anodized anti-abrasive finish." There is no aluminumm alloy, nor Type III finish. The entire light is plastic. That's not a problem for me, but it should be clearer in the description. The lens is glass, which I prefer. The LED is an XP-E R2, and it's behind a smooth reflector. This gives the light a lot fo throw for such a small unit. If you prefer a floodier light, this comes with a snap-on diffuser. The diffuser flips up when attached so you can still use the spotty beam. A spare O-ring is included. The description says a lanyard is included; there's no lanyard.Overall, I'm extremely pleased with this light. The light itself detaches from the head mount so you can stash it in a jacket pocket and use it as a flashlight, which I really like. It takes just one commonly-available AA battery, which makes it cheap to feed. The output levels are bright enough and spaced apart for most uses. Give it a shot.

I have the same review as everyone else.  These things seemingly beep in the middle of the night, and scare our 2 year old out of his mind. I am very happy with the performance of this saw. It feels it's sturdy, like it's the good quality I'm used to from Milwaukee tools. It is easy to change blades by unscrewing a bolt and the bolt does not get loosened while I am sawing. That is a problem I've had with other saws. It has a very comfortable textured handle which is easy to grip and hold in my hand. I sawed a lot of PVC for a new sprinkler system and did not get any blisters. It cuts through the pipe easily and leaves a smooth edge.I have also tried it on plywood just to test it for this review. I had to put a bit more weight into sawing, but the blade moved fairly easily through the wood and again left a smooth edge. The saw is simple to store without taking up much space. I just hang it on a hook on the wall with the other saws. It came with a plastic sleeve to cover the blade, but it is flimsy and I doubt I'll use it. Overall, I am extremely pleased with the ease of using this saw. It is easier than PVC cutters.
summary: Easy to use, gets the job done

reviewText: Had the opportunity to use these clip on aviator style over my metal framed prescription glasses today.  I'm nearsighted and am required to wear them when driving. Clip on was a snap. Squeeze center clip, two "feet" extend, slip them over the frame, let go and the coated  feet grab onto your lenses securely.  One finger now flips them up or  down.I drove to town with a crystal clear sky and the sun was directly overhead. We still have snow on the ground and with the glare and brightness, this was a perfect opportunity to test these out.After you get used to the color difference ( takes about a minute for your eyes to adjust) and flip up the yellow lenses, I IMMEDIATELY noticed how much glare and brightness was bouncing off the snow and into my eyes. Enough where you wanted to squint.  I flipped the lenses down and was amazed at how much more comfortable and clearer my surroundings were. My eyes felt "relaxed" if there is such a thing.I live on a lake and KNOW these will be of great benefit when we're on the boat.  I now understand why snowmobilers and skiers use these lenses. I'll give an update when I use them during  rainy or night time conditions.  But in snow and clear blue skies, these are fantastic in dampening down the glare and brightness.  I also had the opportunity to use them during rain and foggy conditions, and it certainly made a fantastic difference for me.  I bought a pair for my husbands glasses and he cant say enough good things about them. He too was amazed at the difference it made for him.  He suffers from Glaucoma, some macular degeneration and intra ocular eye pressure and wearing these over his prescription glasses has caused less stress........and that's a good thing.
summary: WOW ....Fantastic difference for the both of us!

reviewText: When I'm looking for DeWalt tools, it's always great to find them on Amazon.com. We use a lot of DeWalt tools here, it seems like I am buying a tool all the time. This came in soon and was put to work immediately! Works great!
really really works well cutting small items with my Dremel tool.Have used it three times and it remains sharp and still cuts well

I have a fear of plumbing.  It is the one thing I am always reluctant to try to deal with myself in the house. After a couple of email exchanges with Jeff and with his encouragement, I decided to give in and give this device a try. Like some others, when I first opened the box and saw all the pieces, I was frightened and thought I had made a mistake by agreeing to try this out. A cup of coffee and a half-hour of relaxing guitar playing later, I gathered myself together and went at it.Most of the parts in the box were not needed in my situation which turned out to be a basic install.  Straight-forward and just as carefully (and visually) described in the enclosed directions.  It took this dedicated non-plumber about ten minutes to install and set up. From the first flush, he change was apparent.The control box, which sits atop the toilet tank, has two dial controls. One for short flushes and one for longer ones. You can figure out which is for what.The choice of the short flush is made by simply tapping/pushing lightly on the top of the control box. A green light activates and the short flush ensues. The long flush is the default if the short one is not selected. Each dial has settings from 1-to-10 and is set to manage the flow of water to the around necessary to do the job.  Mine work great set at 2 and 7.Having only installed it about a week ago, I cannot vouch for what the water savings might be, but it is quite obviously saving water. Without it, the toilet would be using the equivalent of a number 10 flush each and every time it was used.I imagine that the installation may be more complex with some toilets - But with my own basic type, it was no problem.  I am actually less afraid of plumbing than I was before! The experience reminded me of the first time I allowed myself to open a computer to add something to it myself. New, successful experience can yield a higher sense of mastery :-}There is no good reason that I can think of to NOT install and use the Tap-n-Flush.Disclosure: I was provided with this device at no cost for the purposes of trial and review.
summary: Does EXACTLY What It Claims To Do! My Fear of Plumbing Is Reduced.

reviewText: I was in need of a new cordless drill. While my current Sears 24V drill still worked, both batteries I had for it had failed and the cost of a single replacement battery was almost two thirds the cost of a new drill. If I was going to buy new I wanted to get something light, and powered by lithium ion batteries. Having previously used my fathers Makita drill in some renovations I searched for this brand. I found the combination kits and picked the one that had a circular saw and reciprocating saw, both which are tools I wanted but didn't have yet.So far I have used the tools for a few light projects around the house, nothing big yet. I can say the batteries last a long time, longer then it takes to charge, so even if your battery dies the other one is ready to go. The drill has an LED that turns on and stays on a few seconds after the drills is off. I found this extra time was just right for aligning the next hole.At the time I purchased my kit it also came with a mail in rebate for free vibrating all-in-one tool making this an even better value. In all I got each tool for far less then I would have paid for individually.

Works great.  Easy to hook up to the dimmer switch and I mounted it under the cabinet and it is out of sight.  I was just a little longer than I wished it was, but the price was right and it has worked very dependably.

I am really enjoying oscillating everything in sight with these versatile tool system.  I've sanded old hardware on cabinets, rocks, pretty much anything in reach has been sanded.One of the really cool things about this Dremel is the quick release wrench that is attached to the drill and won't get misplaced.  You can change out accessories really quickly.  Also cool is the magnet that is built into the blade holder.  That doesn't sound like much but it won't fall while you are trying to tighten it, making that chore just a whole lot easier.It has a lot of power - maybe too much since I've kind of over-sanded a few spots, but that was a learning curve, you know?Love this tool and the cool case it comes in.
summary: So many accessories, so little time!

reviewText: Too many features. Yup, too many. Also very inconsistent. I could scan the same area multiple times and get varying readings each time. This guy got returned. Going to buy the magnetic one and a cheap electric one to "QC" each other.
This does not charge an iPad.  The tamper proof shutters are annoying-I have replaced this witht he Leviton unit (also far from perfect - though better).

Needed an auto motion-sensing light over my Dad's commode since he doesn't bother to turn on any lights.  I tried another slightly smaller unit that used 4 AA batteries but not only did the light only last 5 seconds after the last motion detected, I would estimate the light produced was only in the 10-20 lumen range (even with 8 LEDs).  So when I looked at the Mr Beams website I saw this unit which claimed 100 lumens.  I was actually surprised at how small it was when I received it since its only slightly larger than the one that used AA batteries, but this uses 4 C-cell batteries.  I was also wondering about the light produced claim as I only saw a single LED element in the center.  However it does produce more light which is not as focused as most LEDs.  I assume it uses some sort of diffuser which spreads the light over a wider area which results in a "warm white" rather than "bright light" that most LEDs produce.  In addition the 30 second light duration claim was accurate - there are other products of a similar nature that claim 30 seconds and only last from 5 to 10 seconds.For mounting, the unit comes with a plastic mounting base with two screws and plastic anchors.  The light unit itself attaches to the base with a simple twist.  My only criticism is that the battery compartment uses a screw rather than a pressure release, so that will require the use of a screwdriver when replacing the batteries.  Given that situation, I hope that is not a frequent occurrence.Having had this for about a year now, I have a couple of other comments.  The motion sensor actually has a relatively wide area as the light goes on even if you get near my Dad's bathroom, not just under it.  If you add that to the number of times my Dad uses the commode, that has limited the life of the batteries fairly significantly.  I have had to replace them an average of every two months, so I am now buying C batteries in bulk.  In the end, while helpful, it didn't solve the issue of my Dad "spraying" so I installed a motion sensor for the main bathroom light (and this has reduced the 7 year life span of the  40 watt FL tubes in the main bathroom light to 6 months) - which given that he is 90 and has dementia, hasn't really helped all that much either.  And the one time it would have come in handy - when the power went out - the batteries died.  Regardless, I still think this unit is superior over others I have tried (4 other manufacturers) and I like the Mr Beams products - I have installed the step lights that use 4 AA batteries to light the way from my Dad's room to his bathroom (these units batteries lasted 6 months).
summary: Exactly what I was looking for

reviewText: I didn't actually need this tape at the moment, but I had to add to my cart, to get the free shipping on something else I was buying. I'm not usually one to make household repairs unless they are very minor and require little skill. With a tool like the Porter Cable 3.0 Amp Oscillating Multi- Tool, I have a weapon in my hands; a weapon that makes household handyman tasks even simpler than before and increasing the number of tasks I am willing to conquer.This tool is made for cutting, scraping, sanding, and grinding and it comes complete with several different blades that are easy to switch out with the accessory clamp. The tool is comfortable to handle and can be used for cutting wood or metal. The blades are not as large as some may need, but they are large enough to handle the tasks/projects that most of us will encounter in our homes.Included in the kit, along with the blades, are a sanding platen and twenty- five sanding sheets. I don't do much cutting, but I do have to occasionally sand surfaces to get them primed for finishing and this tool is very nice for that purpose. I like, too, that the manufacturer helps get you started with so many sandpaper sheets. Many manufacturers include no sanding sheets at all, requiring another trip to the store before you can start a project.This Porter Cable tool has a thick, heavy- duty cord and a decent, although not perfect, plastic storage case. It seems like a tool that was made to last and given my limited usage, it will likely last a very long time.All and all, this is a very good tool and one I highly recommend for small to medium size jobs. More experienced handymen and handywomen may find it inadequate, but it suits the needs of the average person quite well.
summary: Good Tool for the Less Experienced Handyman

reviewText: This mask is probably as comfortable as one can be. Your nose will hurt a little after wearing this for hours, but it does great job of filtering outside pollutants.The only issue I had with it is that if you have closed goggles, they won't fit right with this mask on.

This thing works great.  Will only turn on when its dark and was very easy to install.  I am using the Eneloop AA rechargeable batteries with the 'C' fillers.  We used it to put a light in a dark landing going to the basement.  A lot easier than running electric to a new place.

This is a good combo kit for the money.  There are certainly better nail guns and compressors to be had but for what this kit costs there is very little skin in the game.  This is a good tool for the weekend warrior.POSITIVES:The compressor is VERY light.  I take it everywhere with no reservations.  Before getting this kit to do some trim I only had a large Campbell/Hausfield out in the garage that wouldn't move easily.The nail guns worked well.  The depth adjustments are very functional.  My Finish nailer broke before I finished the first box of nails.  I took it back to Home depot and they replaced it.  No problems since.The compressor shuts off at 150 psi so the cycle times are not as often as could be imagined for such a small tank.NEGATIVES:The compressor is loud.  Using it inside I would recommend earplugs.The air hose they provide is WAY to small.  I use the longer one from the garage so that I can keep the compressor further away from where I am working and give me more freedom of movement.  I gave it only 4 stars because it should not have been much trouble or cost to provide a longer hose.

reviewText: When the manufacturer uses weird screws, you need a weird screw driver to remove them.  I needed one of the small star bits with the hole in the center.  To be sure the size I needed was in the set, I checked the size first with a standard star bit (which I have).  Sure enough the size I needed was in this set.  There are plenty of other weird screws in the world which someday this driver set will attack. The set is well made (from a reputable company) and should last me forever.

reviewerName: P. NGUYEN "The truth is temporarily painful"
reviewText: So I bought the variable speed version of this (DF010DSE) which I thought would have the same torque.  However, after using that version, I found out that it only offered 44 lbs of torque whereas this single speed version offers a whopping 177 lbs!  You would think that Makita would somehow incorporate the larger torque in the variable speed version and not the other way around.  Nevertheless, it is an extremely well made tool.  Comes with a nice tool bag and even a belt holster.  Before the days of Li-Ion, the Ni-Cds couldn't hold a charge for more than a day and when you needed it, you would have to set aside at least 3 hours to "re-charge" it.  Thank goodness those days are over.  You can now leave these babies unattended for weeks even months at a time and when you need to use the tools, they are ready at your fingertips.  Okay, back to the review.  I use this single speed version to drive screws into plywood, drywall, and any other things that need high torque, super fast speed.  I don't recommend using this driver on torque sensitive screws because it will strip it easily.  For more sensitive jobs like putting together kits for my R/C hobby, I use the DF010DSE variable speed version which I found to be perfect for the job.  Ironically, the single high torque version is half the price of the weaker variable speed version. Go figure.  All in all, this is a great addition to my line of Makita tools.  My only complaint like others have stated here is the lack of variable speed.
summary: Powerful from such a small little device!

reviewText: This lavalamp works very well.  The wax doesn't get stuck at the top or the bottom, and it heats up for use in a reasonable time frame.  The fit and finish is inexpensive...but not cheap or flimsy.  The reason I knocked off a stars is the bulb--it burned out after about 6 months and I would have like it to go a full year.  We bought a second one and it burned out within about 3 months (it was used more heavily by that boy) so it appears the bulbs just don't go very long on these lamps--or their design kills the bulbs quickly.If you don't mind changing bulbs every few months, this is a great product and makes a wonderful nightlight for kids old enough to have something like this in their room.  The lamp doesn't get hot enough to burn you while in normal use, but if the lamp is removed, the bulb is exposed and it is VERY hot--so probably not good for kids that are too young.

This is pretty unique in my opinion, in terms of integrating the dialer. It is well worth the money, I've had one for years now and it's great to be able to sleep through a storm knowing the device will call me if there's a problem. It's pretty flexible in design so you can have the dialer someplace convenient while still running the water detector to the problem spot (e.g. partway down your sump pump hole so if the pump stops working, you can find out quickly). It works fine and stands up to reasonable use and abuse, and it's easy to figure out the operation; has a battery backup. Instructions are integrated into the device, just remember to remove the little screw in the middle before trying to replace the battery, one of these days I'll break it forgetting about that...
This tool is worth the few extra dollars over the hardware store versions. It's quality and great as a first-attack tool for many repairs.

reviewText: Slow close is really good.The installation was easy.The bolt has very intelligent designs including snap off bolt, metal stud, turn to tighten, etc.It is really ingenious.The finish quality is also smooth and shiny.The wood is solid and strong.Shape and size matches perfectly with the toilet like twins.Highly recommended.

I paid approx 26.00 for this wonderful 2 pack of emergency lights.  I have no complaints about the product.But I happened across exactly the same 2 pack at my local Costco in Waltham. They can be had for $18.00.So check for a better deal before you buy here!

We've got a winner.Of the high-end lights I've owned / used / researched, the Fenix TA21 walks off with my top praise for a number of reasons.  Keeping in mind that like any tool, it has a specific role.  It suites my purpose perfectly.  I will try to give you a good idea of why it appeals to me.  Weigh that against your own requirements.PRO's:  (in no particular order)It uses 2 x CR123A lithium cells.  This is my preferred power source today.  Lithium cells have a 10 YEAR shelf life.  The whole idea of an "emergency" light source is that it is ready when you need it.  If you are "on the job" with this light, on a daily basis, the 18650 rechargeable may be a better choice.  This light handles both."Medium-long Throw"  Those are my words.  Your light can be designed with a shallow reflector with heavy "orange-peel" to give a wide bright beam for close-up work, or with a smooth and very deep dish for a more focused, long-range bright spot.  This light is in-between, though it is clearly more of a thrower, it has the "orange peel" type reflector and a clean, clear "spill" area surrounding the spot.  Nice.12-level bi-directional rotating barrel switch, AND momentary cap switch.  THIS is my favorite feature.  None of that nonsensical twist on / off multiple time to change modes, then clicky-clicky-clicky to find out where you want the light set, and on some lights, then you get to PICK between which modes to use, because you can only choose 2 out of eight, like the Quark tactical.  BAH!  I hate that with a passion.  (and I own one.)I want my lights on LOW by default, and I'll power them up to what level I need / want at the time.  For my use, that is the most logical.  With this light, it will fire-up in what ever mode you have it set to, and it will stay until you change it.  You change it by grasping the barrel switch, and give it a turn.  Also, it "wraps around" so that when you get through all 12 settings, you don't have to go back the other way, the switch just continues right around and starts at the beginning again.  Beautiful.  Logical.  Simple.  Intuitive.Light beam quality:  This is a CREE Q5-based light.  These technologies change FAST, ok.  This WAS "THE" illumination source to have, until just recently.  Up against my XG-R5 based lights, in real-world look-see use, you're not gonna know the dif.  Yes, the R5 is more efficient.  It's not really an issue.Size:  Smaller than it looks in the pictures.  If I wrap my paw around it from the middle, the nose and tail will both stick out about an inch.  However, it's too big for EDC unless you are on the job with it in some capacity.  Roughly 2x"C" battery sized Maglite.  More than that, the "weaponized" crown around the lens makes pocket carry unlikely.  (jacket pocket, ok).It has a heavy-duty pocket clip can be re-located and locked back in place.  You can loosen / tighten the extra thick beveled body ring (which serves to prevent the light from rolling if you lay it on a flat surface) which lets you freely rotate the thick pocket clip ring, without scratching up the barrel.CONS:As far as I know, no one has built the "Perfect" light, yet.  I am obligated to nit-pick.Price.  At this price point (especially for a Q5 led), you should expect a LOT, and I do.  I would expect a top-qauality sheath, a much better lanyard (the one included is a joke) and at least one set of CR123A cells to get you started.  None of this is included.  I anticipate price drops on this light pretty soon.  In the mean time, Amazon's price is the best I'm finding.I don't like to score an item based on price, but it's more on VALUE for the dollar, and the missing sheath, lanyard, and batteries are unfortunate.  I'm obligated to remove a full point, as I can not remove 1/2 point.  So be it.Balance.  The heavy nose over-balances the light.  Most people would never notice this.  Others (and you know who you are) it may really bother them.  I find it impossible to "choke up" by moving the hand closer to the lens, because of the way the diameter varies along the shaft.  To get a balance, under-hand carry just extend the index finger loosely toward the lens.  Doesn't take much.  About 1/4 inch does it for me.  Huge difference.  Over-hand, won't matter.  Nose-heavy is an advantage in that position.  (my opinion)THE BOTTOM LINE:  Why buy the TA21 over OTHER 2x 123A lights?1) The outstanding 12-postiion, logical, rotating barrel switch.  As far as I know, the only one.  This is a truly outstanding set-up for me, I just cant say enough about that.  Did I mention that on "Low" setting (4 Lumens) it will run for 170 hours continuous?  That's about a week, boys 'n girls.  4 lumens is brighter than you think.  You'll see what you give it a try.2) Excellent durability, quality, water-proofing, etc.3) When larger size and weight are desirable for tactical reasons.#3 up there is important.  If you are NOT specifically interested in a heavy "weaponized" light, most people will be better served with a leaner, lighter version of the same thing. You can easily come in at half the weight for the same light and power.  If you want satisfaction, look closely at what will work best for YOUR anticipated use.As for me, I'm giving this light two very solid thumbs up, and give a respectful nod to FENIX, as I am forced to admit that to date, this is indeed the best light I've ever had my hands on.If this is the kind of light you are looking for, there is no way you'll regret this purchase.-Berk

I had some canned lighting, and I wanted to install a newer dome-style cover. However, this required that the bulb be lower than what the can would allow. I just needed an inch or so, so I purchased these. Turns out the plastic is NOT heat-proof. I had a normal edison style bulb and the glass was able touch the plastic. It melted, caused the light to blow, and fatigued the glass. When I went to unscrew it -- and replace the bulb -- I didn't realize it was fatigued and glued (via the melting) to this extension. I twisted the glass from the extension and it broke in my hand, causing a bloody cut!I would recommend these for fluorescent bulbs. They A) don't get as hot as normal 60W bulbs, and B) have a plastic base that sits well past these extenders.Not sure why they ever got rid of Bakelite, this plastic is just not suited for high heat.

I wanted to add Z-wave controllability to a cool old bakelite switch that was probably installed around 1930-1940 in our old house. One of the big heavy old switches in a ceramic housing, back when they used BX wiring and small metal workboxes. However, there was not even close to enough room to fit this behind the switch. It's not Aeon Labs' fault, it's just that there is no way they could possibly make something small enough to squeeze in the tight spacings that were the norm in old electrical boxes, given how fat the old switches were and how small the workboxes were. So, please be aware that if you're looking to use this to retrofit existing switches, they really have to be relatively modern switches installed in modern, large workboxes. That's absolutely the only way you're going to have a chance of sneaking this in behind. Fortunately, one of the switches in the five gang panel was not being used anymore, so I pulled that out and used the empty space for the Aeotec switch. Even then, it was a very tight fit!The way this works is that you hook up your existing switch to some low voltage terminals on the Aeotec device. These are low voltage and just used to sense when somebody toggles the existing switch, and so that's why the terminals are so small: you're supposed to use small gauge wires. The reviewers who complained about stripped terminals didn't read the darn instructions and used full 14/16 gauge high voltage wires. You have to use something more like thermostat wire. In fact, that's exactly what I used and it worked great. You then hook up the high voltage terminals of the Aetec switch to your house power and load. You can either turn the light on and off with the old switch or with a zwave command; it doesn't matter which position the old switch is in. Flipping it always flips the state of the light. Very clever.One more piece of advice: unless you are installing this in new construction, you may not have all the wires you need. This product requires access to a neutral wire, and a lot of old installations didn't bother to run neutral to switch boxes. If you're in this boat, you'll have to either give up on this or do something potentially unsafe: use ground as neutral. I don't advise doing this, however, because you're completely doing away with all the safety advantages of a separate ground path. So, open the box you're planning on installing this in and making sure you've got all three wires you'll need before buying this.In summary, this is an extremely clever device that allows any switch to be used as a Zwave device if you have the right wiring and enough room left over in your box.
summary: Works well, but not possible to install in old work boxes behind old switches

reviewText: i use it all the time. have not changed the batteries yet. its nice to carry, you cant tell you have it in your pocket when your sitting. thats when i really notice things in my pockets. its still in great shape for being in the same pocket as my small pocket knife, wallet, and a small can of mints

I live in the country where it's really dark and a trip to the barn can be a challenge at night.  These are doing the trick.  When I drive in at night and decide to feed the animals before going in the house (where I could turn on the outside lights) I know my motion sensitive garage light won't stay on long enough to still be on when I start back to the house.  When I turn off the barn lights, it's black as pitch out there.  A few of these in strategic places gives me enough light to get back to the house.  I only got one pack which includes two lights to begin with and when I saw how helpful they were, I ordered another pack.The only down side I can see is that in the cold and with the dog setting them off regularly, the batteries may not last terribly long, but I'll see and update.  I worried a little about the elements and decided to make them little hats out of foil which I affixed with a little tube of backward folded duck tape to the top.  So far that is working fine and even seems to diffuse the light a bit more giving somewhat more lighted area.  Of course this is a rustic setting so the fact that it doesn't look quite so neat doesn't matter.  Generally I like that fact that with the dark matte finish they blend into the ground cover and I'm not even aware they are there (except for their new hats :).Oh, one more thing.  The directions in the pack I got said I could set the tiny timer inside to 20 seconds or 5 minutes before the light went off.  I chose the 5 minutes but it doesn't stay on that long, more like 3 minutes.  I'm good with that, but thought I should mention it.I've only been using them a week, so time will tell about long term effectiveness and I'll update one way or the other, but so far so good.Update 3/23/13:  Still doing great.  Been buried in snow, rained on and turned on regularly by the animals with no ills effects.

reviewText: The Bench Dog pro plate is great for my PC 7518, PC7519, or  Milwaukee 5625-20 routers. I am not sure why the picture shows all of those holes in the plate, when it only has 4 for the router base and 2 to bolt it down. I also noticed on other reviews that the mounting bolt heads on other routers barely touch the bottom of the chamfer on the opening, but with my PC routers the bolt takes up the entire hole and with no room to spare with sliding material across. So I am glad they are that size. Being made out of a 5/16" thick piece of machined aluminum I should not have to worry about any sagging. I did make my own table so I have plenty of shoulder in a 2 1/2" thick table. The only problem I have is with the  little screws that hold in the insert. I dropped one in my router while changing out inserts and had to take the router out and shake the screw out. They are stainless so a magnetic driver does not hold them. Terrible design. I also have a JessEm master lift with tab-loc inserts which is a much better design. You listening Bench Dog? Maybe all of the patents for other types had been applied for already and this was all that was left?

this knife is very nice. everything about it screams quality. the blade si very thick and it has a very nice design with one exception; the taper near the tip of the blade. this will only present a problem when batoning, which is not something I do very often anyways. i think this knife isn't designed as much for chopping wood as it is for hunting boar or other similar activities. this knife is around 12 inch's long, has a very comfortable grip, and has good balance. it came pretty sharp but I made it so it can shave even the finest hairs easily using my lanksy sharpening system and its edge retention is pretty nice. its full tang so you can use it for heavy duty work. the sheath is not the best but I have no doubt it will stand up against average to rough use. ( not abuse) it has a fairley large pocket on the front where I keep a small sharpening stone, a firesteel, two cotton balls, and about 3 feet of paracord. I could fit more if I tired but those are just some things I threw in there. the button that holds the knife handle is pretty sturdy and it has a feature that im not exactly sure what its for. it kinda un-velcros all along the area inside of the strap, not removing it from the sheath but just kind of making it longer.im kinda puzzled by this but it doesn't affect the performance of the sheath, so I don't care. so far I just love this knife; its probably the best I own, I think I would have a hard time finding a better knife for the price.update: the partially sharpend part of the knife right before the tip doesn't present a very big problem when batoning. also it makes the perfect edge to use on firesteels without ruining your edge
summary: from what i can see, great knife.

I received the Porter-Cable PC2181DC-2 as an early Christmas present and used them today on a decking project instead my 12 volt DeWalt and my corded 3/8 Milwaukee drills. My 3/4" Porter Cable is too heavy for this kind of project. These are the first 18 volt tools I have ever used and WOW, what torque and power they have. The 3" deck screws flew into the 4x4 lumber without hesitation. This pair is unbelievable for power and battery running time. Thank you Porter Cable. The only downside is they are not made in the USA but no power tools are made here anymore. At least the better tools have great quality control at their foreign factories.

reviewText: My battery poweredDremel 7300did a good job, except that the battery always seemed to be dead, whenever I wanted to use the tool.  This provided the motivation for buying an AC powered rotary tool.  Both Black and Decker and Dremel were under consideration, but when the B&D; RTX-B dropped down to $23, I made my choice, as it was half the price of theDremel 200 kit.An AC powered motor can deliver more power and torque, which typically means, more dramatic results.  The RTX-B motor has three speeds, 12,000 RPM, 24,000 RPM, and 30,000 RPM.  I generally use the lowest speed for better control, but it’s great to have a lot more power available if it is needed.  The battery powered Dremel 7300 has a top speed of 13,000 RPM, and delivers much less torque.The RTX-B has an ergonomic design, with a rubberized area near the front, that provides a nice grip.  The tool incorporates a pretty well designed flip lock safety mechanism to lock the shaft.  Replacing fittings and accessories isn’t as easy as the Dremel, but at least the chuck accepts all my old Dremel accessories, and does a superior job with them.  This is fortunate, as when it comes to accessories, Dremel’s product line is far superior, leaving B&D; in the dust.Some may not think it necessary, but with a rotary tool capable of high speeds, wearing safety glasses is a must.  A carrying bag that isn’t well suited to the tool is included, along with some screwdriver bits.While Dremel accessories are the best, they don’t necessarily have to be attached to a Dremel brand rotary tool.  Although the price has risen to close to $30, the B&D;’s RTX-B is a solid performer, which still remains less expensive than the Dremel 200 kit, and I don’t have any second thoughts about buying one.
summary: B&D delivers a very functional, powerful, and economical rotary tool…

Needed replacements for my ridgid jointer.  These look identical and are exactly the same dementions.  They are razor sharp and mount in there perfectly.  Have not had a chance to try them yet but I have Freud blades in my table saw and router and they hold up great so I would expect the same from these.  I have learned not to be too hard on jointer blades.  Don't cut deeper than you have to and check your blades often.  I didn't bother to check them till I was getting bad cuts and was amazed at how badly I had worn them down.
